DOC.HEAD: Three Dissidents Disappear on Eve of News Conference
DOC.TEXT: Three intellectuals who have been the government's only vocal critics since the student movement for democracy was suppressed last year disappeared on Thursday and their planned news conference was canceled. It was not clear if the three former hunger strikers were voluntarily maintaining a low profile or if they were taken into custody. Sunday is the anniversary of last year's army attack on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing that left hundreds dead and the government has been tightening security measures in anticipation of possible disturbances. Also on Thursday, Chinese newspapers reported 20 people were executed for crimes, including a man convicted of destroying an Air Force jeep during last June's uprising. The three intellectuals had planned to issue an open letter to Chinese leaders calling for the release of political prisoners. Friends said two of the three who drafted the letter, folk singer Hou Dejian and the former editor of a university newspaper, Gao Xin, had not been seen since they left Hou's home early Thursday. Several hours later, Hou telephoned to say he was well but would not be coming back for an unspecified time. Gao, 34, telephoned later with a similar message. Hou, 34, also phoned two foreign journalists and said, ``Because I personally have things to do, I'm not ready to hold a news conference.'' He refused to elaborate. The third intellectual, Zhou Duo, 43, also dropped out of sight on Thursday. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua said at the ministry's weekly briefing later Thursday that Chinese were free to talk to foreign journalists but ``a certain kind of formalities'' should be observed for interviews. She did not comment directly on the case. Authorities may have been willing to tolerate their criticism because it would have only reached a foreign audience and the three were so open that they clearly were not involved in any underground plotting. Holding a major news conference just days before the anniversary may, however, been too great a provocation. Most of the foreign journalists in Beijing were expected to cram Hou's tiny apartment for the meeting. Sunday's edition of the official Sichuan Daily, seen in Beijing on Thursday, said courts in the capital of Sichuan province last week sentenced convicted arsonist Yu Yongchuan to death. He was immediately executed. The newspaper said Yu led others in overturning a jeep and setting it on fire during rioting that broke out in the capital, Chengdu, on June 5, the day after the pro-democracy movement was crushed. The other executed people were convicted of a variety of crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Tensions Within Solidarity Burst Into Open
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leaders who worked together for a decade to rid Poland of communism now find their unity rent by differences over the pace and nature of change. The spectacle of this ``war at the top,'' to use Lech Walesa's phrase, has dismayed activists. Some are choosing sides and others hope to make peace between the factions. Walesa, who led the 1980 strike in which Solidarity was born, brought the long-rumored tensions into the open in April. His method was public criticism aimed at the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and the parliamentary caucus led by Bronislaw Geremek. Both are intellectuals and Solidarity advisers who owe their positions to the shipyard electrician from Gdansk. Walesa said he had been silent too long. He accused the government of advocating a ``steered democracy,'' one that limits dissent, because it thinks it has all the answers. He said the Communist system was being dismantled too slowly and people were dissatisfied. ``Walesa feels the mood of the people very well and the people are getting impatient,'' especially for political changes, said Zdzislaw Najder, whom Walesa has named chairman of Solidarity's national Citizens Committee. Mazowiecki's defenders say Walesa is motivated by personal restlessness and an ambition to be president. They say his criticism threatens to stir unrest when the government needs calm to obtain Western investment and accomplish difficult economic reforms. ``No reasonable person can see any monopolization of power,'' Aleksander Malachowski, a Solidarity member of Parliament, said in an interview, but added that some ``demagogues'' sought excuses to attack the government. ``Very often in (Walesa's) statements you can see reflections of this demagoguery,'' Malachowski said. ``He probably does not realize it.'' The dispute seems to signal a turning away from the 1989 ``round table'' accord in which Solidarity agreed to a transitional stage of coexistence with the Communists, who still held most of the power. With the collapse of Communist control throughout Eastern Europe, Poland has become a rarity where former party leaders retain titular positions of power, including the presidency and high posts in the military, police and Parliament. They have kept their places largely by not disturbing the decisions of Mazowiecki and the Solidarity parliamentary caucus. Walesa speaks for those who want to end the artificial arrangement as quickly as possible. Mazowiecki's allies worry about upsetting a balance that has worked so well. While Walesa says ``the intellectuals'' misled him, some of them hint he is losing his renowned political instincts. ``You are making mistakes in many areas,'' foreign affairs specialist Kazimierz Wojcicki lectured the Solidarity chairman May 13, in a stormy session of the Citizens Committee. ``You use terminology that confuses us,'' he said. ``You start a presidential campaign and then retract it. ... You make us all nervous at a moment when our economic reforms are entering a key stage.'' There also has been sniping between the daily Gazeta Wyborcza and weekly Tygodnik Solidarnosc, two newspapers founded by Solidarity. They are edited, respectively, by Adam Michnik, an intellectual perhaps best known for his ``Letters from Prison,'' and Jaroslaw Kaczynski, a Walesa loyalist. Who will succeed President Wojciech Jaruzelski has become the subject of sometimes acrimonious debate. It is assumed the former Communist Party chief will have to step down before the formal end of his term in 1995. Walesa clearly wants the job and Kaczynski has organized a political group called the Center Alliance to support the candidacy. From the other side, suggestions are being circulated, sometimes even printed, that Walesa is too impulsive and does not have the learning or manners the presidency requires. Malachowski and some others in Parliament and the government say Mazowiecki, who was little known until Walesa made him prime minister in August, is a better presidential candidate. How could people who fought and suffered so long together, with the notion of ``solidarity'' as their highest value, fall out so soon after their hour of triumph? In part, the dissolution of their common foe, the Communist Party, has released various conflicts within Solidarity: left-right, worker-intellectual, Warsaw-provinces. ``Now the most difficult moment has come, because we don't have anyone to fight against,'' actress Maja Komorowska said at the May 13 meeting. ``We are all victims of 45 years of Communist rule and of the lack of democracy,'' said Najder, who recently returned from exile. ``We know how to fight our enemies, but we don't know how to coexist as allies.'' He also said in an interview he felt the differences between Walesa and Mazowiecki were blown out of proportion. ``We have democracy, but when there are differences of opinion, people are aghast,'' he said. ``If somebody criticizes the government, they think he or she wants to bring down the government. ... It's absurd.'' At the same Citizens Committee meeting where he spoke of the ``war at the top,'' Walesa praised the government and the Solidarity leadership in Parliament, Najder said. Walesa said his criticism was meant to help the government by providing a safety vent for growing public frustration. According to Najder, the dispute developed because Walesa is in close touch with public feelings and wants to create a ``more open political game'' by opposing ``monopolistic tendencies'' in Parliament. He said government leniency about pensions for former officials and its mild attitude on recovering property taken by the Communist Party were ``incomprehensible'' to some Solidarity supporters. The government also may be guilty of ``excessive sensitivity,'' Najder said. The returned exile, a former director of Radio Free Europe's Polish section, was sentenced to death in absentia by the Communist regime. Malachowski, who wants Walesa to continue as Solidarity chairman instead of becoming Poland's president, said years of joint struggle had forged links among Solidarity activists that ``occasional arguments'' could not break. Mrs. Komorowska, the actress, said the relationsship between Walesa and the intellectuals should be like a marriage, and observed: ``It is a bad marriage where the couple does not sit down at the table in the evening and say to each other what is painful.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Military President Running as Civilian
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: He once was the man of the hour, the latest strongman installed by the army to lead Guatemala out of corruption, insurrection and bloodshed. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, a born-again Christian with a charismatic style, presided over times of masked tribunals and firing squads, of army massacres that shocked the world. When a coup deposed him in 1983, after 16 months as president, Rios Montt seemed consigned to political obscurity. His ambition, like his faith, has been resurrected and he is running for president as a civilian. Rios Montt is a serious contender scoring high in the polls, a candidate of crisis. Five years of democracy have not brought clean, effective government or ended violence and human rights abuses. Street crime is rampant, drug trafficking on the rise, the economy unraveling. ``It is a moral crisis, an ethical crisis, a failure of hope,'' said Juan Luis Bosch, a leading businessman. ``People put their hope in a democratic government, but hope has become disillusionment.'' Things seem to be spinning out of control and Rios Montt offers to put them right. He is a law-and-order candidate with an Old Testament style, stern and paternal. ``Guatemala needs a man of character, a man who knows and enforces the law,'' the 63-year-old retired brigadier general said in an interview. ``Not a dictator. A man of law.'' Rios Montt's law was harsh. He imposed a state of siege and created special tribunals where masked ``judges'' tried hundreds of people for crimes including sabotage, possession of explosives and the sale of weapons to people deemed subversive. ``Only 15 people were ultimately sentenced to death, but it was a great scandal because we shot five when the pope was here,'' Rios Montt said. Pope John Paul II made a personal plea for clemency during his 1983 Central America tour. ``It would have been easier to shoot them and just dump them in the trash, but that wouldn't have been justice,'' Rios Montt said, curtly closing the subject. During his presidency, the army continued a vicious counterinsurgency campaign to destroy any potential base of support for leftist guerrillas among the peasants. It led to ``the gravest violations of human rights ... including the destruction and sacking of entire villages and massacres of the inhabitants,'' the human rights commission of the Organization of American States said in 1983. Now, an almost nostalgic glow seems to bathe Rios Montt's reign; the worldwide condemnation of human rights abuses seems forgotten. ``You talk to the average person here about human rights and it means getting on a bus and not being robbed,'' a Western diplomat said. ``That is what makes Rios Montt's message so powerful.'' People speak of how his stern measures seemed to work, how the army's scorched-earth campaign in the countryside dimmed the leftist insurgency, how city streets were safe and official corruption waned. ``He is seen as an upright man, a person of principles and order, someone who will end the violence and corruption,'' said Fernando Hurtado, deputy attorney general for human rights. ``He is someone who, in a time of crisis, stresses values.'' Central America's most populous nation seems caught in a time warp. Turn on television and there is Rios Montt again, talking about law and order, the family and clean government, just as he did in evangelistic Sunday homilies as president. More than half a dozen candidates are seeking the presidency, encouraged by the vulnerability of the incumbent Christian Democrats, who are widely seen as corrupt and inept. Rios Montt is running as an independent. Political observers say they detect little solid support for him in the two most powerful segments of Guatemalan society: the army and business. ``I have the support of the people,'' he said in the interview. ``That is what matters.'' The most serious obstacle to his candidacy is a constitution that appears to bar former dictators _ heads of ``de facto'' governments _ from becoming president. Rios Montt says the 1985 constitution is not retroactive and he will run despite an adverse advisory opinion from the Constitutional Court. The opinion was requested by the legislature and is not binding. The former general predicted his followers will start a civil uprising if election authorities refuse to let him register when they meet in June to set an election date and register candidates. ``It will be the people, not the army,'' he said. ``An army uprising doesn't interest me. Coups don't interest me.'' He grabbed a well-thumbed copy of the constitution, with key passages highlighted in yellow ink or underlined in red, and thumped a clause he says makes such an uprising legal. ``It says here that people have the right to defend their rights, and they have a right to vote for me,'' he said. His interest in constitutional law is relatively new. One of his first acts after a March 1982 coup put him in power was to revoke the 1965 constitution, suspend political activity and cancel election laws. Rios Montt, a member of the Church of the Word, based in California, says he does not intend to revive the special tribunals or military rule. Instead, he proposes an extensive system of locally elected judges. ``No more tanks, no more planes, no more soldiers,'' he said. ``More justice.'' His human rights record could make him unacceptable to many other governments if he becomes president. Publicly, the United States is neutral. Privately, U.S. officials say aid might be cut if Rios Montt wins. Rios Montt said his election could provoke a U.S. invasion or assassination attempt. ``Do something like Panama. Shoot me. End everything,'' he said, spitting out the words. Rios Montt's administration was the last but one in a 30-year line of military or military-dominated governments that began with a U.S.-sponsored coup in 1954. He dismisses criticism of his army's counterinsurgency campaign, echoing former President Reagan's comment in 1982 that the general got a ``bum rap.'' ``They blamed me for what Lucas did, but they knew I had an honest government,'' he said, referring to his predecessor, Gen. Fernando Romeo Lucas.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Pact Seen as Trophy Gorbachev Wants Most
DOC.TEXT: If Mikhail Gorbachev fails to bring home a signed trade agreement from his summit meeting with President Bush, it will be another blow to a Soviet economy that is already reeling, analysts say. Both Gorbachev and President Bush have put major emphasis on a new trade agreement as the primary way the United States can provide economic support for Gorbachev's reform program. ``It is a very important trophy for Gorbachev. It won't solve all of his economic problems, but not getting a deal will hurt,'' said Marshall Goldman, a Soviet expert at Harvard University. The pact would normalize trade relations between the two superpowers for the first time in nearly a half century and clear the way for significantly lower tariffs on Soviet products. It would also expand business opportunites for American companies in the Soviet Union. Donald Bowles, an economics professor at American University, said that given the food shortages and other problems besetting the Soviet economy, the boost from a trade agreement should not be underestimated. ``The more quickly that we can normalize relationships, the better we can make things for the Soviet people generally,'' he said. ``That is in our long-term interests.'' U.S. and Soviet negotiators reached basic agreement on the trade pact on April 25 with administration officials expressing optimism a month ago that a few minor loose ends could be resolved in time for Bush and Gorbachev to sign the document during this week's summit. Although the administration has not ruled out a signing cremony during the four-day summit, the outlook has grown considerably less certain. At first, the administration said it would not sign a trade agreement until the Soviet parliament put into law liberalized emigration policies for Soviet Jews and other dissidents. But now the administration, seeking to influence Gorbachev's handling of the Lithuanian independence movement, has linked a trade agreement with the lifting of Moscow's economic blockade on the breakaway republic. While Bush is being pressured by many members of Congress to hold firm to this position, some U.S. business groups were lobbying the administration to go ahead and sign a trade deal. The National Association of Manufacturers sent Bush a letter Wednesday saying that the first role of U.S. trade policy was to advance America's competitive standing in the world, not to serve as a ``poor foreign policy messenger.'' ``Without some clear indication that the pending U.S.-Soviet trade agreement will be implemented, American business proposals will get short shrift in the Soviet Union compared with those from Europe and Japan,'' wrote NAM President Jerry Jasinowski. The trade agreement is needed to grant the Soviet Union ``most favored nation status,'' qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to any other country. Currently, Soviet products sold in the United States bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other countries. By one estimate, the price of Soviet vodka could drop by $1.25 per bottle. U.S. officials have estimated that the $5 billion in annual trade between the Soviet Union and the United States could double or even triple over the next three years with a new trade agreement. In addition to the lower tariffs, the agreement includes a number of provisions aimed at expanding foreign business opportunities. The agreement would provide better copyright protection for American companies and cut down on the time U.S. companies have to wait for approval for commercial operations in the Soviet Union. The agreement would also clear the way for American companies doing business with the Soviets to be eligible for government-subsidized loans from the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corp. Analysts said this provision was significant because it would expand the number of U.S. companies interested in setting up joint ventures in the Soviet Union, a key goal of Gorbachev's economic reforms. The dire economic situation in the Soviet Union was emphasized during a pre-summit press conference Wednesday conducted by a group of Soviet economists who discussed with unusual candor the slumping Soviet economy, which has been beset by food shortages, labor strikes and high inflation. ``Everything we have done so far were half measures. One step forward and two steps backwards,'' said Vladlen Martynov, director of the Soviet Institute of World Economics and International Relations.

DOC.HEAD: `Heavens Gate 2'? It Would Go Over Better Than June Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Ally Sheedy, Robert Blake and Polly Draper turned out for gubernatorial candidate Dianne Feinstein. Jack Lemmon and James Garner made TV commercials against a pair of Republican-backed redistricting measures. But for the most part, Hollywood's big names are sitting out the June 5 primary, saving their star power for the general election, especially for the Big Green environmental initiative celebrity drive headed by Jane Fonda. ``Primaries are too divisive,'' explained Shana Weiss of the Hollywood Women's Political Committee. ``Unless there is a compelling, principled reason to endorse someone, the celebrities are going to wait.'' Feinstein is battling state Attorney General John Van de Kamp for the Democratic nomination for governor. U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson is the favorite to win the GOP nomination. A Feinstein fund-raiser drew some stars, and a GOP fund-raiser that indirectly helped Wilson attracted Charlton Heston, Bob Hope and Chuck Norris. Van de Kamp appears to have garnered no strong celebrity support. No celebrities have been seen at his fund-raisers and his campaign could not provide the name of a single big-name backer. Oddly, it wasn't the usually Hollywood-hip issues of abortion or the environment that got Lemmon and Garner involved. They gave their support to opponents of Propositions 118 and 119, initiatives that would dramatically change the way the state draws legislative and congressional boundaries based on the latest census figures. One measure would require a two-thirds vote of the legislature to approve reapportionment plans rather than the current simple majority. The other would take redistricting power away from the legislature and give it to an independent commission. Both have heavy Republican backing. The commercials touched such a nerve among many Republicans that GOP Gov. George Deukmejian, who backs the measures, assailed the celebrity support and noted that in 1984 a similar ad campaign helped defeat a redistricting effort. ``The opponents are again using a Hollywood star with a message of misrepresentation,'' Deukmejian said. The other initiatives, however, have lacked star appeal: The celebrities didn't offer and the campaigns didn't call. ``We're just not trying to sell it that way,'' said Bob Schmidt with the gas tax initiative, Proposition 111, and a companion measure, Proposition 108. ``Frankly, in any of the strategy conferences, we've never even discussed getting any celebrity types.'' Feinstein, the former San Francisco mayor in a close race with Van de Kamp, got a good celebrity showing at a May 5 fund-raiser at the home of feminist lawyer Gloria Allred. ``As an almost lifelong Republican, I am no longer deluded and I'm delighted to support Dianne,'' said Richard Paul, star of the ``Carter Country'' television series. But Feinstein's star support is low-profile at best. None of the celebrities has been seen stumping for her and many of the stars at the fund-raiser declined to comment on their political leanings. Among them was Dana Delaney of television's ``China Beach.'' ``Dana just didn't think it was something she wanted to talk about,'' said her publicist, Heidi Schaeffer. Wilson also has lukewarm support from Hollywood. The February event that drew Hope, Heston and Norris was technically for the state Republican Party, not Wilson's campaign, and an appearance by President Bush was the draw. Although Van de Kamp has not stirred up Hollywood interest, the Big Green measure he co-sponsors with Assemblyman Tom Hayden, D-Santa Monica, has the entertainment world buzzing. The sweeping environmental initiative has lined up the support of Miss Fonda, Meryl Streep, Robin Williams, Ted Danson, Candice Bergen, Billy Crystal, Martin Short, Chevy Chase, Barbra Streisand, Ed Begley Jr. and Donna Mills.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp
Bush Sets Out Johnson China, Homebred Opera for Gorbachev Dinner
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush is laying out the china _ though not the dishes that got Nancy Reagan in trouble _ for a spectacular evening of socializing and opera at tonight's dinner for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife Raisa. Last-minute details, including finishing touches on the menu, were being completed in secrecy today as White House social officials prepared for the hottest social event of the year. First lady Barbara Bush's office, which oversees planning for state dinners, released minimal information in advance, saying the details could not be divulged until all was absolutely ready. But a few glimpses of the evening's promise penetrated the secrecy shield. The feature entertainment will be American opera singer Frederica von Stade, considered one of the world's foremost mezzo-sopranos. The New Jersey-born von Stade has sung with most of the nation's major opera companies, including the Washington Opera, and has performed all over the world. She is particularly renowned for her French repertoire, especially the role of Cinderella in the opera ``Cendrillon'' by Jules Massenet. The White House planned to set out dishes bought during President Lyndon B. Johnson's administration, which Nancy Reagan once described as just not elegant enough for a state dinner. Mrs. Reagan ordered new china. She later wrote in her autobiography, ``My Turn,'' that the purchase became ``a symbol of my supposed extravagance,'' even though the bill was picked up by the Knapp Foundation, not the taxpayers. The set left behind by the Johnsons, Mrs. Reagan wrote, ``did not include serving platters, finger bowls, dessert bowls and bouillon cups. And while the Johnson china was lovely, with the various state flowers around the edge, it was more suitable for a luncheon than a formal state dinner.'' Maybe so, but Mrs. Bush chose to use that dishware, rather than Nancy Reagan's, for reasons left unsaid _ if not obvious. Simply put, Mrs. Reagan and Mrs. Gorbachev never hit it off, as the former first lady acknowledged in her book. The relationship, she said, ``obviously had been difficult for both of us.'' The administration's chief of protocol, Ambassador Joseph V. Reed, confirmed the Bushes themselves took a strong hand in planning the dinner. As he put it: ``It has their personal stamp of American elegance on it.'' The menu features ``classic continental cuisine,'' said Mrs. Bush's press secretary Anna Perez. She provided no specifics. As is customary, domestic wine will be served. During dessert, the Air Force strolling strings orchestra will perform for the dinner guests. Before and after dinner, the Marine orchestra will play in the White House grand entrance hall where dancing is the custom after guests sit for the entertainment in the East Room. The dinner also affords an opportunity for the two presidents to exchange pleasantries in formal toasts, which are often political in nature. The tightly-held guest list included such American luminaries as Academy-Award winning actor Jessica Tandy, Tandy's husband, Hume Cronyn, actor Morgan Freeman and NBC news anchor Tom Brokaw, sources said. Tandy and Freeman starred together in last year's Academy Award best picture ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' The Gorbachevs also will have a chance to mingle with the Democratic and Republican congressional leaders, also among the invitees. The 130-person guest list was rounded out by assorted political, social, athletic and entertainment world figures. Some questions remained open: Would the Gorbachevs take a whirl around the dance floor? The Bushes always dance a number or two, but whether their more reserved Soviet guests would follow suit was not known. Would Bush and Gorbachev call each other by first names in the formal toasts? Bush frequently addresses his foreign guests by first name, but it remained unclear whether Gorbachev would accept that level of intimacy with the American president. So far in their public comments, Bush and Gorbachev have addressed one another formally, as ``Mr. President.'' The Gorbachevs will reciprocate as hosts on Friday night, when they hold a dinner for the Bushes at the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: American's Plight Highlights Continuing Emigration Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: If no superpower trade agreement is signed during the Washington summit, the plight of Yuri Semenenko may be one small reason why. Semenenko holds a U.S. passport by virtue of his birth in Portland, Oregon, 45 years ago, but he still is unable to leave the Soviet Union. The catch: he also holds a Soviet passport, and visa officials say he cannot leave until he gives it up _ and only they can decide if and when he can do that. Semenenko served five years in prison camps on what he said were trumped-up criminal charges connected to his effort to obtain a U.S. passport in the early 1980s. For him, the political and economic reforms for which the world has praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``are changes in words only.'' ``In deeds, nothing has changed,'' said Semenenko, a trim tennis fanatic and former motocross racer. Even though he knows Portland only through old photographs, he would like to take his wife, Yelena, a ballet dancer, and newborn daughter to the city to live. ``I have some kind of feeling that the city is my home, some kind of ties there,'' he said. Travel and emigration from the Soviet Union have reached record levels under Gorbachev. An Israeli immigration agency reported in January that 71,509 Jews left the Soviet Union in 1989, the highest total in about two decades. But many say Gorbachev's reforms have been limited. Soviet Jews plan to demonstrate in Moscow during the superpower summit to make their point. Soviet officials long have promised a new emigration law to remove obstacles, and President Bush has set that as a criterion for easing trade restrictions against the Soviet Union. Under a 1974 U.S. law, the Soviet Union has been denied the benefits of Most Favored Nation trading status because of its repressive policies toward the emigration of Soviet Jews and other minorities. Bush administration officials have worked on the final wording of a trade agreement, but it was unclear whether it would be put on the table during the summit without a new Soviet emigration law. Gorbachev's economic crackdown on Lithuania was also hindering an accord, officials said. In November, the Supreme Soviet legislature gave preliminary approval to a bill that would allow emigration for virtually anyone who has entry permission from another country and no outstanding alimony obligations, criminal charges or recent knowledge of state secrets. It sets a limit of five years on the period a citizen can be kept from emigrating because of access to secrets. Nevertheless, Jewish activists claim the bill is vaguely worded and might still be used to restrict emigration. There are indications the bill might come up for debate soon, but it has proved little comfort to Semenenko and others caught in the slow grind of Soviet bureaucracy. Semenenko is the son of a Soviet military officer assigned to oversee Lend-Lease shipments in World War II and is American by virtue of his birth in Portland's Wilcox Memorial Hospital on Feb. 10, 1945. His family left the United States several months after Semenenko's birth and he has lived since then in the Soviet Union. Ten years ago he learned he was eligible for U.S. citizenship and in March 1989 obtained a U.S. passport, after being released from prison camp, where he served time on charges of bribery and hooliganism. He began seeking permission from the Soviet Union to leave, but was told only the Soviet government could decide whether and when he can give up his Soviet citizenship. The bureaucracy's gears moved another notch in February. Leningrad visa officials invited him to fill out an application to give up citizenship, and pay a fee of 500 rubles, about twice the monthly wage for an average factory worker. But nothing has happened since he paid the fee and filled out the form. Semenenko said calls to the local visa office indicated the documents still have not been transmitted to Moscow for approval. To Semenenko that means ``my documents are with the KGB, and the visa office can't do anything about it.'' There is no way to guess if the secret police will sign off on his departure, he said. As the Soviet Union struggles through economic failure, ethnic tension and political upheaval, Semenenko said it does not matter what kind of life he finds in the United States. ``Sitting here, it's impossible to construct any kind of possibilities for the future,'' he said. ``I'm ready for any kind of work.''

DOC.HEAD: 600 Essayists in Search of a Respectable Ruble
DOC.TEXT: It has come to this with the Russian currency. So great is its trouble _ so low its value _ that an essay contest was held on ways to rescue the ruble. Six hundred ideas came from 23 countries. Frank Furth, a wealthy Californian who put up $42,000 in prize money, said the idea came to him when a Soviet guest visiting his ranch asked if he had any suggestions on how to make the ruble convertible _ worth something outside of the U.S.S.R. His suggestion was to have the contest. If the ruble isn't convertible, no one wants it. It can't be cashed in for other currencies. When Pepsi-Cola set up shop in the Soviet Union, it worked out a deal to sell Pepsi for rubles, buy vodka with the rubles, export the vodka, then sell the vodka and make its profit that way. It works, but it's clumsy. Economists talk about liquidity, but that's not what they have in mind. The judges _ three American academics, three Russian experts _ went over the finalists and awarded $10,000 prizes Wednesday to two Russians, Giuzel Anulova and K. Panov, and an economics professor from Tufts University, Franklyn Holzman. They gave $4,000 prizes to the runners-up, a Russian, a West German and a Hungarian. The top winners called, one way or another, for creation of a market economy in the Soviet Union as the only effective path to ruble respectability. The others called, one way or another, for a dual economy, which might, or might not, lead to a convertible ruble, the judges said. The judges issued a statement: ``After two days of intense discussion, the jury came away impressed with the difficulties involved in devising a workable strategy for achieving a convertible ruble, and also with the immense importance of making headway on this issue.'' Furth, antitrust lawyer and owner of a California winery, said essays came in from ``the cognoscente of convertibility,'' showing ``that the world was responding to a chance to help.'' Economist Ed Hewitt of the Brookings Institution said he would have been ``chagrined'' if one of the entries had won. It came from a sixth grader, not otherwise identified. Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the U.S.S.R. State Commission on Foreign Economic Relations, promised to call a conference in Moscow in October toweigh the ideas further. All this happened at the Brookings Institution. Over at the National Press Club, five Soviet officials in grey suits lined up behind microphones and took turns for an hour taking aim at the Soviet economy, no punches pulled. ``There is absolutely no logic to our pricing system,'' said Vladlen Arkadyevich Martynov, director of the Academy of Sciences Institute of World Economics and International Relations. ``We have ludicrously low prices on bread, which results in that bread being fed to animals or even being used as fertilizer. ... We must re-educate 100 percent of our managers.'' For all that, Andrei Grachev, an official of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, said it would be appropriate for capitalism to lend a hand to a communist economy trying to reform itself. Said he: ``I would hope that the West would take some responsibilities in perestroika.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Some timber workers have a beef with Burger King over its use of Paul Newman salad dressing. Forty-three sales employees at Willamette Industries sent a letter to Boss Enterprises, which runs eight local Burger King outlets, asking the company to stop using Newman's Own. Newman's company donates profits to environmentalist groups who the timber workers believe want to take the food from their mouths. Their May 16 letter cited Newman's narration of a National Audubon Society TV special last fall on a dispute between environmentalists and loggers. ``This show was pro-preservationist and for the shutting down of all logging in the Northwest,'' the letter read. ``We do not feel it is right that we contribute to the demise of our industry.'' Boss Enterprises co-owner Bob Boss said he had no plans to discontinue using Newman's Own, which he said has a contract with Burger King. ``It's not our own personal support of his causes,'' he said.

Comic Jay Leno will donate royalties from his book ``Headlines'' to a charity that helps children stricken with AIDS. ``My manager had a 3-year-old baby that died of AIDS and at the time people thought it couldn't happen to them,'' Leno said Wednesday. Profits from the book, a collection of wacky newspaper headlines that has sold more than 250,000 copies, will go to the Samuel Jared Kushnick Foundation, founded by his manager, Helen Kushnick. Leno said he didn't know how much money was involved. Kushnick's son died in 1983 after receiving an AIDS-tainted blood transfusion. She said Leno's effort ``makes me feel Sam didn't die in vain.''

Gov. Mario Cuomo showed a winning form on the basketball court in dispatching a couple of TV journalists. The 58-year-old governor, who is expected to announce for re-election soon, challenged anchorman Jim Ryan and political reporter Dick Oliver of WNYW's ``Good Day New York'' to one-on-one Wednesday. He beat them by scores of 7-1. ``They were pretty good for reporters, but we knew the governor would prevail in the end,'' said Karen Polk, an aide to Cuomo.

The British press applauded John Malkovich for his British stage debut in the Broadway play ``Burn This.'' Jack Tinker in The Daily Mail said Malkovich gave ``a performance of wall-blasting intensity'' at the Hampstead Theater. Malkovich, star of ``Dangerous Liaisons'' and ``Places in the Heart,'' is reprising the role he played on Broadway for six months in the 1987-88 season. Lanford Wilson's play casts the 36-year-old actor as Pale, a foul-mouthed restaurant manager who embarks on a relationship with his dead brother's roommate, a dancer named Anna. She is played by British actress Juliet Stevenson. Michael Billington in The Guardian said the star's ``riveting'' performance confirmed his belief that Malkovich is ``the most exciting American actor to emerge since Brando.''

ABC fibbed when it said Laura Palmer's murder would be solved in the season finale of ``Twin Peaks,'' executive producer Mark Frost says _ but withholding the whodunit seems to have gotten the series renewed. ``We had no guarantee that ABC would ever renew us,'' he said Tuesday in a telephone interview from Hawaii. ``I intentionally structured that last hour so that if ABC was really curious about who killed Laura, they'd have to pick up the show. ``Our sole strategy was survival. By withholding the identity of the killer, we thought we were down to our last coin.'' An ABC spokesman said early this month that the mystery would be solved in the last episode, which was last week. On Wednesday, spokesman Bob Wright changed his tune. ``I was always under the assumption that the central part of the story pertaining to the murder would be resolved,'' he said. ``I was wrong. From now on, I will not make any promises about `Twin Peaks.''' ``Twin Peaks'' will be back in the fall, along with, Frost hopes, disappointed viewers who charted every dizzying turn of the show's nine hours trying to figure out who murdered the sleepy Northwest lumber town's homecoming queen. On April 8, television was introduced to a world out of kilter, confected by Frost and film director David Lynch, who made ``Blue Velvet.'' The ratings were only mediocre, but fans threw ``Twin Peaks'' parties and more was written about the program than any other in recent memory.

DOC.HEAD: Weary Gorbachev Will Rap with Private Americans as Well as Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top likely after 10 a.m. EDT meeting
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's first full day of summitry mixes weighty sessions at the White House and private time during which he will play luncheon host to a group of yet-to-be-identified American intellectuals. Gorbachev, accompanied by his stylish wife, Raisa, arrived from Ottawa, Canada, for the four-day U.S.-Soviet summit late Wednesday. He looked slightly weary as he stepped off his jet, but said he was keen to see Bush. ``This is the first time that the president ... and I will have enough time to reflect on and discuss _ not only in a formal setting but also in a more informal surrounding one-on-one _ all the questions either of us might have that fall within our responsibility,'' Gorbachev said in brief remarks at a red-carpet welcoming ceremony at nearby Andrews Air Force Base. Gorbachev will meet twice with Bush at the White House today and attend a state dinner in the evening. After more sessions Friday, the pair will relax at Camp David, Md., the presidential retreat in Maryland on Saturday. Also on today's agenda is the luncheon for American thinkers. That will be at the Soviet Embassy, where Gorbachev is staying, about six blocks from the White House. The Soviets have kept the guest list closely held. When Gorbachev arrived at the embassy, he was greeted by gawkers and protesters. One small group of people chanted ``Stop killing Armenians,'' and another carried signs reading, ``No tanks in Lithuania.'' Gorbachev's car was in a motorcade of more than 50 vehicles. Earlier, as his Zil limousine drove down Connecticut Avenue, Gorbachev's window was open. Gorbachev waved and smiled at people along the sidewalk, who applauded. The promise of an agreement reducing strategic nuclear arms was high on his wish list, Gorbachev said. He and Bush were sure to get down to that topic at their first meeting this morning. Other issues likely to be addressed included a chemical weapons ban, the role of conventional forces in Europe, the unification of Germany, the future of the Baltic Republics, and, according to Bush aides, Gorbachev's domestic problems. Those may have taken a turn for the worse Wednesday with an announcement by Boris Yeltsin, the newly elected Russian president, that he'll seek sovereignty for the largest Soviet republic within his first 100 days in office. Yeltin, a political threat to Gorbachev from the left, said he would try to mend fences with Gorbachev, but outlined a program of economic and social reform must broader than Gorbachev's. Already, the economic reforms initiated by Gorbachev have caused increases in food prices. The sad shape of the Soviet economy _ and Gorbachev's desire to improve ties with capitalist countries _ must have been a factor in the Soviet leader's decision to meet with South Korea's president next week in San Francisco, U.S. officials said Wednesday. Moscow and Seoul have no formal diplomatic relations, and Gorbachev's decision to hold the meeting represents the strongest Soviet gesture yet toward South Korea. Gorbachev is scheduled to meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on Monday in San Francisco, where he also will see Ronald Reagan and former Secretary of State George Shultz.

DOC.HEAD: `Newhart' Finale No. 1 in Nielsens
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: ``Newhart'' went out with a bang, ending its eight-year run on CBS with the most-watched show of the week. It was the first No. 1 finish for ``Newhart'' since 1983, but NBC remained the top-rated network overall, according to figures Wednesday from the A.C. Nielsen Co. With the May sweeps over, the Big Three now head straight for summer rerun season. Ratings during the sweeps period are used to set local advertising rates. NBC had an 11.1 average for last week, well ahead of ABC with 10.4. CBS had four of the top 10 shows on television last week but was in its usual last-place spot, with a 10. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. The last episode of ``Newhart'' _ which saw the Stratford Inn in danger of being purchased by the Japanese and Bob Newhart awakening next to Suzanne Pleshette (his wife from ``The Bob Newhart Show'' in the 1970s) and realizing the last eight years were just a dream _ drew an 18.7 rating. NBC dominated with reruns of mega-hits such as ``Cheers,'' which finished second, ``A Different World,'' which landed in sixth place, and ``The Cosby Show,'' which came in eighth. The season finale of CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' which married off the annoyingly cheerful Corky, was third. ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' which has consistently placed in the top five for ABC, plummeted to 18th. More than half the top 50 shows last week were repeats. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Newhart,'' CBS, 18.7; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 18.3; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 17.7; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 17.2; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 16.1; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 15.9; CBS Tuesday Movie ``A Killing in A Small Town,'' 15.8; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 15.7; ``ABC Sunday Night Movie'' tied with ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 15.5. In the evening news, ABC was No. 1 for the 20th consecutive week with an average of 9.3. CBS had an 8.5 and NBC a 7.8.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rican Government to Give Employees Time Out for Soccer
DOC.TEXT: By presidential decree, government employees will be able to put aside their work and watch Costa Rica play in its first World Cup soccer tournament. ``I'm not going to miss the game. So it's fair that all public employees, for two hours, have the right to watch it in their places of work,'' President Rafael Angel Calderon said after signing the decree Wednesday. Two of Costa Rica's first three games will be on weekdays, in the morning local time. ``Employees will have permission from 9 a.m. until 11:30 a.m. local time. After that, everybody to work,'' Calderon said. The team caused national jubilation when it became the first to qualify for a World Cup in Costa Rican history. The first match is June 11 against Scotland in Genoa. The other opponents in Group C are Brazil and Sweden. Calderon had planned to go to Italy for the matches but later decided to send his son instead.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say `Deranged Don' is `Crazy Like a Fox'
LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Vincent ``The Chin'' Gigante is no dapper don: he prefers a bathrobe and pajamas to a silk shirt and designer suits and wears slippers instead of Guccis as he rambles through the streets of Greenwich Village. But authorities say that Gigante's befuddled ways are a dodge and that the reputed boss of the Genovese crime family is every bit as ruthless as the better-known, better-dressed John Gotti. Gigante even put a contract out on Gotti in 1987, authorities in New Jersey allege. Gigante, who until now had been untouched by a government crackdown on the Mafia, was among 15 people from four mob families charged Wednesday with monopolizing the installation of windows in the city's housing projects since 1978. The business brought mob companies more than $191 million, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said. Andrew Maloney, U.S. attorney in Brooklyn, said the cooperative effort by the four rival families was an unusual arrangement, prompted by the profits available. Gigante mediated disputes between the crime families, Maloney said. Gigante's brother and other family members says he's no don, he's deranged. They maintain Gigante is mentally and physically unfit to care for himself. Law enforcement officials reject the claim as bogus. ``He's crazy like a fox,'' FBI organized crime and narcotics chief Jules J. Bonavolonta said last year. Gigante, 62, was in his robe and striped sleepwear when he was arrested early Wednesday and charged with racketeering. The FBI says the Genovese family, with 250 members, is second only to Gotti's Gambino crew in power and influence. The family maintains a lock on waterfronts and unions in New York and New Jersey, officials say. Gigante's alleged ascent to the top spot followed the 1986 racketeering conviction of his predecessor, Anthony ``Fat Tony'' Salerno. His organized crime career began more than three decades earlier as a mob hit man, the FBI said. Investigators said his most famous job was one he bungled, a 1957 hit on mob boss Frank Costello. ``This is for you, Frank,'' Gigante allegedly announced before firing a shot at Costello's head. Costello was only grazed. He refused to identify his assailant. Gigante was acquitted; Costello retired and Vito Genovese assumed control of the family that now carries his name. Investigators say Gigante, whose nickname apparently came from an early boxing career, moved up through the ranks of the family, his climb interrupted by a jail term from 1959 to 1964 on a heroin charge. But since beating a 1970 bribery rap by pleading mental incompetence, he has avoided prosecution. Authorities attribute Gigante's elusiveness to his bizarre lifestyle. They say most of his conversations with mob colleagues are conducted on long walks through Greenwich Village, far from the wiretaps that brought down other crime bosses. Gigante is a familiar, shuffling presence on the streets of the Village. Clad in a robe and mumbling incoherently, he strolls from his headquarters, the Triangle Social Club, to a store across the street. He sits and plays cards. FBI agents serving Gigante with a subpoena several years ago found him standing naked in a shower holding an open umbrella. Gigante's brother, the Rev. Louis Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest, tried unsuccessfully for years to have his brother declared incompetent. He claims his brother's frequent visits to a sanitarium are evidence of his mental anguish, and notes a psychiatric report detailing Vincent's schizophrenia and hallucinations. ``His mental state is such that he couldn't be the boss of a candy store,'' Gigante attorney Barry Slotnick argued earlier this year. Federal prosecutors, unswayed by such arguments, had targeted Gigante as their No. 2 priority behind the thrice-acquitted Gotti.

DOC.HEAD: Capitalists of the World Unite in Karl Marx City
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: KARL-MARX-STADT, East Germany (AP) _ Karl Marx looks awfully angry as he stares at a city that no longer practices his principles and no longer wants his name. The imposing two-story bust of socialism's intellectual architect rests on a massive block of granite in front of city hall, staring stern-faced across a main avenue that also sports his name. The area around it is empty of people, but nearby streets are crawling with commerce. Hundreds of booths, stands and trucks loaded with Western merchandise fill plazas and malls, the frontline forces of capitalism's advancing army. Like virtually every other major population center in East Germany, Karl Marx, the city, has become Karl Marx, the market, one of the places to be if you have something to sell. ``You can do a lot of business here. It is incredible,'' said Jochen Siebke, head of marketing for the West German branch of Citroen, the French automaker. This 825-year-old city was known as Chemnitz until 1953, when the former Communist government changed the name. In an April referendum, 76 percent of those voting said the city of 308,000 should be changed back to Chemnitz. The city council has not yet formalized the change, however, and the drab industrial town is known alternately by both names. Highway signs switch back and forth, and the government news agency, ADN, uses a ``Karl-Marx-Stadt@Chemnitz'' dateline on stories from the city. If the city is still somewhat schizophrenic about its name, there is little doubt about which ideology is prevailing. Furniture is peddled from the backs of trucks and a seemingly endless string of booths sell everything from Barbie dolls to Black & Decker tools. In a plaza, models cavort to a Michael Jackson song and tout a line of surf wear. The show takes place under a banner that says ``Test the West.'' West is a brand of cigarette. Citroen recently parked a dozen of its shiny cars on a dusty parking lot in town, set up tables under red-and-white parasols and blared music and commercials touting its sleek sets of wheels. The automaker wasn't necessarily looking to sell cars today, Siebke said, but after July 2, when the German states merge their economies and East Germans can convert their money to coveted West German marks. ``You have to get out here, get you're name known,'' Siebke said. ``It's in preparation for the whole economic union.'' The cheapest car sells for about $9,000 _ about $1,800 more than the average East German's annual salary. About half of the people who come by cannot pay, and many work in outmoded industries that are likely to face high unemployment, Siebke says. ``We don't press people to buy,'' he said. But he added that many people have large savings accounts. ``People have been saving for 20 years, but they have had nothing to buy,'' he said. ``One man came here and he had a savings account book with 500,000 East marks in it.'' Under the conversion system, that will be worth about 252,000 West German marks or $152,000 after July 2. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere has urged East Germans to refrain from spending their new currency so they will not erode its value and cause inflation in both Germanys. But Wolfgang Hufenbecher, director of the West German Commerzbank and the head of its new East German operation said the influx of Western products may be too tempting. ``You can see that already,'' he said speaking in East Berlin recently. ``Lots of West German companies put out various goods at rather high prices, but people still buy it. There is a lot of money around.'' He said average East German savings accounts range from the equivalents of $3,010 to $6,020. Last week, Trabant workers staged a brief strike in the nearby city of Zwickau to demand protection from the unemployment expected as outmoded enterprises try to compete with their inferior products. ``It is ironic, of course,'' Siebke said. ``East Germans will accelerate the decline of their own industries by buying Western products.''
