DOC.HEAD: Senators' Income Includes Honoraria, Gifts, Free Trips
DOC.TEXT: Senators padded their incomes by $2.7 million last year by speaking to special-interest groups, but the practice seems to be losing some of its appeal. The total honoraria income for senators in 1989, reported Wednesday in annual financial disclosures, was slightly below the levels for the two previous years. And the lobbying group Common Cause said that for this year, more than one-third of the Senate _ 34 members, up from 19 in 1988 _ have sworn off keeping speaking fees for their personal use. One member on the Common Cause list, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, has relapsed. After declining in the past to keep honoraria, he retained $11,284 last year, saying he was strapped for funds because of the cost of maintaining three houses. Boschwitz, president of a lumber company, has holdings that could be worth more than $3.4 million. Common Cause said he has promised to resume his old policy this year. As usual, the top talker was Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., who raked in $108,900. Senators are not allowed to keep more than 40 percent of their salaries in honoraria, so Dole gave all but $35,750 to charity. Also big on the speaking circuit were Sens. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., who collected $90,600; Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, with $92,499; and Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., with $73,450. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, took in $50,000. The House, which disclosed its finances on Tuesday, has moved to eliminate the practice of accepting honoraria after this year. Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer said the Senate should follow suit. ``It is ludicrous for the Senate to have lower ethical standards than the House, the executive branch and the judiciary,'' he said in a statement, calling the practice ``a totally discredited system.'' Otherwise, the voluminous disclosure forms highlighted how little many senators rely on their taxpayer-paid salaries, reflected the popularity of travel financed by special interests and listed the quirky gifts senators receive from various groups. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, was given a dog named Gus and a pair of long underwear. Dole got 14 neckties, among other items. And Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate's tax-writing committee, accepted a $940 Steuben glass bowl from the Washington-based Tax Foundation. Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., received eight trips paid for by interest groups, including four to West Palm Beach, Fla., near where he owns a vacation condominium. Another frequent flier was Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., who took nine trips on the special-interest tab. The forays included Moscow, Israel, West Palm Beach, and Indianapolis on the weekend of the Indianapolis 500 auto race. As the disclosures illustrate, the Senate remains largely a rich men's club. Wisconsin freshman Democrat Herbert Kohl, owner of the Milwaukee Bucks pro basketball team, said he grossed more than $15 million from that source alone, pushing his 1989 income to $20 million or more. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., reported assets that could exceed $17 million from the family food empire. Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., whose family founded Ralston Purina, disclosed holdings that could be in the $15 million range, and the assets of Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., appeared to be worth upwards of $8 million. The disclosure forms require only that assets and income be reported in broad ranges, so it is impossible to determine net worth with any specificity. Some senators with extensive holdings in blind trusts, such as Hollings and Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and John D. Rockefeller IV, D-W.Va., are required to report only the income they receive from the trusts. The forms can cause problems. Sen. Dave Durenberger, D-Minn., who already is the subject of a Senate ethics investigation, said Wednesday he had failed to report a short-term $484,000 loan to buy a house and a friend's gift of lodging in previous years. He filed amended disclosures for five years. His office said the 35 days of lodging had been left out by mistake, and that the loan was overlooked by someone who didn't understand the disclosure forms. Durenberger is under investigation for failure to report a $100,000 book-promotion deal in the past. Durenberger's aides said he also will amend his 1989 form to report his legal fees as a liability. Among other odds and ends reported by senators: _Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the senior Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee, reported income of $1,836 as his one-eighth share of proceeds from a family corn and soybean farm in his home state. _Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., got $120.80 in royalties from a record of fiddle music he recorded several years ago. _Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, received $40,000 in book royalties, including income from volumes he co-wrote with Mitchell and with former Sen. Gary Hart, and an advance on an upcoming mystery novel. _Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., probably the Senate's best golfer, got a set of clubs worth $1,870 from Ely Callaway of Carlsbad, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: College Presidents Offer Advice on Dealing With Campus Racism
DOC.TEXT: ``Listen'' is one of the suggestions Kenneth A. Shaw, president of the University of Wisconsin System, offers to fellow college administrators trying to deal with campus racism. Shaw's comment is included in a new book on dealing with a problem that many contend is becoming more visible at U.S. colleges and universities. The book, ``The Lurking Evil: Racial and Ethnic Conflict on the College Campus,'' was unveiled by the American Association of State Colleges and Universities during a news conference Wednesday. ``It is clear that this is an issue that is rearing its ugly head in a lot of ... segments of society,'' said Anthony F. Ceddia, president of Shippensburg University in Pennsylvania and a contributor to the book. The publication contains 16 articles _ most of them written by college administrators _ that describe problems with campus racism and offer suggestions for dealing with them. ``Listen. Listening gives us information about what is important to other parties. It allows adversaries to relax and focus on solutions,'' Shaw wrote in the book. Another writer, Washington lawyer David S. Tatel, suggests that administrators use the means most available to them to fight racial intolerance on their campuses. ``Universities should respond by doing wht they do best; namely education,'' he said. The schools should avoid implementing written policies that punish students for racial slurs and other verbal acts, Tatel said, because they could wind up in court defending the rules. Lower federal court rulings, he said, ``have said even racial slurs are protected speech.'' The Supreme Court has yet to rule on the issue. Schools that believe policies are absolutely necessary should draft them as narrowly and as clearly as possible, Tatel said. In addition, he said, ``universities ought not to write these policies from the administration building.'' He said students, faculty and community representatives should be involved to minimize the chances of a court challenge and to ``demonstrate to the courts a deliberate and careful response of the entire community.'' One way to change student attitudes is by making sure that all groups are represented among the faculty and administration, said Ceddia. He added, however, that he would ``be very cautious about using words like portions or quotas or goals.'' Ceddia said schools can do many things to help students learn to deal with those of other races, but he warned, ``You can't just accomplish reteaching in a two- or three-day or week-long program. Programs need to be ongoing throughout the year.''

DOC.HEAD: Football's Intrusion in Oakland Politics May Throw Mayor For a Loss
DOC.TEXT: The long and apparently fruitless haggling to bring Oakland's beloved Raiders home from Los Angeles may cost Mayor Lionel Wilson his bid for a fourth term. The city of about 350,000 people has some of the highest crime and unemployment rates in the state, a deeply troubled school system, widespread drug abuse, budget problems and earthquake damage. But those woes have been overshadowed in the campaign leading to Tuesday's mayoral election by questions about Wilson's handling of the Raiders deal. The 75-year-old Wilson, mayor since 1977, had only 18 percent of the vote in a May 22 poll in The Tribune of Oakland. Leading was state Assemblyman Elihu Harris, with 32 percent, followed by City Councilman Wilson Riles Jr., with 22 percent. If none of the eight candidates wins more than 50 percent in the non-partisan election, the two top vote-getters will face off in November. The deal had seemed like a political bonanza when Wilson announced in March he was bringing back the NFL team that left in 1982. The city offered Raiders owner Al Davis a $602 million package, including guaranteed ticket income and up-front payments. But Wilson and the City Council had to quash the deal after critics charged that the city, already strapped with huge expenses and with debts from the earthquake, would end up paying millions if Raider games didn't sell out. City officials have returned to the bargaining table, but their offer has dwindled to $475 million, and it appears unlikely to be accepted. Wilson's critics say his handling of the deal shows he has lost his common touch. ``It exemplified people's feeling that they are not in control of their government,'' said Harris, who was endorsed Wednesday by The Tribune. ``The city is not accountable to the community.'' ``People are concerned about the kind of time and energy and resources that our elected officials have spent trying to consummate this deal when we have such other problems,'' said Dezie Woods-Jones, a candidate who trails far behind the leaders. Wilson did not return repeated phone calls. But aide Erica Huggins said the Raiders are not a priority in his campaign. Riles, an 11-year City Councilman who finished second in the 1985 mayoral race and has been one of Wilson's staunchest opponents on the Raiders deal, said Wilson's handling of the Raiders was an example of his ``bumbling, hands-off method of administration.'' The mayor's inattention is at the root of the blight in many of Oakland's neighborhoods, Riles charged. Don Perata, president of the Alameda County Board of Supervisors and chief architect of the Raiders proposal, said the Raiders deal had given Riles an issue ``to move out on.'' ``Take the Raiders issue out, there wouldn't be a clear issue in the campaign itself,'' he said. The other candidates are Leo Bazile Jr., a lawyer and seven-year City Councilman; Hector Reyna, who runs a recycling business; Philip Haymon, a teacher and computer programmer, and Michael Kinane, owner of a trading and consulting firm.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Again Grounds Transport Helicopters
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has grounded its fleet of twin-rotor H-46 Sea Knight transport helicopters for the second time this month. The 340 helicopters were ordered not to fly after routine maintenance found fractures in the rotor-hub connecting links that hold the rotor blades to their hub, said a Pentagon statement released Wednesday. There are 259 helicopters in the fleet assigned to the Marine Corps and 81 to the Navy. ``Aircraft will be returned to flight status following electronic inspections of the connecting links,'' the statement said. ``Periodic follow-up inspections will be implemented to identify and remove from service any links which show evidence of developing cracks.'' The problem with the links is not related to trouble in the copter's aft transmission that led to a May 13 grounding order, the statement said. That transmission problem was discovered after an investigation of an H-46 accident earlier this month. Seventeen Marines were injured at the Marine Air-Ground training center at Twenty-Nine Palms, Calif., when their helicopter made a rough landing during an air-assault exercise. The transmission problem meant that the aircraft's rear rotor system could lose its drive power. The helicopters were to be returned to service after the May 13 grounding and repair.
DOC.HEAD: FEC Settles Case Against 1984 Reagan-Bush Campaign for $2,500
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Election Commission has accepted a $2,500 fine to settle a complaint charging the 1984 Reagan-Bush campaign with violating campaign finance laws, according to documents. The campaign agreed to pay the fine as part of a conciliation agreement that quells FEC allegations that the campaign failed to keep records to justify voter-registration and recruitment efforts paid for in part with public money. The FEC raised questions about the expenditures during its routine audit of the campaign and asked for records detailing the voter identification and mobilization efforts. The campaign committee balked at the request, saying many of the documents requested by the commission didn't exist. In March 1987, the commission referred the audit to its legal staff for further action. ``The overall result of the committee's failure to produce these documents has been that no final audit determination could be made regarding the appropriateness'' of the spending, the FEC's general counsel said in a memo included in the documents made public Wednesday. The Reagan-Bush campaign signed the conciliation agreement last month. The FEC released the records Wednesday in keeping with its practice of making previously confidential investigations public within 30 days after the case is closed.
DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Says Some Doonesbury Stamps Appearing
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service says ``Doonesbury'' stamps protesting the upcoming postage stamp price increase are starting to appear in the mail. Cartoonist Garry Trudeau included a sheet of mock stamps, featuring Zonker Harris of the Doonesbury comic strip, in Sunday papers May 20. The stamps carry the legend ``Mad as Heck'' and ``Ticked Off'' and show a value of minus-5, which the comic strip indicates is minus-5 cents. The stamps were intended to protest the coming increase in postal rates from 25 cents to 30 cents. Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt said an empty envelope from California bearing two of the stamps arrived at Postmaster Anthony Frank's office and that a few others have also been delivered. But Eberhardt said he did not know how many of the stamps were used. He said many envelopes with the stamps may have ended up in dead letter offices, although some may have gotten through because of the large volume of mail. Eberhardt said Frank finds Trudeau's work funny and takes the stamps in the manner in which they were intended _ as a protest. Eberhardt said letter-writers should have no problem if they put the cartoon stamps in addition to valid 25-cent stamps on their mail, but Doonesbury stamps alone are not legal postage.

DOC.HEAD: New York GOP Chooses Political Neophyte to Face Cuomo
LaserPhoto XRB1
DOC.TEXT: After searching nearly a year for a candidate, New York Republicans nominated Pierre Rinfret, a political unknown with deep pockets, to challenge Gov. Mario Cuomo. The 66-year-old millionaire economist said after his nomination at the state GOP convention Wednesday that he's no sacrificial lamb. ``I think we're going to take this guy,'' Rinfret told the convention. Cuomo is expected to announce a bid for for a third, four-year term within days. Considered a potential 1992 Democratic presidential contender, he is generally viewed as a big favorite for re-election, even by Republicans. In trying to find a candidate to challenge him, the state GOP had been turned down by one big-name Republican after another, including U.S. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato. It was only last week that party leaders settled on Rinfret. Rinfret, who has never run for public office, admitted he doesn't know much about such major issues as closing the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island and development in the 6 million-acre, public-private Adirondack Park. But, he promised, ``I will know more than Mario Cuomo come Election Day.'' Born in Montreal and raised in New York City, Rinfret heads an international economic, financial and political intelligence and trading firm. He put his net worth at about $14 million but wouldn't say how much of that he was willing to spend to try to unseat Cuomo. The Democrat has more than $7 million in his warchest. Rinfret was an unpaid economic counsel to Presidents Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon and chief economic spokesman for Nixon's 1972 presidential campaign. His unorthodox economic policies included calls for tax cuts during the Nixon years and a ban on credit cards to bring order to the economy. In his acceptance speech to the convention, he had delegates cheering as he advocated executing drug dealers to ``get the vermin off the streets.'' Cuomo has vetoed the death penalty ever year since he became governor in 1983. But Rinfret took the same position as Cuomo on abortion. ``I'm pro-choice, period,'' he said. A few delegates jeered. The convention opened Tuesday with the adoption of an abortion-rights platform plank, putting the New York GOP at odds with the national party and President Bush. The state's Conservative Party, which usually agrees on a candidate with the GOP, split with the Republicans over abortion. This weekend, the Conservatives plan to nominate 51-year-old New York University professor Herbert London. The split is expected to divide the anti-Cuomo vote and make the governor's re-election even more likely. Cuomo has presided over two consecutive years of $1 billion-plus tax increases, made necessary by budget deficits and economic problems in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Hold First Space Exhibit at a U.S. Museum
LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: In October 1957, a beeping sphere streaked across the sky, striking terror in the hearts of unsuspecting Americans. Sputnik I, the first artificial satellite, had been launched by the Russians. For the next decade, American schoolchildren were inundated with lessons on the space program, all intimating that if the United States lost the space race, and the Soviets landed first on the moon, the free world was doomed. Today those children can bring their children to see and touch the technology that once seemed so terrifying _ a full-size replica of Sputnik hangs in an exhibit opening Friday at Boston's Museum of Science. ``Soviet Space'' is the first major U.S. exhibit of Soviet space technology. It tears down yet another wall between East and West. The exhibit represents ``a new age in space,'' said Dana Wilson, the museum official who helped organize the show. ``The new space age is cooperative.'' Visitors through Sept. 23 can see working models of probes sent to Mars and Venus, a Soyuz space capsule, Soviet spacesuits, a returned moon probe, even Soviet space food. There's a fetching portrait of Laika, the first dog in space. Cosmonauts Valentin Lebedev and Aleksei Leonov, the first man to walk in space, will visit during the opening week, and artifacts and history once shrouded in secrecy will be available for comparison to the U.S. program. The exhibit brings to light Soviet failures along with successes. Included is a full-size model of the Phobos probe to Mars. An incorrect radio command caused Phobos I to lose contact with Earth in 1988 about six weeks after launch. Phobos 2 orbited Mars in 1989, gathering data for two months until it, too, was lost. To create the exhibit, Wilson and J. Kelly Beatty, who covers the Soviet space program for the magazine Sky and Telescope, made two trips to the Soviet Union. All doors were opened to them, Wilson said, including those of a rocket factory. ``The feeling now is cooperation,'' Wilson said. ``No one country can afford to have its own space program. Space belongs to all of us. You hear that over and over.'' Despite the alarm caused by Sputnik and by cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin's becoming the first human in space in 1961, the superpowers have long collaborated on space, including the Soyuz-Apollo mission of 1975. Today, Soviet and American scientists are cooperating on unmanned travel to Mars and hope some day to send a manned mission to the planet. Although Americans ``won'' the race to the moon, the Soviets have racked up a long list of firsts, including the first human in space, the first spacewalk and the first woman in space (Valentina Vladinirovna, 1963), Beatty noted. Most impressive is their work in conditioning cosmonauts to long space stints, something necessary for flights to Mars or other planets, Beatty said. On Dec. 21, 1988, Vladimir Titov and Musa Manarov returned to Earth exactly one year after they were launched into space. The mission provided scientists with extensive data on the effects of prolonged weightlessness.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,130.80, up 204.54 points or 0.62 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Layman Elected Presbyterian Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SalmonCampbell in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A 67-year-old layman with little experience in national church affairs gave assurances he's no renegade after his longshot election as leader of the 2.9 million-member Presbyterian church Price H. Gwynn III of Charlotte, N.C., was named moderator of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) on Wednesday at the faith's 202nd General Assembly. Gwynn is the son of a Presbyterian minister but hasn't held a national church position since 1961, when he was a commissioner to that year's General Assembly. He was elected on the second ballot on 322 votes, or nearly 53 percent, from the 605 commissioners who voted. He succeeds the Rev. Joan SalmonCampbell and will serve for a year. The last time the church elected a lay moderator was 1987. Gwynn claimed a darkhorse victory over five other candidates, all deeply involved in national and international church dealings. Afterward, he said: ``I'm not a renegade. But I am open to innovation.'' Gwynn roused the assembly with a speech critical of bureaucracy but hopeful that faltering membership and divisiveness can be solved through faith. The church has lost more than 120,000 members in the past three years and 30 percent of its membership since 1970. On two major issues the assembly probably will take up next week _ abortion and allowing homosexuals into the ministry _ Gwynn said he would support the church's current positions. The convention runs through June 6. He said he sees homosexuals as sinners deserving of God's love but not of ordination. Abortion, he said, must be a last resort arrived at only after much counseling and prayer. ``I'm for responsible choice,'' he said. A semiretired president of a Charlotte packing company, Gwynn is chairman of Presbyterian Hospital and Presbyterian Health Services Corp. He is the eighth Presbyterian moderator since church factions reunited in 1983, healing a Civil War-era split over slavery.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Higher, Index Edges Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed sharply higher against the Japanese yen Thursday, and the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange edged up. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 204.54 points, or 0.62 percent, closing at 33,130.80. The dollar closed at 151.75 yen, up 1.00 yen from Wednesday's 150.75-yen finish. The currency opened at 151.65 yen and ranged between 151.53 yen and 152.15 yen. Dealers said the dollar's rise followed its overnight gains on overseas markets. Market players bought the dollar amid uncertainty over Soviet politics, dealers said. Dealers cited the election of Boris Yeltsin, a frequent critic of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as Russian president. Dollar-buying interest by Japanese institutional investors remained strong, said a trader with a commercial bank in Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said the market is also watching the Washington summit between President Bush and Gorbachev. On the stock exchange, Hideyuki Matsuda, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., attributed the index's small losses in early trading to the yen's weakness against the dollar. ``However, because market players feel strongly that trading has been influenced too much by the currency market movements, they started buying issues that have little to do with foreign exchange, and that's when the index started recovering,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Parties Lose Overall, But Express Satisfaction Anyway
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of minor parties say they're satisfied with their isolated victories in local elections, even though unofficial results showed overwhelming support for Solidarity nationwide. Candidates from Solidarity-backed Citizen's Committees had a commanding lead in Sunday's elections for local councils, partial returns showed. Solidarity made an especially strong showing in large cities, where the Citizen's Committees are better organized than in the countryside. It won 59 of 60 seats in the Baltic port of Gdansk, where the union was founded a decade ago, 72 of 75 seats in the city of Krakow and 301 of 345 in Warsaw, according to unofficial returns published Wednesday in the Gazeta Wyborcza daily. Official results for the 52,000 individual races in more than 2,000 councils were delayed because of slow reporting from some outlying areas. Among the 80 other parties and groups that fielded candidates were the Social Democrats, the party formed in January as main successor to the now-dissolved Communist Party, various peasants parties and the anti-Communist Confederation for an Independent Poland. The Social Democrats appeared to have scored only marginal success. The party won two seats in the cities of Kielce and Czestochowa, six in Lodz and 15 in Warsaw. The small Confederation for an Independent Poland, a staunch anti-Communist group that has been politically active for a decade, won six seats in the city of Lublin, one in Katowice and three in Krakow. But Leszek Moczulski, the leader of the group, lost his race in Warsaw. Solidarity's landslide victory last June in races for all but one of the parliamentary seats it was allowed to contest broke the Communist Party's monopoly on power and led to the formation of the first non-communist government in the East bloc three months later. The aim of the latest elections was to establish independent local councils. During four decades of Communist rule, the local councils were dependent financially and politically on central authorities. Turnout in what amounted to the country's first fully free elections since World War II was only 42 percent, with a large number of parties as well as splits in Solidarity cited as reasons for ignoring the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Historical Society Ponders Man in Dress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hyphen is cq in New-York Historical Society
DOC.TEXT: The New-York Historical Society hopes to unravel a centuries-old art enigma: who WAS that guy in the blue dress? Since 1952, the society has proudly displayed a portrait said to be of Viscount Cornbury, royal governor of the colonies of New York and New Jersey from 1702 to 1708. Reflecting Lord Cornbury's reputed preference for women's clothing, the subject of the portrait is decked out in a jewel-adorned dress and a lace head covering. Patricia U. Bonomi, New York University history professor, used to accept historical depictions of Lord Cornbury as a cross-dresser. But recently, while writing Cornbury's biography, she concluded that the anonymous, undated portrait is not of him. She also believes his political opponents launched a 200-year-old legend by lying about his alleged proclivities. Philip Davenport-Hines, a fellow of the Royal Historical Society in England, pronounced Bonomi's findings inconclusive. He said he still thinks the portrait accurately depicts Cornbury. This summer, a graduate student from Columbia University will research the painting for the New-York Historical Society, said Annette Blaugrund, senior curator. The society also hopes to consult Bonomi. ``I think there were questions all the way down the line about the history of the painting,'' said Blaugrund. The historical society bought it from a British family named Pakington, which kept the work on its estate. It's not clear when it was painted. But Bonomi determined the work was first alleged in 1796 to depict Lord Cornbury, who died in 1723 after inheriting the higher title of Earl of Clarendon. ``I believe it was done as a serious portrait; it was not meant to be kinky,'' said Blaugrund. ``When you look at it, there's nothing very sexy about this picture.'' A label that was on the frame when it arrived at the society's museum identifies the subject as ``Lord Cornbury, half-witted son of Henry, Lord of Clarendon.'' The viscount was said to receive colonists ``dressed up in complete female court costume because truly, he represented the person of a female sovereign, his cousin, German Queen Anne,'' according to the label. The portrait and label remain prominently displayed in the museum in New York City. How do visitors react? ``Some of them stop and giggle. A lot of them just pass it by as being one of our large group of colonial paintings,'' said Blaugrund. After all, ``a lot of these paintings have both women and men seemingly with 5 o'clock shadows. That's a matter of painting technique, the undercoats coming through, what time does to a certain painting,'' she said. ``And there were some pretty hefty women in their day.'' Blaugrund said that in the case of this painting, ``It's pretty clearly a man. ... He has a man's facial features: a bigger nose, more jowly.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Conduct First Nuclear Test Since 1988
DOC.TEXT: China has detonated a nuclear device with at least twice the destructive force of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima, its first nuclear weapons test in nearly two years, Swedish monitors reported. Seismic signals indicated the explosion occurred at the Lop Nor test site in the far western province of Xinjiang, Nils-Olov Bergqvist of the Swedish Defense Research Establishment at the Hagfors Observatory said Wednesday. The last Chinese test was Sept. 29, 1988, when Beijing tested a low magnitude bomb of less than 10 kilotons, Bergqvist said by telephone. The seismic indicators detected Saturday registered 5.8 on the Richter scale and indicated a bomb with a yield of 40 to 50 kilotons, according to the government-run observatory. One kiloton has the explosive force of 1,000 tons of TNT. The bomb dropped on Hiroshima, Japan during World War II had an explosive force of 20 kilotons. The Chinese have conducted only four tests since 1984, apparently restrained by the high cost of building and exploding a nuclear bomb. China, which set off its first atmospheric explosion in 1964, is the only nuclear nation that makes no announcements about its tests. Little is known about its nuclear capabilities. It was only the second test this year of a nuclear weapon, following an explosion at the U.S. test site in Nevada on March 10. Last year, 27 tests were carried out around the world, including 11 by the United States and seven by the Soviet Union. China insists that its nuclear weapons are solely for self-defense and will never be used to strike first. Its nuclear arsenal is believed to include a half-dozen intercontinental ballistic missiles and more than 100 medium-range ballistic missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin vs. Gorbachev Program, Point by Point ^With PM-Yeltsin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, newly elected president of the Russian republic, earned his reputation as a radical reformer by criticizing the slow pace of reform under Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Following are some of the points on which they differ:

Gorbachev: believes the Soviet Union was right to choose ``the Socialist road'' 72 years ago and that perestroika should merely breathe new life into socialism. Yeltsin: backed private ownership in his campaign speech and never mentioned socialism, prompting Gorbachev to brand him anti-socialist.
Gorbachev: refuses to redraw any of the Soviet Union's internal boundaries for fear of unleashing chaos. Yeltsin: urges a commission to examine the internal boundaries of the Russian Federation, which contains some two dozen autonomous regions, with an eye to re-examining the boundaries and creating new regions.
Gorbachev: has ruled out whittling the Soviet army down to a small professional corps. Yeltsin: says the army must go professional.
Gorbachev: has overseen some reform in the KGB. Yeltsin: urges the KGB be merged with the Interior Ministry in one investigative body.
Gorbachev: has been reluctant to take out major foreign loans to try to cure the economy. Yeltsin: proposes taking out foreign loans and pulling in a percent of the government's foreign currency income to gather 20 billion rubles and direct them mainly toward buying scarce consumer products.
Gorbachev: backs government plan to raise prices and introduce a five-year plan to shift to a partial market economy. Yeltsin: says government plan is based on lowering the already-low Soviet standard of living, and the shift to a market economy can be faster and less painful by changing property laws, freeing enterprises and taking out foreign loans.
Gorbachev: imposed a partial economic blockade on Lithuania. Yeltsin: says Russia should strike deals with Lithuania and other regions that want to sign direct contracts with Lithuania without going through Moscow.
Gorbachev: backs the government plan of a maximum tax of 55 percent on profits. Yeltsin: says the maximum should be 35 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Abul Abbas Notorious For Achille Lauro Hijacking
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Abul Abbas, who claimed responsibility for the latest Palestinian guerrilla attack on the Israeli coastline, also masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro Italian cruise liner. The stocky Abul Abbas heads a faction called the Palestine Liberation Front that has launched guerrilla attacks for 14 years. His group is loyal to Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat. Abbas is a longtime supporter of the armed struggle to establish a Palestinian state. His faction is said to number no more than a few hundred. Abbas' guerrillas shot to death wheelchair-bound American Leon Klinghoffer, 69, during the 52-hour Achille Lauro hijack that began Oct. 7, 1985. They tossed his body overboard. Abul Abbas, the nom de guerre of Mohammed Abbas, said the guerrillas had intended to travel to Israel aboard the liner and launch terrorist attacks there, but the plan was scrapped when their weapons were discovered. After the passengers were released, the U.S. Justice Department issued an arrest warrant for Abbas, charging him with piracy, hostage-taking and conspiracy to commit both crimes. U.S. warplanes diverted an Egyptian plane carrying Abbas to Sicily, but Italian authorities allowed Abbas to leave for Yugoslavia before the warrant could be served. Abbas, now 42, was one of three Palestinians tried in absentia in Genoa in 1986 for the Achille Lauro crime. He was convicted and sentenced to life in prison, while the others received lesser prison terms. After he was convicted, the United States withdrew its arrest warrant, saying that since Abbas had been tried in an Italian court, a U.S. conviction was not important. In 1981, his group launched the first air infiltration attempts from south Lebanon into Israel. A Front guerrilla flew a motorized hang glider into northern Israel in a failed attempt to bomb an oil refinery. Later that year, another Front squad flew a hot-air balloon into Israel but Israelis said troops spotted the aircraft and shot it down. Since then, there have been recurrent clashes between the group's fighters and Israeli troops, both inside Israel's so-called ``security zone'' in south Lebanon and northern Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Letter Claims Responsibility for Oakland Earth First! Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Earth First! is cq
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper has received a letter from a writer identified only as ``the Lord's avenger'' claiming responsibility for a pipe-bomb explosion that injured two radical environmentalists in Oakland. The letter includes specific details about the construction and placement of the bomb that injured Earth First! leaders Judi Bari and Darryl Cherney, The Press Democrat reported today. The bomb blew up in Bari's car May 24. Police have accused Bari and Cherney of knowingly carrying the bomb. They have denied it. The writer also claimed responsibility for a bomb that went off outside a lumber mill in Cloverdale on May 9, the newspaper said. The letter contained accurate details matching never-disclosed information about the Cloverdale bomb, Larry Sheets, a bomb expert with the Sonoma County Sheriff's Department, told the newspaper. Nobody was injured in that blast. The newspaper turned the letter over to the FBI and said it had agreed to the bureau's request not to divulge previously unreleased details on the bombs. ``You've obviously got a piece of evidence that we're interested in,'' said John Rikes, leader of the FBI's team of investigators. ``We would like to have it analyzed, along with all the other evidence.'' Rikes cautioned, however, that details about the bombs ``could be taken straight out of `The Anarchist's Cookbook,''' which tells how to make explosives out of household items. The three-page, single-spaced typed message was mailed to a Press Democrat office in Ukiah. ``I built with these Hands the bomb that I placed in the car of Judi Bari,'' the letter begins. The author claims to have been driven by religious zeal and anger at Bari's opposition to anti-abortion protesters and to timber cutting. ``I am the Lord's avenger,'' the anonymous writer said. The letter was sprinkled with quotes from the Bible. The letter bore no return address and was postmarked Tuesday at a post office in Petaluma that handles all letters mailed in a 200-mile-long area north of San Francisco, a Postal Service spokesman said. Oakland police arrested Bari and Cherney for investigation of possession of explosives. But prosecutors on Tuesday postponed filing charges, saying they wanted to review the evidence. Cherney was freed on $100,000 bail. Bari remains hospitalized under police guard. Bari is a leader in the Redwood Summer, a planned series of demonstrations aimed at slowing the pace of logging.

DOC.HEAD: Terrified Residents Sleep in Streets of Jungle Town
LaserPhoto LIM1
DOC.TEXT: Frightened residents of this jungle town spent their second night in the streets after earthquake-prone Peru's deadliest temblor in two decades killed at least 115 people and injured hundreds more. Hundreds of people crowded into Rioja's central plaza, afraid to enter their damaged homes. Many lay inside tents or beneath umbrellas while others crowded around smoky cooking fires in the jungle twilight. More than 800 people were injured and at least 40 missing after the earthquake, which registered 6.2 on the Richter scale, rocked northern Peru late Tuesday night, civil defense authorities said. The damage was centered around Moyobamba, a farming center of 50,000 and the capital of San Martin department, 400 miles north of Lima, officials said. Rioja is 15 miles west of Moyobamba. Most of the confirmed deaths occurred in Soritor, a small town six miles south of Moyobamba that was nearly flattened by the quake. At least 23 people were killed in the town, including a family of 15 living in a two-story house that collapsed. The other dead were from nearby villages such as Rioja, a colonial town where eight people were killed. ``It was very ugly,'' said Flor de Maria Masaboya of Rioja, holding her year-old son in her arms. ``We were almost knocked off our feet by the shaking.'' ``All of us slept in the streets, but we were afraid to take out our beds because we might be trapped by another tremor,'' said Masaboya, pointing to a three-inch-wide crack in her adobe-walled home. Another resident of Rioja, Juan Soplin Ruiz, said ``all the homes are cracked and everyone fears the walls may collapse.'' Soplin said the town has received no emergency aid from the government. Some residents were going hungry rather than enter their damaged homes, he said. Many people had begun to return to their red-tile-roofed houses Wednesday morning, Soplin said. A strong aftershock at midday, however, sent them fleeing back into the streets, he said. According to the Peruvian Geophysical Institute, the aftershock, one of 45 during the day, registered 5.5 on the Richter scale. The main quake occurred at 9:33 p.m. Tuesday and lasted 45 seconds. It was centered in the jungle 75 miles northeast of Moyobamba, the Geophysical Institute said. Authorities declared a state of emergency in battered San Martin province, which had almost no communications with the rest of Peru. The area also had no water or electricity. Local police reports reaching Lima by radio Wednesday said several villages around Moyobamba were 60 to 80 percent destroyed. Gen. Jorge Ferreyro, Peru's civil defense chief, said the area had few doctors and authorities there were asking the government to send doctors, medicines and generators. Health Minister Paul Caro Gamarra said an air force plane left for Moyobamba Wednesday afternoon carrying a team of 10 doctors and emergency supplies. Two more planes filled with rescue supplies were to leave today. Health department workers have been on a nationwide strike for two months, but a union official in Lima said Wednesday that workers were helping with emergency plans. Patricia Vargas Llosa, the wife of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, visited the area on Wednesday, accompanied by former President Fernando Belaunde Terry. ``The people there are terrorized because the ground is still shaking,'' said Mrs. Vargas Llosa on her return to Lima. She said many people were being treated in tent hospitals for fractures and other injuries. Belaunde Terry said the worst damage appeared to be in Soritor and the nearby town of Porvenir. The temblor came two days before the 20th anniversary of a devastating earthquake that killed 70,000 people in the northern Andes Mountains. That quake, the most deadly natural disaster ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere, registered 7.7 on the Richter scale. An estimated 20,000 people in the city of Yungay were killed that day, buried in mud and ice that came crashing down from a nearby mountain. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of a magnitude of 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Improve Method for Finding Ages of Fossils
DOC.TEXT: Scientists said today they have made a breakthrough that will let them accurately estimate the ages of fossils up to 30,000 years old, compared with the old limit of about 9,000 years. The gain in the technique known as radiocarbon dating has already paid off by corroborating a theory on how variations in Earth's orbit affected ancient glaciers, and it could help research into climate and other topics, scientists said. The new work can correct the technique's tendency to underestimate ages by up to 3,500 years, researchers from Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades, N.Y., wrote in the British journal Nature. Scientists have long sought ways to make radiocarbon dating accurate for older objects, and the new work seems to have succeeded, said Harry Gove of the University of Rochester, co-inventor of one radiocarbon dating technique. Another expert, Paul Damon of the University of Arizona, said, ``My guess is it will have a significant effect on the (estimated) timing of past events'' in such areas as long-term variations in climate. But Eric Delson, an anthropology professor at Lehman College of the City University of New York, said he doubted the development would make much difference in studies of human history. It would simply adjust dates of many events in the same direction without affecting the more important issue of the order in which they occurred, he said. The 30,000-year time period covered by the study included the spread of humans to the New World and cave painting in Europe, he said. Radiocarbon dating is based on the fact that all living things absorb a type of carbon called carbon-14. At death, the absorption stops, and the amount trapped within the living thing begins to decay at a constant rate. Scientists can date an object by comparing the amount of carbon-14 in it today to the amount it had presumably absorbed from the atmosphere while it was alive. The problem is that concentrations of carbon-14 in the atmosphere vary unpredictably over time. Scientists have solved the problem for objects younger than about 9,000 years, using calculations based on ancient tree rings of known ages. But no reliable tree ring data is available for objects older than that. In the new work, the researchers dated coral samples with both carbon-14 dating and a second method, which depends on the constant radioactive transformation of uranium-234 into thorium-230. The second method, like the tree rings, provided an independent measure for calibrating the carbon-14 data. The work was done by researchers Edouard Bard, Bruno Hamelin, Richard Fairbanks and Alan Zindler. In a telephone interview, Zindler said the newfound accuracy cleared up an inconsistency in a climate theory. Scientists had theorized that subtle changes in Earth's orbit affected growth and melting of glaciers by changing the amount of solar energy reaching the surface, he said. But previous carbon-14 dating of ancient coral clashed with that theory by suggesting the last peak of glaciation was about 18,000 years ago, he said. The corrected date from the new study was 21,500 years ago, which ``fits with that theory very well,'' Zindler said.

DOC.HEAD: Six Gang Members Charged With Assault and Battery
DOC.TEXT: Six Japanese gang members who were seen on a television variety show severely beating a loan debtor have been charged with assault and battery, officials said today. The six are accused of beating a 41-year-old real estate agent at their office in Tokyo on Feb. 7 because he didn't pay back $397,000. The man received an injury that required a one-month treatment, police said. Part of the scene was broadcast on a variety program of the Tokyo Broadcasting System Inc. on March 20. The tape was shot by a production company under a contract with TBS. The assault occurred ``unexpectedly'' while the television reporters were closely covering the gang organization, according to Kanji Mizukami, chief of the Criminal Affairs Department in the Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office. ``There was no conspiracy or incitement on the side of the defendants and program producers,'' Mizukami told Japanese reporters, according to an official in the prosecutors office. After the incident, police launched an investigation and arrested the gang members. On May 16 they confiscated 29 original videotapes containing the beating scene. The six men charged Wednesday include Katsuhiko Miyata, 42, leader of Enomoto-gumi, an affiliate of the Kyokuto Sekiguchi-ikka, an organized crime group based in Tokyo. The gang is believed to have hundreds of members, police say.

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Mafia Bosses Arrested in Window Scam
With PM-The Chin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Four of New York's Mafia families used their combined muscle to assume near-total control over installation of windows in city housing projects, prosecutors alleged in announcing the indictment of 15 people. Among those charged were the reputed bosses of the Genovese and Lucchese crime families. ``Today's indictment closes the cash window on this lucrative enterprise,'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said at a news conference Wednesday. Since 1978, more than 75 percent of the window contracts awarded by the city's Housing Authority, totaling more than $191 million, went to companies controlled by the criminal enterprise, Thornburgh said. Payments of up to $2 per window for about 1 million windows were funneled to the Lucchese family, prosecutors said. The scheme made even higher profits by illegally using non-union labor and by employing intimidation and threats of labor unrest to keep legitimate contractors from making lower bids on the window contracts, prosecutors said. The scam cost taxpayers tens of millions of dollars, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Gregory O'Connell. Andrew Maloney, the U.S. attorney in Brooklyn, said the four normally rival crime families cooperated because of the profits to be made. ``Most if not all of the companies bidding on New York City Housing contracts were mob-owned or mob-controlled,'' Maloney said. The indictment charges the defendants with labor racketeering, labor payoffs, extortion, mail fraud and conspiracy. If convicted, the defendants could spend the rest of their lives in jail. Vincent ``the Chin'' Gigante, the 62-year-old alleged boss of the Genovese family, and Vittorio Amuso, reputed head of the Lucchese family, were among those indicted. Gigante was said have mediated disputes among the families. Gigante, who often walks the streets in his pajamas and mumbles to himself, denies he is a mobster and claims to be mentally ill. On Wednesday, he refused to get dressed when agents arrested him. He appeared in court in a hooded bathrobe. Also named were Benedetto Aloi, an alleged underboss in the Colombo crime family, and Peter Gotti, brother of reputed Gambino boss John Gotti. John Gotti, who was acquitted the last three times he was tried, was not named. Gigante's lawyer, Barry Slotnick, entered an innocent plea for him and said he was mentally incompetent and has severe heart problems. ``Any stress could cause sudden death,'' Slotnick said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles E. Rose said prosecutors believed Gigante's behavior is an act. U.S. Magistrate John L. Caden ordered Gigante held in a psychiatric ward pending a hearing. Four other defendants were ordered held without bail. Gotti and five others were free on $1 million bail. Three others were being sought.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Agree To Disarm in Accord With Gov't
DOC.TEXT: The Contra rebels have agreed to disarm by June 10 after reaching accords with the government that give them zones for settlement, their own police force and a voice in government. According to the agreement signed Wednesday, some Contra commanders could be sent to Nicaraguan embassies abroad for their safety, a government source said. Top Contra leader Israel Galeano said he was ``taking responsibility'' to complete the disarmament of his 13,000-member force by June 10, a deadline set in an earlier accord signed May 4 with the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Mrs. Chamorro, announcing the accord, said: ``What we want as Nicaraguans ... is peace and reconciliation.'' The president, who defeated the long-ruling leftist Sandinistas in elections Feb. 25 and took office two months later, said she was satisfied that the ``misunderstandings'' that led the U.S.-backed Contras to suspend disarmament for a time had been overcome. The latest accord, which spells out the aid to be given demobilized rebels, says former combatants will form a police force to ensure public order within regional development centers where they may settle. The government will ask the United Nations to expand the mandate of its peacekeeping forces to include instructing the Contras in the creation of a professional police force, which will be under the Interior Ministry. ``It's like the formation of a state within a state, and it's very dangerous, because Nicaragua could become another Lebanon,'' said Reynaldo Antonio Tefel, a Sandinista deputy in the National Assembly. ``It would be forming another army disguised as a police. In this manner, instead of distancing ourselves from war, we'd be getting closer to it,'' Tefel added. Galeano, who goes by Commander Franklin, sent a commission to Managua last week to talk about resuming the demobilization that began May 8. The commission last Friday accused the army, under Sandinista control, of slaughtering 14 demobilized fighters and 100 civilians. They halted the disarmament, saying they had no security. Investigators, including representatives of the Contras, government, and international organizations found no evidence of the killings. Galeano said there would be no more suspensions of the dismantling process. ``We are assuming the responsibility,'' he said. A top government source, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press the government offered top Contra commanders diplomatic posts abroad for their own security. ``Those who don't feel safe here can go to one of our missions and stay away for a year or so, and come back when they feel safe,'' the source said. The source said the posts offered would be as low-level diplomats. He said the only purpose would be to afford Contra commanders some protection and keep them out of Nicaragua. The Contras agreed to demobilize at least 100 rebels daily in each of the five security zones where the guerrillas are massed. But if the deadline is to be met, the number of rebels disarming would have to be at least 200 per day in each zone. So far, fewer than 2,000 rebels have turned in their weapons to United Nations and Organization of American States peace missions supervising the demobilization process. Galeano said the establishment of regional development centers, where demobilized combatants can settle, was important in resuming the disbanding. Both sides announced Tuesday an agreement establishing more than 20 regional development centers in rural areas. Under the accord, demobilized rebels, who are largely peasants, would be given priority in recovering their farmland confiscated by the Sandinistas. They also will be guaranteed representation in municipal governments of towns within the development centers as well as in government ministries that will have to deal with helping them rejoin civilian life.

DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Tries a New Attack Against Medfly Spraying
DOC.TEXT: Unable to banish malathion-spraying helicopters from its skies, Los Angeles wants to bar them from its airfields. In a unanimous vote, the 15-member City Council on Wednesday ordered an ordinance drafted barring the helicopters from Los Angeles airports. Choppers in past months have been spraying malathion to kill the crop-devouring Medfly. The ordinance should be ready by Tuesday, said Greg Nelson, spokesman for Councilman Joel Wachs. Courts thus far have rejected lawsuits from Southern California municipalities trying to block the state-ordered spraying. Opponents contend not enough is known about malathion's long-term health effects. State officials say the pesticide is safe. Officials sprayed Garden Grove on Wednesday, but it was to be the last city sprayed unless new flies are found. Officials are trying to supplant the spraying with the use of sterile flies, which disrupt the Medfly breeding cycle. Meanwhile, U.S. Agriculture Department officials in Washington on Wednesday declined a request from Florida officials to quarantine all California produce. More than 1,300 square miles in California already are quarantined. A total quarantine would have been disastrous for California's multibillion-dollar farm industry and a boon to Florida. Nearly two dozen of the flies, which can turn fruit to mush, have been spotted since April 16 in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev-Roh Meeting Seen as Prelude to Diplomatic Relations
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail Gorbachev's meeting with South Korea's president in San Francisco next week could eventually lead to diplomatic relations between the two nations and unification of Korea, a scholar says. ``I don't expect any particularly shattering development right away, but it's a first step of great symbolic importance,'' Lawrence Lau, Stanford University professor in Asian economics, said Wednesday. ``I wouldn't be surprised if diplomatic relations are established out of this.'' The Soviet leader, who begins four days of talks today with President Bush, will meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo on Monday during Gorbachev's 21-hour stay here, said U.S. officials speaking on condition of anonymity. Better relations between Moscow and Seoul, for more than 40 years a pro-U.S. foe of Soviet-backed North Korea, would help the Soviets by giving them a cheap, close source of consumer goods and a market for natural resources, Lau said. ``From the Soviet point of view, South Korea also is in a position to help North Korea,'' Lau said. ``Unification is pretty far up the road, but the North Koreans need help and their principal supporter _ the Soviet Union _ is no longer in a position to support them.'' Youn Ja Shin-Chey, a leader of the Korean Center in San Francisco and a Russian scholar, said the 100,000-strong Korean community in the Bay Area was surprised and thrilled by the meeting. ``There are maybe 60 million Koreans all over the world, and if you asked any Korean, `What is your one wish?' the answer would be, `The unification of North and South,''' Youn said. Korea was divided at the 38th parallel into Soviet and U.S. zones of occupation after World War II. North Korean forces invaded South Korea, prompting the Korean War from 1950 to 1953; the peninsula since has remained two independent nations. The nations have no formal diplomatic relations and the Soviets maintain strong ties with North Korea. In December, the Soviet Union and South Korea opened consular departments in their trade offices in each other's capitals. But officials working there do not have normal diplomatic privileges.

DOC.HEAD: Less Glamorous Side to Gorbachev Visit
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: There's the glamorous side to Mikhail Gorbachev's visit, and then there's the not-so-glamorous side: the ropes, barrels, flatbed trucks, directional signs and portable toilets. Just ask the advance team preparing for the six-hour visit to the Twin Cities area Sunday by the Soviet president and his wife, Raisa. ``There are very few portable toilets left in town,'' advance team member Karen Gruenberg said Wednesday. ``We were trying to track down 85 and we finally found them.'' While politicians, business leaders and others prepare for meetings and handshakes, the advance team prepares for those who will watch the meetings and handshakes: the public and news media. The 1,000 barrels to be used as barricades are a ``hot commodity'' because so many already are in use at construction sites and elsewhere, said Julie Drake, another advance team member. Then there's the rope _ 31,000 feet of it. Consultations with the Secret Service were required to decide what kind to buy. ``They said they would prefer bright yellow so it can be easily seen and nylon for strength and (so) it won't stretch,'' Drake said. Oh yes, and the rope should be a half-inch thick, she said. Then there was the flag snag. Ever try to get a 4-by-6-foot Soviet flag on short notice? ``We needed only about eight and yesterday there were 11 left around the country you could buy,'' Gruenberg said. ``They were all gone this morning.'' Among other items needed: About 120 media platforms, 100 two-way radios, 2,000 welcome and directional signs in Russian and English, 4,000 box lunches for media and staff people at the Metrodome media center, and 16 flatbed trucks for reporters and photographers.

DOC.HEAD: Four Children Found Dead In Their Home
DOC.TEXT: Four children were found fatally stabbed in their beds and their mother was in critical condition with a stab wound that may have been self-inflicted, police said. The children, all under 12, had been stabbed in the neck, Police Chief Carl Verrastro said, as was their mother, 36-year-old Maria Isabella Amaya, a native of El Salvador. She had been under psychiatric care for about eight months, Verrastro said. The youngsters' father, Halley William Amaya, 33, came to a neighbor Wednesday and asked her to call a doctor to the home, said the neighbor, Andrea Orphanos. ```She killed the little ones and tried to kill herself,''' Orphanos quoted Amaya as telling her. Verrastro said an arrest was expected today. He stressed that other people were not at risk. ``I don't want the community's imagination to run wild that a Jack the Ripper is at large,'' he said. Police found the bodies of the children _ Halley Jr., 11, Jessica, 8, Christopher, 6, and Edward, 3{ _ on beds throughout the house. They had been dead ``for some time,'' said Verrastro. Mrs. Amaya was found alive on another bed and rushed to the hospital. The Amayas and their oldest child came eight years ago from El Salvador to the United States, where the other three children were born, Verrastro said. Orphanos said they were ``very nice people, hard-working people.'' Port Chester, a village of about 25,000 people, is north of New York City near the Connecticut border.

DOC.HEAD: Beijing Executes 20 People, Including Pro-Democracy Protester
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese government has executed 20 people, including a man convicted of destroying an Air Force jeep during last June's pro-democracy uprising, Chinese newspapers reported. Sunday's edition of the official Sichuan Daily, seen in Beijing today, said courts in the capital of Sichuan province last week sentenced nine people to die, including convicted arsonist Yu Yongchuan. All were immediately executed. The newspaper said Yu led others in overturning a jeep and setting it on fire during rioting that broke out in the capital, Chengdu, on June 5, the day after the bloody military suppression of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing. The official press has reported the executions of at least 20 participants in anti-government disturbances last June, although the number of actual executions is believed to be substantially higher. Yu is the first reported case since a Beijing court last December sentenced two men to die for killing a policeman on June 4. The official Beijing Daily also reported today that a local court ordered the execution of 11 criminals the day before. The court cited the need to ensure social stability for the Asian Games to be staged in Beijing in September. The condemned, convicted of murder, robbery, rape and ``hooliganism,'' were immediately taken to an execution grounds and shot to death, the daily said. Beijing Municipal Intermediate People's Court chief Ji Shuhan, in handing down the verdict, said the city must ``severely attack criminal elements'' to ensure the security of the Asian Games and October 1 National Day, the Beijing Daily said. The Sichuan and Beijing trials followed another mass execution in Zhengzhou, central China, on Saturday, when 11 train robbers were put to death. China does not release capital punishment figures, and many executions go unreported in the official press. However, recently the press has carried numerous reports of death sentences and condemned men have been paraded before mass rallies to emphasize the government's tough stance toward crime. A Shanghai court last week sentenced 10 people to die on various murder and robbery charges. In Canton last month, 10 people were executed for selling tainted liquor and 11 others were put to death for robbery and murder.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0495 to remove garble from command field.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against key European currencies this morning after gaining strongly against the Japanese yen in Tokyo trading. Gold prices were lower. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 151.75 yen, a gain of 1.00 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 152.05 yen. The dollar, which had risen on overseas markets overnight, rose further in Tokyo as institutional investors and investment trust companies bought the U.S. currency against the yen for technical adjustments, said Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank in Tokyo. ``But the dollar did not rise as high as 152.50 yen because manufacturers started selling it just above the 152-yen line, while life insurance companies also sold the dollar at that level for profit-taking,'' he said. The dollar was also held back by concerns over the release of the U.S. jobless rate for May, scheduled for Friday in Washington, Tabata said. Approximately $12 billion changed hands in spot trading, unchanged from Wednesday. Other dollar rates compared with late Wednesday: _1.6905 West German marks, up from 1.6810 _1.4235 Swiss francs, up from 1.4210 _5.7000 French francs, up from 5.6715 _1.8945 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880 _1,243.00 Italian lire, up from 1,237.25 _1.1760 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1778 The British pound traded in London at $1.6835 compared to $1.6930 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $363.75 an ounce today, from $366.65 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold opened at a bid price was $363.85, down from $366.25 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.22 an ounce today, to close at $365.25. Silver in London was quoted at a bid price of $5.07 a troy ounce, down from Wednesday's $5.15.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Marcos Claims State Dept. Offered Deal
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos says the State Department offered to return her to the Philippines for trial if she agreed to campaign for the renewal of U.S. military base leases, according to a report today. Mrs. Marcos, on trial for allegedly looting the Philippine treasury, said in an interview with the New York Post that U.S. officials made the suggestion in a two-day visit over the weekend. ``They suggested a graceful way out of my situation was if the Philippine congress could unanimously demand my return so that I may stand trial back home,'' Mrs. Marcos told the Post. A State Department official denied the agency had contacted Mrs. Marcos or had met with her last weekend, the Post said. The newspaper did not name the official. ``We're engaged in discussions with the Philippine government about the future security relationship. ... Mrs. Marcos is not a part of the Philippine government,'' the official said. American and Philippine negotiators are preparing to resume talks on whether to renew leases on Clark Air Base, Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. The leases expire in September 1991. Opposition to the bases is growing because many Philippine citizens view them as an infringement on national sovereignty. In the copyrighted article by columnist Cindy Adams, Mrs. Marcos said, ``The American government which is prosecuting me is now asking me for my help. ... ``The conditions being that, when I step from the plane, somebody would ask, `Mrs. Marcos, are you pro-bases?' and I would say `Yes' and immediately start campaigning,'' she said. ``Apparently they have no more aces. Their only ace is me.''

DOC.HEAD: Raisa's Tour Sparks Excitement Along Fisherman's Wharf
DOC.TEXT: While Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev samples lamb at a business luncheon, his wife, Raisa, will be treated to the tasty treasures of Fisherman's Wharf: sourdough bread and walkaway cocktails of shrimp, lobster and crab. Mrs. Gorbachev will take a whirlwind tour of the city from 3 p.m. to 4 p.m. on Monday after she and her husband return from Stanford University and he goes on to meet with executives of 150 West Coast companies. Fishermen and merchants along Fisherman's Wharf are planning a colorful and musical welcome for Mrs. Gorbachev. ``We'll have the most marvelous flowers for her and a sample of our Epicurean delights _ prawns, shrimp, crab, lobster, Petrale sole,'' said an enthusiastic Al Baccari, executive director of the Fisherman's Wharf Association. Baccari plans to have a band play for Mrs. Gorbachev and boats along the wharf hoist the Soviet flags. She'll be offered a platter of food to nibble on during her tour and a coloring book with crayons to take home, along with a framed etching of the wharf. ``It's all just to say welcome, even for a few minutes,'' said Baccari. ``I remember with affection when another Russian leader (Nikita S. Khrushchev) visited us and he captured theimagination of the town. Things like this add to the international flavor of San Francisco, the birthplace of the United Nations, and make it a joyous city.'' The shopkeepers are not offended at all by Gorbachev skipping the tour and attending to business. ``Raisa would have more fun ... She could go shopping,'' said Ian Bader of Ripley's Magic Shop along the wharf. It's not likely Mrs. Gorbachev will have time for shopping. Among the sights listed on an itinerary released Wednesday are Golden Gate Park, Civic Center, Davies Symphony Hall, the Bank of America Building and Fisherman's Wharf, with possible stops at the M.H. de Young Museum and the Opera House. Mrs. Gorbachev is expected to be escorted on her tour by Tatyana Kamenev, wife of the Soviet consul general, and perhaps Sherry Agnos, wife of Mayor Art Agnos, said Charlotte Mailliard Swig, San Francisco's chief of protocol. ``They won't have much time, but I think she'll like it and come back,'' Swig said. ``I just hope they don't stop in Civic Plaza.'' Civic Plaza, across from City Hall, has become a campground for the homeless in recent years. After returning to the consul general's residence, Mrs. Gorbachev will meet with Friends of Raisa Gorbachev, including women who have met her on trips to the Soviet Union to promote peace. ``It's people who really respect her and want to show her some hospitality,'' said Swig, ``and think of her as being a really strong intellectual, a caring, strong woman.'' Patricia Montandon, founder of Children as the Peacemakers, has traveled extensively in the Soviet Union on behalf of world peace and has met Mrs. Gorbachev several times. ``I will see her here but I think it's very important for other people in San Francisco to meet her,'' Montandon said. ``She is very much interested in causes for women and children. She has a mind of her own. She's a doctor of philosophy and taught at the university in Moscow. She's not just a supporter of her husband, she's in partnership with him.'' The Gorbachevs are scheduled to leave at 5:30 p.m. for a rush-hour drive across the Golden Gate Bridge to Vista Point before returning to San Francisco International Airport for their departure at 6:30 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: China to Send High-Ranking Official to Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: China will send an assistant foreign minister to Hanoi next month for the highest-level official visit to Vietnam since the two countries fought a brief war in 1979, the Foreign Ministry said today. Xu Dunxin, who also heads the ministry's Department of Asian Affairs, will travel to Bangkok in early June for consultations with Thai leaders on the Cambodia war, and then go on to Hanoi, said ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua. Xu will exchange views on Cambodia with Vietnamese officials, Li said. Xu's trip to Bangkok and Hanoi will coincide with talks in Tokyo among the warring parties of Cambodia on a possible cease-fire. China officially supported the Hanoi government during the Vietnam War, but relations between the two socialist countries turned hostile when Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and drove the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge from power. China launched a short border war against Vietnam in early 1979 to ``punish'' Hanoi. Since then China has been the main military supporter of the Khmer Rouge and other resistance forces battling the Vietnamese-backed Hun Sen government in Cambodia. In recent years, Vietnam has sought better relations with China and has sent several high-level delegations to Beijing. Vietnamese First Deputy Foreign Minister Dinh Nho Liem visited Beijing in early May for talks on Cambodia. The Beijing government, however, insists that normalization of relations can only take place after a political settlement is reached in Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Fliers Offering $10,000 for Deaths of Desegregation Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Willye is cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A flier has been distributed offering a reward for the slayings of seven black leaders involved in a local school desegregation struggle. Police refused to give details of the case, including where the fliers had appeared. They said security measures were being taken to protect those threatened. Listed on the fliers were School Board members Wendell Holmes and Samuel Nesbitt; National Association for the Advance of Colored People education chairman Fred Matthews; Jacksonville Urban League President Ronnie Ferguson; the Rev. Rudolph McKissick; Assistant Superintendent Alvin White and Willye Dennis, president of the local chapter of the NAACP. In December, a package bomb similiar to those that killed a federal appeals court judge and a Savannah attorney was intercepted at Mrs. Dennis' office. The fliers declare the seven ``wanted dead or alive for self-serving crimes, murdering our kids future! Shoot on sight. $10,000 price guarantee.'' School security officials, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office and the FBI are investigating the messages, said schools Superintendent Larry Zenke. School officials and black leaders are struggling to come up with a school desegregation plan that complies with a federal court order. The seven are key players in the negotiations. Nesbitt said he first heard of the fliers early Monday when police showed up at his home with one. Ferguson said he had seen a copy and had talked to police about his safety. ``We have been cautious ever since the bomb scare, and we're going to continue to be cautious,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dramatic Fetal Surgery Corrects Birth Defect in the Womb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to CORRECT spelling of Schultz sted Shultz. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The second...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons today said they have found a way to forestall a usually fatal birth defect by opening up the mother, operating on the fetus and putting it back in the womb to develop normally. Experts say the operation, which involves rearranging the fetus's organs, is the most extensive fetal operation ever successfully performed. However, it is also controversial because of the risks to both the mother and fetus. The first successful operation was performed on Blake Schultz, now 9 months old, the son of Elizabeth and Richard Schultz of Waterloo, Mich. ``I'm just glad he's healthy. And hopefully it will help other people too,'' Ms. Schultz said. The surgery was pioneered at the University of California, San Francisco, to correct fetal diaphragmatic hernia, a defect that occurs in about one of every 2,000 babies. About three-quarters of all babies with the defect die. During development, a hole in the fetus's diaphragm fails to grow shut, and the stomach, intestines and other organs squeeze into the chest cavity. As a result, the lungs fail to develop, and the baby is born unable to breath. ``This problem is immensely frustrating for pediatric surgeons, because the babies are otherwise perfectly nice, but they die,'' said Dr. Michael R. Harrison, who developed the surgery. ``It seemed as though this was one of those situations in medicine where fixing it earlier would be the only way to have an impact.'' Harrison has performed the highly experimental surgery eight times. The first six fetuses died, but the last two went on to become healthy children, Blake Schultz and a girl. A report on the first success was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. During the surgery, doctors cut into Ms. Schultz's uterus and pulled the fetus's arm through the hole. Then they put the misplaced stomach, intestines and other organs back where they belonged and covered the hole in the diaphragm with a Gore-Tex patch. Finally they tucked the fetus's arm back into the womb and closed up the incision. Ms. Schultz carried the fetus for seven more weeks before giving birth. The baby was premature and had to spend a month on a respirator but is now healthy. The second successful operation was performed March 3 on Devona Anderson, of Tacoma, Wash., now 6 weeks old. She did better and was able to breathe on her own on her second day of life. Her father, Stephen Anderson, said he and his wife, Lora, were devastated when they learned the fetus had only a 25 percent chance of survival if born with the defect. ``The more we thought, the more we thought, `Let's do it,''' he said. The operation takes just under an hour and costs about $16,000. At the University of Manitoba, Dr. Frank Manning said a major difficulty is separating those fetuses that will survive without surgery from those that are doomed, since the operation itself is highly dangerous to the fetus. He also noted that women who undergo the surgery risk a ruptured uterus if they get pregnant again. ``I don't want to pour on cold water, because this is an innovative thing he has done,'' said Manning. ``But I can't give you unbridled enthusiasm and tell you this will be the panacea for diaphragmatic hernia.'' ``The disease he is attacking is a very big problem in pediatrics,'' said Dr. Joseph P. Vacanti of Children's Hospital in Boston. ``It is an important approach that ought to continue to be investigated.'' Doctors have experimented for the past decade with treating and repairing defective fetuses before birth. Most such operations have been relatively minor, however. Among the most common is opening up urinary blockages. Harrison said he worked on the latest procedure for about 12 years. His team tested it on 1,000 fetal lambs and 200 fetal monkeys and reviewed 200 fetuses in which the disorder was not treated before birth.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Northwest; Cool Temperatures in East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of Casper.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the Northwest early today, and early-morning temperatures were unseasonably cool in the East. Strong winds buffeted the Rockies from Las Vegas to Casper, Wyo. Temperatures dipped into the 40s across the East, but sunshine was expected to warm the region by 30 degrees later in the day. Pittsburgh was 40 degrees and Portland, Maine, recorded 39 at 5 a.m. Freeze warnings were posted overnight for much of Michigan and parts of West Virginia and western Pennsylvania. Up to 10 inches of snow were possible above the 7,000-foot elevation of the Sierra Nevada. Scattered showers were expected today in the northern Plains, and scattered thunderstorms in the southern Plains and lower Mississippi Delta. The high for the nation Wednesday was 102 degrees at Lajitas and Presidio, Texas.
