DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Bush Strive To Set Post-Cold War Agenda
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new graf after pvs 4th graf bgng, Baker, interviewed, on difficulty of Lithuania, German issues; breaks a0514 into 2 takes; will be led with Gorbachev's arrival at White House at 10 a.m. EDT; first meeting set for 10:30.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is welcoming Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the White House today for summit talks marked by hopes for a strategic arms control agreement but sharp differences over the shape of a united Germany in the post-Cold War era. As Soviet and American flags waved side-by-side along Pennsylvania Avenue, Bush and the Soviet president headed for their first negotiating session in four days of summitry at the White House and Camp David, Md. A few hours before ritual welcoming ceremonies on the White House South Lawn, Secretary of State James A. Baker III held out the prospect of ``significant and concrete progress'' on arms control at the summit, the first since Bush and Gorbachev met six months ago at Malta. Baker, interviewed on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' saw encouraging signs of a ``dialogue'' on Lithuanian independence, an issue that has left plans for a Soviet-American trade agreement in limbo. But Baker cautioned that neither Lithuania nor the German issue is likely to be resolved at the summit. On his arrival from Canada late Wednesday, Gorbachev declared that the summit ``stands out in its importance, first of all, for the promise it holds as the first major step to reduce strategic nuclear arms.'' White House chief of staff John Sununu, like Baker, sought to discourage speculation of major breakthroughs at the summit. ``I don't think it ought to be measured in terms of what gets signed and what doesn't get signed, but how it develops the relationship,'' Sununu said on NBC's ``Today'' show. Treaties and lesser agreements covering arms control, chemical weapons, air travel and other subjects were in various stages of readiness. But the list of differences ran to conventional weapons cutbacks, trade, human rights, Gorbachev's handling of the secessionist republic of Lithuania - and Germany. Whatever the diplomatic prospects, Washington was eagerly awaiting its springtime summit. Oversized American and Soviet flags hung side by side over the entrance to the federal office building next door to the White House - Old Glory on the left and the Hammer and Sickle on the right. In the elegance of the White House, waiters were setting out the china for the state dinner on the first evening's schedule. Across the street at Lafayette Square, authorities doled out space to competing protest groups, and assigned undercover officers to keep an eye on things. For his part, Gorbachev moved about town in a motorcade that stretched for more than 50 vehicles. Even as Gorbachev arrived came a fresh reminder of his difficulty at home. Newly elected Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin said he would press for swift sovereignty for his republic - the largest and most influential one in the Soviet Union.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: Soviet Union.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet leader made no mention of Germany when he arrived at Andrews Air Force Base, although he said earlier in the day in Canada the United States and its allies were trying to `` dictate'' the terms of the merger between East Germany and West Germany. ``This will not suit us,'' he said. Baker referred to Germany when he welcomed the Soviet leader to America. The challenge of the summit, he said, was to ``leave behind not only the Cold War but also the conflicts that preceded it. To do that we must see a Germany unified and Europe reconciled.'' Soviet commentator Georgi Arbatov, also interviewed on NBC-TV, said today that NATO represents ``an anti-Soviet military bloc'' that cannot last. ``Europe needs a totally new organization,'' he said. ``You cannot bring Cold War structures into a post-Cold War world.'' Soviet Foreign Ministry adviser Vitaly Churkin said on ABC-TV that ``we're flexible'' on the German issue and that U.S. officials were showing signs of ``creative movement.'' The two leaders are expected to sign a declaration of basic agreements on cuts in long range nuclear weapons, with a long-sought treaty hopefully to follow by the end of the year. The goal is to reduce arsenals of nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 to 35 percent. A formal signing ceremony was scheduled for Friday. Agreements ranging from chemical weapons to air travel were ready for signatures, as well. Talks on proposed cuts in troops and conventional weapons were on the agenda, as well, but progress there seemed to hinge on the outcome of what shaped up as the thorniest issue of the summit. The White House said Bush was sympathetic to Soviet concerns about the military might of a reunified Germany, and added it would pursue an answer that was ``politically acceptable and reasonable.'' Privately, U.S. officials said Bush would cut no deal at the summit to limit German troops, but he is prepared to discuss a formula that might eventually scale down those forces along with the Red Army. Bush has insisted that a unified Germany remain within the NATO alliance. Gorbachev has proposed that it be a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, or that both military alliances be disbanded. West Germany has been in NATO. East Germany has long been in the Soviet-sponsored Warsaw Pact, but its alignment is uncertain following the fall of the Communist government there last year. Before leaving Canada for Washington, Gorbachev challenged Bush to offer another solution to the German question. ``It seems that it is just like an old record that seems to be playing the same note again and again. ... I would like us to find a new melody,'' the Soviet leader said.

DOC.HEAD: Ads Welcome Gorbachev, Bid Him Good Buy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to change reference to `news pages' sted of `editorial pages.'
DOC.TEXT: Welcome, visitor from the land of Glasnost, to the land of Huckster. Behold, Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, free enterprise at work. While the news pages of the nation's newspapers are filled with accounts of your visit, it is on the advertising pages where brotherly feelings hold sway. Who can resist the message of warmth and good fellowship in the full-page advertisement dominated by a steaming cup of coffee and this message across the top: ``We hope this is the only thing that comes between Mikhail Gorbachev and George Bush this week.'' If you are wise in the ways of advertising, Mikhail Sergeyevich, you will search for the hook. There it is, at the bottom, discreetly. ``Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation,'' it says. The firm, Mr. President, makes coffee. We turn the pages to see two drink glasses, each half full, with the American Stars and Stripes and the Soviet Hammer and Sickle decorating the stirrers. ``Sometimes the best relationships start on the rocks,'' is the message. And below, in smaller print, it continues: ``Tomorrow the superpowers begin yet another historic summit. Stolichnaya _ the import that broke the ice in 1972 _ hopes their discussions go as smoothly as their toasts.'' There are two metaphors at play here, and you have to know the idiom to get the point. On the rocks is a mariner's term for running his ship aground. In this case it refers to past U.S.-Soviet difficulties. On the rocks has a second connotation. It refers to straight booze over ice. The advertisement, placed by Stolichnaya, the Russian vodka, combines the two ideas. That's not all that's combined. Stolichnaya is exported to this country by PepsiCo which is allowed, in turn, to sell Pepsi Cola in the Soviet Union. Let us move on to a less subtle advertising presentation, also a full page. In three rows of three each, it shows battleships, helicopters, tanks, fighter planes, submarines, missiles, trucks with missiles and soldiers with guns at the ready. Each set of the figures is covered with a big red X _ as if to indicate the summit had done away with their threats. The ninth panel is left unscathed, as if it were all that remains after the tools of war had been done away with. It shows nine bottles of Smirnoff Vodka, and this legend across the bottom: ``Now that's what we call a successful summit.'' In smaller type, the ad mentions that ``first, the Russians welcomed Smirnoff back in the USSR after 73 years. Next, who knows? With a start like that, anything is possible.'' In case the news media missed their ad, Stolichnaya followed with a personally delivered statement to say that five cases of their premium product were delivered to the White House for Friday's state dinner. There was also something about a drink called the ``Glasnost Mary'' being served, using guess-whose vodka. Just because these samplings are about beverages, Mr. President, doesn't mean that their makers are the only ones to do, shall we say, business as usual at this propitious time. The Smith Corona Corporation, maker of office machines, boasts that your delegation, Mr. President, will use Smith Corona's personal word processor and electronic portable typewriter products this summit week. With Cyrillic alphabet, yet. The firm pointed out that it is selling its products through Vneshtorgizdat. In case you want to get one at home.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Says Last Man Florida Executed Was Tortured by Electric Chair
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for a condemned murderer argue in an appeal that the last man Florida sent to the electric chair was tortured in a botched execution that the state is not investigating properly. ``An inmate about to be executed in Florida will likely be burned and tortured during that execution, will be conscious during the event, and will suffer pain,'' says the appeal. Color photographs of the bodies of 10 executed men accompanied the motion filed Wednesday by state-paid attorneys for a prisoner condemned to die July 10. Fire, smoke and sparks flew from the head of the last man executed in Florida, on May 4. ``Jessie Joseph Tafero was burned alive in Florida's electric chair,'' the appeal said. ``There is no assurance that William Michael Squires will also not be burned alive.'' Tafero's execution for the fatal shootings of two law enforcement officers 14 years earlier shows that executing Squires would be a violation of the constitutional guarantee against cruel and unusual punishment, the motion argues. Squires, 48, is condemned for the September 1980 fatal shooting of service station attendant Jesse Albritton in Hillsborough County. He is under his first warrant, and no death row inmate has been executed on a first warrant since since the state reinstituted capital punishment in 1979. Reporters and prison officials who witnessed Tafero's execution said he appeared to breathe and move after the first and second jolts. Gov. Bob Martinez ordered an investigation. Four days later, the state Department of Corrections concluded Tafero's death was instant but that the mistaken replacement of a natural sponge with a synthetic sponge had caused the burns on his head. Squires' attorneys blasted the corrections department for testing the flammability of the sponge used in Tafero's execution by using a household toaster. ``Scientific testing is not done with a toaster,'' the attorneys wrote. The attorneys, from the state agency that represents poor death row inmates, said corrections officials are not competent to carry out executions without unneccessary pain. Spokesmen for Martinez and Corrections Secretary Richard Dugger said Wednesday that the state stood by its investigation. In a statement, Dugger called the allegations absurd, frivolous and ``designed to distort Eighth Amendment issues with a smokescreen of technical and procedural fault-finding.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Promises to Patch Up Differences With Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Yeltsin promising to resolve differences with Gorbachev, lawmakers concerned about conflict. No pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin said today he expected to meet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev soon and assured concerned lawmakers that the two political rivals would ``resolve most issues'' between them. Yeltsin, who was elected Tuesday to the powerful post despite the opposition of Gorbachev, said he would try to mend fences with Gorbachev but outlined a far more radical program than that of the Soviet president. As president of Russia, the largest and most powerful of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, Yeltsin could pose a major challenge to Gorbachev and his economic reforms. Yeltsin promised to seek a ``businesslike'' relationship with Gorbachev, despite their personal differences. ``True, we have our differences,'' he said. ``I renounce all these personal aspects fully and completely. I leave that behind.'' Deputies speaking today at the Russian Congress ``expressed concern over the exchange of statements about each other'' by Yeltsin and Gorbachev, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Yeltsin answered that after Gorbachev returns June 4 from the summit with President Bush in Washington, ``I think we'll have an appropriate conversation, and we'll resolve most issues without damaging the sovereignty and aims of Russia,'' Tass said. Gorbachev told reporters in Ottawa on Tuesday he was ``somewhat concerned'' about Yeltsin's victory and feared that if Yeltsin ``is playing a political game, then we may be in for a difficult time.'' There have been no reports that he sent congratulations to Yeltsin on his election. Yeltsin's election as Russian president capped a remarkable political comeback. Gorbachev brought him to Moscow to head the city's Communist Party, but sacked him in 1987 for criticizing the slow pace of reform. He returned to power through a popular election to the Russian Congress, and survived _ perhaps even benefited from, a last-minute attack by Gorbachev, who accused him of working toward the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Despite his conciliatory statements, Yeltsin at times seemed to be baiting Gorbachev. Asked by reporters whether he thought leaders should hold top posts in both the Communist Party and government, Yeltsin said: ``I am against combining any post in one person. And I am talking not just about the chairmanship of the party at the Russian level, at the regional level, or at the local level.'' It was an oblique call for Gorbachev _ Soviet president and Soviet Communist Party general secretary _ to give up one post. Yeltsin on Wednesday urged making the Soviet Union a federation of strong states that can overrule Gorbachev's central government on most matters. Outlining his plans at a news conference in the Grand Kremlin Palace, the radical populist reformer said he would seek sovereignty for Russia within his first 100 days in office. He also demanded that Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov resign for what he called a failure to deal decisively with the country's economic turmoil, and said he would open treaty talks immediately with the secessionist Baltic republics. ``We must turn this pyramid on its head,'' Yeltsin said. Yeltsin attacked the reform program that Ryzhkov presented one week ago, touching off panic buying by outlining plans to double food prices Jan. 1 and triple the price of bread on July 1. The run on provisions prompted Moscow officials to bar non-residents from stores in the capital. ``Regrettably, the ... (national) leadership and government at this point is losing the trust of the nation,'' he said. ``I do think we should demand its resignation.'' Yeltsin outlined a far more radical program than that of Gorbachev. The price increases Ryzhkov seeks would be part of a transition to a partial market economy in the next five years. Yeltsin wants faster steps toward a market economy, but opposes sharp price increases, an apparent contradiction. In addition, under Yeltsin's plan, Russia and the other 14 Soviet republics would remain within a reconstituted Soviet Union but have far more power than the central government in most matters, excluding defense and national security. ``We must withstand the diktat of the center,'' Yeltsin said. ``If we withstand 100 days, if we are not pulled down ... Russia will be independent in every respect. It will make its own decisions. Russian laws must take priority over the union (national) laws. ``The Russian constitution must precede the union constitution.'' Any declaration of Russian sovereignty must be approved by the Russian Congress, of which Yeltsin is chairman, or president. The Russian Congress is a newly created body that is the highest authority in the Russian republic. As its leader, Yeltsin will play a major role in shaping his own powers and duties.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Of Thousands Flock To Memorial For Moslem Clergyman
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants today fired automatic weapons in the air and swore to die for an independent Kashmir as 300,000 mourners paid tribute to Kashmir's top Islamic leader, assassinated last week. The conservative Hindu newspaper said ``elements of three divisions'' have been transferred from India's east to the troubled states of Punjab and Jammu-Kashmir. The report, quoting senior officials, was the first mention in the Indian press of a believed troop build-up on India's border with Pakistan. The Associated Press earlier reported that three divisions, amounting to 30,000 men, were moved into the region from India's northeastern border areas. The newspaper report said officials declined to specify how many troops have been moved into Jammu-Kashmir, the site of a bloody campaign for independence from mostly Hindu India, or Punjab where Sikh militants have also been battling for a separate homeland. India blames Pakistan for the troubles, especially in Kashmir where it accuses Pakistan of training and arming Moslem militants. Pakistan denies the claim and says India is brutally crushing a movement for self-determination. Relations between the two countries have sunk to their lowest point in years. Since independence from British rule, India and Pakistan have fought three wars, two over Kashmir, in 1948 and 1965. The Hindu said the purpose of the troop transfer was to further seal India's borders with Pakistan to prevent reported infiltrations of Pakistani-trained or armed militants. It said India's director general of military operations had informed the Pakistan army of the build-up. In Kashmir, hundreds of thousands of mourners of the slain clergyman, Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, filled the roads and dirt paths to a prayer ground 13 miles from Srinagar. Farooq was killed May 21 by three unidentified gunmen. A few hours later, security forces fired on crowds carrying his body, killing at least 58 people. It was one of the worst days of violence since Jan. 20, when India launched a crackdown on the separatist movement in Kashmir valley. So far at least 480 people have been killed. At the prayer ground ceremony Kashmiri militants stood on a stage and fired their guns in the air. A young man, saying he represented a coalition of about a dozen militant groups, spoke to the crowd, blaming Farooq's death on security forces and accusing the government of trying to split the movement by killing the clergyman. The government has denied the charge. ``We are united and will fight for the cause of freedom,'' he said. ``We will talk with our guns.'' He urged Kashmir's people to burn every Indian product they owned, beginning Friday. The Moslem insurgency in Kashmir stems from the region's division along a still-disputed frontier between predominantly Hindu India and Moslem Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned along religious lines in 1947. Kashmir was mainly Moslem, but its Hindu maharajah, or king, opted to join India instead of Pakistan. Today, the Indian-governed part of Kashmir is incorporated into the state of Jammu-Kashmir, the only one in India with a Moslem majority. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, but nationwide Moslems acount for only 12 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Premier Slightly Hurt in Car Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Tass saying Ryzhkov, two others slightly hurt, different version of accident. Pickup 8th, `Ryzhkov, 60...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov was slightly injured in a collision between his limousine and a military bus on the outskirts of Moscow, the official Tass news agency said today. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev, asked at a regular news briefing about the accident early Wednesday, said the premier received some bumps but ``feels just fine.'' Tass also said another person in the premier's car and one of 20 soldiers in the bus were slightly injured. Earlier, the Interfax news service reported the accident but said Ryzhkov had not been injured. Just before the accident, the bus was approaching Ryzhkov's limousine on Rublyovskoe Shosse, a highway on the western edge of Moscow that leads to country houses outside the capital where top officials live. Fleets of black ZIL limousines often are seen traveling along the highway at high speed. Tass, quoting Moscow Interior Ministry official Boris Koryakovtsev, said a security car in Ryzhkov's motorcade alerted the bus by flashing its lights, and the bus pulled aside. ``The bus's wheels struck the curb, the bus spun and blocked the road, prompting the collision,'' Tass quoted Koryakovtsev as saying. Interfax had reported that the accident occurred Wednesday evening, and that a car following Ryzhkov's had collided with the rear end of the premier's limousine when it braked for the bus. Ryzhkov, 60, is the head of the Soviet government. Last week, he presented an economic reform program that spurred panic buying in Moscow and other cities as residents sought to stock up before state-controlled prices go up. Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly elected president of the Russian republic, told his first news conference Wednesday that Ryzhkov and his government should resign because the public has lost confidence in it.

DOC.HEAD: Printer Misspells Naval On Naval Academy Diploma
DOC.TEXT: No, midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy have not been contemplating their bellybuttons for the past four years. But they may have thought so after receiving their degrees because of a mistake by a printing contractor. ``The Seal of the Navel Academy is hereunto affixed,'' read the diplomas handed out to 990 graduating midshipmen Wednesday. ``Yes, there was an error... made on the part of a commercial printer by the Navy,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Mark Van Dyke, the Naval Academy's public affairs officer. ``Naval Academy officials detected the error, but there was not sufficient time to make corrections prior to graduation ceremonies this morning.'' Van Dyke said the printer has agreed to reprint the diplomas and distribute them to graduates at no cost to the government. ``We're trying to look on the bright side,'' he said. ``There are 990 of our graduates tonight with a very unique souvenir from the Naval Academy _ and that's with an A.''

DOC.HEAD: Montreal Wallops Boston in Battle of the Fittest
DOC.TEXT: Why is Montreal's flag flying over Boston City Hall today? Because Montrealers walloped Bostonians when it came to exercising for 15 minutes Wednesday, that's why. A total of 328,258 people from the Boston area called into the local YMCA Wednesday saying they had exercised for a quarter-hour, compared with 425,787 residents of Montreal, said Gerdy Weiss, a spokeswoman for the YMCA. The whole thing ran on the honor system. Callers didn't even have to huff and puff as proof. Any activity that raised the heartbeat for 15 minutes counted for points in the second annual Boston vs. Montreal Challenge, the brainchild of a Montreal-based fitness organization called Participaction. For its punishment, Bostonians this morning got to see Montreal's flag flying over City Hall. Two inches of rain and 25 mph wind kept 67-year-old Ellie Marino indoors. So she just paced up and down three flights of stairs in her Charlestown home. ``I had a stroke two years ago so I'm doing great,'' Mrs. Marino said after calling the Challenge Hotline to register her quarter-hour of civic exertion. ``People got to keep going, that's the thing.'' Jane Flynn, a 32-year-old housewife in Marshfield, jogged a little, did jumping jacks and then switched on her calisthenics tape before she called the hotline. ``I'm not really that great about exercising every day, so this is a little inspiring to get me going,'' she said. Organizers planned to use a plaza outside City Hall for daylong athletic activities, from basketball to Hula Hooping and hopscotch. But until the rain stopped around midday, the only people around were dressed up as giant bags of popcorn, giving away samples. Mayor Raymond Flynn, a regular entrant in the Boston Marathon, postponed his run around the city to the afternoon. Exercising brain and muscle power, about 400 Boston schoolchildren went for an urban hike along the Boston Women's Heritage Trail. In Montreal, the temperature was about the same, in the high 50s. But winds were a milder 10 mph and the sun was out. Montreal is much like Boston in size and ambiance. Last year, Boston lost to Montreal, 420,868 to 248,328. Montreal Mayor Jean Dore got things moving in the morning, riding behind a chauffeur on a tandem bicycle, and then joined in a large public aerobics class. Corporations marshaled their employees for 15-minute walks and Montrealers could catch games of volleyball or concentrate in a spell of tai chi.

DOC.HEAD: Calif. Judge Rules Illegal Aliens Must Pay Out-of-State College Tuition
DOC.TEXT: Illegal aliens who live in California are not eligible for the in-state tuition discount at California universities and must pay the amount charged out-of-state residents, a judge ruled. Superior Court Judge David P. Yaffe issued a 10-day stay of his ruling Wednesday to allow attorneys for the University of California Board of Regents to appeal. Charles Pereyra-Suarez, attorney for the regents, said he would discuss an appeal with the regents. Yaffe ruled on a lawsuit by David P. Bradford, 35, who claimed he was forced to resign from his job at the University of California, Los Angeles, in 1985 after he refused to enroll undocumented students. Bradford, who processed student applications for residency status, contended the state has spent up to $13 million over the past five years to subsidize illegal aliens who pay in-state tuition. Yaffe cited a 1984 opinion by state Attorney General John Van de Kamp finding that under the California Education Code undocumented aliens were not legal residents for tuition purposes. UCLA attorney David Birnbaum said the university's tuition policy conformed to a 1985 Alameda County Superior Court order requiring campus registrars to treat aliens' residency applications the same way they would for U.S. citizens. Under the order, California students who were in the United States illegally were eligible for state financial aid as well as in-state tuition rates. California residents pay an average $1,633 per year in tuition at state universities, compared with an average $7,432 per year paid by out-of-state residents, according to a regents spokesman. Peter Schey, director of the Center for Human Rights and Constitutional Law, said Wednesday's ruling would be unenforceable. ``The university is not in a position to become the second line of defense to the Border Patrol,'' he said. Schey successfully argued a 1982 case that allowed children of undocumented workers to attend public schools in Texas. State universities, Schey added, ``have neither personnel nor expertise to evaluate the immigration status of every student or potential student. It would take an army of immigration agents to figure that out.'' Bradford's lawsuit contesting his firing has yet to go to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Report Claims Moscow, Prague Secret Police Plotted Revolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with secret police headquarters placed under protection. Pickup 3rd graf, `The plotters...'
DOC.TEXT: The peaceful revolution that swept away Communist rule in Czechoslovakia six months ago was engineered jointly by leaders of the secret police in Moscow and Prague, the British Broadcasting Corp. reported. In Prague today, police chief major Pavel Hoffman said secret police headquarters have been put under special protection after a heated debate of seveal dismissed agents ended up in personal threats. A BBC television documentary contends that secret police leaders in both the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia conspired to bring down the hard-line Communist leadership in Prague because it rejected Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms in the Soviet Union. The plotters planned for more reform-minded Communists to replace the hard-liners but miscalculated the depth of public desire for change, said John Simpson, the BBC foreign affairs editor. Milan Hulik, an investigator for the Czechoslovak parliamentary commission probing the plot, told the BBC it was not yet known if the revolution was instigated by the Czechoslovak secret police or the Soviet KGB. ``But all the facts point to KGB connivance,'' he said. ``We cannot reach any conclusion other than that the whole affair had been given the blessing of the Soviet political leadership.'' The plotters on the Czechoslovak side are now under investigation and some are in prison, charged with misusing their positions as public officials, while a parliamentary inquiry into the plot continues, Simpson said. The 50-minute news program, ``Czech-Mate: Inside the Revolution,'' was broadcast on BBC-TV late Wednesday. The Gorbachev administration has also been reported to have had a hand in the nearly concurrent fall of Erich Honecker, the former East German Communist leader who had resisted implimenting Soviet-style reforms. Simpson said the spark that ignited the Czechoslovak plot was the erroneous report of a death of a youthful demonstrator during an officially sanctioned march in Prague on Nov. 17. The demonstration marked the 50th anniversary of the murder of a Prague student by Nazi troops in 1939. The plotters believed a death during the November commemoration ``would provoke a hostile reaction,'' Simpson said. According to the BBC report, several thousand young demonstrators were lured into a narrow street leading to Wenceslas Square by Lt. Ludek Zivcak, a secret policeman who had infiltrated the student movement. The documentary showed a photograph of Zivcak apparently urging the marchers to take the narrow street which had not been part of the original route of the demonstration. Once in the street, marchers were hemmed in by police and brutally beaten. About 560 people were injured. Zivcak fell to the ground, his body was covered with a blanket and an unmarked ambulance took the body away. The event sparked rumors that riot police had beaten to death a student named Martin Smid. In the days that followed, people poured into Wenceslas Square in the heart of the capital to mourn the death and the protests grew. Demonstrations continued even after the only two students named Martin Smid at Prague University were shown to be alive. The mass protests finally brought about the downfall of hard-line President Gustav Husak's government, the creation of Czechoslovakia's first non-Communist government in four decades and the election to the presidency of playwright Vaclav Havel, the country's best-known opposition figure. Simpson said the chief plotters were the Cezchoslovak secret police chief, General Alois Lorenc; the KGB head in Prague, General Teslenko (first name unavailable), and KGB deputy chairman General Viktor Grushko. He said they monitored the Nov. 17 demonstration together in Prague and Grushko returned to Moscow the next day. The plotters' candidate to replace Communist Party chief Milos Jakes was Zdenek Mlynar, who had been a leading figure in Alexander Dubcek's doomed reform government in 1968. Mlynar, a friend of Gorbachev when they were law school students together in Moscow, had been purged by his own Communist leaders in 1969. But Mlynar did not want the job when it was proposed to him and Havel and his non-Communist Civic Forum were ushered into power by popular acclaim.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Soviet Events During the Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1 graf for final graf to UPDATE with report of premier slightly injured in accident. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A summary of events in the Soviet Union while Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in Washington today for his summit with President Bush:

YELTSIN _ Newly elected Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, mapping out his first 100 days in office, called for making the Soviet Union a federation of strong states that can overrule Mikhail S. Gorbachev's central government on most matters. He also said he will seek sovereignty for Russia, the largest of the Soviet republics.

EARTHQUAKE _ A strong aftershock jolted Romania and Bulgaria a day after a major earthquake felt from the Crimea to the Baltics killed at least 12 people and caused widespread damage. Eight of the deaths in Wednesday's temblor occurred in Romania, one in Bulgaria and three in the Soviet Union.

RYZHKOV _ A car carrying Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov was involved in a collision with a military bus on the outskirts of Moscow, the official Tass news agency said. The premier was slightly injured, according to a Soviet official. News reports said one other person in the premier's limousine and a soldier on the bus were also slightly hurt.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP Arts: Acadian Accordions, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0402,1207
DOC.HEAD: Accordion Makers: Old Hands and New Folk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf `Since it...', to restore dropped word `key.'
DOC.HEAD: Sent May 29 as b0186.
DOC.TEXT: A half-dozen accordions stand on Lawrence ``Shine'' Mouton's kitchen table, the result of hundreds of hours of work and decades of experience. ``My daddy was a musician _ Amadia Breaux. He composed `Jolie Blonde.' I tried to learn to play ... but didn't learn to play as well as he did,'' said Mouton, 63. ``I said if I couldn't play, I'd learn to make 'em.'' Mouton's name is now as well known among Cajun musicians as his stepfather's. His accordions are played by such performers as the popular ``Zydecajun'' musician Wayne Toups, and Jimmy Basile of Cajun Tradition, the Mamou group nominated for a Grammy award this year. As Cajun music and its spinoffs have become more popular, so has Mouton's craft. About 45 people now make the little German-style squeeze boxes, most of them in little backyard sheds. ``I figured I wasn't any dumber than the next fellow. I figured if he could make it, I could make it too,'' said John Elton Doucet, whose workshop is in his grocery store. ``The first one wasn't too, too good. But then the second one was good.'' Doucet makes six to 10 accordions a year. It's painstaking work. The flat metal reeds and the bellows are imported from Italy, but everything else is made by hand. Or at least adapted. For instance, many people make the big silver buttons on the left end of the accordion from chrome-plated chair glides. They snip off the little prongs, solder a wood screw onto the back and fill in the curve with lead. ``You drill a hole, and it's all threaded and ready to go,'' said Larry Miller, who makes accordions only for his family but makes and sells Cajun triangles, spoons set in wooden blocks so they're easy to use as a rhythm instrument and the over-the-shoulder style metal washboards used by Zydeco bands. The four wooden stops used to close off the four sets of accordion reeds are made from cabinetwork spindles. And tiny coiled screws inside the accordion were made to put tension on stereo tuning knobs. Some people paint their accordions, others varnish them to show off fine-grained woods. The long curved half-dowels which open or close the reeds often are covered with gold Mylar tape, which gives even more glitter than the once traditional gold paint and is a lot easier to apply. Miller said he began learning to play the accordion because of a lecture from Cajun music great Dewey Balfa, after an assembly at the school where Miller was principal. Miller told Balfa that his father had made triangles and played accordion, but none of his brothers or he had kept it up. ``He said, `If you're concerned about it dying in your family, it'll probably be your fault _ you were the one that broke the chain,''' recounted Miller. ``It hit me like a ton of bricks. Three days later, I went and bought an accordion and commenced to learning.'' About seven years later, he started thinking about making the instruments. He was influenced by stories he had heard about Mouton and a few other men who had loved the instrument so much that, after repairing and re-repairing German instruments made before World War II, they started making their own. Strictly speaking, the Cajun accordion is a melodeon or diatonic accordion _ a very different instrument from the big piano accordion popular shortly after the turn of the century. For one thing, the Cajun accordion is much smaller. It's about 11 inches high and six inches deep, and will squeeze down to 14 inches across. It weighs about eight pounds _ less than a third the weight of its big cousin. It's held on with a strap around the back of the left hand and a smaller strap for the right-hand thumb, and played like a hand-driven harmonica. Each of the 10 right-hand buttons gives two notes: one when the accordion is squeezed, the other when it's pulled out. The 28-pound piano accordion can't be held up without heavy padded shoulder straps. Its two-octave keyboard is twice as long as the Cajun accordion's little row of buttons; each key always plays the same note. Since it does have all 12 notes of the chromatic scale, it can play in any key while the Cajun accordion is limited to four _ if a player is particularly adept _ and plays every note of the scale only in one. However, Cajun accordion makers say that their instrument can overpower the bigger one, because it has four sets of melody reeds. German accordions began showing up in Cajun country around the 1890s, and quickly upstaged the quieter fiddle as lead instrument. World War II stopped imports, and the factories were destroyed or converted to other uses. Factories resumed making accordions later, but the style popular in Louisiana _ four sets of reeds controlled by one set of buttons _ wasn't used much elsehwere. Mouton, Charlie Ortego and Sidney Brown and Marc Savoy are generally considered the pioneers of modern-day accordion building. Mouton began making accordions in 1961, opening up his father's old German-made Sterling accordion and using it as a reference. In 1970, heart trouble forced him to choose between a transfer and retirement from work as a civil engineer for Conoco. His hobby became his full-time job. ``Not to say a living. I don't make that much money making accordions, because the cost of reeds and bellows is so high,'' he said. Those two parts are ordered from Italy and cost hundreds of dollars. Reed makers don't give any discounts, Miller said, but he and about 25 other accordion makers recently began ordering bellows together. ``I remember when you could buy reeds for $5 a set,'' said Mouton. Now, the cheapest reeds are $90, and bellows start at $150 _ and those are for a brand scorned as vastly inferior to those made in Italy. Importing presents other problems. ``I ordered some reeds Oct. 19, 1989. They have my money. I still don't have the reeds,'' said Mouton. Mouton still works in a little backyard shed, though his heart problems have cut back to six or seven hours a day and about 20 accordions a year. A friend has begun cutting out the wooden parts for him to put together. Photographs of his father and his wife, Betty, stand on a shelf over his workbench. On the walls are a plaque naming Breaux to the Cajun Musicians Hall of Fame in 1984, musicians' signed promotion photographs, and several Wayne Toups posters, one of them inscribed, ``To Mr. Shine _ thanks for being a special friend.'' Mouton opens a corner cabinet. ``This is my daddy's old accordion. He bought it in 1918 for $7.50. I don't know what it would cost today. But I turned down $2,500 for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Reserve Officer Charged in Colombian Arms Deal
DOC.TEXT: A court today charged a high-ranking reserve officer and a company he heads with illegally providing military expertise and equipment to a group of civilians in Colombia. The defendant, Lt. Col. Yair Klein, is also wanted in that South American country for allegedly helping to train fighters for cocaine cartels. The case involving Klein and his Hod Hahanit, or ``spearhead'' company, has prompted wide debate in Israel over the practice of retired military officers working as mercenaries overseas. Klein's company is defined in the charges as an organization that trains and builds counterterrorist fighting squads. The four-page charge sheet makes no mention of the Colombian charges that Klein was involved in training assassination teams for the Medellin drug cartel. Klein has vigorously denied such allegations. A copy of the charge sheet provided to The Associated Press charges Klein with making an illegal deal with a group known as the Farmers' Organization in Colombia around April 1988. The illegal-export charges by the Jerusalem Magistrates Court do not give details on the farmers' group. Klein maintained earlier that he had legally provided training to a group of Colombian cattlemen. Klein, who was involved in secret counterterrorist operations with the Israeli army, came under investigation in August. At the time, Colombia sought him in connection with a spate of drug-related shootings. Klein is still wanted in Colombia for allegedly organizing, training and equipping paramilitary groups for drug traffickers. He has been declared a fugitive from justice and may be tried in absentia. He was also questioned by Israeli police last month for an alleged role in the illegal diversion of weapons destined for Antigua to the Medellin cartel. He has denied any such involvement. An Antiguan Commission of Inquiry opens hearings on the case Friday. The Israeli court has charged Klein with three counts: negotiating to sell military expertise without a license, the actual sale of expertise, and the unlawful sale of equipment such as weapons, belts and night gun-scopes. Such actions violate a 1986 law on the export of Israeli goods and services and a 1956 law on the activities of reservists, the charge sheet says. The charges carry a maximum three-year sentence, army radio reported. No trial date has been set. The Maariv newspaper said state prosecutor Uzi Hasson plans to call a number of Defense Ministry officials to the stand. Also named in the charge sheet is a man identified as Yitzhak Ben Shimon Shoshani. He is charged with mediating Klein's negotiations for the illegal deals and direct involvement in the illegal export of military equipment.

DOC.HEAD: `Information, Please...': Michigan Bell Returns to Past
DOC.TEXT: In name only, Directory Assistance is no more at Michigan Bell. Call it Information, please. That's what most people call it anyway. Now, Michigan Bell is changing the name of its service from Directory Assistance to Information. The service goes beyond giving out telephone numbers, to offering area code information or emergency numbers, Michigan Bell said. When the service began shortly after the turn of the century, it was called Information. In 1967, it was changed to Directory Assistance. In 1971, the name was changed to New Number Information. A decade later, it returned to Directory Assistance. The return to Information completes the circle, Eileen Dixon, a Michigan Bell spokeswoman, said Wednesday. The rules for use of the number are the same _ 20 calls to Information a month are free with residential service. More calls cost 22 cents each.

DOC.HEAD: Printer Misspells Naval On Naval Academy Diploma
DOC.TEXT: No, midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy have not been contemplating their bellybuttons for the past four years. But they may have thought so after receiving their degrees because of a mistake by a printing contractor. ``The Seal of the Navel Academy is hereunto affixed,'' read the diplomas handed out to 990 graduating midshipmen Wednesday. ``Yes, there was an error... made on the part of a commercial printer by the Navy,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Mark Van Dyke, the Naval Academy's public affairs officer. ``Naval Academy officials detected the error, but there was not sufficient time to make corrections prior to graduation ceremonies this morning.'' Van Dyke said the printer has agreed to reprint the diplomas and distribute them to graduates at no cost to the government. ``We're trying to look on the bright side,'' he said. ``There are 990 of our graduates tonight with a very unique souvenir from the Naval Academy _ and that's with an A.''

DOC.HEAD: Quake Strikes Mexico City, People Flee To Streets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, ``The only...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE that Red Cross now saying power lines, sted poles, were toppled.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake centered southwest of the capital shook Mexico City early today, sending frightened residents into the streets. There were no immediate reports of serious damage or injuries. The quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale and struck at 1:35 a.m. (3:35 a.m. EDT), according to the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. The epicenter was about 180 miles southwest of Mexico City, said Waverly Person, the center's director. The quake lasted about 15 seconds. ``A lot of people were in a state of panic,'' said Carlos Aguilar, a radio operator for the Mexican Red Cross. The quake tore down power lines and caused fuses to burn out in elecowed up at the apartment of a friend with a torn, bloody T-shirt and bite marks on his back, testimony showed. He told the friend that he was forced to shoot the dog to get away from him.

DOC.HEAD: University of South Carolina President Resigns; Spending Was Criticized
DOC.TEXT: The president of the University of South Carolina has resigned after weeks of criticism about lavish spending on fund-raising trips and hiring of celebrities as visiting teachers. James B. Holderman, 54, who has headed the 40,000-student state university since 1977, will step down on July 1. Holderman made no reference to the controversy when he announced his resignation Wednesday, and declined to answer reporters' questions. He read from a statement in front of his home on the campus in downtown Columbia. ``For my whole family, this has been more than a job, it has been a total commitment,'' he said. ``In our collective judgment, we have determined that it is time to pursue new personal and professional challenges.'' Holderman regularly used luxury hotels while on fund-raising trips; hired $35-an-hour chauffeured limousine services in Washington; and frequently chartered jets or flew first class, according to records from the university and private foundations affiliated with the school. Holderman argued that expensive hotel rooms were necessary to woo wealthy donors, and said his critics overlooked the fact that he has helped raise $22.5 million in the past year. Much of the money spent came from the president's discretionary account, which is funded not from tax revenue but from such things as profits from campus vending machine sales. As a result of the controversy, the board of trustees last week implemented guidelines aimed at limiting his expenses, forcing him to obtain prior approval for exceptional spending and making him more accountable for funds spent. Critics said Holderman's spending was excessive since during the same period he told lawmakers courses were being canceled for lack of state funds. Holderman first came under criticism in 1986 for lavish spending on his travels, for giving expensive gifts to donors and students and for paying top dollar to lure celebrity lecturers and speakers to the school. Jihan Sadat, widow of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat, was paid $200,000 to teach a course in Egyptian culture for three semesters in 1985 and 1986. More recently, the school has drawn criticism for paying actor-director Robby Benson $158,367 to teach filmmaking and $15,600 for rent, with Holderman kicking in $10,000 from his discretionary fund for travel and moving expenses. Board of Trustees chairman Michael Mungo said the board did not pressure Holderman to resign, though he acknowledged that criticism of the university because of the spending should end with Holderman's departure.

DOC.HEAD: Dow 3,000 Looms Closer on Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with this morning's trading. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Many traders...'. Longer version running on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones industrial average is cruising toward the once-unimaginable 3,000 mark in what analysts call a signal that the bull market of the 1980s has shrugged off both scandal and the crash of 1987. In less than five weeks from April 27 through Wednesday, the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices surged 233.51, or 8.8 percent, to an all-time high of 2,878.56. It needed only a 4.2 percent advance to reach 3,000. In today's early trading, the Dow edged even higher, rising 4.98 to 2,883.54 by 11 a.m. Many traders and money managers minimized the significance of the milestone. The average of 30 blue chip stocks does not necessarily mirror what is happening to the hundreds of other substantial companies. Still, ``I think it is a big psychological target,'' said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall-Twenty-First Advisers Inc. A move to 3,000 in the Dow any time soon would come less than 3{ years after the average first broke 2,000, in January 1987. That kind of pace has few parallels in the history of the century-old average. It first touched 1,000 in 1966, faltered badly in the bear markets of 1969-70 and 1973-74 and did not break 1,000 decisively until early 1983. Analysts are skeptical about the significance of a 3,000 Dow for the economy as a whole. During much of the 1980s, and again more recently, the market has staged its strongest advances during periods of sluggish economic growth.

Here is the text of the arrival ceremony at the White House for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: President Bush: Friends and distinguished guests, welcome to all of you, especially our guest from the Soviet Union. It is my great honor to welcome to the White House the President of the Soviet Union, Mikhail Gorbachev. Mr. President, just _ (applause) Mr. President, just over a year ago I said that the United States wanted to move beyond containment in its relations with the Soviet Union, toward a new era, an era of enduring cooperation. When we last met in Malta we agreed to accelerate our efforts on a full range of issues. Today differences remain, of course, but in the short six months since the Malta summit we have made encouraging progress and I want this summit to take us further still, and I know that that is your view as well, Mr. President. We have seen a world of change this past year and now on the horizon we see what just one short year ago seemed a distant dream, a continent truly divided East and West, has begun to heal with the dawn of self-determination and democracy. In Germany where the Wall once stood, a nation moves toward unity, and peace, and freedom, and in the other nations of the most heavily militarized continent on earth, at last we see the long era of confrontation giving way to the prospect of enduring cooperation in a Europe whole and free. Mr. President, you deserve great credit for your part in these transforming events. I salute you, as well, for the process of change you've brought to your own country. As we begin this summit, let me stress that I believe we can work together at this historic momewnt to further the process of building a new Europe, one in which every nation's security is strengthened and no nation is threatened. Around the world, we need to strengthen our cooperation in solving regional conflicts and building peace and stability. In Nicaragua, for example, we've shown that we can work together to promote peaceful change. In Angola, our support for an early resolution of that country's tragic conflict is a resolution acceptable to the Angolan people, is now paying off. So let us expand this new spirit of cooperation, not merely to resolve disputes between us, but to build a solid foundation for peace, prosperity and stability around the world. In that same spirit, Mr. President, let me quote the words of one of your nation's great minds, one of the world's great men in this or any age, Andrei Sakharov. Fourteen years ago, he wrote, ``I am convinced that guaranteed political and civil rights for people the world over are also guarantees of international security, economic and social progress.'' Sakharov knew that lasting peace and progress are inseparable from freedom, that nations will only be fully safe when all people are fully free. And we in the U.S. applaud the new course the Soviet Union has chosen. We see the spirited debate in the Congress of People's Deputies, in the Soviet press, among the Soviet people. We know about the difficult economic reforms that are necessary to breathe new vigor into the Soviet economy, and as I've said many times before, we want to see perestroika succeed. (Applause.) Mr. President, I firmly believe, as you have said, that there is no turning back from the path you have chosen. Since our meeting in Malta, we have reached agreements in important areas, each one proof that when mutual respect prevails, progress is possible. But the agreements we've reached cannot cause us to lose sight of some of the differences that remain. Lithuania is one such issue. We believe that good faith dialogue between the Soviet leaders and representatives of the Baltic peoples is the proper approach and we hope to see that process go forward. Over the next four days we're not going to solve all of the worlds problems, we won't resolve all of the outstanding issues that divide us, but we can and will take significant steps toward a new relationship. This summit will be a working summit in the strictest sense of the term, one where we mark the real progress we've made by signing new agreements and where we address the differences that divide us in a spirit of candor, in an open and honest search for common ground. In a larger sense, though, the success of this summit depends not on the agreements we will sign, but on our efforts to lay the groundwork for overcoming decades of division and discord, to build a world of peace in freedom. Mr. President, together, your great country and ours bear an enormous and unique responsibility for world peace and regional stability.

We must work together to reduce tensions, to make the world a little better for our children and grandchildren. And to this end, I pledge you my all-out effort. (Applause.) Mr. President, you brought us a beautiful day, and you brought back Mrs. Gorbachev that brings joy to all of our hearts. A hearty welcome to her as well. And _ (applause) _ so it is my _ (applause) _ so it is my privilege to welcome you to the White House. And may God bless our peoples in their efforts for a better world. Welcome, sir. (Applause.)
