DOC.HEAD: First Summit Accord: No Answers in Oval Office
With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev reached their first agreement even before their summit talks began today. They decided not to answer reporters' questions in the Oval Office. The switch from the policy observed by President Reagan, who allowed questions during summit photo sessions in his office, was engineered by Bush as he posed with the Soviet leader for cameramen and photographers moments before their first round of talks. ``I do not take questions during photo opportunities in the Oval Office,'' Bush explained as the reporters crowded into the room. ``If they yell questions at you, which they're unlikely to do, but if they did, you should feel free to answer if you want,'' Bush told his guest. A reporter immediately asked Gorbachev about his differences with Bush on the issue of a united Germany. ``I've been told by the president that the current policy is that there are no questions during the photo opportunity,'' Gorbachev said. He promised they would report later to the press on their talks.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: Welcome, Sir. (Applause.)
DOC.TEXT: President Gorbachev: Mr. President, Mrs. Bush, ladies and gentlemen, comrades, thank you for this welcome. May I also greet all Americans on behalf of the peoples of the Soviet Union? My present visit to the United States is a confirmation that Soviet-U.S. relations are acquiring greater stability, clarity and predictability. I am convinced that both the Soviet people and the Americans approve such changes. I think that they are also properly appreciated throughout the world. Therefore, it is the great responsibility of the President and myself to make sure that the capital of trust and cooperation accumulated in recent years is protected and constantly increased. I remember well my first visit to the United States, and not only because I saw America for the first time then. During those days in December 1987, President Reagan and I signed the treaty on the elimination of INF missiles. That was truly a watershed, not only in our relations, but in the history of modern times. It was the first step taken together by two powerful countries on the road leading to a safe and sensible world. Since then, our two great nations have traveled a long way toward each other. Thousands of American and Soviet citizens, dozens of agencies, private companies and public organizations are involved in political and business contacts, humanitarian exchanges, scientific and technological cooperation. In the same years, the world around us has also changed beyond recognition. Mr. President, this generation of people on earth may witness the advent of an irreversible period of peace in the history of civilization. The walls which for years separated the peoples are collapsing. The trenches of the cold war are disappearing. The fog of prejudice, mistrust, and animosity is vanishing. (Applause.) I have come to the United States with the impressions still fresh in my mind of how our people celebrated the 45th anniversary of the victory over Nazism, and of my meetings with war veterans. I have recently had many meetings with my countrymen. They all understand the importance of Soviet-U.S. relations. They look upon their improvement with hope that the tragedies of the 20th century, those horrible wars, will forever remain a thing of the past. I think that this is what the Americans want, too. (Applause.) Mr. President, living up to these hopes of our two nations is your mission and mine. This meeting is part of it. My colleagues and I have come to do serious work in order to make a decisive step toward an agreement reducing the most dangerous arms which are increasingly losing their political significance, and to provide further impetus to interaction between our two countries, interaction and of course cooperation in solving international problems in trade, scientific, technological, and humanitarian fields and cultural exchanges, in expanding information about each other and in people to people contact. We want progress in relations between the Soviet Union and the United States of America. I am looking forward to meeting with the Americans and, to the extent possible, getting to know better your unique and great country. On behalf of Mrs. Gorbachev and myself and of all those who have come with me to your nation's capital, I thank once again President George Bush and all those present here for this warm welcome.
DOC.HEAD: END
Two Medellin Policemen Killed, Dynamite Found in Car
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed two policemen in the cocaine capital of Medellin today, bringing to 42 the number of law officers killed in that city this month, police said. Security forces in Medellin also found an abandoned car containing nearly 80 pounds of dynamite, a Metropolitan Police spokesman said in an interview. A series of bombs exploded in Medellin and several other cities in the two weeks preceding Sunday's presidential elections, killing 37 people and wounding about 350. Authorities have blamed the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel for the bombings and assassinations of policemen. The cartel has offered to pay $4,300 to anyone willing to kill a policeman. The bounty for a member of Colombia's Elite Police Corps, a group specially trained to fight drug traffickers, is said to be as high as $10,000. The police spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the two policemen were killed by unidentified gunmen in two separate attacks today in southern Medellin. So far this year, 324 policemen have been slain in Colombia, an average of two a day, police said. On Sunday, Colombians elected Cesar Gaviria, 43, of the governing Liberal Party, to be their next president. Of the four major candidates, Gaviria took the toughest line against drug traffickers. He said he favors extraditing them to the United States and opposes negotiating with them. He takes office Aug. 7, when President Virgilio Barco steps down.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Delays Foreign Trip Because of Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto today postponed visits to four Moslem nations because of ethnic unrest that has killed at least 306 people in her home province and threatened her power base. Sporadic gunfire rang through Karachi, Pakistan's largest city, for the fifth straight day today. Officials said at least seven more people were killed in the violence that broke out May 15, raising the overall death toll to 126. Ms. Bhutto has rejected demands to dismiss the government of Sindh Province, headed by her Pakistan People's Party, and bring it under control of the federal government in Islamabad. Instead, she has called out the army to help restore law and order. Soldiers and local security troops were patrolling the largely deserted streets of Karachi, the capital of Sindh and the country's financial and industrial hub. Most shops and businesses, including the Karachi Stock Exchange, have been closed this week because of around-the-clock curfews that have brought life in this city of 8 million people to a standstill. The army also was patrolling Hyderabad, a city of 3 million people 150 miles to the north, after clashes there killed at least 180 people. The trouble is rooted in deep hatred between native Sindhis and the Mohajirs, descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. Sindhis accuse the better-educated Mohajirs of taking the best jobs and most valuable land. Police blame the latest violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing the Moslem Indian immigrants. The party is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindhis. The prime minister had planned to leave June 3 on a four-day trip to Qatar, Iraq, Kuwait and Bahrain, to drum up support for Pakistan in its dispute with India over the Kashmir region. Moslem secessionists there are trying to break away from Hindu-dominated India. India blames Pakisan, a Moslem country, for fomenting that unrest, but Pakistan denies the charge. Ms. Bhutto's aides said today the two weeks of random shootings and clashes between rival ethnic groups and security forces in Pakistan had forced her to delay her trip, aides said. ``The prime minister has decided to delay her trip until some normalcy returns,'' said one aide, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: New NYC Transit Police Guideline: Eject All Panhandlers
DOC.TEXT: The Transit Authority has instituted a new policy following court battles over begging in the subways: All panhandlers will be ejected. The chief of the TA police, William J. Bratton, instituted the new rule Wednesday and explained it to officers in a videotape. Bratton said that under the new stringent guidelines, all panhandlers, even those silently holding out a cup, would be kicked out of the subway system. Earlier this month, a federal appeals court threw out a lower court's ruling that had held that begging was a constitutionally protected form of speech. The new rules are the first attempt since the ruling to instruct officers in how to handle beggars. Some forms of soliciting will still be allowed in the system, although not on trains. They include musical performances and requests for money for legitimate, registered charities or religious or political groups. In the videotaped message, Bratton said the guidelines were needed ``to clear up any misunderstanding and confusion'' among officers and to ``restore order to a system that the public believes is out of control,'' the Times said. Bratton asked officers to use their ``skill and experience'' in ejecting beggars. The New York subway system transports roughly 3.5 million passengers a day.

DOC.HEAD: `I Didn't Know if Half my Head Was Blown Off'
With PM-, AM-Jets Collide
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ward Bushee, executive editor of the Sioux Falls Argus Leader, was in a South Dakota Air National Guard A-7 fighter jet when it collided Wednesday with another A-7 over northwest Iowa. He gave his newspaper this account of his flight with Maj. Duncan Keirnes, of Sioux Falls, and of the crash.

It was a great day for flying. My wife, my 5-year-old son and young daughter watched from the runway as we took off. I've always been scared to fly. But the plane takeoff was so smooth. I was feeling very comfortable and was talking to Duncan much of the way. We flew in formation to the tanker and practiced fueling in air. Everything was going so smoothly. ... I handled the plane for a couple of minutes. Then Duncan took control for good. We took it for a roll. We went up and did some G-force testing to see how I would react. ... Then he brought the squadron back together and began setting up for combat exercises. ... We did the first exercise. It was pure Top Gun. ... We were moving so fast _ I saw Duncan's head swinging around looking at the other planes. It was very aggressive. ... We were engaged in a dogfight with another plane and we were the aggressor. Suddenly, it got turned around and another pilot was the aggressor. Duncan told me on his radio, ``Now we're on defense.'' We began going around with Greg Gore, the other pilot, in pursuit of us. ... I noticed way down to the left of what I could see that Gore's plane was coming up in an arch towards us. Duncan suddenly pointed the nose higher and seemed to be backing off the fight. That is when I fixed on Gore coming at us. The pilots later said they were trying to exercise a scissor maneuver. Those planes go so fast, a mere second makes such a difference. I said to myself, ``There isn't any danger. These guys are too good of pilots. We won't collide.'' Then it became obvious he was going to hit us. I saw the whites of the other pilot's eyes. We went up, but I think we took the hit low. He hit us from underneath towards the tail section. Gore said later he thought he was going to take it right in his canopy and he would have died instantly. ... Duncan hit the ejector button as soon as we hit, sending me exploding through the canopy and him following a second later. Then everything came apart. It was just a ball of flame. Duncan later told me that if he had waited a couple of seconds longer to eject, we would have been crispy critters. It was just a surreal scene. I was floating up in the air and my flight suit was burning like a torch. My first thought was, ``I'll never see my wife and kids again. This is it.'' Pieces of the plane were going by. Flames were all over me. I couldn't remember where the cord was to open the parachute, but it went open automatically. It was like one of those movies. The plane and debris were spiraling down below me in flames. It was completely silent up there. The parachute was swinging me around. I thought, ``Oh my God. I'm alive.'' Then I noticed blood was dripping from my head. The only thing I could think was, ``I wonder if I'm really seriously hurt.'' I didn't know if half my head was blown off. I looked down at my feet and saw my shoes were completely singed, but they were both there. I saw the other guys were alive. Duncan gave me the thumbs up. I gave him the thumbs up. It was very peaceful floating down. But I kept smelling this smell and finally figured out it was my own skin that had burned. I was trying to remember everything they told me about landing _ how to avoid trees, power lines. It seemed like five minutes to get down. It was very, very slow. The whole world was sitting out there. I saw people gathering in cars below us. There were a lot of farmers there with the wreckage off in the distance. ... I just sort of floated down and hit kind of awkwardly. I thought I'd broken my leg. I couldn't get out of the chute right away and it was blowing me across the field. A farmer came out and grabbed the chute and helped me. ... Duncan came along and asked me if I was all right. He said he was sorry it had to happen.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Wins Political Asylum After Fleeing Forced Abortions
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese couple who fled their homeland because of China's harsh family planning laws have been granted political asylum in the United States, their lawyer said today. Li Jin Mu and Wang Sai Zhen are the first known refugees to be granted asylum under an order President Bush issued last November that established fear of forced abortion as grounds for asylum. At the time they fled China last year, Ms. Wang was pregnant with the couple's second child; only one was allowed. She had undergone several previous abortions and her doctor had warned her another could damage her health. The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service notified the couple that they had been granted asylum late Wednesday, said the lawyer, Kathleen Rimar. She said the letter did not specifically mention the abortion issue. ``It's a form letter,'' Rimar said. ``It basically just says that they have demonstrated a well-founded fear of persecution.'' Ealier this month, the State Department had recommended that asylum be granted. Li, 37, and Ms. Wang, whose age has not been disclosed, now live in New York City. They must undergo a follow-up interview with the INS within a year to confirm their asylum status, Rimar said. After the asylum is confirmed, the couple would qualify for permanent resident status, although it could be a few years before they win it because of a backlog of applications, Rimar said. Five years after becoming permanent residents, they could qualify for citizenship. The couple fled their hometown of Fuzhou early last year, along with a nephew, Chun Kong Cheung, 19, and made their way to Canada. There, they paid smugglers about $1,500 apiece to get them into the United States. The INS caught them in Albany and sent Li and Chun back to Canada. Ms. Wang was allowed to stay because of her advanced pregnancy and gave birth to a daughter in New York. Li and Chun tried again to get into the United States last October, but government agents found them in the back of a truck at a border crossing near Buffalo. The three applied for asylum after Bush issued his Nov. 30 order, which was part of a directive allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States after the Tiananmen Square massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. The couple left their first child, a 10-year-old daughter, behind with relatives in China. They have said they would like to go back someday and get her. The State Department has rejected the nephew's application for asylum, but Rimar said she has asked it to reconsider. He is still in the United States, but the INS is trying to have him sent back to Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Science Father Charged in Ill Son's Death Said Boy Seemed Better
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with manslaughter in his 2{-year-old son's death testified that the ill boy appeared to be improving the day he died. David Twitchell, and his wife, Ginger, both Christian Scientists, were charged with manslaughter because they did not seek medical help for their son, who died of a bowel obstruction that could have been corrected by surgery. The couple says they rely on spiritual healing to cure physical ailments according to Christian Science principles. Twitchell took the stand Wednesday, describing the days and hours before their son, Robyn, died in 1986. Twitchell's testimony continued today. Defense attorneys have sought to show that Robyn's symptoms resembled the flu and that he died suddenly while cradled in his father's arms. An autopsy showed the boy had a birth defect that caused the obstruction. Officials from the Christian Science Church, which is based in Boston, contends the state of Massachusetts has put the religion itself on trial. Prosecutors maintain medical attention would have saved the boy's life, and deny that they are prosecuting the couple's religious beliefs. Twitchell broke down a few times during almost three hours of questioning by his attorney, Rikki Klieman. He became emotional when describing the hours leading up to his son's death when the Twitchells believed he was getting well. ``I remember holding him and him being quiet in my arms and then quietly shaking,'' said Twitchell. ``It wasn't violent shaking and it didn't last very long. After the shaking, I noticed he half closed his eyes.'' Twitchell then began to cry quietly and Suffolk County Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin called a brief recess. Twitchell said he and his wife were never far from Robyn's side during his last days. After calling in a Christian Science practitioner two days before Robyn's death, Twitchell said he and his wife began spoonfeeding Robyn every 30 minutes in an effort to get him to eat. The day the boy died, he appeared much better, Twitchell testified. ``It was like a sunny day after a hazy day,'' he said. ``We were pleased and happy it had turned out that way. Things had appeared to turn out so wonderfully.'' Twitchell said he believed the boy was recovering when he followed his father and older brother into the kitchen Tuesday night for dinner. But after drinking some liquid, Robyn vomited, Twitchell said. Later that night, the boy died in his arms, Twitchell testified. Twitchell called a funeral home director who told him to call 911. Operators coached him in cardiopulmonary resuscitation over the phone, until paramedics arrived to take the child to the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebel Leader Rejects Political Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Doe saying he won't resign in an effort to end the fighting. Pickup 7th, `Taylor, who...'
DOC.TEXT:
The leader of a rebel army that has advanced to within 25 miles of Monrovia rejected any political settlement today and vowed to seize the capital city and form a new government. In another development, the United Nations canceled an emergency food program for refugees of the civil war, and its remaining foreign workers in Monrovia prepared to leave. It took the actions after a U.N. compound was attacked by government soldiers Wednesday and a guard killed. President Samuel Doe said today he will not resign to help end the fighting, heightening fears that the two armies will clash in the capital. Doe commented while meeting with diplomats to discuss the attack on the U.N. compound. One diplomat quoted Doe as saying: ``I will not resign but will be the last person to leave'' Monrovia. That position represented a reversal for Doe, who reportedly had offered at an earlier date to resign if that would help end the fighting. Lawmakers in the Parliament on Wednesday unanimously rejected a request from Doe to hold early elections and install an interim government. The lawmakers called on Doe to fulfill his promise to resign, a source said. Rebel leader Charles Taylor said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. today that he would not be satisfied with Doe's resignation. The rebels have accused Doe's administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. The rebel forces led by Taylor, a former Doe aide, launched their insurgency five months ago in eastern Liberia. The fighting has killed more than 1,000 people in this West African nation of 2 million. The country was founded by freed American slaves and became independent in 1847.
Taylor, who said he was calling the BBC from the port of Buchanan, said his fighters would not stop until they had taken Monrovia and formed their own government. Taylor's fighters captured the country's main port of Buchanan, 95 miles east of the capital, five days ago. Rebels were reported today to be ambushing troops within a few miles of the main Robertsfield International Airport, 20 miles from the capital. The Standard newspaper in Monrovia reported that rebels had sent a telex to the general manager of the aiport saying all employees should evacuate because an attack would occur soon. Ghana Airways, the main commercial air link to Liberia, said on Wednesday it would no longer be flying into the country. However, several other carriers were still serving the airport. Bridges to Guinea were reported to have collapsed under the heavy traffic of refugees, but roads were open to Sierra Leone. Thousands of Liberian refugees have fled to neighboring countries. In Monrovia today, there were reports that members of Doe's Krahn tribe and Mandingos, who are accused of supporting Krahns and exploiting other tribes, were trying to evacuate for fear that rebels would attack the capital. Many of the rebels are members of the Gio and Mano tribes, who last week were the target of attacks that killed 11 people. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said about eight soldiers wearing masks forced their way Wednesday into the U.N. compound in Monrovia, where 1,000 refugees had gathered to demand protection and safe conduct out of the country after last week's killings. Giuliani said the soldiers killed one guard and wounded another, then abducted about 30 people. The bodies of three abducted men and a youth were found later that day dumped on a roadside outside the capital. Doe denied responsibility and said he would punish those who carried out the attack. At U.N. headquarters in New York, officials said they were evacuating 57 U.N. personnel still in Liberia and protesting to the Foreign Ministry over the attack. The 11 remaining foreign officials prepared to evacuate today. Terry Lewis, chief of the U.N. Disaster Relief Organization in Liberia, told reporters the evacuation means an end to an emergency food relief program begun April 6. The program aimed at feeding 135,000 people displaced during the fighting. The first mass food distribution in the capital was scheduled for today.

DOC.HEAD: Toxins from Rocky Mountain Arsenal Flow into South Platte River
DOC.TEXT: At least five toxic chemicals from the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, including a nerve gas byproduct and two banned pesticides, have migrated underground four miles to the South Platte River, officials said. Environmental Protection Agency officials said Wednesday that they did not believe there was any public health threat from the wastes dumped by the Army and Shell Oil Co. ``When it reaches the South Platte, it's very diluted,'' said Connally Mears, who directs an EPA-supervised cleanup at the arsenal north of Stapleton International Airport. The EPA had not previously disclosed that pollution from the arsenal was affecting the South Platte, which supplies water for drinking and irrigation to thousands of rural northeastern Colorado residents. The pollution apparently is seeping around the edges of underground barrier systems the Army and Shell built along the arsenal's northern and northwestern borders to cleanse groundwater. The 27-square-mile arsenal's contamination of groundwater dates to the early 1950s. Shell Oil Co. manufactured pesticides at the arsenal for 30 years beginning in 1952. Before that, the Army manufactured and stored chemical warfare weapons there. EPA officials said a plume consisting of many pollutants reached the river, but they are chiefly concerned about five: an Army nerve gas byproduct called DIMP; PCE, an industrial solvent; chloroform; dieldrin, a Shell pesticide banned for most uses in 1974 because of links to cancer; and DBCP, a Shell pesticide banned for most uses in 1979 because it can cause sterility in workers. ``The key uncertainty is over the long-term health effects of DIMP,'' Mears said. Last month, the EPA and the Colorado Department of Health announced plans to test wells used by 150 homes north and northwest of the arsenal for DIMP. Results are expected this summer.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp
Bush Praises Process of Change in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs, with editing.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today praised the ``process of change'' Mikhail S. Gorbachev sparked in the Soviet Union but wasted no time in laying out U.S. displeasure over the Soviet president's policy in Lithuania. In an official greeting on the White House South Lawn, Bush noted the ``encouraging progress'' made by the two countries since he and Gorbachev held their first summit meeting in Malta last December. However, he said, ``The agreements we've reached should not cause us to lose sight of some of the differences that remain. Lithuania is one such issue.'' Reiterating the U.S. call for negotiations by the Soviets with leaders of the breakaway republic, Bush said, ``We believe that good faith dialogue between the Soviet leaders and representatives of the Baltic peoples is the proper approach and we hope to see that process go forward.'' Gorbachev stood impassively at Bush's side as a smattering of applause rippled across the audience of several hundred dignitaries and guests. Bush greeted Gorbachev with a warm handshake and the two smiled frequently during the ceremonial part of the official greeting at the start of their second summit. ``Mr. President, you deserve great credit for your part in these transforming events'' that have brought dramatic reform to Eastern Europe, Bush said. ``I salute you as well for the process of change you've brought to your country.'' Bush ended his welcoming statement on a hopeful note. ``We are not going to solve all of the world's problems. We will not resolve all of the outstanding differences that divide us, but we can and will take significant steps toward a new relationship,'' he said. Bush came to the talks after two days of intensive briefings and telephone talks with the leaders of Canada and West Germany. In a summit-eve briefing session, the president ``went through all the possible issues that could be raised, all the points he wants to raise with Gorbachev,'' Vice President Dan Quayle said after attending the meeting on Wednesday. The president spoke with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on the Canadian leader's just-finished talks with Gorbachev. Mulroney told Bush the Ottawa talks had gone well, the White House said in a statement shortly after Gorbachev arrived in Washington. Bush thanked Mulroney for his report ``on the current thinking of Mr. Gorbachev,'' the statement said. Going into today's talks, Bush was ``upbeat, he's confident. He knows what he wants to talk to Gorbachev about,'' Quayle told The Associated Press. High among the topics was the pending unification of Germany, aides said. White House officials said Bush would hold firm on keeping Germany in the NATO alliance, and not singling it out for special troop reduction deals outside future talks on reducing forces throughout Europe. However, officials said Bush also was prepared to listen to Soviet concerns on the subject. ``We want to hear their concerns and their interests,'' said White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater, adding that Bush would be ``exploring mutually acceptable options and positions'' with Gorbachev. He said military troop levels in Germany constituted a proper subject for ``follow-on conventional arms control negotiations'' once a treaty to reduce troops and tanks throughout Europe is reached. Other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Bush was prepared to discuss with Gorbachev a formula for such talks that could have the Western allies limit the size of the German army in exchange for proportional cuts in the size of the Red Army within the Soviet Union. Bush spent most of Wednesday in the Cabinet Room with top advisers, as Gorbachev wrapped up a 29-hour stopover in Canada before flying to Washington. Bush also consulted with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl by telephone. He held meetings earlier in the year with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and French President Francois Mitterrand. ``The president's mood ... is one of anticipation and confidence,'' Fitzwater told reporters. Bush's Wednesday briefings dealt with economic and trade issues, arms control, and on ``overview questions, the general tone and texture of the summit,'' Fitzwater said. The spokesman said the agenda called for the two leaders on Wednesday and Thursday to discuss arms control, conventional arms, chemical weapons, trade and other issues that could lead to ``various specific agreements.'' Fitzwater said German unity likely would be discussed in greater depth when Gorbachev joins Bush on Saturday at the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Launch Off Until Next Week at Earliest; Leak Problem Studied
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with tiny leak found, but it's not believed to be the one that caused the problem. Picks up 4th graf, `Columbia's launch...'.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronomy mission is on hold for at least another week, and possibly longer, as NASA tries to track down a small leak in a shuttle fuel line that caused the launch to be scrubbed. Workers entered the engine compartment early today to search for the leak after the shuttle's external fuel tank was purged of combustible hydrogen. A tiny leak was found in a so-called ``flex line connector'' in the extensive plumbing in the suspected area, but it was believed to be too small to have leaked so much hydrogen Tuesday, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``The feeling is at this point that's probably not what they're looking for,'' Buckingham said. If workers can't find the main leak, the shuttle would have to be rolled back into its hangar, NASA officials said. That would mean about a one-month delay. Columbia's launch, which had been set for 12:38 a.m. Wednesday, was scrubbed six hours before liftoff because of leaking hydrogen during fueling of the shuttle with more than a half-million gallons of super-cold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. It was the first time a shuttle launch had been scrubbed during fueling. The mission already had been delayed two weeks because of repairs to the cooling system. Columbia will carry into orbit seven astronauts and a $150 million observatory called Astro. The astronauts returned to Johnson Space Center in Houston to practice liftoffs and landings in a shuttle simulator. The earliest another launch could be attempted is the middle of next week, said Bob Sieck, launch director for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. If the problem is ``something obvious that we can repair on the pad, then we'll do that and fly,'' said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of prelaunch operations for Columbia. The odds of that happening are 50-50, NASA officials said. Engineers believe the leak is in a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the external tank to the main engine. The effect of the delay on the shuttle's astronomy mission was not clear, but the postponement is likely to affect what can be seen of Comet Austin, which was discovered last year and is receding rapidly from the solar system. NASA plans to open Columbia's payload bay Friday to replenish the argon used to keep Astro's X-ray telescope cold. Astro's three other telescopes, which track ultraviolet radiation, have no special needs. The space agency said it would proceed as planned with Friday's launch of a German X-ray observatory known as Rosat. It will be boosted into orbit by an unmanned Delta rocket. Sieck would not say what impact Columbia's delay will have on this year's flight schedule. NASA does not want anything to threaten an October mission to deploy the Ulysses satellite, which will explore the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: Train Hits Police Van; Six Dead, 54 Wounded
DOC.TEXT: A passenger train slammed into a police vehicle crossing the railroad track, and six police officers were killed, newspapers reported Thursday. The Cairo paper Al-Akhbar said 54 civilians were injured in the accident Wednesday afternoon at the village of Tukh, about 25 miles north of Cairo. It said the crossing's stop signal was lighted, but the driver of the police vehicle ignored it. The paper said the impact derailed three cars of the train, which was headed to the city of Alexandria.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Government Moves to Reduce TV Violence
DOC.TEXT: The government moved Thursday to reduce the violence shown on television, particularly in news programs. Transport and Communcations Minister Kim Beazley said he supported the recommendations in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's report on television violence, which was brought up for discussion in Parliament. The key recommendation is that the television industry draw up a uniform code on how to treat violence. Although the emphasis is on ``supervised self-regulation,'' Tribunal Chairman Deirdre O'Connor said in a separate statement that if the code could not satisfy meet public concerns, ``the Tribunal would be driven to consider a range of options which could include imposing program standards and license conditions.'' The report said there was widespread worry about the repetition of violent images, close-ups of blood and intrusion on grieving people. The overriding concern was the effect of violence on children. The report said it was clear that news had assumed an overwhelming importance in the competition for evening ratings. The depiction of violence in sport was also criticized, particularly slow-motion replays of brawls and the use of fighting in promotions.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Disrupts Train Traffic; Airport Strike Set For Monday
DOC.TEXT: Train traffic was disrupted throughout the country Thursday as engine drivers began a two-day strike, and air traffic controllers warned that they would also strike. The airport workers, set to begin interrmittent strikes Friday, and the railway workers want better working conditions and more money. Teachers, also calling for better pay, demonstrated in the center of Brussels on Thursday, adding to the traffic mayhem caused by the train strike. Only a third of the trains were running, causing delays of up to two hours during the morning rush hour. It was the third major strike of train engine drivers since September.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Six Soldiers; Reward Offered for Killers of Americans
DOC.TEXT: A truck carrying Philippine soldiers on their way to cut bamboo ran over a land mine planted by Communist rebels, and six soldiers were killed and four wounded, the military said Thursday. Col. Benjamin Enrile, spokesman of the Philippine army, said the attack took place Wednesday on the outskirts of Rizal in Cagayan province, about 225 miles north of Manila. Enrile said soldiers from the 65th Infantry Battalion were on their way to to cut bamboo for a construction project when their vehicle tripped the mine. Following the explosion, New People's Army rebels opened fire on the vehicle, touching off a brief gunbattle. There was no report of rebel casualties. Also Thursday, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos offered a $45,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of four rebels the military says killed two American airmen near Clark Air Base on May 13. Ramos said witnesses identified the four as Alex Capitulo, Allan Gutierrez, Gonzalo Bondoc and Ric Manansala. The New People's Army claimed responsibility for killing airmen John Raven and James Green last month. The killings occurred on the eve of U.S.-Philippine talks on the future of American military bases in the Philippines. The Communist rebels oppose an extension on the lease for the six military facilities, which expires next year. The government has been fighting the Marxist rebels for 21 years.

DOC.HEAD: Capitalizing on the Summit
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks ago, Kevin A. Smith was in the library poring over Russian history and recipes. Now he's in a restaurant kitchen preparing blue-plate specials, Soviet-style. Smith is a chef at the Hard Rock Cafe, one of many Washington establishments looking for a way to capitalize on the U.S.-Soviet summit. The cafe kicked off a special ``Glasnost Week'' on Monday and sold out of Hard Rock summit T-shirts the same day. The festivities continued Tuesday with a performance by Soviet musicians and a children's choir. Throughout the week, Hard Rock is featuring its own menu translated into Russian and rubles, along with Smith's daily Soviet creations. Thursday's Russian special was chicken and dumplings, swordfish with green sauce and ground chocolate cake. On Friday the curious can order beef stroganoff, freshwater fish soup, broiled trout and coffee cream roll. The regular menu, with dishes such as Bordertown guacamole, veggie sandwiches, chiliburgers and root beer floats, was translated for the occasion into a strange mixture of literal and phonetic Russian. ``This is the best compromise,'' said translator Rudy D'Alessandro. ``Titles transliterated into Cyrillic letters, explanations in Russian for the people ordering _ because you can look at a `pig sandwich' and say what is this thing, then you read the explanation and say, `it's edible.''' The restaurant, which already has branches in a number of countries, says it is planning one in Moscow.

Elsewhere, Benetton, the preppie clothing company, ran a full-page ad Thursday in The Washington Post _ a photograph of two children with six Soviet and American flags in their hair and on their cheeks. The full text says ``United Colors of Benetton,'' the firm's current advertising theme. The day before, Smirnoff vodka took up a full Post page. The ad featured a large red ``X'' through groups of tanks, missiles, soldiers, helicopters, submarines and the like. There was no red ``X'' through three rows of Smirnoff bottles. ``Now that's what we call a successful summit,'' said the ad. ``First the Russians welcomed Smirnoff back in the U.S.S.R. after 73 years. Next, who knows? With a start like that, anything is possible.'' ``Certainly we are by no means making a political statement,'' said company spokeswoman Vivian Brooks.

The Ritz-Carlton hotel says dove-shaped peace cookies are replacing mints on its guests' pillows during summit week. They are accompanied by a card quoting President Bush on his expectations for the summit. Not the biggest news, but it did give the Ritz-Carlton a chance to remind journalists that it is a four-star hotel, what celebrities have stayed there and that it had been featured on ``Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.'' Those dove cookies are going to be served at ``the famous Jockey Club, home of power dining in the nation's capital.''

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Will Investigate Communist Property Holdings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Parliament approving creation of the commission. Pickup 8th pvs, `They want...'
DOC.TEXT: East German lawmakers voted today to create a commission that will investigate and perhaps seize the vast property held by the former Communist Party. The coalition government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere asked Parliament to form a commission that would have broad powers to seize evidence, search houses and interrogate witnesses. When it is created in the next few days, all property owned by political parties and other organizations under the former regime would be put in trust while the government decides how to dispose of it. The law was passed as the young democratic government grapples with how to convert state-owned property to private ownership, a prerequisite to unification with West Germany. The two German states are to merge their economies and social institutions on July 2, when West German currency will become the currency of East Germany. The property commission is to report its findings to Parliament by June 30. The commission is part of the monumental process of dismantling the nation's vast system of state ownership. The proposal calls for the property of all political parties, unions and other organizations to be investigated, but it is clearly aimed at the former Communist regime. Lawmaker Gregor Gysi, leader of the reconstituted Communist Party that now supports a form of democratic socialism, said the government proposal was aimed at eliminating his party's role as an opposition faction. ``They want all opposition eliminated,'' said Gysi, whose party is now called the Party of Democratic Socialism. ``That is the goal and nothing else.'' He said his party already has given up a large part of its property. Richard Schroeder, leader of the Social Democratic lawmakers in Parliament, said the proposal is aimed at merely shedding light on who owns what in the country. ``We should bring clarity and light to the property proportion,'' he said. ``We have the impression that the history of the former Communist Party property is still being written.'' The left-leaning Social Democrats are part of conservative de Maiziere's coalition. Under the government's proposal, the property commission would report back to the Parliament by June 30. The issue of distributing East German property has generated much argument in both Germanys. Hans Klein, spokesman for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said on Wednesday that property seized when the Communists assumed control of East Germany 40 years ago should be given back to the original owners. More than 1 million West Germans are expected to lay claim to property they or their ancestors left behind when fleeing after World War II or during the Communist regime. East Germany wants instead to pay compensation to former owners and let East Germans have the initial opportunity to buy the property. Some West Germans already have written letters to tenants of East German apartments, warning them that they will seek to claim the land on which the buildings stand. East Germans also fear high unemployment and rising prices when the two nations merge their economies. East Germans have been lining up at grocery stores to stock up on food and other household goods, creating huge shortages of meat, milk and other basic necessities, officials said. Lawmaker Vera Wollenberger said meat was selling out in stores within one hour of opening in the cities of East Berlin and Halle. Commerce Minister Sybille Reider said consumer demand has increased 300 percent to 400 percent in recent days. Soap, bread and other goods are selling out, she said.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean President Says He Wants to End Anger With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Roh Tae-woo said Thursday his talks next week with Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be aimed at helping to end hostility on the divided Korean peninsula. Roh is scheduled to meet with the Soviet president in San Francisco on Monday after Gorbachev ends summit talks with President Bush. Afterward, Roh is to meet Bush in Washington. The Roh-Gorbachev meeting will be the first between leaders of the two nations, which have no diplomatic relations. The talks come at a time when economic ties between Seoul and Moscow are rapidly increasing. Their two-way trade doubled to $600 million last year and is expected to surpass $1 billion in 1990. The meeting also represents the culmination of South Korea's ``northern policy,'' which is aimed at fostering ties with Communist nations able to influence Communist North Korea. Since that policy went into effect in July 1988, South Korea has established formal diplomatic relations with every nation in eastern Europe except Albania and East Germany. Roh said Thursday he will try to use the San Francisco talks not only to improve ties with the Soviet Union, but also to force open North Korea's closed society. The president said he would be trying to make overtures through Gorbachev to officials in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. ``Since there is no way opened for me to go to Pyongyang, I have to go there by way of Moscow,'' aides quoting Roh as saying. Chief presidential spokesman Lee Soo-jung said Roh and Gorbachev will discuss normalizing relations between Seoul and Moscow, trade between the two nations, and peace on the Korean peninsula. ``They will also discuss world affairs with emphasis on the situation in Northeast Asia and discuss ways to help ease tension and promote peace on the divided peninsula,'' Lee said. South Korea and North Korea have been arch-enemies since the division of the peninsula in 1945. The Soviet Union is a close ally and arms provider of North Korea. South and North Korea have held sporadic talks on easing tensions, but little progress has been made.

DOC.HEAD: Atlas Rocket Damaged, Launch Date Uncertain
DOC.TEXT: A commercial rocket sustained minor damage during a test, possibly delaying its June launch with a satellite that will study space radiation, NASA said Thursday. The unmanned Atlas-Centaur rocket had been scheduled to lift off June 23 from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station with the Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite. The satellite was not inside the rocket at the launch pad when the damage occurred. A preliminary investigation showed that a high-pressure helium line failed Wednesday as the system was being pressurized, said Jim Cast, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The line failure apparently caused two small holes in the rocket's interstage adapter. The launch will be the first of a commercial Atlas, built by General Dynamics Corp. General Dynamics said it is forming an investigation team to determine the cause of the damage and to assess the launch date. NASA and the Air Force will participate in the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Trustee Asks Judge to Approve Sale of PTL Network to California Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details from hearing; San Diego man seeking to buy network that Oral Roberts had sought as well as other assets. Picks up 9th graf, `PTL has...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A court-appointed trustee overseeing the sale of Jim Bakker's bankrupt empire today asked a judge to approve a $7 million bid by a California minister for the PTL television network. Morris Cerullo, head of Worldwide Evangelism Inc. of San Diego, agreed to purchase PTL's remaining assets if he could be guaranteed the cable network, trustee Dennis Shedd told U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Thurmond Bishop. Cerullo, 58, an Assemblies of God pastor, has an organization with branches in Great Britain, Canada, Israel and Zimbabwe. In 1978, he unveiled plans for a $100 million ``world outreach center'' in San Diego, but unlike Bakker's Heritage USA complex 10 miles south of Charlotte, N.C., it never materialized. Earlier this month, evangelist Oral Roberts signed a $6.45 million contract that gave him the right to buy the cable network unless someone else bid more or agreed to buy all of PTL's assets as a package deal. In urging Bishop to approve the sale of the network to Cerullo, Shedd did not mention whether Cerullo had signed a contract for other PTL assets. The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer reported today that Cerullo signed a $52 million contract Wednesday that included Heritage USA, PTL's former religious theme park and retreat in Fort Mill. Also Wednesday, Cerullo deposited $7 million in an escrow account for the network, said Brad Leggett, an attorney representing Shedd. Shedd has said that any offer he accepts must be paid in full at the time of the sale, not paid over time. It was not clear whether the reported $52 million price included the $7 million for the television network. Shedd would not answer questions during a recess called so he could confer with attorneys. Cable television's Home Box Office had asked the Bankruptcy Court to block Shedd's deal with Roberts, because it doubted Roberts could make the $242,000 monthly payments for the use of a satellite HBO provides for PTL. PTL has been in bankruptcy proceedings since June 1987, three months after Bakker resigned in the sex-and-money scandal that led up to his 45-year federal prison term for fraud and conspiracy. Although the PTL network still carries other evangelists' taped programs, Heritage USA, where Bakker had his studios and church, has been closed since September. The 500-acre retreat near Fort Mill also has five restaurants, a $10 million water park and two 500-room hotels, one of them unfinished. It includes about 1,700 undeveloped acres. Last year, Toronto businessman Stephen Mernick failed to close on a $65 million deal to buy PTL with bank financing. The lenders wanted title insurance for Heritage USA, and Mernick could not obtain it because of a Catawba Indian lawsuit claiming 144,000 acres of land, including the Heritage USA site, was illegally sold to the state in 1840.

DOC.HEAD: PR Effort Sours: National Guard Jet Crash Injures Newspaper Editor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to note that guard is not releasing names of pilots.
DOC.TEXT: In a public relations effort gone awry, a newspaperman who had criticized National Guard flyovers as dangerous was invited along on a flight exercise _ and nearly was killed in a crash that destroyed two jets. The two A-7 fighter jets of the South Dakota Air National Guard collided over northwestern Iowa on Wednesday, raining debris on a soybean field. Both pilots and Ward Bushee, executive editor of the Sioux Falls (S.D.) Argus Leader, ejected. The pilots were uninjured, but Bushee was taken by ambulance 70 miles to a Sioux Falls hospital, where he was in fair condition. Bushee said that just before the planes collided ``I saw the whites of the other pilot's eyes.'' After the pilot of his plane hit the ejection release, ``everything came apart. It was just a ball of flame,'' Bushee said in an account published in his newspaper. ``It was just a surreal scene. I was floating up in the air and covered with fire. My first thought was, `I'll never see my wife and kids again. This is it.' ``Pieces of the plane were going by. Flames were all over me. I couldn't remember where the pull was to open the parachute but it went open automatically. It was like one of those movies. The plane was spiraling down below me in flames. It was completely silent.'' Bushee, 41, had written an editorial in August criticizing ceremonial flyovers as noisy and dangerous. ``Flyovers pose a risk for neighborhoods,'' he wrote. ``What if the jet crashed?'' The piece apparently led to an invitation to an ``orientation flight,'' which the Air Guard offers ``to show civic leaders and community personnel what our mission is and why there is an Air Guard,'' said Lt. Ruth Christopherson. ``We've had no problems until this,'' she said. Bushee, 41, suffered a broken vertebra in his neck, cuts and burns, but said he felt lucky to be alive. ``I've always been kind of scared of flying. I don't like to fly that much. I think I will fly commercial, but I don't think I'll fly in an A-7 soon,'' Bushee said. ``It's incredible we survived it.'' The pilots, Maj. Gregory Gore of Collierville, Tenn., and Maj. Duncan Keirnes of Sioux Falls, were treated at a hospital in Spencer and released, Christopherson said. Bushee said it was a clear, calm day and the planes were taking part in exercises with two other A-7s. ``We were doing dogfights,'' Bushee said. ``One of the planes started coming at us, and it just seemed like we couldn't get out of the way. We seemed to be dodging into each other ... The next thing I knew I was ejected out into the air and parachuting down.'' The Guard was not releasing the names of the two pilots involved in the crash. The cause of the accident is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Review: Stylized, Staccato `Tracy' Better Than `Batman'
DOC.TEXT: You've seen ``Dick Tracy: The Hype.'' Now it's time for ``Dick Tracy: The Movie.'' The Disney Co. screened the Warren Beatty-Madonna film for reviewers Wednesday, climaxing months of buildup aimed at acquainting potential patrons with the half-forgotten comic strip and Beatty's efforts to convert it into a megahit. Scheduled for wide release on June 15, ``Dick Tracy'' bears Disney's hopes for another smash like ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' The production cost was high _ estimates range from $23 million to $30 million _ for a film with little apparent built-in appeal for the younger crowd that is the backbone of today's film audience. The competition for summer tickets is fierce: ``Total Recall,'' ``Days of Thunder'' and rehashes of ``Die Hard,'' ``Robocop,'' ``48 Hrs'' and ``Back To The Future.'' Against such predictable fare ``Dick Tracy'' is distinguished by its originality. The plot is basic comic strip: good cop vs. the bad guys. Chief bad guy Big Boy Caprice schemes to rule the metropolis with his band of grotesques ranging from Flattop to Pruneface. Big Boy mows down his opposition, but his efforts to destroy Dick Tracy repeatedly fail. Even his luscious moll, Breathless Mahoney, can't seduce the dedicated cop. Forget the plot. The essence of ``Dick Tracy'' lies in characters and style, and there it exceeds last summer's clunky, over-produced Batman. The characters are outrageous and for the most part entertaining. Dustin Hoffman does a delightful bit as the unintelligible Mumbles. Al Pacino, in the best coverup since Albert Finney's Hercule Poirot in ``Murder on the Orient Express,'' is properly obnoxious as Big Boy Caprice. James Caan is wasted as the gangster Spaldoni. Beatty plays Tracy straight and true blue. There's no wit to the character and little sagacity; on a scale of 1 to 10 with Sherlock Holmes ranked 10, Tracy ranks 3 among fictional detectives. But Tracy's very straightness provides a solid core for the film. After a couple of flops, Madonna finally registers on the screen as the oversexed Breathless. She's busty and brash with the kind of lines (``What I'm looking for is a driver, preferably one with some mileage.'') that Lauren Bacall used to murmur to Humphrey Bogart. As the orphaned Kid, the only sympathetic character, Charlie Korso almost steals the film. Glenne Headly registers nicely in the thankless role of Tracy's patient girlfriend, Tess Trueheart. Also notable: Mandy Patinkin as 88 Keys, Paul Sorvino as Lips Manlis, Charles Durning as Chief Brandon, and Dick van Dyke, also unrecognizable, as District Attorney. Richard Sylbert's design for ``Dick Tracy'' is self-conscious but eye-filling. The same reds, greens, blues, etc., are everywhere as in the Sunday comics. Director Beatty maintains a staccato pace punctuated by Danny Elfman's overpowering score. In keeping with the 1930s atmosphere, Beatty uses three extended montages to advance the plot. The few quiet moments with Tess and Kid are welcome relief. Disney's Touchtone Pictures is releasing the film, originally designed for the Walt Disney Pictures banner. The switch seems logical, since the PG-rated film contains Madonna's sexual innuendo and much gunfire (although no blood). Beatty also produced ``Dick Tracy.'' The writing passed through several hands but the credit goes to Jim Cash and Jack Epps Jr. Running time: 100 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Field Narrows in National Spelling Bee
DOC.TEXT: The field of youngsters competing in the 63rd annual National Spelling Bee narrowed today to 65 super-spellers as the competition became more intense and the words became harder in the closing rounds. After completion of the fourth round, almost two-thirds of the 226 young spellers who had made it to the national event had been eliminated. Ninety youths, 10 to 14 years in age, fell by the wayside in the fourth round alone. They were victims of such words as ``cerebriform,'' ``cambistry'' and ``consanguinity.'' ``Take a deep breath,'' one of the judges suggested to William Aston, 13, an eighth-grader from Jackson, Tenn., as the youngster struggled with the word, ``hamartia.'' He did and spelled it correctly to advance to the next round. Heather Ambrose, 12, of Front Royal, Va., was not as lucky. She left the competition after failing to spell ``sayonara'' _ Japanese for goodbye. About two-thirds of the 226 young spellers who entered the national finals survived the opening rounds Wednesday and moved on to today's competition. The field was expected to narrow rapidly. In early rounds Wednesday the spellers were given words that had been included in a study list of more than 2,000 words. In later rounds today, however, the words were not in the study list. In Wednesday's competition, 71 of the 226 competitors fell out of the competition after failing to spell such words as ``upeygan,'' ``ipsedixitism,'' ``quercitron'' and other words equally challenging. Last year spellers went through 903 words before Scott Isaacs, 14, of Englewood, Colo., won. The 127 girls and 99 boys who entered this year's spelling bee competed against nearly 9 million other students at the local level to advance to the national contest. The competition, which began in 1925, is sponsored by Scripps Howard Newspapers and 208 other daily, weekly and Sunday newspapers in 47 states. The champion will win $5,000, a trophy cup and special prizes from Encyclopaedia Britannica. In all there are $26,550 in cash prizes. In Wednesday's competition, eight spellers were eliminated in the first round. The tougher second round took 33 additional contestants, including Erika Harrell, the only 9-year-old and the youngest competitor this year. The fourth-grader from Muncie, Ind., stumbled on ``soliterraneous'' _ forgetting the second ``r''. Thirty other contestants fell in the third round. The youngsters, ages 9 to 14, sat on rows of chairs on a stage and when it was their turn walked to the microphone to be challenged. To some the wait was worse than the word. ``Waiting for your number to come around'' is the hardest, Melissa Lake, 14, an eighth grader from Denver, said between rounds. She had just spelled correctly ``erubescent'' and survived the third round with ``segue.''

DOC.HEAD: Germany Is A Potential Spoiler In Bush-Gorbachev Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 6 grafs of Bush and Gorbachev remarks on Germany; picks up 7th graf pvs, bgng, `There were.'
DOC.TEXT: Germany loomed as the potential spoiler, as President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev opened talks today gently sparring over the future of the powerful European nation. Bush, in a White House arrival ceremony for the Soviet leader, hailed the impending unification of East Germany with West Germany as a milestone toward ``enduring cooperation in a Europe whole and free.'' But mindful of Gorbachev's reservations about a more powerful neighbor, the President assured him ``we can work together at this historic moment'' to reduce remaining East-West tensions. ``The trenches of the Cold War are disappearing,'' Gorbachev said in response. But, in a thinly veiled reference to his concerns about German unification and U.S. demands that the new country have NATO membership, the Soviet leader recalled the Allies victory over Nazism in World War II and, earlier, the defeat of Germany in World War I. Gorbachev then pointedly expressed a hope that ``these horrible wars will forever remain a thing of the past.'' Earlier, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said that all the Western allies _ and even some Warsaw Pact members _ agree that a unified Germany's full membership in NATO is important to assure European stability. ``So the Soviet Union is, to some extent, alone among the nations involved in this who have a problem with it,'' Baker said on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America.'' ``So our job is to see if we can better explain it, see if we can find other things that the Soviets can point to, to justify Germany's membership in NATO to their domestic population.'' There were indications the two sides may be in a mood to compromise. U.S. officials are hinting at negotiations in the future to scale down both the German and Soviet armies. A Soviet official, speaking today on condition of anonymity, said the German problem should be taken up by the 35 nations that form the European Security Conference. It was not clear at the outset if the two leaders would find ways to resolve the nettlesome issue of Germany before it obscures the arms control agreements and other accords Bush and Gorbachev have on their agenda. ``There should be no attempt to dictate a solution'' Gorbachev said in Ottawa just before leaving Canada for his date with Bush. The Soviet leader has repeatedly declared, however, that the United States should find an alternative to NATO membership for the powerful nation that will be formed when East Germany is merged with West Germany. But U.S. officials said there would be no retreat from that position, nor any deal cut by Bush to scale down the size of the new German army. Gorbachev's reservations are behind a Soviet slowdown in multilateral negotiations to cut conventional forces in Europe, including troop levels, tanks, aircraft, helicopters and other non-nuclear weapons. And the issue has clouded other key issues on the summit agenda, including a framework agreement to slash long-range nuclear missiles, a halt in the production of chemical weapons and a commercial pact to nearly quadruple travel between the two nations. Gorbachev has said time and again, as he did in Ottawa on Wednesday, that for a united Germany to rejoin NATO in an era of sweeping change and cooperation throughout Europe would be a Cold War affront to the sensibilities of the Soviet people, who suffered greater losses than any other to Nazi Germany in World War II. Canada's prime minister, Brian Mulroney, expressed some sympathy for that point, saying he hoped each side would explore alternatives. American and Soviet representatives, for the fifth day, held a round of talks at the State Department to try to overcome the negotiating slump on conventional forces, and to expand on the categories of long-range nuclear weapons to be reduced in another treaty. They met for an hour and a half in the morning Wednesday, but did not resume in the afternoon. ``Everybody would like to see things progress, but there isn't a lot of progress,'' a U.S. official said. ``They are waiting for the rest of the team.'' The only evident accomplishment over the four days was an agreement Tuesday on a definition of tanks and armored personnel carriers. This will make it easier to reduce U.S. and Soviet arsenals of the weapons and also to police compliance with a treaty. But the two leaders will issue joint statements setting goals and calling for quick follow-up talks on future nuclear and conventional cutbacks once a new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty is finished, U.S. officials said. Baker, who made arrangements to meet separately at the White House with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said last Thursday that Bush would press Gorbachev at the summit to accelerate the troop reduction negotiations. But Gorbachev, who got the ball rolling in the first place by volunteering to withdraw Red Army units and tanks from Eastern and Central Europe threatened on Friday to reconsider his policies if the Western allies kept insisting on NATO membership for Germany. The Soviets suffered a loss of at least 20 million people in World War II, and with the Warsaw Pact weakening, Gorbachev is concerned about the re-emergency of German military power. Administration officials said last Thursday that Bush will cut no deal with Gorbachev to limit German troops, but he is prepared to discuss a formula that might scale down the size of the Red Army as well. But the officials said any settlement would require the participation and consent of West Germany and the other partners in the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``We are opposed to any proposal which would single out Germany for special limits,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. However, Bush and Gorbachev will discuss the ``general question'' of German unification and ``we want to hear their concerns and interests,'' Fitzwater said. The formula other U.S. officials said Bush was ready to take up with Gorbachev involved a tradeoff, to be negotiated by NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna after the treaty governing U.S. and Soviet conventional forces in Europe is completed. The Western allies would consider imposing limitations on the size of the German army, but in exchange the Soviets would have to agree to cut down the Red Army proportionally within the Soviet Union, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. And, in a concession to Gorbachev, NATO troops would keep out of what is now East Germany while some Red Army troops could stay there for ``a transitional period,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Protest in Park Across From White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material throughout; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A wide variety of political and religious demonstrators protested discreetly and without incident in Lafayette Square today as President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev began summit talks across the street in the White House. Two dozen Vietnamese refugees demanding democracy in their homeland sang patriotic songs and waved the former flag of South Vietnam. Nearby, 30 members of the ``New Testament Church'' carried banners denouncing the summit. ``Both Communist bloc and democratic rule are Satan's deceptions,'' read one sign. A self-described former Soviet political prisoner, Michail Makarenko, was accompanied by a man wearing a gas mask and a translator who carried signs calling for the Soviet Union to get out of Lithuania. Makarenko criticized the use of poison gas to put down an uprising in the Soviet republic of Georgia and alleged that 8,000 forced labor camps containing 14 million prisoners dot the Soviet Union. Meanwhile, a half-dozen Buddhists who favor total disarmament pounded drums as they sat cross-legged on the ground facing a small statue of Buddha and burned incense. Across the park, the Moscow rock group Gaza played for the second consecutive day in support of a cure for AIDS. About a dozen horse-mounted police officers and nearly 100 local and federal officers patrolled the park and adjacent streets. By midday, there were no arrests of demonstrators. Trees blocked most of the view of the park from the White House and the only electronic amplifiers were used by the rock band, so it was unlikely that Bush and Gorbachev saw or heard any of the colorful protests on the other side of Pennsylvania Avenue. U.S. Park Police Sgt. Peter Gentile said about a half-dozen organizations involving up to 2,000 people had been granted permits to demonstrate Thursday. But Gentile estimated that only 150 protesters had shown up by mid-morning. Vietnamese refugee Le Tuy, a 32-year-old car restorer who arrived in the United States in 1981, said he doubted the U.S. and Soviet leaders would see his group's pro-democracy demonstration. ``We try the best we can to raise our voice, the real voice of the Vietnamese people,'' Tuy said. ``With the help of the media, we can carry our message to the two presidents.'' Tuy's uncle, Nguyen Ngoc Bich, said the U.S. government still has some sway over Vietnam's leaders. ``They need several things from the United States,'' said Bich, who arrived in this country in 1975. ``They want normalization. They want to lift the trade embargo. We think there should be quid pro quo. We're asking for respect for human rights, for freedom to be restored and for a return to a more democratic system of government.'' Many groups that reserved space for the entire week at Lafayette Square, on the Ellipse behind the White House and at the Capitol's reflecting pool planned to make appearances only on certain days. Saturday should be the biggest day for demonstrations, said Park Police Maj. Carl Holmberg. He noted that Gorbachev and Bush plan to spend Saturday at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the mountains of western Maryland. In Lafayette Square on Wednesday, before Gorbachev's arrival from Canada, was Concepcion Picciotto, 45, who has been there since 1981 as part of an anti-nuclear peace vigil. ``I want to do something for humanity,'' she said. She handed out leaflets that read, ``Every gun that is made, every warship launched, ever rocket fired, signifies a theft from those who are hungry and are not fed, from those who are cold and are not clothed.''

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Probing Spate of Prostitute Murders in Capital Area
DOC.TEXT: Authorities investigating the killings of three young women in five days were trying to determine Thursday if they were linked to the apparent homicides of five prostitutes over the past year in the Washington area. The latest deaths have renewed fears among prostitutes who recall that last year's epidemic of slayings was never solved, said Prissy Williams-Godfrey, head of a prostitution-advocacy group. Alexandria police officer Don Hayes said detectives are going over the background of a woman found dead late Wednesday to find if she was ever arrested or had any connection to the other women killed recently. The woman, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, was found at the bottom of a grassy embankment. She was partially clothed, wrapped in a plastic bag and had her hands tied. There was no immediate word on how or when the woman had died. The bodies of two other women who police said had been arrested in the past on prostitution charges were found over the Memorial Day weekend within a mile of each other in neighboring Arlington County. ``We are working with other jurisdictions in the area trying to cover all possibilities at this time,'' said Arlington Detective Mike Rocconi. ``We are following several leads.'' He said he could not comment on whether there were similarities between the victims and the circumstances of their deaths. The two deaths followed five killings since April 1989 of women authorities said had worked as prostitutes. Autopsies of 20-year-old Sandra R. Johnson and 26-year-old Sherry Larman showed both women died of asphyxiation. Williams-Godfrey said another prostitute, whom she knew only as Cindy, has been missing since Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Officials See Little Risk From Chemical, Drug Residues
DOC.TEXT: Recent tests show that consumers run little health risk from drug, chemical and pesticide residues in meat and poultry, agriculture Department officials said Thursday. ``The residue rates are the lowest they've been in years,'' said Richard L. Carnevale, assistant deputy administrator of USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service. He released the latest testing results at a news briefing. The tests were performed on a broad range of food animals, including cattle, calves, swine, goats, sheep, chickens, turkeys and ducks. Department officials acknowledged growing consumer concern about the residues of pesticides, other farm chemicals such as fertilizers and drugs in the food that they buy at the grocery store. Such residues are found when drugs have been administered improperly and when the animals have eaten crops sprayed with chemicals. Carnevale, however, said pesticide and chemical residues were not shown to exist in illegal levels in the most recent tests and that only a few problems were found with drug residues. Young veal calves were one area of concern, he said. Illegal levels of residues were found in only 0.3 percent of the 41,505 samples tested in the agency's routine monitoring last year, he said. The Food Safety and Inspection Service conducts three types of residue testing programs. Carnevale said the routine monitoring system ``provides us with the most meaningful residue statistics.'' He said the results of testing 41,000 samples showed that statistically fewer than one out of 100 animals marketed contained illegal residues and perhaps as few as one in 1,000. He did announce that as a result of the test findings producers and others will have to present ``a full complement'' of signed statements before so-called bob veal calves _ less than 3 weeks old or 150 pounds _ would be accepted for slaughter. Carnevale said that certification program was needed because the monitoring program found 38 instances in which calves, primarily of the bob veal variety, contained excessive levels of sulfa and antibiotic compounds. Tests also showed high levels of sulfa residues in cull dairy cows _ ones that are no longer producing milk and are on their way to slaughter, Carnevale said. He said the potent antibiotic gentamicin is being used frequently in food animals, even though that is not permitted. He said USDA officials are notifying dairy producers through organizations such as the National Milk Producers Federation that better control of the use of such drugs in cull animals is needed. Carnevale said the high levels of sulfa and antibiotics are being found in the bob veal calves and cull animals because ``they are the most susceptible to infection'' and in some cases ``the farmer is trying to keep them alive'' and ``using everything he can find to get them to market.''

DOC.HEAD: After 50 Years, Circus Family May Finally be Buried
DOC.TEXT: More than 50 years after their deaths, circus magnate John Ringling and his wife, Mable, may be on their way to a final resting place. The 2nd District Court of Appeal in Lakeland on Wednesday upheld a judge's order last year allowing burial of the Ringlings at the Sarasota art museum that bears their name. Sarasota was the winter home of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and the Ringlings were benefactors of the museum. Ringling died in 1936, seven years after his wife. ``It means we're prepared to move forward with the appropriate memorial,'' said lawyer Lamar Matthews. Matthews represents Ringling's nephew Henry Ringling North in his quest to have the couple buried at the museum alongside North's mother, Ida North, who was Ringling's sister. Pat Buck, a grandniece of Ringling, had opposed burying Mrs. North with the Ringlings because she had nothing to do with the circus. Because of the dispute, Mrs. North's body has been in storage at a Sarasota funeral home since her death in 1950. North had the Ringlings' bodies moved in 1987 from Fairview, N.J., to crypts at a cemetery in nearby Port Charlotte. Buck and other relatives had taken the burial dispute into court. Family discord dates back over decades. The state-owned museum's board of trustees voted 8-1 last year to allow the burials on the museum grounds, provided family differences could be worked out. Museum director Laurence Ruggiero said he believes the appeals ruling will settle that question and allow the burials. ``As soon as I get assured by our attorney that the legal stuff is over with, we're going to proceed,'' Ruggiero said. Secretary of State Jim Smith, whose office oversees the museum, also has endorsed the burials.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Seen Slumping in Latest Government Report
DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories slumped 2.3 percent in April, helping to push orders for the year so far down 2 percent, the government said Thursday in a report showing further evidence of a slow manufacturing economy. ``Basically, it shows the manufacturing sector is still dead in the water,'' said Evelina Tainer, senior domestic economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. ``It's just not going anywhere.'' The Commerce Department said orders to factories for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $235.6 billion. That followed gains of 4 percent in March and 1.8 percent in February. Despite the gains, the April decline and a 5.5 percent drop in January means factory orders have fallen 2 percent in the year's first four months. And, the department said, orders have been relatively flat since the beginning of 1989. The January decline was the steepest since a 7 percent plunge in December 1974. Factory orders are a key economic barometer of manufacturing industry plans for production. A decrease in orders may forecast a slump in that sector and layoffs in the future. ``The decrease in April new orders was concentrated in the durable goods sector which declined ... 4.3 percent to $123.4 billion,'' the department said, revising the drop in durable orders from the 4.1 percent decline first reported last week. ``The largest decrease was in transportation equipment, down ... 14.7 percent to $31.7 billion,'' it added. ``Both motor vehicles and aircraft were down.'' Excluding transportation, orders were unchanged. Transportation orders had risen 24.1 percent in March and 10.1 percent in February. Also unchanged during April were non-durable orders, which remained at $112.2 billion. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders fell 9.8 percent to $36.9 billion after a 13.3 percent gain the previous month. Excluding aircraft, they were off 0.2 percent in April and 1.1 percent in March. Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said the capital goods spending report spells bad news for industrial production. ``Businesses are starting to pull in their horns,'' Evans said, because of high interest rates and ``a 16 percent decline in profits last year and, in the first quarter, they're not getting any better.'' The volatile defense category posted a 2 percent gain to $8 billion after advances of 4.5 percent in March and 18.3 percent in February. Excluding defense, orders fell 2.4 percent. Inventories ticked up 0.1 percent to $372.3 billion following two months of declines. But Ms. Tainer said, ``They remain lean.'' If inventories were to increase without a corresponding gain in orders, production cutbacks could occur as factories try to get rid of goods stored on shelves and backlots, often causing job layoffs. Besides transportation orders, other durable declines included orders for non-electrical machinery, down 2.9 percent to $21.7 billion, and primary metals, down 1.4 percent to $11.6 billion. Electrical machinery orders rose 4 percent to $20.4 billion after falling 1.7 percent in March and rising 2.8 percent in February.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Finds Raisa Gorbachev `Very Warm'
