DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with details of tea; picks up pvs 3rd graf bgng, The two; SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, Mrs. Bush wore, to identify suit as a Bill Blass; SUBS pvs 12th graf bgng, The two, to list daughters-in-law at tea.
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev renewed ``an old friendship'' at the White House today, sharing tea and conversation while the Bushes' pet dog, Millie, sat at the Soviet first lady's feet. There was an air of cordiality between the U.S. and Soviet presidents' wives from the moment the Gorbachevs arrived at the White House for the start of the four-day summit. After a ceremonial welcoming ceremony on the South Lawn and a diplomatic receiving line inside the White House, Mrs. Bush took her Soviet guest upstairs to the second-floor family quarters for tea and a tour that included the Lincoln Bedroom. Mrs. Bush's press secretary, Anna Perez, quoted the U.S. first lady as saying afterward, ``We had a great meeting renewing an old friendship.'' ``She said Mrs. Gorbachev was very knowledgable and very warm,'' said the spokeswoman. ``She said that Mrs. Gorbachev and Millie bonded,'' Ms. Perez added with a laugh. The English springer spaniel is a favorite of many White House visitors, and is quick to warm to strangers. ``Millie sat on Mrs. Gorbachev's foot and she followed her ... all over the house,'' the spokeswoman said. The first ladies had tea in the West Sitting Room, which overlooks the Rose Garden and the Oval Office where President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev began summit talks. Mrs. Bush was quoted as observing that Mrs. Gorbachev is ``very beautiful'' and having ``the most beautiful complexion.'' Earlier, Mrs. Bush put a gentle hand on Mrs. Gorbachev's back and guided her down a line of dignitaries to their appointed place on the White House South Lawn as their husbands took center stage for the arrival ceremony. The two first ladies exchanged pleasantries and an occasional laugh, waved to familiar faces in the crowd and watched the pageantry of unfold before them. The last time Mrs. Gorbachev visited Washington, in December 1987, she ruffled Nancy Reagan's feathers by observing that the White House was more a museum than ``a regular house.'' This time, cordiality reigned supreme. President Bush and his wife strolled out of the Rose Garden to greet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife on a driveway lined with soldiers holding American and Soviet flags. Mrs. Bush wore a Bill Blass suit, with a lime-green jacket trimmed in white over a white skirt, and her trademark triple strand of fake pearls. Mrs. Gorbachev wore a scarlet double-breasted jacket over a black skirt. Even in her black high heels, Mrs. Gorbachev was a couple of inches shorter than Mrs. Bush, who had on white pumps. As they walked down a line of VIPs and shook hands with Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and his wife, Susan, and other guests, Mrs. Bush put her hand on Mrs. Gorbachev's back, introducing her and guiding her along. Their places were marked in white on a green runner on the lawn, a few steps from the speaker's platform. During Bush's long opening remarks and Gorbachev's briefer response, Mrs. Gorbachev stood ramrod straight, clutching a black handbag in her right hand. Mrs. Bush, who had both hands free, often shifted from one foot to another and occasionally checked her watch. She led the applause when Bush said Mrs. Gorbachev's return to the White House ``brings joy to all of our hearts.'' The two first ladies had tea with two of Mrs. Bush's daughters-in-law, Margaret Bush of Alexandria, Va., and Susan Bush of Denver, as well as the the wives of Quayle, Baker, Assistant Secretary of State Ray Seitz, Jack Matlock, the U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union, and Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet ambassador to Washington. Later, Mrs. Gorbachev and her husband were having lunch at the Soviet Embassy with American film stars, intellectuals and other luminaries. This afternoon, while Gorbachev conferred again with Bush, Mrs. Gorbachev planned separate visits to the Library of Congress and the Capital Children's Museum. Industrialist Armand Hammer is host at a reception at the Library of Congress in the afternoon for Mrs. Gorbachev and 350 guests, including Marilyn Quayle, Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, and Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Co. Mrs. Gorbachev was to tour the library's Jefferson Building and cut the ribbon on an exhibit of Russian religious manuscripts, ``Living Traditions of Russian Faith: Books and Manuscripts of the Old Believers, Fifteenth Century to the Present.'' Next on the schedule is the Capital Children' Museum, which is teeming with hands-on, interactive exhibits for kids of all ages and draws 250,000 visitors a year. It is currently showing the works of Anton Kumankov, a Soviet writer-illustrator of children's books, who will be on hand to welcome Mrs. Gorbachev. Later the Gorbachevs return to the White House for a formal state dinner in their honor. They were last here in December 1987. The two first ladies will jet together to Massachusetts on Friday morning to address the graduates at Wellesley College and take in sights in the Boston area. They fly back to Washington that afternoon in time for the Gorbachevs to host a return dinner for the Bushes at the Soviet Embassy Friday night. Both first ladies will accompany their husbands to Camp David, Md., the mountain retreat 75 miles from Washington, on Saturday for what the White House billed as a day of relaxation.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Book Tells All on Turner and Company
DOC.TEXT: Robert Edward Turner III, a.k.a. ``Terrible Ted,'' ``Mouth of the South'' and ``Captain Outrageous,'' is short on words and long on bravado. Even when someone is writing a book about his baby, the Cable News Network. ``Ted's out there,'' said author Hank Whittemore, in what may be one of the understatements of the decade. ``He's like a brief tornado in your life.'' Whittemore has written ``CNN: The Inside Story,'' a 308-page chronicle of the little network that could. Its release Friday by Little, Brown & Co., coincides with CNN's 10th birthday. Excerpts have appeared in TV Guide. Some of the stories in the book have been told more times in more journalistic watering holes than Dan Rather's infamous seven-minute stroll off a live CBS newscast. Take, for example, the time a light bulb exploded in the CNN Washington bureau and ignited the clothing of on-camera reporter Dan Schorr. Or the time weatherman Stu Siroka was victimized by the Chromakey process, which allows one picture to be placed behind another. All viewers saw was Siroka's bald head, suspended above the weather map. Take Turner, who after agreeing to cooperate with Whittemore, would walk in to scheduled interviews and say ``Hi, Hank, how much time you want? I've got about nine minutes.'' Whittemore spent six months interviewing present and former CNN movers and shakers. His account tells a spirited and sometimes bizarre tale of how Turner, equipped with $100 million and even more chutzpah, screamed, bullied, sued, cajoled and bankrolled his way into television history by launching the first 24-hour all-news network. On cable. And here is Whittemore, the author a best seller called ``The Super Cops,'' magazine articles and television documentaries, on a nationwide tour to promote his book and calling from a pay phone in Washington's National airport. Asked to explain Turner, Whittemore pauses. There was an awards dinner in Kansas City that Whittemore attended recently. ``Now I'm still working on the book,'' Whittemore recounted, ``and he comes up to me and says `What are you going to write about me? Just don't make me out to be an ass.' ``Then he looks around and kind of beams, and says `Well, maybe I was.' ``I felt like I was in a Harold Robbins novel,'' Whittemore says, and laughs. ``The man will say the most outrageous things and you wonder `Is the man just not thinking or is he being very calculating?' '' Whittemore talked not only to Turner. He spent hours with Ted Kavanau, an early CNN executive who became president of Headline News only to be forced out, and Reese Schonfeld, the network's founding president, who also left, as well as former anchor Mary Alice Williams, now with NBC, and several others. ``CNN: The Inside Story'' begins in a dilapidated white clapboard house that was the network's first home and ends in the megalomaniac structure in Atlanta that now houses the international news agency. It copiously notes many weird tales of the upstart network, from the early days when work crews were literally finishing the set as anchor Bernard Shaw read the news. And the time a cleaning woman, not knowing Shaw was on live, walked right up to his desk and emptied his trash basket, and the time a reporter said that ``Mary Ass Williams'' was standing by, and yet another instance when a correspondent reported that scientists were trying to grow ``genetically engineered orgasms'' in the laboratory. But gaffes are not the only events noted. Loud and clear, Whittemore's book comes through with the underlying theme that CNN made television history by making the Big Three sit up and take notice. And by making CBS, NBC and ABC reluctantly admit they were no longer the only games in town. Round-the-clock news coverage gave CNN a number of firsts: President Reagan walking into a Washington, D.C., hospital after being shot; a split-screen of the hostages being released in Iran as Reagan was sworn into office, and a lonely cameraman perched atop a cherry-picker with the only live feed of a nuclear warhead being removed after an Air Force explosion in Arkansas. ``It seems to me that what they want to do is wire the entire world,'' Whittemore said. ``They want to be totally global, in terms of sending and receiving signals so that you get what Turner calls the world talking to itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen Pleads Guilty In `Wilding' Incident That Preceded Rape Of Jogger
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old charged in the Central Park ``wilding'' case pleaded guilty to assault today in connection with an attack on a male jogger the same night a female jogger was nearly killed. The defendant, Michael Briscoe, had not been charged in the infamous April 19, 1989, gang rape and beating attack on the woman investment banker, who was left for dead. Briscoe pleaded guilty to one count of second-degree assault, the top count in his indictment, before state Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan. The charge related to an attack by a gang of youths on David Lewis, 31, a banker who was jogging in the park the same night the woman was attackes. Galligan sentenced Briscoe to one year in prison in connection with the assault on Lewis. He could have been sentenced to seven years in prison on the second-degree assault charge. At the same time, Galligan sentenced him to one year for his guilty plea of May 7 to a charge of fifth-degree criminal sale of a controlled substance. That charge related to Briscoe's selling a small quantity of PCP, or ``angel dust,'' to an undercover police officer on March 4. Galligan ordered the sentences to run concurrently. Briscoe was one of eight teen-agers indicted in the assault on Lewis. Another of the defendants, Jermain Robinson, pleaded guilty to first-degree robbery in connection with the attack on Lewis and on another man jogging in the park, teacher John Loughlin. The other six defendants await trial in connection with attacks on Lewis and Loughlin as well as the rape and attempted murder of the woman jogger, a 29-year-old woman. The woman was attacked as she jogged on a park roadway and was left for dead in a muddy gully. She has since recovered remarkably from her physical injuries, doctors say, and has returned to work at Salomon Bros., where she is a vice president. Jury selection for the trial of three of the defendants is scheduled to begin June 13. Briscoe's lawyer, Joseph Klempner, said that as a condition of the plea, Briscoe must continue to talk to the prosecution about the Central Park case. But Klempner said he would be surprised if Briscoe ended up testifying and added, ``there's no deal here.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicu Ceausescu's Trial Suspended Until June 25
DOC.TEXT: A military court Wednesday suspended the trial of Nicu Ceausescu, son of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, until June 25 for further evidence and testimony from new witnesses. Nicu Ceausescu is charged with complicity in ``genocide'' for allegedly ordering security forces to fire on demonstrators during the December revolution that ended his father's 24-year dictatorship. At the time, Nicu Ceausesc was the Communist Party secretary of Sibiu County in central Romania. He pleaded innocent to the genocide charge but has pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of illegal possession of arms and ammunition. Witnesses have testified that Ceausescu only ordered troops to open fire when he was drunk. Maj. Dorel Ursu, president of the five-judge panel, agreed to allow 19 new witnesses to be called, including 10 civilians wounded in the revolution. He also agreed to a prosecution request to call Mirela Cosa, a girlfriend of Nicu Ceausescu who was in contact with him during the height of the revolution. During the trial, Ceausescu has been allowed to sit in the dock because he is still recovering from a stab wound inflicted Dec. 22, the day he was captured and his parents overthrown. The ousted dictator and his wife were executed Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Hit Region After Quake; Death Toll Rises to 13
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs and subs 14th, `Dumitru with 1 graf to UPDATE death toll to 13, 100 aftershocks, no. hospitalized. Pickup 4th, `There were...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: A strong aftershock jolted Romania and Bulgaria early today, sending panicked people back into the streets and damaging more buildings a day after a major earthquake killed at least 13 people. The aftershock struck at 3:18 a.m. and was the strongest of about 100 recorded after Wednesday's quake, which was felt from Moscow to Istanbul and caused major damage to buildings in Romania and Bulgaria, officials said. Romania's Ministry of Health reported today that nine people were killed in Wednesday's quake and 994 people sought hospital treatment. A ministry communique carried by Radio Bucharest said 207 people were hospitalized. The temblor also killed one person in Bulgaria and three in the Soviet Union. There were no immediate reports of casualties today. The Bulgarian news agency BTA said that, like Wednesday's quake, today's aftershock was centered in the Carpathian Mountain region of Vrancea in northern Romania. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., measured Wednesday's quake at 6.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion and today's main aftershock at 5.9. A strong earthquake also struck near Mexico City today, frightening residents but apparently causing no serious damage or injuries. The quake registered 6.1 on the Richter scale. Damage from the aftershock appeared most serious in Vrancea County, 190 miles northeast of Bucharest, where the state news agency Rompress reported ``panic and a large amount of material damage.'' Severely damaged were the mayor's house, a theater, a medical center, the national bank and a building with 60 apartments in the county capital of Focsani, it said. In northern Bulgaria, thousands of people frightened by the aftershock reportedly spent the night in the street, or fled their cities. Cities and villages on the Danube river, including Ruse, Silistra and Svishtov ``were panic stricken,'' BTA said. It said thousands of people milled around city streets all night, or fled in their cars. The city of Silistra has appealed for aid, saying it urgently needed glass, cement, bricks and tiles to repair damaged homes, schools, kindergartens and the lone hospital, the agency said. In Bucharest, people fled into the streets and stood in small groups under dim lights. In the Bucharest Hotel, about a dozen people remained in the lobby, frightened to go upstairs. Dumitru Enescu, director of Romania's Earth Physics Institute, told Rompres that 100 aftershocks were recorded in the first 26 hours after Wednesday's quake. Prof. Stefan Tataru, chief of a seismic station in Vrancea County, told Rompres that about 10 of the aftershocks registered between 3 and 4 on the Richter Scale and the rest were of lower intensity. Damage reports from Wednesday's quake continued to filter into the capital. In Urziceni, 38 miles east of Bucharest, the roof of a technical-medical store collapsed, destroying the building. Nobody was injured. In the capital Wednesday, chunks of concrete from high-rise buildings crashed to the ground, crushing two people to death. Ceilings fell, walls cracked, books toppled from shelves, and tens of thousands of people rushed into the streets, many crying and screaming in fear. Romanians leaped in panic from windows and balconies, and some were badly hurt, ambulance officials said. The quake hit when Bucharest's streets were crowded with lunch-hour shoppers and pedestrians. It lasted about 45 seconds and was the third major earthquake since 1977 with its epicenter in the Romanian Carpathians. The Uppsala Seismological Center in Sweden said it was felt so widely because it was about 63 miles deep. ``I think it was this deafening sound of cracking walls that scared people,'' said clerical worker Sica Burcea, 52. ``The building was swinging horizontally and vertically. We were lucky only to have some cracks in the walls. I shivered when I realized 1977 was coming back.'' More than 1,500 Romanians died in a 1977 earthquake. In the Soviet republic of Moldavia, which borders Romania, the quake left three people dead and six hospitalized but caused little structural damage, the chairman of the national legislature said today. Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov said in Moscow that one person died in Moldavia after jumping out a second-floor window and two elderly people died of heart attacks, the official Tass news agency reported. BTA said one person died in Silistra of a quake-induced heart attack. A communique from Romania's General Inspectorate of Police said two people died in Bucharest, two in the Danube River port of Braila, and one each in eastern Buzau, southeastern Ialomita, central Brasov and nearby Prahova County. Food shop clerk Petruta Lungu was killed in Bucharest when she ran outside and was hit by bricks and concrete falling from an upstairs wall, police said. A man's body was pulled from rubble outside the shop. The inspectorate reported 296 people injured, 45 critically. It said 35 of the critically injured were in Bucharest, where 102 people were hurt. In Moscow, where the quake shook buildings, Soviet officials said it was felt from the Crimea to the Baltics and damaged dozens of buildings in the southwest. Telephone lines were knocked out and buildings shook in at least four Soviet republics. In Istanbul, the Anatolia News Agency said tremors were felt in eastern Thrace in Turkey and elsewhere around the Marmara Sea region. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measured by the ground motion recorded by seismographs. A quake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage. One of magnitude 7 is reckoned as a major earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: Former Owners Charged With Illegal Disposal of Hazardous Waste, Napalm Bombs
DOC.TEXT: A defunct storage company and its former president have been charged with conspiracy to illegally dispose of hazardous wastes, including surplus napalm bombs, near people's homes, officials said today. ``This case represents perhaps the most serious type of environmental misconduct,'' U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said at a news conference. He said that the 12-count federal grand jury indictment was the first federal felony prosecution of environmental crime in Utah. The company, EKOTEK, and its officers had ``duped environmentally conscious businesses into believing that waste materials were being properly disposed of,'' Thornburgh said. The indictment alleges the company knowingly burned, poured out and improperly stored a variety of hazardous wastes in violation of an array of state and federal laws in the middle and late 1980s. The site is now on the Superfund cleanup list. Among the incidents leading to the indictment was that of a 17-year-old boy who reported that his shoe began to bubble and disintegrate after he accidentally stepped in some liquid while running near the site, officials said. Tests have been conducted around 125 homes near the site. The charges were filed Wednesday afternoon in U.S. District Court. Named in the indictment were EKOTEK and Steven M. Self, the company's president. The company was involuntarily dissolved Nov. 1. If convicted on all charges, Self could face a prison term of up to 45 years, and he and the company would face up to $24 million in fine. Company vice president Steven F. Miller pleaded guilty Wednesday to felony charges of conspiracy and violations of federal resource conservation and recovery laws and the Clean Water Act, Thornburgh said. Miller was allowed to plead guilty in exchange for his cooperation in the prosecution of Self, authorities said. He could face up to 13 years in prison and a $750,000 fine; sentencing was set for July 10. Self and his company are alleged to have purchased millions of gallons of oil and solvents and burned them as fuel in a refinery in northern Salt Lake City about three miles northwest of the downtown area. The burning violated the federal Clean Air Act. In other cases, wastes were illegally poured into storm drains or stored in an improper manner. State Department of Health officials said tens of thousands of gallons of the wastes have leaked into the ground and contaminated nearby homes. In addition, the indictment alleges that in July 1986, Self arranged to accept two napalm bombs for ``testing, storage and treatment'' from the Navy Weapons Support Center in Fallbrook, Calif. State explosives experts had to haul the bombs away and dispose of them in 1987. The site, currently being cleaned up through the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund program, reportedly still contains almost a half million gallons of used petroleum products and other toxic wastes in leaking tanks and drums. Among the chemicals found at the plant were poisonous polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs; methylene chloride, which has been linked to tumors; and the toxic solvents n-butyl acetate, methyl ethyl ketone, toluene and xylene. The site was identified for EPA cleanup in 1988. The agency has identified 32 companies as being responsible for cleanup of approximately 500,000 gallons of aging, used petroleum products and other hazardous wastes at the site. EKOTEK-Petrochem formerly operated an oil refinery on the site. The state Division of Environmental Health had determined it might pose a risk to nearby residents and the EPA took soil samples from land surrounding about 125 homes earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Company Agrees To Replace Water Coolers With Lead Contamination
DOC.TEXT: Schools and other owners of old water coolers that put too much lead into drinking water can receive free replacements under a final agreement announced Thursday by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission. Under terms of the consent agreement, the Halsey Taylor Division of Scotsman Group Inc. will mail notices of the replacement offer to public and private school officials; universities and colleges; day care centers with enrollments of 10 or more; and headquarters for the YMCA, the YWCA and boys and girls clubs. It also will run advertisements in trade journals aimed at public building managers. The offer to provide either a replacement cooler or a cash refund _ at the option of the cooler owner _ applies to any Halsey Taylor model made prior to 1979 that tests show emits excessive amounts of lead _ more than 20 parts per billion _ into the water passing through it. Halsey Taylor models made since 1979 do not have internal water storage tanks and are not under suspicion. The Consumer Product Safety Commission maintains that a lead-dip used on the exterior of some pre-1979 models to help attach cooling coils to the tank resulted in lead migrating to the inside of the tank and into the stored water. The Vernon Hills, Ill., company denied that any of its products constituted a health risk, but said in a statement signed on April 2 by Scotsman Group President Richard C. Osborne that it was agreeing to the replacement program ``for the purpose of resolving this matter without resorting to protracted administrative and judicial proceedings.'' At a news conference to publicize the replacement program, commission officials said they could not estimate how many of the thousands of pre-1979 Halsey Taylor water coolers might dispense water with unacceptably high lead levels, and that the only way to be sure is to test each cooler. One complication is that such lead levels could be in the water before it reached the cooler. Michael Cooke, head of the Environmental Protection Agency's drinking water office, said thousands of EPA tests at schools have disclosed unacceptably high lead levels at 10 percent to 20 percent of ``outlets'' tested. However, outlets are not limited to water coolers. They also include bathroom and kitchen sinks and uncooled water fountains. The company has established a toll-free number to provide further information _ 1-800-635-2358 _ and has designated a special mailing address: Halsey Taylor Water Cooler Program, 775 Corporate Woods Parkway, Vernon Hills, Ill., 60061.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says He'll Put Aside Differences With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin, the new president of the Russian Federation and a leading critic of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Thursday he will try to make peace in his personal feud with the Soviet president. Yeltsin, a radical reformer, was quoted by the official Tass news agency as saying he would put aside personal differences with Gorbachev when the president returns from the Washington summit. Yeltsin was seeking to calm the fears of the deputies of the republic's Congress about his stormy relationship with Gorbachev, his former mentor. In his new position as president of Russia, the largest Soviet republic, Yeltsin has a formidable platform from which to challenge and criticize Gorbachev, who opposed his election. Deputies speaking Thursday at the Russian Congress ``expressed concern over the exchange of statements about each other'' by Yeltsin and Gorbachev, Tass reported. Yeltsin answered that after Gorbachev returns June 4 from the summit in Washington, ``I think we'll have an appropriate conversation, and we'll resolve most issues without damaging the sovereignty and aims of Russia,'' Tass said. At a news conference Wednesday, Yeltsin called for achieving Russian ``sovereignty'' within 100 days. The term is used here to mean not independence, but autonomy in most internal decisions. Yeltsin also urged the Kremlin to allow the other 14 republics to enjoy the same autonomy, making the country a federation of states that could overrule the central government on most matters. Although Yeltsin said he wanted a ``businesslike'' relationship with Gorbachev, he also made an oblique call Thursday for Gorbachev to give up one of his posts: either Soviet president or Communist Party general secretary. ``I am against combining any post in one person. And I am talking not just about the chairmanship of the party at the Russian level, at the regional level, or at the local level,'' he said. In Ottawa on Tuesday, Gorbachev said he was ``somewhat concerned'' about Yeltsin's victory and feared that if Yeltsin ``is playing a political game, then we may be in for a difficult time.'' There have been no reports that Gorbachev sent congratulations to Yeltsin on his election. Gorbachev brought Yeltsin to Moscow to head the city's Communist Party but fired him in 1987 after Yeltsin publicly criticized the pace of reform. Relations have been strained ever since. Yeltsin capped a remarkable political comeback by winning election Tuesday as Russian president. However, at Thursday's session of the Russian Congress, Deputy Ivan Galushko from the Jewish autonomous region in the Soviet Far East said Yeltsin was overstepping his authority with some of his statements the day before. He called on Yeltsin ``to refrain from hasty statements on questions that are within the competence of the Congress or Supreme Soviet.'' Tass said many deputies seconded Galushko's opinion. In his reply, Yeltsin acknowledged disagreements with Gorbachev but said he would put them aside. ``True, we have our differences,'' said Yeltsin. ``I renounce all these personal aspects fully and completely. I leave that behind.'' A deputy of the national Supreme Soviet legislature, Anatoly Denisov, said in an interview that the differences between Yeltsin and Gorbachev are so pronounced they portend ``very bad consequences'' and ``difficult conflicts'' for the nation. He said they could lead to the imposition of Soviet presidential rule nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters of Varying Political Stripes Seek Attention of Summit Partners
DOC.TEXT: Two dozen Vietnamese refugees waved the former South Vietnamese flag and sang patriotic songs as they urged President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday to push for democracy in their homeland. They were but one of many ethnic, political and religious groups trying to send a message across Pennsylvania Avenue to the superpower leaders meeting in the White House. At the height, there were some 400 people massed in Lafayette Park, according to Maj. Carl Holmberg of the U.S. Park Police. He said there were no arrests by early afternoon. The orderly protesters included a self-described former Soviet political prisoner, a half-dozen Koreans and the same number of Buddhists and about 75 Cubans who were moved to the Ellipse behind the White House. Also gathered there were some 30 members of the New Testament Church, Afghans who want the Soviet Union to stop supporting the government there, and a Moscow rock band that wants the two nations to cure AIDS, not build more missiles. Police presence was heavy. About a dozen horse-mounted officers plus close to 100 local and federal officers patrolled the park and kept demonstrators and pedestrians away from Pennsylvania Avenue when Gorbachev was inside the White House. Trees block most of the view between the park and the White House, and the only electronic amplification was used by the rock group, so it was unlikely Gorbachev or Bush heard or saw any of the colorful protests. Holmberg predicted that Saturday would be the biggest day for demonstrations, even though Bush and Gorbachev are scheduled to be out of town then at Camp David, the president retreat in Maryland. Vietnamese refugee Le Tuy, who arrived here in 1981, said he expected the U.S. and Soviet leaders would not see his group's signs or hear its songs. But he said, ``With the help of the media, we can carry our message to the two presidents.'' Tuy's uncle, Nguyen Ngoc Bich, contended that despite the Vietnam War, the U.S. government still has some sway over the current leaders in Vietnam. ``They need several things from the United States,'' said Bich, who arrived here in 1975. ``They want normalization. They want to lift the trade embargo. We think there should be quid pro quo. We're asking for respect for human rights, for freedom to be restored and for a return to a more democratic system of government.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Taker Captured After Cutting Own Throat
DOC.TEXT: A former mental patient who once tried to hijack a plane killed his 75-year-old father, took a woman hostage at an eye clinic and cut his own throat before police captured him, authorities said. Ralph Adolphys Hughes, 38, was in stable condition at a Tyler hospital Thursday with a self-inflicted knife wound to his throat and two police gunshot wounds to the leg, authorities said. ``The tactical officers fired two shots when they went in, but none were life-threatening,'' said Lt. Robin Roberts. ``He did cut his throat. He cut a fairly good gash but nothing life-threatening.'' The woman Hughes held hostage for 3{ hours Wednesday wasn't injured. Police found the body of Hughes' father, Leon, in the vehicle the younger Hughes drove to the DeHaven Eye Associates Clinic, where Barbara Shamburger was taken hostage. ``Right now, it looks like they had some kind of argument in the car,'' said Tom Giorgio, a police spokesman. ``He said God made him do it. That's what he told his mother on the phone,'' Justice of the Peace Bill Beaird said. He said an autopsy showed the elder Hughes died of two stab wounds to the heart. Investigators filed murder, aggravated assault and aggravated kidnapping charges against Hughes. Beaird recommended that Hughes be held in lieu of $1 million bond when he is arraigned. In 1987, Hughes was acquitted of an air piracy charge by reason of insanity. He was accused of holding a flight attendant at knifepoint moments before a plane carrying 200 people landed at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport on Feb. 5, 1986. No one was harmed. Defense attorney R.H. Wallace said at the time that Hughes had regained his sanity and would be all right, ``as long as he's on medication.'' Police said Hughes appeared Wednesday at television station KLTV brandishing a knife. He was covered with blood and demanded to be allowed on the air. He left after station employees called police, said Giorgio. Shortly after that, Hughes entered the eye clinic, said Donna Rayborn, the clinic's manager of administrative services. Ms. Rayborn said the clinic employs about 60 people and had about 10 patients inside at the time. Detectives had not determined a reason for Hughes' behavior, Giorgio said. ``We tried to negotiate with him,'' Giorgio said. ``They waited as long as they could, but about 3{ hours into it they decided the negotiations were going nowhere and they went in.'' Police knocked out a window at the clinic and threw in a stun grenade before rescuing Mrs. Shamburger. Psychiatrists who treated Hughes after the plane incident said he was schizophrenic and unable to distinguish friends from enemies. During the hijacking attempt, authorities said, Hughes demanded protection for himself and his family from mob killers who he believed were on the plane. He said killers were after him because of a romantic relationship he had with the girlfriend of a narcotics kingpin.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Rescinds Law on East German Resettlers
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers on Thursday repealed a 40-year-old law giving East German resettlers special benefits, and they tightened rules on ethnic Germans emigrating from elsewhere in Eastern Europe. The decision to repeal the law on resettlers is expected to gain automatic approval of the Bundesrat, or upper house of parliament. The effective date for repealing the law is July 1, one day before monetary, social and economic union of the two Germanys is to take effect. The law provided special benefits, including housing and financial assistance, for East German resettlers to West Germany and granted them automatic West German citizenship. Repealing the law means that East Germans will be treated exactly like West Germans who decide to move to other parts of the country. More than 500,000 East Germans have resettled in West Germany since January 1989. The influx last fall brought on the downfall of the hard-line East German Communist government and led to the country's first free elections in March. But East Germans continued to flood into West Germany, straining West Germany's already tight housing and social services. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government resisted cutting the resettlers' benefits until the monetary union takes effect. In addition to the East Germans, some 175,000 ethnic Germans from other East European countries have arrived in West Germany this year. The legislators Thursday tightened requirements for ethnic Germans emirgating from East Europe. They must now apply at West German embassies to be recognized as ethnic Germans in their homelands before they are granted permission to immigrate to West Germany. In the past, the emigres could arrive in West Germany and then apply to be recognized as ethnic Germans.

DOC.HEAD: Weary Gorbachev Will Rap with Private Americans as Well as Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new with Gorbachev luncheon, picks up 4th graf pvs, bgng, `But he,' Edits to tighten
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hosting a luncheon for American thinkers and performers, said today he needs time to accomplish radical economic reforms in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, tossed a lunch party for some of America's best-known personalities including actress and aerobics guru Jane Fonda, actor Gregory Peck, writer Ray Bradbury and former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. Jesse Jackson was the only politician on the guest list. In his remarks, Gorbachev appealed for more cooperation between the Americans and the Soviets, and told his guests that, like a pregnant woman, his country needs at least nine months to give birth to economic reforms. ``We need time,'' he said to his guests who were seated at crystal-laden tables underneat chandeliers in an ornate reception room at the Soviet Embassy. The Gorbachevs are staying at the building about six blocks from the White House. Others on the guest list included Robert Redford, Burt Lancaster, Frank Sinatra, Jack Lemmon, Dizzy Gillespie and Van Cliburn, J. Carter Brown, director of the National GIt said the main reason was an upswing in fruit and vegetable imports from Latin America in the wake of December's freeze in Florida and Texas. The department forecast the U.S. agricultural surplus for the year at $18 billion, only a shade below that for fiscal 1989. The surplus had been rising steadily since fiscal 1986 when it skidded to an anemic $5.4 billion. In terms of volume, the estimate of $150 million tons is up from last year's total of $146.4 million. The forecast puts exports of grains and feeds at $16.3 billion, wheat and flour at $5.1 billion, rice at $800 million, coarse grains overall at $7.9 billion and corn at $6.9 billion. It estimates total exports of oilseeds and their products at $5.9 billion, with soybeans at $3.7 billion, soybean cake and meal $900 million and soybean oil at $400 million. The forecast was for livestock products of $5.5 billion, poultry and products $800 million, dairy products $400 million, horticultural products $5 billion, tobacco $1.3 billion, cotton and linters $2.9 billion, seeds $600 million and sugar and tropical products $1.4 billion.

USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service is proposing to lower from 25 percent to 22 percent the limit on fat in ground beef under its institutional meat purchase specifications used by schools, hospitals and the armed services. The change would be part of a broader revision of the institutional meat specifications, the department announced. It said the move was designed to reflect increased consumer interest in lower-fat beef. ``Its a step in the right direction,'' said Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``They could do more.'' Currently, USDA defines lean beef as having no more than 10 percent fat by weight but makes an exception for ground beef and puts its level at 22.5 percent. ``That's why I like to speak of so-called lean ground beef,'' Liebman said. Regular ground beef can range up to 30 percent fat by weight. Under the institutional purchase specifications, the limit applies only if the buyer does not negotiate to obtain the beef at a different level of fat.

USDA is cosponsoring a National Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resources Conference on Aug. 15-18 in Lincoln, Neb. Sustainable agriculture refers to growing techniques that reduce reliance on pesticides and other chemicals that have been shown to pose health risks. ``The conference is designed to achieve a profitable agriculture that is environmentally sound, resource efficient, socially acceptable and thus sustainable in the future,'' said Charles E. Hess, assistant secretary of agriculture for science and education. The conference will bring together educators, government officials, farmers, agribusiness executives and environmentalists, USDA said. It said they would ``develop guidelines to form state teams to implement programs for sustainable agriculture throughout the nation.'' Other sponsors include the Rodale Institute, Dupont Co., the American Forestry Association and the Wildlife Management Institute.

DOC.HEAD: ``Mad Cow'' Disease Turns Into French-English Beef
DOC.TEXT: The British ``mad cow'' disease has now made Britain mad at France, which rejected demands Thursday that it lift its ban on imports of beef from across the Channel. British officials were irate when France imposed the temporary ban on British beef Wednesday. The French say the beef may be tainted by bovine spongiform encephalitis, the nervous disorder known as ``mad cow'' disease. Taking up Britain's cause, the European Community on Thursday criticized the French action and demanded the ban be lifted. But French Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said the ban will stay in place at least until the return this weekend of a team of French veterinarians sent to Britain to assess the disease. Nallet acknowledged that his ``difficult decision'' had been denounced abroad but said he acted to avert ``worry and panic'' among French consumers. France buys more than half of Britain's beef exports, by far the biggest market. British officials accused France of using the disease as an excuse to protect France's domestic market. ``They ought to lift that ban straightaway,'' said Francis Maud, British minister of state in the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. ``British beef is perfectly safe. All the scientific evidence points in that direction. This French ban is unjustified and clearly in breach of Community Law, and as good Europeans we find that intolerable.'' Other Western European countries have banned imports of cattle from Britain, but they have not banned beef imports. Two associations representing the French beef industry praised the ban, saying their profits were being hurt by a flood of low-priced beef imports after British customers began shying away from the product. Not all the French took the ban seriously. Jacques Cagna, a well-known Paris chef, posed for a photograph in his restaurant holding a platter of British beef, which he vowed to serve to his patrons. The cause of the disease is not known. Because the symptoms are similar to scrapie, a sheep disease, it is assumed the disease was transmitted through cattle feeds. They use sheep offal as a protein supplement. The British government is sponsoring research on the disease, which was identified in Britain in 1986. The outbreak has largely been confined there. The disease, which has killed 13,648 cows in Britain, eats holes in the brains of infected cattle and makes their tissue spongy. British officials say there is no indication the disease can be transmitted to humans, but beef sales have dropped sharply in Britain. The European Community Commission, in its statement Thursday, said it ``regrets ... the action of the French authorities, taken without prior consultation.'' EC Agricultural Commissioner Ray McSharry said there was ``absolutely no justification'' for France's action.

DOC.HEAD: Realtors' Group Says Homes More Affordable
DOC.TEXT: Lower prices and higher consumer incomes boosted the typical American family's ability to buy an existing single-family home in April, a real estate trade group said Thursday. The National Association of Realtors said its housing affordability index reached 104.6 in April, up from 103.9 in March. That means a family earning the median income of $34,032 had 104.6 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a median-priced home costing $95,300. The median income means half the families earned more and half less. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less. The median price of a home in April declined $1,000 from March, meaning the income needed to qualify for a loan dropped $96 to $32,544. At the same time, the median family income rose $108. Realtors president Norman D. Flynn said the typical price of an existing home in many cities is below the national median. The Commerce Department reported on Wednesday that the median price of a new home was $135,900 in April, but analysts generally agreed that reflected a big jump in new home sales in the expensive Northeastern market that month. The median had been $119,400 in March. The housing affordability index would have been higher in April, the Realtors said, except for an increase in the interest rate used to compute the index from 10.07 percent in March to 10.15 percent in April. The mortgage rate used to calculate the index is a composite of closing rates offered for both fixed-rate mortgages and adjustable-rate mortgages for existing homes as reported by the Federal Housing Finance Board. ``We do expect a gradual decline in rates in the third quarter to stimulate a healthy home buying season this summer,'' said John A. Tuccillo, the Realtors' chief economist. The Realtors said the changes in the index _ home price, mortgage rate and income _ resulted in a $2 decrease in monthly mortgage payments to $678. Under April's affordability conditions, the Realtors said, a family earning $20,000 would qualify for a $58,500 home using a $46,800 loan. A family earning $30,000 would qualify for a $87,500 home with a $70,200 loan. A family earning $40,000 would qualify for a $117,000 home with a $93,600 loan, and a family with $50,000 income would qualify for a $146,300 home with a $117,000 loan. But Flynn noted buyers may still face a major hurdle in obtaining down payments even with incomes sufficient to qualify for loans.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Marcos Collapses at Defense Table, Bleeding From Mouth, Nose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from doctor. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The incident...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos collapsed at the defense table during her fraud trial today, her mouth and nose bleeding, and was admitted to a hospital. Mrs. Marcos, 60, uttered a faint cry before she slumped forward, and attorneys and family members rushed to her aid. She was taken, apparently unconscious, to a nurses station in the federal courthouse, and then by ambulance to New York Hospital. Dr. David Case, who has been treating Mrs. Marcos for high blood pressure, said at midafternoon that tests were under way on Mrs. Marcos' digestive system to determine what was wrong. Her condition is stable and she will be admitted to the hospital, he said. Asked whether the condition she suffered today could be stress-related, he said, ``It could be.'' Asked if it was life-threatening, he said, ``Not at the moment.'' He said he doesn't think the problem is related to high blood pressure. ``I think the agony of a lengthy, drawn-out trial is taking its toll on her as it has on all of us,'' said Benjamin Cassiday, one of Mrs. Marcos' lawyers. It was the third time in the past month _ and the most serious _ that Mrs. Marcos became ill in court, prompting the judge to call a recess. The incident occurred just as another of Mrs. Marcos' attorneys, Gerry Spence, completed his cross-examination of a witness. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan ordered the courtroom cleared after several minutes of confusion. Spence said later Keenan had offered to recess the trial earlier in the day when informed that Mrs. Marcos was feeling ill, but that Mrs. Marcos ``wanted to continue. She didn't want the trial recessed.'' According to James Linn, attorney for Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, Mrs. Marcos hemorrhaged from her nose and mouth as she fell forward and clutched her left hand to the side of her head. ``It was terrible,'' said Khashoggi. ``I never saw so much blood come out of someone.'' Linn, who was sitting with his client about eight feet from Mrs. Marcos, said she appeared to have fainted. Others said she apparently was not fully conscious as she was taken from the courtroom. Keenan recessed the trial until Tuesday. As on previous occasions, the illness occurred as testimony involving her family was being heard. The witness, Robert Shaheen, had just finished telling about dealings between Mrs. Marcos and her husband, the late President Ferdinand Marcos, and Khashoggi. Mrs. Marcos is accused of having helped her late husband steal more than $220 million from their country's treasury. He was deposed as Philippine leader in 1986, at which time the couple moved to Hawaii. Khashoggi is charged with fraud and obstructing justice for allegedly faking documents to show that he owned real estate and artwork of the Marcoses'. The trial began in late March.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Will Probe, Perhaps Seize Vast Holdings of Old Regime
LaserPhoto BER3
DOC.TEXT: East German lawmakers Thursday gave the government broad powers to seize land, houses and businesses controlled by the privileged elite of the old Communist regime. The action freezes the party's vast holdings _ amassed after it came to power after World War II _ just four weeks before the nation merges its economy with West Germany's and begins shifting state property to the private sector. Lawmakers also voted to remove the old Communist insignia, a hammer and drafting compass, from state buildings. The government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere had asked Parliament to let him form a commission that would have the power to wrest away the holdings of the many organizations that existed under the former government. De Maiziere is to form the commission in the coming days, after which all land, buildings and enterprises owned by the Communists would be held in trust pending an investigation of their value and legitimacy. The new law also gives the commission power to interrogate witnesses, search houses and seize evidence during its investigation. The law calls for a system to be set up under which the government could reclaim the property in the public interest, even if the property is in other countries. The proposal came as the young democratic government grapples with the monumental task of converting state-owned property to private ownership, a prerequisite to unification with West Germany. The German states are to merge their economies and social institutions on July 2, when West German currency will become the currency of East Germany. The independent property commission is to report its findings to Parliament just two days before the economic union becomes official. Lawmaker Gregor Gysi, leader of the reconstituted Communist Party that now supports a form of democratic socialism, sharply criticized the proposal during a bitter nine-hour Parliament session. ``They want all opposition eliminated,'' said Gysi, whose party is now called the Party of Democratic Socialism. ``That is the goal and nothing else.'' He said his party already has surrendered a large part of its property. Richard Schroeder, leader of the Social Democratic lawmakers in Parliament, said the proposal is aimed at shedding light on who owns what in the country. ``We should bring clarity and light to the property proportion,'' he said. ``We have the impression that the history of the former Communist Party property is still being written.'' The property investigation would cover all parties, unions and organizations that came into being after 1945, but is clearly aimed at the assets of the old regime. It would technically include de Maiziere's own Christian Democrats, who were allowed to exist as a formal party. Large amounts of property are believed held by former Communists. Prosecutors on Thursday charged a former district Communist Party chief from the city of Erfurt, Gerhard Mueller, with breach of trust and theft, the government news agency ADN said. Mueller, 62, was arrested in December. He is accused of building a luxurious hunting lodge with three baths at a cost of $210,000 in public money. Many questions remain about the pace and process of distributing land and industries owned by the state to private hands. West Germany wants West Germans to be able to reclaim any property they lost in East Germany when the Communists came to power. East Germany wants its citizens to have first crack at the property. East Germans are expected to face a rough transition to a free market in July. Widespread joblessness and rising prices are expected as socialist subsidies are eliminated and outmoded, state-supported factories are forced to compete. East Germans fearing higher prices have been lining up at grocery stores to stock up on food and other household goods, creating huge shortages of meat, milk and other necessities, officials said. Lawmaker Vera Wollenberger said meat was selling out in stores within one hour of opening in the cities of East Berlin and Halle. Commerce Minister Sybille Reider said consumer demand has increased 300 percent to 400 percent in recent days. Soap, bread and other goods are selling out, she said. A line formed early Thursday at a large East Berlin grocery store selling both East German and West German goods. Clerk Jutta Petrick said the crush of hoarders began about two weeks ago. ``We are running out of everything,'' she said, gesturing to the sparse shelves.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Measure Asks $332 Million for San Francisco Earthquake Work
DOC.TEXT: San Francisco officials don't want to wait until the next big earthquake to repair and protect about two dozen municipal buildings, including City Hall, from the ravages of a major tremor. So nearly eight months after the Oct. 17 quake, voters are being asked Tuesday to approve the city's largest-ever bond measure to pay for quake repairs and quake-proofing. Mayor Art Agnos and other city leaders are pushing Proposition A, which would allow the city to raise $332 million to pay for quake repairs and seismic improvements to the city-owned buildings during the next decade. ``You cannot escape the reality that this work has to be done,'' said Rudy Nothenberg, the city's chief administrative officer. There has been little controversy surrounding Proposition A, he said. The measure has been unanimously endorsed by the city Board of Supervisors and faces no opposition from other groups. ``This is work the city would have had to do in any event sooner or later, and given our experience in the last year, we thought sooner rather than later,'' said Nothenberg. The biggest chunk of the money _ $207 million _ would be spent preparing about 20 buildings, including City Hall and the War Memorial Opera House, for another quake. The second priority would be addressing the estimated $53 million in needed earthquake-damage repairs left over from the October quake. An additional $26 million would be spent to fix underground sewer lines and pipes at the San Francisco Zoo that fractured in the quake. The federal government may eventually reimburse the city for an undetermined amount of the repair costs, Nothenberg said. The quake, which measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, caused more than $7 billion in damage in Northern California. A month after the earthquake, voters approved an $60 million bond issue for emergency repairs and some initial seismic strengthening. Most of the buildings on the Proposition A list are in critical need of strengthening or repairs because of the numbers of people that use them. City Hall requires the most time-consuming and expensive work. It will cost about $94 million to make the building more quake resistant through a method called ``base isolation,'' Nothenberg said. City Hall would be separated from its foundation and placed on rollers that would absorb some of the shock when the next quake hits, he said. An additional $23 million would be spent to fix a crack in the plaster of the rotunda and reattach loose marble on walls and archways. The bond issue also would pay for less expensive repairs and reinforcements to the 3,000-seat Opera House, the 10,000-seat Civic Auditorium, the Veterans Building and the Public Health building.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Australian rock band Midnight Oil took their music and environment theme to the streets, performing amid the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan for a lunchtime crowd. ``We've got a megacrisis on our hands that we all have to approach,'' lead singer Peter Garrett said after Wednesday's performance. ``We've got a crisis that our leaders, corporations and governments have a prime responsibility to address seriously.'' The band is on a U.S. tour to promote their new album, `Blue Sky Mining.'' Although they have been performing for 10 years, their U.S. breakthrough wasn't until 1987 with their hit song ``Beds Are Burning'' from their album ``Diesel and Dust.'' Their songs concentrate on the ecosystem, world peace, and corporate greed. At the invitation of Midnight Oil, the environmental group Greenpeace sets up information tables at each concert. Garrett is also an attorney and president of the Australian Conservation Foundation, the country's leading advisory board on problems of national heritage and environment. ``We can't just do a one-day Earth Day,'' said Garrett.

After a two-year hiatus, Willie Nelson is reviving his Fourth of July picnic and outdoor concert, with help from officials of his hometown. The country singer's last Fourth of July bash was in 1987 in north Texas, where it drew only about 8,000 people. Nelson's daughter, Lana Nelson, and Mayor Lee Cooke announced Wednesday that the party will be revived this year in the city's Zilker Park. Over the years, the picnic has been held in a variety of locations and sometimes marred by arrests and vandalism. Cooke said his city would be happy to sponsor the event with the promise that $1 of every ticket sold would benefit a children's playground in the park. ``I say welcome back, Willie,'' the mayor said. Nelson, performing in Las Vegas, was not on hand for the announcement. This year's lineup includes Johnny Cash, Kris Kristofferson, Waylon Jennings, Kinky Freedman, Johnny Gimble and Kimmy Rhodes. The Geezinslaw Brothers, Asleep at the Wheel, Little Joe y La Familia, and Little Whisper and the Rumors will also appear.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company has withdrawn a $46 million offer to buy Arnold Palmer's Bay Hill golf club and is suing the golfer and other owners to get back its $3 million deposit. WDI Systems Inc. said in its breach of contract lawsuit that club buildings are riddled with asbestos and that club owners did not file some required income tax materials, among other complaints. ``The allegations are totally devoid of merit,'' said William Carpenter, a lawyer for the Cleveland-based International Management Inc., an agent in the sale and one of the defendants. ``There's nothing to these complaints,'' Carpenter said Wednesday. WDI agreed to purchase the club, site of an annual professional golf tournament, in February. It paid the $3 million deposit and gained access to the club and its records. Palmer owns 47 percent of the club. Club officials said Thursday he was out of town and unavailable for comment. International Management is known as the biggest sports agency in the world. It represents or has represented top athletes such as Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Chris Evert.

Musician Duke Robillard will be taking his guitar south, replacing Jimmie Vaughan in the blues-rock band Fabulous Thunderbirds. ``It's a very comfortable situation for me to walk into,'' he said. ``We're all excited to see how it's going to work out, what it will sound like.'' Robillard is already familiar with the Austin, Texas-based band. Drummer Fran Christina and bassist Preston Hubbard of the Thunderbirds played with him in Roomful of Blues, the band he founded in 1968. And Robillard toured with Thunderbirds' vocalist Kim Wilson and others last summer. Meanwhile, Robillard has a tour planned with his own band through June 16. The Thunderbirds were nominated for a Grammy for their biggest success, ``Tuff Enuff,'' and the group was named blues band of the year in 1986 by the Blues Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Unlikely to Produce Quick-Fixes For Gorbachev
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: However big the headlines, this week's summit seems unlikely to provide Mikhail S. Gorbachev with any quick solutions to the burgeoning economic and political trouble at home. The Soviet leader said as much Thursday, telling an enrapt American audience that his reforms will depend on time and ingenuity. ``One has to wait nine months before a child is born,'' he said. One translation quoted Gorbachev this way: Soviet thinkers, he said, will have to ``twist their brains'' to achieve a successful, market-oriented economy. In his animated luncheon remarks, Gorbachev appealed for Western patience as he grapples with the Lithuanian independence movement. His approach, he said, is to ``be very cautious, to consider a matter seven times, or even 100 times before one takes a decision.'' His summit partner, President Bush, has questioned Gorbachev's action _ not his caution _ over Lithuania. The Kremlin leader slapped an economic blockade on the republic and has declined to lift it. Even as Gorbachev asked for forbearance, Bush pointedly mentioned Lithuania as an area that divides the two nations. And there is little on the summit agenda that is likely to ease the Baltic rebellion or help the Soviet economy. ``Over the next four days we're not going to solve all of the world's problems,'' Bush said in his welcoming remarks to Gorbachev. He might have added ``nor the Soviet Union's.'' Burning ethnic rivalries and growing nationalism in several Soviet republics continue to threaten the stability of the union. Gorbachev's plan to raise food prices touched off panic buying and emptied store shelves. And political nemesis Boris Yeltsin won the presidency of Russia, the vast republic that stretches the length of the Soviet Union with more land and people than the other 14 republics combined. Yeltsin immediately announced he would seek sovereignty for Russia, giving its laws precedence over national law and effectively weakening the union over which Gorbachev presides. The White House in recent months has expressed a desire to buttress Gorbachev at home after concluding that Soviet stability and Gorbachev's political survival are in the U.S. interest _ overriding anxiety over issues such as Lithuania. Agreement on a new trade pact, which would provide some tangible benefits for the Soviets, is essentially at hand, but Bush has backed away from signing it. He initially cited the Soviet parliament's postponement of passage of a new law liberalizing emigration policies. Now the administration is linking agreement on trade with the lifting of Moscow's economic blockade against the tiny Baltic republic. Even with a trade agreement, the Soviets would enjoy few immediate benefits because their industries do not now produce much that could compete on world markets. Improving production through better training, quality control and industrial design will take years in an economy that has effectively destroyed the work ethic and has yet to implement long-promised market incentives. The Soviet president has argued passionately for trade concessions to help his country pull out of its economic tailspin, but few suggest there is anything short of a massive airlift that could work fast enough to have an impact on the problems feeding present public anxieties. Gorbachev's other summit goals _ agreement on cutting nuclear weapons by 50 percent, eliminating chemical weapons and establishing a non-threatening military posture for a unified Germany _ are unlikely to help him much at home, where he already has established his credentials as a peacemaker. But returning empty handed could further weaken his stature if he were viewed as losing his effectiveness in the international arena. At their first summit meeting, in Malta last December, Gorbachev and Bush announced they would try to reach broad agreement on reducing troops and conventional weapons in Europe by their next meeting. That goal has proved elusive, and U.S. officials say the Soviets are stalling and attribute the lack of progress to Soviet concern about the future of Germany. Other observers have suggested Gorbachev may want to slow the pace of withdrawal from Europe not just for security reasons but because he is under pressure from his own military, which has no place to house homecoming troops and little enthusiasm for mustering out large numbers of career officers in the shrinking of defense forces.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Michael Putzel is The Associated Press' Moscow bureau chief.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Joint Chiefs Finds Possible Successor at Graduation
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff welcomed 895 West Point cadets to the ranks of commissioned Army officers Thursday and learned that one of them already is gunning for his job. The ambitious cadet is Kristin Baker, 22, who had already risen to the top of the academy by becoming brigade commander and the first female captain of the corps of cadets. After Gen. Colin Powell told the graduates of the U.S. Military Academy that the United States must maintain a strong military, even though ``the prospect of peace is now more than a dream,'' he appeared at a news conference with Baker. Powell noted that he and Baker had been appointed the same day last October. Baker than admitted having aspirations to his job. ``It takes a long time,'' she said. ``About 30 years'' Powell said. ``See me in about 30 years,'' said Baker. Powell, 53, said the world has changed greatly since he entered the military in the 1950s, but advised the newly commissioned second lieutenants to recognize ``what has changed and what has not. We must identify what threats have receded and which have not.'' Powell said he believes Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is ``sincere in wanting to reform his country as he is in making sure it continues to play a dominant role in world affairs.'' But Powell said that despite any economic revolutions, ``one fact remains: the Soviet Union will still possess thousands of nuclear warheads that can destroy America in 30 minutes. We must never allow ourselves to be at a nuclear disadvantage.'' West Point's 806 male and 89 female graduates this year list that includes Robert E. Lee, Ulysses S. Grant, Douglas MacArthur and Dwight D. Eisenhower. Women were admitted to West Point beginning in 1976. The two Rhodes Scholarships awarded to cadets this year went to women: Jennie Koch of Potomac, Md., and Carolyn Ford of Pensacola, Fla. Baker, born in Dickinson, N.D., de-emphasized her role as a woman in her job as brigade commander and said there was still a lot to be done for women at West Point. She called her appointment ``another step in a long line of steps being taken for women'' at the 188-year-old school.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Israel Urges Washington to End PLO Dialogue; Arafat Denies Responsibility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Arafat denying PLO responsibile, saying he doesn't have power to expel Abbas. Pickup 6th, `Israeli Foreign...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel today urged the United States to end all contacts with the PLO after seaborne Palestinian guerrillas loyal to a top PLO official tried to attack crowded beaches and hotels on a Jewish holiday. But PLO chief Yasser Arafat said the PLO was not responsible for the attack and that he does not have the authority to take action against the PLO official whose guerrillas claimed responsibility, even if he wanted to. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured by Israeli forces in Wednesday's Libyan-sponsored infiltration. No Israelis were harmed in the attack, even though tens of thousands were on beaches for Shavuot, the Jewish holiday that marks the giving of the Ten Commandments. The Palestine Liberation Front, headed by Mohammed Abbas, claimed responsibility. Abbas, known as Abul Abbas, is a member of the PLO Executive Committee and loyal to Arafat. He planned the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro. Israel radio said today the government had sent Washington details of the interrogations of the 12 captured PLO guerrillas. Israeli leaders called Wednesday's attack proof that Arafat had violated his December 1988 pledge to renounce terror. It was Arafat's pledge that led the United States to open a dialogue with the PLO. Arafat said today in Baghdad, where he attended a summit of Arab leaders, that the PLO was not responsible for the guerrilla attack on Israeli beaches. Asked whether he would expel Abbas from the elected PLO Executive Committee for carrying out the attack, Arafat said: ``He was elected in a democratic way by the Palestine National Council, and only the council has a say on that.'' He added, ``We are a democratic organization, and decisions should be taken democratically.'' Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Motti Amihai claimed today that Abbas and Arafat met in Tunis, Tunisia, five days before the attack. ``We believe that Abul Abbas at that time knew for sure that this operation is going to take place,'' Amihai said. ``I think there is little doubt that Arafat personally, and also probably (Libyan leader Moammar) Gadhafi, knew beforehand about this operation.'' The PLO is an umbrella group for several factions. The smaller groups sometimes fight among themselves or launch independent attacks on Israel. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said Israel would try to persuade the United States to abandon contacts with the PLO. ``If we can convince them there that the basic assumption for dialogue no longer exists, then it's possible that the United States will decide to cease the dialogue,'' he said on Israel radio. ``The only question is whether they (the Americans) will see reality as it is,'' said Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In Washington, U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said it was too early to say whether the attack would affect the 17-month dialogue, but added that ``we would view this as a very serious matter.'' She said the United States was ``horrified at this terrorist attack'' and was ``pleased that all terrorists were apprehended or killed in action.'' The infiltrators were trained in Libya with the aim of attacking ``the hotels in the Tel Aviv region to conduct a massacre,'' said Maj. Geb. Amnon Shahak, chief of army intelligence. The army said that on maps of Tel Aviv found in the possession of the guerrillas, circles had been drawn the Kolbo Hashalom department store, and Kings Square next to Tel Aviv city hall. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir did not say whether Israel would retaliate against Libya. Asked on Israel television about the Libyan involvement, he said: ``We have to take this into account.'' According to army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, the infiltration began three days ago when a Libyan merchant ship carrying five fiberglass speedboats and a refueling vessel left the Libyan port of Benghazi, about 800 miles from Israel. Before dawn Wednesday, the mother ship cast off its cargo 120 miles off Israel. Three speedboats malfunctioned and the mother ship and the refueling vessel sailed toward Egypt, Shomron said. Two boats, equipped with rockets, machine guns and anti-aircraft missiles, headed toward the Israel coast. One of the boats, carrying 11 Palestinians, was attacked by helicopters and troops of the elite Givati brigade as it sliced into an almost empty beach near Nizzanim, 18 miles south of Tel Aviv. Four guerrillas were killed there and seven captured. Israeli gunboats intercepted another boat near the communal farm of Gaash, about 12 miles north of Tel Aviv, and five guerrillas surrendered. Police ordered the evacuation of a 30-mile stretch of beaches south of Tel Aviv jammed with people for Shavuot. ``Some bloodthirsty terrorists tried to turn our holiday into a day of mourning,'' Shamir said. ``But the guardians of Israel succeeded once again. The campaign organized by Abul Abbas was a complete failure.'' In the Iraqi capital of Baghdad, Palestine Liberation Front representative Hussein el-Abed said the attack was aimed at ``teaching the enemy a new lesson on the road to liberating Palestine.'' The faction supports armed struggle to establish a Palestinian state. The infiltration came on the last day of the emergency Arab summit in Baghdad. In a final communique, the summit blamed the United States for the explosive situation in the Middle East. The Arab leaders said U.S. backing for Israel encourages the Jewish state to resist peace initiatives and settle Jews in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Official Released from Detention
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress official Glen Thomas has been released by police after protests from the United States and four other Western nations, authorities said Thursday. Thomas was the first ANC official to be detained since the organization was legalized Feb. 2. He was held for almost three weeks after being arrested May 11 following a meeting with ANC and United Democratic Front activists. Police did not say why Thomas was detained nor elaborate on his release Wednesday. The arrest was protested by the United States, Britain, West Germany, Canada and Australia. The ANC also protested Thomas' detention under Section 29 of the Internal Security Act, which allows police to retain suspects indefinitely. It said the detention was not ``in the spirit'' of talks with the government on ending white-minority rule. Thomas said his treatment by police was ``gentlemanly,'' but expressed concern about Robert Nogumla, who was arrested with him and is still held.

DOC.HEAD: Cultural Clash: Exurban Farmer Arrested for Nighttime Plowing
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: A farmer in a once-rural area has been arrested for plowing his fields too late at night after a neighbor in an adjoining subdivision complained that the drone of the tractor was keeping him awake. ``The way I feel, he moved next to the field _ the field didn't move next to him,'' said Ray Dettmering, who farms 600 acres about 30 miles south of Chicago. ``The only question I have is, this fall when I go to harvest it, what happens then?'' Dettmering's neighbor, Leonard Reh, said he, too, must make a living. And he can't because of the noise. ``I don't want to stop him from making his living,'' said Reh, a Postal Service employee. ``But farming land at midnight is just a little bit too outrageous.'' Reh's home is in a new subdivision in Matteson, about 30 miles southwest of Chicago. The village has seen an influx of middle- and upper-middle class commuters in recent years. Reh and other neighbors say that since they must turn their lawnmowers off at 7 p.m. because of village ordinances, why should a farm tractor be different? And so, about 11 p.m. on April 26, police responded to Reh's complaint. They tromped through muddy fields to arrest Dettmering as he, his wife, Kathy, and a hired hand finished plowing the land he leases. Dettmering faces a June 11 hearing on two counts of disturbing the peace. Each count carries a maximum fine of $500 and six months in jail. Dettmering, 28, of Peotone, has a day job and farms someone else's land on nights and weekends. ``Almost all producers depend to a certain extent on rented land,'' especially in rapidly urbanizing areas, said Ralph Heimlich, an agricultural economist for the U.S. Department of Agriculture in Washington, D.C. Heimlich said suburban growth areas, while attractive to the middle-class, often pose conflicts between suburbanites and their farm neighbors. ``People want to move out in the country and enjoy the open space, but some of the things that go with it aren't so pleasant, such as spreading manure from a dairy operation or ... dust and noise with a tillage operation,'' he said. Dettmering, who grew up in a farm family, said in a telephone interview Thursday he'd like to be a full-time farmer but can't afford it. He said he depends on his second job as a farm equipment mechanic to make ends meet. ``I've got an eight-hour-a-day job,'' he said. ``There's not enough money on the farm to be living off of.'' The Illinois Farm Bureau estimates 25 percent of the family farmers in the state work 200 or more days off the farm. ``If you have a small or medium-sized operation, for many people they find it a necessity. It's just one of those facts of life,'' said Dennis Vercler, a bureau spokesman. This year, Dettmering said a wet spring has put him behind in preparing the land for corn. The days when it wasn't raining meant even longer days _ and nights _ in the field, he said. Reh said, however, he just wants a good night's sleep. ``I have to get up at 4 o'clock in the morning to go to work,'' he said. ``Whoever owned this land before used to work the land during the day _ he never bothered anybody.''

DOC.HEAD: `Brownie' Agents Will Get the Blues
DOC.TEXT: ``Ephemeral, clean'' blue will signal the brash new fashion statement of traffic agents, long saddled with the nickname ``Brownies'' because of their oh-so-drab uniforms. ``Brown looks dirty; it seems to remind you of congestion,'' said Joe DePlasco, spokesman for the city Department of Transportation. And so on Friday, at ceremonies marking the 30th anniversary of the traffic enforcement division, the department will reveal all _ via mannequins adorned with uniforms past, present and future. Much has changed since June 1, 1960, when the city sent forth its first corps of so-called ``meter maids.'' That all-woman ticket-writing force wore white blouses, navy blue skirts and scarves, black kid pumps and a hat modeled after that worn by the era's airline stewardesses. A men's version was created when the force went co-ed in 1967. In 1974, the duds du jour became a brown skirt or pants; brown jacket and overcoat; brown shoes; brown tie and white shirt. You might say that brown became all the rage after that. In recent years, the color has become to some belligerent motorists what red is to a bull. ``There is a lot of Brownie bashing that is going on in the streets,'' said DePlasco. ``We'd like to change the image that traffic agents can be abused by the public.'' In the first four months of 1990, 167 traffic agents were assaulted or otherwise confronted by unruly motorists; in the same period last year, the number was 114. Besides, says DePlasco, the Brownies _ er, traffic enforcement agents _ found their nickname to be pejorative. They hope the new garb will signal a new era of respect. ``We think the uniform could give a greater sense of pride, would be cleaner, look nicer, make the person feel happier about themselves and win more respect from the public,'' said DePlasco. The city's 1,900 traffic agents will phase in the new look, using their $480 a year uniform allowance. It will feature a navy blue hat, white shirt, navy blue tie, navy blue jacket, gray trousers with a navy stripe and black shoes. A committee is being formed to add the finishing touches, and the final creation is expected by fall. ``We're willing to take suggestions from renowned New York fashion designers,'' said DePlasco.
