DOC.HEAD: 9-Year-Old Faces Felony in Schoolyard Fight
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old who flattened a schoolmate's nose after the boy called him ``Fatso'' faces a felony charge, and the father of the accused is outraged. Bobby Woods of suburban Sunrise is charged with aggravated battery, a second-degree felony, in the fight with Khalid Fathallah at an elementary school where both were attending summer school. ``This is incredible,'' Bobby's father, Nolan, said Wednesday. ``I think this kind of court time should be spent on kids who need it. Kids vandalizing, raping, stealing. Not over a little fistfight.'' Bobby was charged partly because Khalid suffered a broken nose. ``That raises it above a simple schoolyard incident,'' said Assistant State Attorney Gary Ford. But defense attorney Paul Stark said he would ask a judge next week to dismiss the case. Bobby, who at 5 feet and 101 pounds is bigger than the average 9-year-old said the fight started after Khalid and another boy called him names. ``Fatso ... `Hey, Fatso, like cookies? Oink, oink' and all that,'' he said. If convicted, Bobby's sentence could range from a reprimand to being put in state custody, Ford said. Ford said the youngster is unlikely to suffer a heavy penalty because the 9-year-old has no criminal record.

DOC.HEAD: Algeria March Draws Tens of Thousands
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of demonstrators on Thursday marched through Algiers pressing for a ``true democracy'' in the latest in a series of demonstrations leading up to the June 12 municipal elections. The peaceful demonstration was called by the head of the Socialist Forces Front, Hocine Ait-Ahmed. It mostly attracted Berber-speaking residents of the Kabyle regions; they carried signs, mainly in the Berber language, calling for ``real democracy'' and ``linguistic pluralism.'' The march, headed by a young girl carrying a rose, began at the May 1 Square and passed the parliament building. Previous marches, by the Islamic Salvation Front on April 20, the Democrats on May 10 and the ruling National Liberation Front on May 17, drew more than 100,000 people. At least 12 parties have cropped up since Algeria's Constitution was changed last year to allow political pluralism. The June municipal elections will be the first multiparty elections since Algeria gained independence from France in 1962. The fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front is seen as the ruling party's main contender, expected to draw about one-third of the votes.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0657 AM-House Finances, or a0742 AM-House Finances 1st Ld, transmitted May 29 under a WASHINGTON dateline, are asked to use the following. FYI, Green appeared in the last paragraph of the original story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on May 29 in a story on the 1989 financial disclosure forms of House members that New York Rep. William Green's campaign committee had given him between $100,000 and $250,000 as repayment of personal funds he had lent to his 1984 reelection campaign. Green's loan to the committee has not yet been repaid.

DOC.HEAD: High Wind Keeps Deaf and Blind Climbers From McKinley Summit
DOC.TEXT: An international team that includes two blind climbers, a deaf climber and an amputee nearly made it to the top of Mount McKinley, but 50 mph winds forced them to turn around, officials said Thursday. The group got up to at least 18,000 feet, said Roger Robinson, a U.S. Park Service ranger. At 20,320 feet, Mount McKinley is North America's highest mountain. ``They've all descended. They're at 14,000 now. Indications are they're not going back up,'' he said. ``They did very good considering that only about half the folks that try McKinley make it to the top.'' The ascent was attempted by 1,009 climbers last year; only 524 reached the summit. Adaptations were made for the disabled climbers. ``Apparently they've got ropes stretched out to the latrines when they're at camps,'' said Bob Seiber, chief mountaineering ranger. ``They work extremely well together and develop their other senses, I guess.'' Patrick Reinhart, a member of the expedition and director of Challenge Alaska, a group that helps develop recreational and sports opportunities for disabled climbers, came up with the idea for the ascent. Reinhart, who has an artificial foot, always wanted to climb McKinley. So did Ross Watson, a Canadian member of the expedition who lost his sight at age 12 in a pellet gun accident. Patrick Hurst, a 27-year-old Englishman who teaches outdoor sports to physically disabled people, also is blind. Lkakpa Sonam, a Sherpa from Nepal, is deaf. In overall charge of the expedition is George Rooney, a member of the American Alpine Club who's been up McKinley twice and tried climbing Everest in a joint American-Polish expediton. He's also an emergency medical technician and a specialist in mountain rescue.

DOC.HEAD: Placid Lawns of Wellesley Crawling with Secret Service, Reporters
DOC.TEXT: The normally placid, rolling lawns of exclusive Wellesley College were crawling Thursday with Secret Service agents, reporters and harried college administrators in preparing for Friday's arrival of Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev. But the earlier commotion over Mrs. Bush's selection as commencement speaker has all but disappeared. Instead, many of the students, teachers and alumnae trying to dodge television camera crews inside the enormous tent had a new gripe. In the words of graduating senior Kelly Brown, 21,: ``Now we have this big circus and we just wanted a quiet graduation ceremony.'' Graduation for the Class of 1990 at Wellesley, an oasis of brick towers and woodsy green meadows in this affluent suburb 10 miles west of Boston, will be anything but quiet. That was guaranteed last month when about 150 of Wellesley's 2,200 students signed a petition complaining that Mrs. Bush had gained recognition through her husband's achievements. That, they complained contradicted the school's philosophy that women should stand on their own. Mrs. Bush will now address the 600 graduating seniors with Mrs. Gorbachev at the Friday morning ceremony. The Gorbachevs arrived in the United States Wednesday night for the start of a four-day summit. The two first ladies will speak for six minutes each. A phalanx of Secret Service agents has been on campus for five days. Wellesley security officials said the graduation tent, which will accommodate 5,500, was the biggest they have ever put up. The petition, co-authored by seniors Peggy Reid, 21, and Susana Cardenas, 21, gained national attention. The two women said Thursday that they still oppose the selection of Mrs. Bush as speaker, but plan no protests. ``When she comes to speak I'm going to welcome her on her own merits and not because she's the president's wife,'' said Reid, a religion major who plans to teach English in Costa Rica next year. Cardenas, an American citizen from Lima, Peru, echoed many on campus when she said the media had distorted the intent of the petition. She said students never wanted publicity about the controversy and did not want to be ``discourteous'' to Mrs. Bush. ``We didn't intend it to be a personal judgment against her,'' said Cardenas. ``We brought the petition to the college president and she was very sympathetic but said we couldn't change speakers and it was resolved.'' Others on campus said the petition, signed by about 150 students, represented only a tiny minority of students. Marion Patterson, 82, president of the class of 1927, said she attends every Wellesley graduation and is a ``great admirer of Barbara Bush. She grew up in an era when careers weren't the mode. She married and raised five children and I think she's a great asset to the country.'' Patterson took a dim view over the controversy about Mrs. Bush. ``I was distressed by it,'' she said. ``It was fostered by a South American student here on scholarship.'' Susan Hand, a college librarian whose two daughters have attended Wellesley, said she was ``very angry'' about the media's ``distortion'' of events. ``I never heard anybody talking out against it,'' Hand said. ``I think Barbara Bush coming will be neat and interesting for the kids. She has a different point of view from a lot of them but it's good to have a different point of view.'' Karen Tucker, 22, a graduating senior from Cambridge, said Thursday that ``most people are happy with the decision.'' ``When you think of a commencement speaker, you look for inspiration and I think Mrs. Bush proved herself of being capable of providing inspiration,'' she said. Mary Griffin, 21, a junior who was jogging across campus Thursday morning, looked wistfully over at the graduation tent. ``I wish it was my year,'' she said. ``I was really excited when I heard about them coming. It's exciting when you think _ we're going to have the first ladies of the two superpowers here.''

DOC.HEAD: Events in the Soviet Union
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at events Thursday in the Soviet Union:

BALTICS _ The legislature of Soviet Moldavia voted to recognize Lithuania's independence, the Tass news agency reported, making it the first Soviet republic outside the Baltics to do so. The move by the southwestern republic represented a direct challenge to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to isolate Lithuania from the rest of the Soviet Union.
YELTSIN _ Boris N. Yeltsin, seeking to ease the fears of Soviet deputies about his stormy relationship with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, pledged to put aside his personal differences with the Soviet leader.
JAPAN-FISHING _ Moscow protested illegal Japanese fishing in Soviet waters and said it wants millions of dollars in compensation for what it calls economic damage.

EARTHQUAKE _ An aftershock hit Moldavia one day after an earthquake centered in Romania was felt in the southwestern republic. The initial quake killed four people, injured 30 and damaged the homes of nearly 600 people in Moldavia.

SPACE _ An unmanned module containing facilities to produce high-quality semiconductors in orbit was launched from Soviet Central Asia to rendezvous with the Mir space station. The Kristall space module is to link up with the Mir on June 6.

DOC.HEAD: Archaeologist Finds 200-Year-Old Shoes in Well
DOC.TEXT: If you can tell a lot about people by the shoes they wear, archaeologists in the nation's oldest city hope to learn something about whoever lost a pair in a well 200 years ago. City archaeologist Carl D. Halbirt retrieved the shoes and other valuable finds during the past month from an underground well. ``It's kind of a rarity to find leather shoes,'' Halbirt said Wednesday. ``It doesn't happen all the time, and I've got two of them.'' The worn leather shoes are wet but preserved. They have heels with the cobbler nails still in them, and an area on the front where buckles would fit. ``The water in the well area is slightly alkaline, which helped preserve everything,'' he said. The shoes are probably about the equivalent of size 8-8{ in contemporary men's shoes, said Halbirt. Lab work will be needed to determine their exact age. Other items found in the well include a pocket knife, bucket handle and some nails, all of which date to about 1780-1800. The well was discovered during the city's installation of new utility lines under a street.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Strike East Europe After Quake That Left 14 Dead
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: A strong aftershock rocked Romania, Bulgaria and the Soviet republic of Moldavia before dawn Thursday, causing people to flee into the streets a day after a major earthquake killed at least 14 people. The 3 a.m. aftershock was the strongest of about 100 recorded after Wednesday's quake, which was felt from Moscow to Istanbul and caused serious structural damage to buildings in Romania and Bulgaria, officials said. Romania's Ministry of Health reported nine people were killed in Wednesday's quake and 994 people injured. A ministry communique on Radio Bucharest said 207 required hospitalization. The temblor also killed one person in Bulgaria and four in southern Moldavia. There were no reports of casualties Thursday. The Bulgarian news agency BTA said that, like Wednesday's quake, the aftershock was centered in the Carpathian Mountain region of Vrancea, in northern Romania. The National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., measured Wednesday's quake at 6.5 on the Richter scale and Thursday's aftershock at 5.9. In Moldavia, which borders Romania, the quake left four people dead and 30 injured but caused little structural damage, the chairman of the national legislature said. Supreme Soviet Chairman Anatoly Lukyanov said in Moscow that one person died in Moldavia after jumping out a second-floor window, two elderly people died of heart attacks and that another also died from undisclosed injuries, the official Tass news agency reported. Earthquakes also struck two parts of Latin America. An earthquake measuring 6.1 rocked the western areas outside Mexico City before dawn Thursday, frightening residents but apparently causing no serious damage or injuries. Late Tuesday, an earthquake in northern Peru left at least 135 people dead, Civil Defense officials said Thursday. The quake measured 6.3, and was centered 400 miles north of the capital Lima near the jungle villages of Moyobamba and Rioja. Aftershocks were also reported in that area Thursday. Damage from Thursday's Romanian aftershock appeared most serious in Vrancea County, 190 miles northeast of Bucharest, where the state news agency Rompress reported ``panic and a large amount of material damage.'' Severely damaged were the mayor's house, a theater, a medical center, the national bank and a building with 60 apartments in the county capital of Focsani, it said. In northern Bulgaria, thousands of people frightened by the aftershock reportedly spent the night in the street, or fled their cities. Cities and villages on the Danube River, including Ruse, Silistra and Svishtov ``were panic stricken,'' BTA said. It said thousands of people milled around city streets all night, or fled in their cars. The city of Silistra has appealed for aid, saying it urgently needed glass, cement, bricks and tiles to repair damaged homes, schools, kindergartens and the lone hospital, the agency said. In Bucharest, people fled into the streets and stood in small groups under dim lights. In the Bucharest Hotel, about a dozen people remained in the lobby, frightened to go upstairs. Dumitru Enescu, director of Romania's Earth Physics Institute, told Rompres 100 aftershocks were recorded in the first 26 hours after Wednesday's quake, some as high as 4 on the Richter scale. Damage reports from Wednesday's quake continued to filter into the capital. In Urziceni, 38 miles east of Bucharest, the roof of a technical-medical store collapsed, destroying the building. Nobody was injured. In the capital Wednesday, chunks of concrete from high-rise buildings crashed to the ground, crushing two people to death. Ceilings fell, walls cracked, books toppled from shelves, and tens of thousands of people rushed into the streets, many crying and screaming in fear. Romanians leaped in panic from windows and balconies, and some were badly hurt, ambulance officials said. The quake hit when Bucharest's streets were crowded with lunch-hour shoppers and pedestrians. It lasted about 45 seconds and was the third major earthquake since 1977 with its epicenter in the Romanian Carpathians. The Uppsala Seismological Center in Sweden said it was felt so widely because it was about 63 miles deep. ``I think it was this deafening sound of cracking walls that scared people,'' said clerical worker Sica Burcea, 52. ``The building was swinging horizontally and vertically. We were lucky only to have some cracks in the walls. I shivered when I realized 1977 was coming back.'' More than 1,500 Romanians died in a 1977 earthquake. The Richter scale gauges the amount of energy released by a quake as measured by the ground motion on seismographs. A quake measuring 6 can cause severe damage. One of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake.

DOC.HEAD: At Lunch with Gorbachev: Flattery, Joshing and Caviar
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev used a wily politician's old trick to win over his audience at lunch: flatter them and call out to some by name. There was Henry Kissinger and Gorbachev ribbed him gently, calling him, ``my old man who always contests things.'' There was musician Van Cliburn, ``and,'' said Gorbachev, ``I heartily welcome him here, because he has done much to promote understanding between our two peoples.'' Cliburn was accompanied by his mother, Rildia Bee, who will be 94 in October. The concert pianist responded to Gorbachev's greeting, saying how much he appreciated Gorbachev's hospitality in the Soviet Union last summer. He said Gorbachev's attendance at his concert there ``thrilled all my friends in Texas.'' There was John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist. Gorbachev called him ``a wise man, being loaded with knowledge.'' The Soviet president twitted him, too, noting that Galbraith had switched to another table ``so that we could see him better.'' The occasion was a chicken kiev and caviar lunch at the Soviet Embassy. It came between summit session one and two. The guests, bearing invitations in oversized envelopes, climbed a wide carpeted staircase in the old mansion, passed a portrait of a glaring Lenin, and sat down at round tables covered with pink linen and laden with china and were treated to a long, long rambling welcome from their host. His theme: the age of Soviet-American alienation is over. ``We are living in one civilization,'' he said, ``regardless of all the differences that we have _ and I believe the differences are not a liability, it is a plus to a certain extent because it provides a good foundation for reaching a higher level plane of knowledge...'' The flattery came when Gorbachev called his guests ``members of the American intellectual community.'' Some would fit that title _ certainly Galbraith, certainly cowboy-boot clad Stephen Cohen of Princeton, one of America's keenest analysts of the Soviet system _ but most probably would reject being called intellectuals. The old Hollywood was represented by Gregory Peck. From the new Hollywood came Jane Fonda, wearing a short and clingy orange suit and holding hands with her latest escort, cable television mogul Ted Turner. Raisa Gorbachev reportedly had especially wanted to meet some movie stars. It was an eclectic group. Jesse Jackson was the only out-and-out politician. The Washington cultural community was represented by James Billington, the Librarian of Congress and also a noted Sovietologist, and by Robert McC. Adams, head of the Smithsonian. Also present: Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of a U.S. president, and her Soviet husband, physicist Roald Sagdeev, and Pamela Harriman, doyenne of the Democratic Party and widow of FDR's wartime ambassador to Moscow; science fiction writers Isaac Asimov and Ray Bradbury, two authors who, Gorbachev said, turning on the flattery again, were his daughter's ``favorites.'' Mingling among the guests were 40 Soviet members of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Wesley Posvar, president of the University of Pittsburgh, said the fact they were flown to Washington just for the occasion was important, ``more than symbolic.'' After lunch, Kissinger said the affair was a disaster _ ``for my diet.'' He called Gorbachev ``serene.'' The Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, president of Georgetown University, said the Soviet leader was extraordinarily relaxed ``and a smile played constantly around his mouth.'' For Cliburn, the occasion must have brought forth old memories. He won a reputation and esteem for American musicianship when he won the Tschaikowsky music competition in Moscow in 1958 and was welcomed home as a national hero, ``the new American Sputnik.'' During Gorbachev's first American summit, with Ronald Reagan in December 1987, American ``intellectuals'' were also Gorbachev's guests at a mix-and-mingle reception at the embassy. Kissinger was there then too. Last time, Yoko Ono and Billy Graham were guests. Ms. Ono wasn't there this time, and religion was represented this time by Robert Schuller, the televangelist who has been asked to prepare 12 spiritual messages to be aired on television to the Soviet people over the next year.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms In South, Record Lows In Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across the South on Thursday, with locally heavy rain in already sodden parts of Texas and Louisiana, and temperatures hit record lows around parts of the Great Lakes. Showers and thunderstorms continued into the afternoon over southeastern Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, northeastern Texas and the southern half of the Florida Peninsula. Showers were scattered over central Georgia and east-central Missouri, and light rain fell over southwestern Missouri. The heaviest rain was over sections of northwestern Louisiana and east-central Texas, areas already hard hit by flooding along the Red and Trinity rivers. Shreveport, La., got 3.30 inches of rain between 2 a.m. and 8 a.m. EDT, and 2.09 inches fell during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT at Monroe, La., the National Weather Service said. Rain and showers extended from the northern Pacific Coast and the northern coast of California inland all the way to the northern Rockies, with showers turning to snow at higher elevations. Redding, Calif., tied its record low of 48. As much as 8 inches of new accumulation of snow was possible at higher elevations of the Oregon Cascades. South of the rain and snow, high wind advisories were posted over the valleys of southwestern Utah, extreme southern Nevada and the eastern Mojave Desert in California. Unseasonably cool air rolled southward across parts of the Great Lakes. Record lows included 38 at Pittsburgh; 36 at Muskegon, Mich.; and 35 at Youngstown, Ohio. Harrisburg, Pa., tied its record of 43, and Wilkes-Barre-Scranton, Pa., tied its record of 39. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 38 at Redmond, Ore., to 97 at both Beeville and Wink, Texas. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 29 at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices Up in May, USDA Reports
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products increased 2 percent from April to May, raising the overall commodity index 3.4 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Higher prices for hogs, corn, hay, broilers and lettuce fueled the increase over the last month, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. The average price for all hogs of $60.50 per hundred pounds of live weight was the second highest on record, topped only by $62.10 in August 1986. Lower prices were reported for eggs, onions, milk and cattle. While beef cattle prices showed a slight decline, calf prices increased. Prices for sorghum and soybeans were also up from April levels, but barley, wheat and rice dropped slightly. USDA economists said the climb of 3.4 percent in the index of all commodities over the year-earlier level was propelled by increases in hogs, cattle, milk and grapefruit. The economists have been saying net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $53 billion last year. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. Another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that net farm income for 1990 may be in the range of $47 billion to $51 billion, according to USDA. Last year's level of $49 billion set a record. Consumer food prices are forecast by the department to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Based on the preliminary figures, the May price index for livestock and poultry rose 1.2 percent from April and averaged 10 percent above the level of a year ago. Milk prices dropped 20 cents from April to an average of $13.20 per 100 pounds. Even so, the preliminary May price remained 90 cents above the level of a year ago. Crop prices, overall, rose 3.1 percent from April but averaged 4.9 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices fueled by oranges and grapefruits were up 3.6 percent from last month, about the same level as a year ago. The index for commercial vegetables climbed 3.4 percent from the April level but was down 21 percent from a year earlier. Lettuce and tomatoes were up while carrots and onions were down. Tomatoes averaged $18.70 per hundred pounds, up from $14.60 last month, although still far below the May 1989 figure of $43.30. Lettuce was at $10.90 per hundred pounds, up from $8.32 last month and $6.84 a year ago. Carrots sank to $7.71 per hundred pounds from $10.60 in April and a year-earlier level of $18.20. Onions averaged $13.80 per hundred pounds, down from $19.40 in April but above the $9.47 of a year ago. The report said: _Cattle averaged $74.30 per hundred pounds of live weight nationally, down from $74.60 in April but up from $68.80 in May 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $60.50 per hundred pounds, compared with $53.80 in April and $41.60 in May 1989. _Corn, at $2.66 a bushel, was up from $2.51 in April and $2.58 from the level of a year ago. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.44 a bushel, compared with $3.49 in April and $4.01 a year ago. _Rice averaged $7.21 per hundred pounds, compared with $7.31 in April and $6.78 in May 1989. _Soybeans were $5.92 per bushel, compared with $5.82 last month and $7.20 in May 1989. _Upland cotton was reported at 66.3 cents per pound, up from 65 cents in April and 58.3 cents a year ago. _Eggs were 60.2 cents a dozen, compared with 71.4 cents a dozen in April and 62.6 cents a year ago. _Milk was $13.20 per 100 pounds compared with $13.40 in April and $12.30 at the year-earlier level. _Broilers were 35.2 cents per pound compared with 33.2 cents in April and 44.6 cents a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: 15 Disneyland Visitors Swim to Safety After Canoe Sinks
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen Disneyland visitors paddling furiously aboard a canoe kept getting wetter and wetter, apparently in the belief a good soaking was part of the adventure. Moments later, the boat sank. As the canoe slipped into the Rivers of America lagoon Tuesday evening, about six riders swam to shore while others treaded in the 8-feet-deep water for a second canoe and a raft, said Brian Burnap, a park visitor from Sacramento. Burnap said they didn't panic. In fact, most of the riders remained stoically in their seats as the canoe took on water. Life preservers were stowed at both ends of the canoe, but in the confusion they weren't distributed, said Disneyland spokesman Bob Roth. The sinking was blamed in part on two young men who splashed and rocked the canoe, causing it to take on water, Roth said. The only injury was a bruised toe, Roth said. The soggy riders were taken to a first-aid station, where they were given clothes to wear while theirs dried. The canoes continuously loop Tom Sawyer Island in the theme park's Frontierland section. A Disneyland employee steers and a second crew member rides in the front while riders paddle the course.

DOC.HEAD: Triplets Finish Among School's Top 10 Students
DOC.TEXT: Triplets have finished Nos. 1, 3 and 9 among the 125 graduating seniors at Harvey High School. David Bitkowski will be valedictorian at Monday's graduation. His brother, Mark, will graduate third and a sister, Amy, will graduate ninth. The three 17-year-olds are members of National Honor Society. Harvey guidance counselor Sherm King the Bitkowskis are the only set of triplets to attend the school in the 27 years he's been there. Amy plans to attend Wright State University at Dayton to study retail management and child care. David and Mark will attend the University of Toledo to study pharmacy and physical therapy, respectively. ``There's a higher female population there than guys,'' Mark said of his decision. ``Fifty-five percent to 45 percent _ I'll take it!'' Mark said Amy chose Wright State, near Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, ``because the `fly boys' come over there.''

DOC.HEAD: NY Police Evicting Beggars from Subway, Rail Stations
DOC.TEXT: Police have begun evicting the city's panhandlers and homeless from their last great public refuges: the subways, Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal. The Transit Authority on Wednesday began aggressively ejecting panhandlers from the subways and removing sleeping people from station floors and benches. The Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road said that on Friday they will begin enforcing court-approved regulations banning begging and various activities, such as sleeping or using more than one bench seat, primarily associated with the homeless. The evictions have drawn criticism from advocates for the homeless. In recent years, the homeless have gone to Grand Central, Penn Station and the subways in search of warmth during the winter and for safety year-round. On May 10, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that panhandling in transit systems didn't amount to constitutionally protected free speech. ``The courts clearly said the subways are not the place to wage the social battles,'' Transit Authority police chief William J. Bratton said Thursday. ``They have to be waged elsewhere.'' Bratton said authorities have to demonstrate that they are in control of the subways. ``It's been quite apparent that the previous approach to panhandling was not giving that sense at all, that we were being laughed at,'' he said. An estimated 400 people a night have been spending the night at Penn station, officials said. A count for Grand Central wasn't immediately available. The prohibition on panhandling was part of Operation Enforcement, a set of rules outlined by the Transit Authority last October. In April, the Metropolitan Transit Authority, which overesees the Transit Authority and the commuter railroads, approved regulations for behavior in railroad stations. Under Bratton's orders, beggars are to be ejected without warning regardless of whether they are aggressive or passive. The police chief said he would be satisfied with a 25 percent reduction in panhandling. He also labeled as ``bogus'' and ``baloney'' accusations that the effort against begging would divert officers from fighting escalating crime in the subways. Among those criticizing the evictions was Peter Smith of the Partnership for the Homeless advocacy group. ``Where are the homeless supposed to go, where are they supposed to beg?'' Smith said. ``Is the MTA going to put together a shuttle to the moon? It's getting absurd.'' But the eviction plan is supported by shopkeepers at Penn Station. ``It's not good for business to have people sleeping down here,'' said Singh Cheema, who runs a jewelry store near Track 17. ``Some customers are offended.'' At 2 a.m. on any given night at Penn Station, the homeless sleep side by side _ pregnant women, children, gray-haired men with crutches by their sides, an occasional person with a dirty plaster cast on an arm. The huddled line stretches for a block. Until Friday, the sleepers were rousted at 5 a.m. On Friday, anyone lying down at any time or using more than one bench seat will be awakened and told about available social services, said Long Island Rail Road spokesman Brian Dolan. ``If they refuse to take advantage of the assistance offered ... they will be told to leave the station,'' Dolan said. ``They will be ejected.'' At Grand Central, Metro North has already closed off many areas previously inhabited by the homeless, and began enforcing the panhandling ban the day after the May 10 court ruling. Social services are available there also.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Measuring 6.1 Shakes Mexico City Area, None Injured
With AM-Europe-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale shook metropolitan Mexico City early Thursday, sending frightened residents into the streets. The Red Cross reported no injuries or major damage. The 1:35 a.m. jolt, which lasted 15 seconds, was centered about 180 miles southwest of this quake-prone capital, according to the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center at Golden, Colo. Hotel clerks in Acapulco said the quake was felt in the Pacific resort but that there was no damage. Mexico City, spread across a basin prone to earthquakes, suffered one of the century's most devastating temblors on Sept. 19, 1985. That earthquake, which measured 8.1, and an aftershock the next day, left 9,500 people dead and 150,000 homeless. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake measuring 6 can cause severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Guard Says Crash Probably Won't Change PR Flight Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th graf pvs, `Bushee, who...,' to UPDATE with editor's description of his injuries. Pick up 7th graf pvs: `Christopherson said...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SI1, AH1
With BC-Jets Collide-Account
DOC.TEXT: The collision of two Air National Guard fighter jets while one was carrying a newspaper editor probably will not change Guard policy on public relations flights, a spokesman said Thursday. But the South Dakota Air Guard will not be able to take any more civilians aloft for a while because one of the A-7s that crashed Wednesday over northwestern Iowa was the Guard's only two-seater, Capt. Reid Christopherson, Guard executive officer, said in Sioux Falls, S.D. ``At the national level, I don't anticipate and am not aware of any reason why it should change the way that program's administered,'' Christopherson said. The pilots of both planes and Ward Bushee, executive editor of the Sioux Falls (S.D.) Argus Leader, ejected and parachuted to the ground. The pilots were released from a Spencer hospital after treatment of minor injuries. Bushee, who was invited to join the flight as part of the Guard's public relations program, was listed in fair condition at McKennan Hospital in Sioux Falls. The hospital would not comment on the extent of Bushee's injuries or when he would be released. Bushee said from the hospital that his sixth vertebra was chipped and he suffered burns on his left arm, shoulders and knees. Bushee said he wouldn't need surgery, and expected to be released Saturday. Christopherson said taking civilians on a flight is a lengthy process that goes through the public affairs office at the Pentagon. An editorial by Bushee in August that criticized ceremonial flyovers did not affect that decision, he said. Bushee gave his newspaper an account of his flight with Maj. Duncan Keirnes, of Sioux Falls, saying it started smoothly and that they later went into a dogfight exercise with another jet. Then the two planes collided. ``Duncan hit the ejector button as soon as we hit,'' he said, ``sending me exploding through the canopy and him following a second later. Then everything came apart. It was just a ball of flame. Duncan later told me that if he had waited a couple of seconds longer to eject, we would have been crispy critters. ``It was just a surreal scene. I was floating up in the air and my flight suit was burning like a torch. My first thought was, `I'll never see my wife and kids again. This is it.' ``Pieces of the plane were going by. Flames were all over me. I couldn't remember where the cord was to open the parachute, but it went open automatically.'' Christopherson said the unit's guest-ride program is part of the Guard's national public relations program. ``We probably do two to four of these a year,'' he said. ``The program will probably continue,'' he said. ``I don't see any reason why it shouldn't.'' Christopherson said neither of the pilots faced disciplinary action and both could continue to fly military missions. ``Any restrictions would be strictly limited to medical decisions,'' he said. ``I don't see any reason why they wouldn't be returned to flying status.'' Keirnes and the other pilot, Maj. Gregory Gore of Collierville, Tenn., are pilots for civilian air lines, but Christopherson declined to say which ones. The Guard would not release names of two other pilots flying in the same exercise and would not permit interviews with any pilots. Christopherson said the accident was the first since the South Dakota Air National Guard unit began flying the A-7s in 1977 and that the Guard last lost a plane in 1974. ``The airplanes probably won't be replaced,'' he said. ``We are scheduled to convert from A-7s to F-16s in early 1992.'' Christopherson said he talked to both pilots early Thursday but that there was no discussion on what caused the crash. The Guard is determined to get to the bottom of what happened, Christopherson said. ``It's in no one's best interest to hide anything,'' he said. ``The objective is to learn from what went wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Moldavia Recognizes Independence of Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: The legislature of Soviet Moldavia on Thursday recognized Lithuania's independence, the Tass news agency reported, making it the first Soviet republic outside the Baltics to do so. The move by lawmakers in the southwestern republic represented a direct challenge to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to isolate Lithuania from the rest of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev imposed an economic embargo of key raw materials to the Baltic republic for failure to rescind its pro-independence laws, and he has decreed Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence to be unconstitutional. According to the official news agency Tass, deputies of the Moldavian Supreme Soviet, meeting in the capital of Kishinev, favored the establishment of direct diplomatic, economic, political and cultural relations with Lithuania. The legislature also proposed to exchange ``permanent missions'' with the Lithuanian parliament, or Supreme Council, Tass reported. The news agency did not give vote totals on the measure. So far, only the Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia have formally acted to cooperate on such levels with Lithuania. On May 12, the three Baltic republics revived a 1934 political alliance pledging mutual cooperation. Tass noted pro-Moscow deputies who are members of the ``Soviet Moldavia'' alliance opposed the decision on recognition, specifically objecting to the term ``diplomatic ties.'' They said that term cannot be applied between republics that are part of the same nation, Tass said. The news agency added that some members of the group were not represented at the session because deputies from predominantly Russian-speaking towns have not attended parliament since May 22. It gave no reason for their absence. Like the Baltic states, the region that is now Moldavia was forcibly annexed into the Soviet Union by Josef Stalin in 1940. Before the annexation, Moldavia, then called Bessarabia, was part of Romania and had long been regarded as a cradle of Romanian culture. The Moldavian People's Front, an independent political movement, has been pressing demands for greater autonomy from Moscow, although it has moved cautiously on any reunification with Romania. The People's Front won a battle to establish Moldavian as the official language of the republic and return to the Latin alphabet used by Romanians, dropping the Cyrillic letters of the Russian alphabet imposed under Stalin. Gorbachev's embargo, imposed April 18, cut off all oil, most supplies of natural gas and other key raw materials to Lithuania after it failed to rescind pro-independence laws. Since then, Lithuanian officials have sought to establish ties with other Soviet republics to trade for materials the republic desperately needs. One major obstacle to such an arrangement, however, is that Moscow controls rail lines and highways needed to transport goods to Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: A `Gonzo' Celebration After Charges Are Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday formally dismissed all charges against Hunter S. Thompson and the ``gonzo'' journalist celebrated. He stood up and poured a glass of water on his own head. Thompson had been bound over for trial last week on three felony counts of possession of a controlled substance and one of unlawful possession of incendiary devices. He also faced misdemeanor charges of sexual assault, simple assault and marijuana possession. Thompson, 53, was charged after Gail Palmer-Slater, a business entrepreneur and former porn film producer, accused him of grabbing her breast and throwing a drink at her when she visited his Woody Creek home Feb. 21. She wanted to interview him for a story she planned to write. ``I didn't beat up that woman. She came to my house and got sloppy and rude. If the taxi would have come sooner, this never would have happened,'' Thompson said. During a telephone interview from her St. Clair, Mich., home, Palmer-Slater, 35, said prosecutors decided to drop the charges because of her background. ``I had a very public career in the mid '70s and I'm really easy to trash, which is exactly the reason why I said I can't do anything about this,'' she said Wednesday. ``But my husband insisted it be reported,'' she said. ``Then Hunter said I was doing this for publicity, so I was damned if I spoke to the press about my side and damned if I didn't, because Hunter kept making all these statements about me.'' Pitkin County District Attorney Chip McCarory said he didn't think the case could be proved beyond a reasonable doubt anymore. He said she changed her statements between the time she talked with investigators and the time she testified at the preliminary hearing. After District Judge Charles Buss brought Thursday's 15-minute hearing to a close, the courtroom audience applauded. Thompson rose and poured a cup of water over his head. Thompson is best-known for his accounts of political campaigns, shark hunts in Hawaii and the Hell's Angels. He often laced his writing with exaggerated first-person accounts of drug and alcohol abuse, a writing style that became known as ``gonzo'' journalism.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Jolts Soviet Moldavia
With Europe-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An aftershock hit the southern Soviet republic of Moldavia on Thursday, one day after an earthquake in the region killed four people, injured dozens and damaged the homes of nearly 600 people, Soviet media reported. A government commission met in the republic's capital of Kishinev to assess damage from Wednesday's earthquake, which measured 6.5 on the Richter scale and was centered in neighboring Romania's Carpathian Mountains. Tass said the earthquake caused significant damage to 40 schools, 42 day-care centers, 36 medical clinics and an undetermined number of industrial and agricultural facilities. In Kishinev, about 1,000 apartments need emergency repairs, and 340 were being evacuated, the official news agency said, quoting preliminary information. Worst hit were the southern regions of Moldavia, including the cities of Komrat, Chadyr-Lunga and Kakhul, Tass said. Earlier Thursday, the chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature in Moscow, Anatoly Lukyanov, said one of the quake's victims died after jumping out a second-floor window. He also said two elderly people died of heart attacks, according to Tass. Details on the fourth victim were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: NYNEX Phone Company Indicted for Business Practices of Tennessee Unit
DOC.TEXT: Regional telephone giant NYNEX Corp. was indicted Thursday on a charge of violating the 1982 court order that broke up the old Bell system. The New York City-based company was indicted on one count of criminal contempt of court for allegedly providing information services to customers in violation of the 1982 consent decree. NYNEX denied any wrongdoing Thursday. The indictment is likely to provide ammunition to those opposing efforts in Congress to lift some of the restrictions the 1982 decree imposed on the regional Bell companies. The landmark 1982 ruling by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene had prohibited the seven regional Bell holding companies from engaging in certain types of business, including processing computerized data. The indictment, obtained by the Justice Department's antitrust division, accused NYNEX through its Nashville, Tenn., subsidiary, Telco Research Corp., of providing data processing and information retrieval services over telephone lines from April 1986 to February 1987. The indictment did not cite possible penalties. Telco provided a computer and software to the long-distance company, MCI Communications Corp., to aid in making MCI's network more efficient, NYNEX spokesman Bob O'Brien said Thursday. He said Justice alleged that NYNEX did not provide enough of the computer to MCI. Justice said NYNEX violated terms of the 1982 consent decree, known as the Modification of Final Judgment, that prohibit NYNEX and the other regional Bell companies from providing information services. The consent decree was set up to divide different types of communication services between American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and the spinoff companies. ``Our position is that there was no violation of the MFJ,'' O'Brien said. NYNEX purchased Telco in April 1985 and ``Telco was providing service through MCI prior to our acquisition,'' O'Brien said. NYNEX in May 1986 asked Justice to scrutinize the computer service to avoid any possible violation, he added. The indictment said NYNEX modified the MCI agreement on two occasions, in April and October 1986. NYNEX, with Justice approval, subsequently tried to transfer title of the computer to MCI, but MCI didn't want it and NYNEX ended the agreement in February 1987, O'Brien said. In a statement, Assistant Attorney General James F. Rill said, ``A willful violation of any consent decree is a very serious matter deserving of criminal penalties. ``A court order is the law and companies bound by a decree are not free to deliberately or recklessly disregard that decree,'' Rill said. The Federal Communications Commission in February fined NYNEX a record $1.4 million for alleged $118.5 million in overcharges sold by NYNEX's purchasing arm to its two telephone companies, New York Telephone and New England Telephone. NYNEX appealed the fine.

DOC.HEAD: Judge OK's Sale of PTL Network to California Minister
DOC.TEXT: A judge accepted a California evangelist's $7 million bid for the PTL television network Thursday as the first step toward selling the rest of Jim Bakker's bankrupt empire for an additional $45 million. The religious cable network was sold to Morris Cerullo, an Assemblies of God pastor who heads Morris Cerullo World Evangalism Inc. of San Diego. The deal must also be approved by the Federal Communications Commission. Cerullo on Wednesday signed a $52 million contract to purchase all PTL assets if he could be guaranteed the cable network, PTL trustee Dennis Shedd told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Thurmond Bishop. Cerullo can back out of the deal to buy the rest of PTL, including Heritage USA, a retreat and religious theme park 10 miles south of Charlotte, N.C. But Shedd expects Cerullo will make good on his offer. ``He's the only person who went through the whole process of negotiations. And he put his money on the table,'' Shedd told reporters after the hearing. ``This may not be the terms everyone wants but ... it's the only terms we could get,'' Shedd said. ``It's the best thing out there.'' Cerullo on Wednesday deposited the $7 million for the network in an escrow account, said Brad Leggett, an attorney representing Shedd. Shedd said he will ask Bishop to set a date before mid-July for a hearing on selling the rest of the assets. Cerullo's organization has branches in Great Britain, Canada, Israel and Zimbabwe. In 1978, he unveiled plans for a $100 million ``world outreach center'' in San Diego, but unlike Heritage USA, it never materialized. ``It is our hope to go back and achieve what the Bakkers failed to do,'' said Cerullo's attorney, Tim Treadwell. Cerullo didn't attend the hearing. Treadwell said the ministry will most likely be moved to California. Earlier this month, evangelist Oral Roberts signed a $6.45 million contract giving him the right to buy the cable network unless someone else bid more or agreed to buy all of PTL's assets as a package. Roberts didn't return a telephone message left Thursday at his office in Tulsa, Okla. Bishop rejected four other offers, including an $8 million bid from Media Arts International Ltd., to purchase the cable network because the bidders wanted more time to negotiate. Treadwell said Cerullo would withdraw his offer if a delay was granted. In approving Cerullo's offer, the judge included a stipulation that cable television's Home Box Office must come to an agreement with Cerullo over transfer of lease arrangements. HBO provides a satellite for PTL. HBO had asked the court to block Shedd's deal with Roberts because it doubted the evangelist could make the $242,000 monthly payments for the use of its satellite. The closing date on the deal is Aug. 31, but can be extended if the FCC doesn't grant Cerullo a license by then, Leggett said. If the FCC rejects the license transfer due to some fault of Cerullo's, PTL could keep $1 million of the $7 million Cerullo would have paid for the network. PTL has been in bankruptcy proceedings since June 1987, three months after Bakker resigned in the sex-and-money scandal that led to his 45-year federal prison term for fraud and conspiracy. The failed ministry owes creditors millions of dollars. The PTL network still carries other evangelists' taped programs, but Heritage USA, where Bakker had his studios and church, has been closed since September. The 500-acre retreat also has five restaurants, a $10 million water park and two 500-room hotels, one of them unfinished. It includes about 1,700 undeveloped acres. Last year, Toronto businessman Stephen Mernick failed to close on a $65 million deal to buy PTL with bank financing. The lenders wanted title insurance for Heritage USA; Mernick could not obtain it because of a Catawba Indian lawsuit claiming that 144,000 acres, including the Heritage USA site, was illegally sold to the state in 1840.

DOC.HEAD: Central Bank Denies Rift Over Monetary Union
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's central bank denied Thursday that it differed with the government's pace and terms for a monetary union with East Germany. In a statement issued at a policy-making meeting, the Bundesbank said it wanted to ``counter recent impressions'' in the news media that the bank had not played a large enough role in negotiations on the monetary union agreement. The central bank also said it was ``satisfied'' that its requirements for a monetary union were met. The statement was similar to comments made late Wednesday by Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl, who said the central bank was in agreement with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government on the monetary union pact. ``I regret that the impression has arisen of a great confrontation, a war between the Bundesbank and Bonn. The impression is wrong,'' Poehl said Wednesday night. Earlier this year, the Bundesbank indicated it was opposed to rapid monetary union. But it soon altered its stance and expressed support for Kohl's push for quick union. Two weeks ago, the two German states signed a treaty under which they will become a single economic entity beginning July 2. Under the treaty, West Germany's deutsche mark will be legal tender for East Germans and all banking and monetary policy in East Germany will come under the Bundesbank's jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Firm Charged With Illegal Disposal of Hazardous Waste, Napalm Bombs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT that attorney in Utah sted California.
DOC.TEXT: A defunct petroleum disposal company was charged Thursday with illegally burning, dumping and storing hazardous waste, including surplus napalm bombs. Prosecutors alleged that a puddle of waste from the company was so noxious it melted the shoe soles of a passing jogger. ``An environmental crime is like a robbery or assault against all of us,'' said Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, who came to town to announce the first federal felony environmental prosecution in Utah. A 12-count indictment alleges Steven F. Self of Fallbrook, Calif., and his defunct Ekotek Inc. of knowingly ignoring federal environmental laws. The indictment provides a clear signal ``to environmental profiteers seeking to improperly cash in on the growing waste-handling business,'' Thornburgh said. The indictment alleges Ekotek ``duped environmentally conscious businesses into believing that waste materials were being properly disposed of.'' The indictment alleges conspiracy to violate the clean air, water and resources conservation and recovery acts and involves charges that Self and others illegally burned and discharged solvents, oils, grease and contaminated runoff, then concealed the violations by falsifying manifests and logs. Self's attorney in Salt Lake City didn't respond to telephone requests for comment. Before Ekotek was shut down by state regulators in October 1987, residents of nearby homes complained of malodorous smoke coming from the site. Prosecutors said a 17-year-old boy reported his shoe began to ``bubble and disintegrate'' after he accidentally stepped in a puddle while running by the site. Ekotek _ which was in the business of recycling or destroying waste oil products _ discharged into the public sewer system approximately 10,000 gallons of wastewater per day, the indictment said. The indictment alleges that in July 1986, Self arranged to accept two napalm bombs for ``testing, storage and treatment'' from the Navy Weapons Support Center in Fallbrook and later told state officials they had been properly disposed of. State explosives experts had to haul the bombs away the following year. Company vice president Steven F. Miller pleaded guilty Wednesday to three felony charges of conspiracy and violations of federal environmental laws. Miller, who agreed to testify against Self and cooperate with cleanup officials in exchange for his plea, faces up to 13 years in prison and a fine of up to $750,000. He remains free on his own recognizance. If convicted on all charges, Self and the company may be fined up to $24 million and Self would face a prison term of up to 45 years. Miller's California attorney, Barbara Caulfield, said her client would not comment before his sentencing July 31. The defendants are alleged to have purchased millions of gallons of oils and solvents and burned them as fuel in a refinery, which was about three miles from downtown Salt Lake City. State Department of Health officials said tens of thousands of gallons of wastes have leaked or been dumped into the ground and have contaminated nearby homes. Ekotek operated the site from 1981 until October 1987. Peter Stevenson, the Environmental Protection Agency's on-scene cleanup coordinator, said agency crews have been stabilizing and evaluating the site since 1988. It has designated for EPA Superfund cleanup.

DOC.HEAD: Searchers Find One Leak, but Not the Main One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to update with temporary search halt, NASA administrator news conference, picking up at the 6th graf previous, ``If the leak.''
DOC.TEXT: NASA workers found a tiny leak in Columbia's rear engine compartment Thursday, but judged it too small to have caused the hydrogen leak that delayed the shuttle launch. ``The feeling is at this point that's probably not what they're looking for,'' said Bruce Buckingham, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The search continued until late afternoon, then was halted so Columbia's on-board fuel tanks could be drained. Officials planned to increase pressure on the shuttle's external tank, which was filled with nonflammable helium, to find the main leak, Buckingham said. At a news conference in Washington, NASA administrator Richard Truly said a special test _ using another gas chilled to a liquid state _ might have to be run ``because the leak appeared only when the temperature got so cold.'' The external tank was being filled with more than a half-million gallons of super-cold liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen Tuesday when the leak was detected. NASA called off the launch, set for 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday, and drained the explosive propellant. Truly called the news conference to announce that NASA has launched a program to solicit new and innovative ideas to carry out President Bush's call for establishing a manned base on the moon and sending a human expedition to Mars in the next 30 years. He named retired Air Force Lt. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, a veteran of two Gemini and two Apollo space flights, to head the effort, which will receive $4.5 million. Engineers believe Columbia's leak is in or near a 17-inch valve in a pipe that carries fuel from the external tank to the main engines. If the leak is detected and repairs can be made at the launch pad, Columbia might be ready to lift off by the middle of next week. But if Columbia has to be returned to a hangar, the delay would be about a month, NASA officials said. Columbia's astronomy mission, with a $150 million observatory called Astro, already had been delayed two weeks because of repairs to the shuttle's cooling system. The latest postponement will mean even more changes to Astro's observing schedule. One of the prime targets, Comet Austin, is speeding away from Earth, making observations more difficult with every passing day. Halley's Comet was to have been studied had the mission proceeded as scheduled in March 1986, but the Challenger explosion pushed everything back.

DOC.HEAD: 9-Day Shipping Strike on Danube River Ends
DOC.TEXT: A nine-day strike by 10,000 shipping and harbor workers that paralyzed traffic on the Danube River ended Thursday, the state news agency Rompres reported. The strike had left Romanian and foreign ships stranded for miles along the famed riverway. Rompres said the shipping union and the Ministries of Labor, Social Security, Finance, Economy and Transport reached agreement on the workers' demands, issued in a May 23 communique, The demands included a 50 percent salary hike and retroactive payment of night shifts for the past three years. Unions at Romania's largest steel plant, in the port of Galati, said the length of the strike was beginning to affect the national economy, noting their plant was running out of coal and limestone. Sailors, dockers, harbor workers and administrators struck in the Danube ports of Galati, Sulina, Tulcea, Cernavoda and Braila. The government had previously agreed to some of the demands presented by the shipping union on April 25: a 25 percent salary increase for night shifts, allowances in hard currency and food allocations for the merchant marine. Union leader Gheorghe Vrabia was quoted as saying Sunday: ``We do not require the increase of our salaries. We just want to be given back what had been taken back from us in the dictatorial regime (of Nicolae Ceausescu). These are our rights and we will not cease the strike until our claims will be met.'' Ceausescu was overthrown in a popular revolt last December and executed Dec. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Police Patrol Ethiopian University Campus
DOC.TEXT: Police are patrolling a university campus in Ethiopia's capital to prevent further student demonstrations protesting the recent execution of 12 top generals, Western diplomats said Thursday. The envoys said students at the University of Addis Ababa began boycotting lectures and staging demonstrations after the executions were reported May 21. The most recent protest was Wednesday. The executions were reported on radio and television two days after a special court convicted the officers of trying to overthrow the government. ``The students began their protest immediately and riot police moved in,'' said one Western diplomat. He said there were reports the students removed photographs of President Mengistu Haile Mariam from the walls and replaced them with those of the executed generals. He also said there were reports police arrested about 300 students and held them three days. There were, however, unconfirmed reports some of the students were still in custody. The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, were interviewed by telephone from Addis Ababa. The generals, including some of Ethiopia's most distinguished military leaders, were convicted of staging an abortive coup against Mengistu's government in May 1989. Loyalist troops crushed the revolt in three days, and at least 13 generals were killed in the fighting. The executed officers included Maj. Gen. Haile Gebre-Michael, 57, commander of all ground forces; his deputy, Maj. Gen. Alemayehou Desta, 55; and air force chief of staff, Brig. Gen. Solomon Begashaw. The trial of another 35 senior officers is continuing while an additional 130 officers are awaiting trial.

Here is a transcript of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's comments to reporters Thursday after his second meeting with President Bush, as translated by Gorbachev's interpreter. Q. ``Have you resolved the German question? With a new melody?'' Gorbachev: ``Well, I think it is not here that the German question will be resolved.'' Q. ``Why not?'' Gorbachev: ``I'll explain. But this extended meeting of two delegations was dedicated to an exchange of views about the development of the situation in Europe with due regard to the settlement of all aspects relating to the external aspects of German unification. I think that we have had a very substantive discussion with the President, and also with other members of both the delegations who participated. We understand the positions of each other. ``I hope that we understand each other's concerns better as well, and in this context both the US side and the Soviet side put forward certain ideas, certain suggestions. And I believe, and the President has agreed, that this exchange of views now requires that our foreign ministers have a more in-depth discussion of these issues and the experts who also participate, and we have instructed the ministers to have that discussion. I understand that of course you would like to find out more than I've said, but we don't know everything yet. Q. ``Do you still think President Bush is dictating: NATO in Germany, Germany inside NATO?'' Gorbachev: ``Well, I will say this to this: President Bush is ... what President Bush is doing is probably protecting ... defending his viewpoint. I think that dictating is unacceptable in situations when there are so many participants involved in this problem.'' Q. ``Have you heard a different melody today or the ...'' Gorbachev: ``Well, I think since ... since we have decided that our ministers and experts should have a more in-depth discussion of what was discussed today, I think that means that something has emerged that requires such ... and our view is that ... our view is ... our view is that ... our view is that as a result of this settlement of this question, not only the security of the Soviet Union and of other countries should not be diminished but also no damage should be done to the positive processes underway now in Europe and elsewhere in the world and certainly no damage should be done to the Soviet-US relationship which is very important. And that's why we have to act in a very, very responsible way.'' Q. ``Have you discussed economic assistance, and are you going to ask for ... seek more assistance economically?'' Gorbachev: ``Well, let's just say ... well, let's just say that ... let me say that in the morning, we had a rather conceptual, philosophical discussion with the President, specifically, broadly on US-Soviet relationship in this rapidly-changing world. And we said that without Malta, without that meeting that we had in Malta, and the exchange of views that we had there, really developments could have taken a rather different course, and we predicted over there in Malta, that there might be problems that we ... challenges that we will have to meet, and it is very important to act in a responsible and prudent way. And that is how we really acted after Malta. ``And we have said that it is very important to have understanding between our countries, and to continue to have that understanding. So that was a rather broad and conceptual discussion about the role of our two countries. And in that context, we did discuss also the economic trends, and I made some explanations to the President about the situation ... the economic reforms that we are undertaking in the Soviet Union. ``But I would say that that was a discussion in that kind of broad context. In addition, those economic matters, the matters of economic cooperation, were discussed by our ministers and tomorrow the Presidents will continue this discussion. ``Thank you.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Arafat a0681 and AM-Israeli-Peace a0677
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Thursday rebuffed Israel's plea to end all contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization after an attempted beachfront attack on Israeli civilians. But the White House condemned the action as a ``cowardly attempt to target innocent people.'' ``We are deeply concerned about the responsibility for this attack and we are looking into it,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said about Wednesday's foiled attack on beaches south of Tel Aviv by seaborne Palestinian guerillas loyal to a top PLO official. Other officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, stressed that no decision had been made on whether to keep talking with the PLO or break off the discussions. PLO chief Yasser Arafat said in Baghdad the PLO was not responsible for the attack and that he does not have the authority to take action against the PLO official whose guerrillas claimed responsibility, even if he wanted to. He said only the PLO Council could expel that official, Mohammed Abbas, also known as Abul Abbas, an Arafat loyalist and member of the PLO Executive Committee who planned the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro. Fitzwater told reporters: ``We don't have any conclusions at this point. We are investigating this matter and reviewing all the information we can gather on it. We are very concerned about what the ramifications might be but at this point we do not want to express any conclusions.'' Asked if continued discussions with the PLO was under review in light of the fact that the administration has conditioned such talks on PLO renunciation of terrorism, Fitzwater said, ``No, not at this point.'' He said the United States first wants to investigate the matter and see who is responsible. ``President Bush condemns the terrorist attack yesterday in Israel and is outraged by what appears to be a cowardly attempt to target innocent people,'' Fitzwater said in a prepared statement. Other U.S. officials, asking not to be identified, said they don't consider Arafat's remarks to be the official PLO response. At the same time Arafat spoke, the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, Robert Pelletreau, was meeting in Tunis with PLO officials. The U.S. officials said they are awaiting a reply from the PLO to questions set forth by Pelletreau. Once all the information is made available from the PLO and other sources, the officials said a judgment will be made on how to proceed. On Wednesday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said it was too early to say whether the attack would affect the 17-month dialogue with the PLO on ways to peace talks started between Israel and Palestinians, but added that ``we would view this as a very serious matter.'' Thursday the State Department referred all queries to Fitzwater. Israel urged the United States to end all contacts with the PLO after seaborne Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Abbas tried to attack crowded beaches and hotels. Israeli leaders called Wednesday's attack proof that PLO leader Yasser Arafat had violated his December 1988 pledge to renounce terror. It was Arafat's pledge that led the United States to open a dialogue with the PLO after years of refusing to negotiate with the organization. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured by Israeli forces who headed off the attack. No Israelis were hurt in the attack, even though tens of thousands were on beaches for the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. Fitzwater said Bush commended the action of Israeli forces. Israeli officials claimed Abbas and Arafat must have known about the attack in advance. Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Motti Amihai said Abbas and Arafat met in Tunis, Tunisia, five days before the attack. ``We believe that Abul Abbas at that time knew for sure that this operation is going to take place,'' Amihai said. ``I think there is little doubt that Arafat personally, and also probably (Libyan leader Moammar) Gadhafi, knew beforehand about this operation.'' Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said on Israeli radio that Israel would try to persuade the United States to abandon contacts with the PLO. ``If we can convince them (the United States) there that the basic assumption for dialogue no longer exists, then it's possible that the United States will decide to cease the dialogue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Say Power Of University's Next Leader Should Be Checked
DOC.TEXT: Following the resignation of the controversial president of the University of South Carolina, some legislators called Thursday for strict spending guidelines for his successor. The surprise resignation Wednesday of the university's president, James B. Holderman, followed weeks of controversy over his spending during fund-raising drives. He was criticized for using luxury hotels, chartered jets and chauffeured limousines. In announcing his resignation, which is effective July 1, Holderman didn't refer to the controversy. The 54-year-old administrator said he was seeking ``new personal and professional challenges.'' Some lawmakers said the university should take a lesson from other Southeastern schools, where less is spent on fund-raising. At the other universities, presidents enjoy much smaller discretionary accounts than Holderman's $533,000 personal account, funded by concessions. ``It'll be important for the new president to get out into the state, to get people to know him and not give the impression that he's a jet-setter,'' said state Rep. Mike Fair. Fair and state Reps. Herb Kirsh and David Beasley said spending guidelines imposed on Holderman two weeks ago by USC's board of trustees should be vigorously applied to his successor. ``The board needs to have a long, hard, solid meeting to determine what they are looking for in a president,'' Beasley said. Holderman, 54, ran the university since 1977. He regularly used luxury hotels on fund-raising trips, hired $35-an-hour chauffeured limousines in Washington, and chartered jets or flew first class, according to records from the university and private foundations affiliated with the school. Holderman argued that expensive hotel rooms were necessary to woo wealthy donors. Holderman first came under criticism in 1986 for spending on his travels, giving expensive gifts to donors and students and paying top dollar to lure celebrity lecturers and speakers to the school. Jihan Sadat, widow of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat, was paid $200,000 to teach a course in Egyptian culture for three semesters in 1985 and 1986. More recently, the school has drawn criticism for paying actor-director Robby Benson $158,367 to teach filmmaking and $15,600 for rent, with Holderman kicking in $10,000 from his discretionary fund for travel and moving expenses. Benson announced Thursday he wasn't renewing his contract and cited Holderman's resignation as the reason. Trustee Charlie G. Williams, state superintendent of education, said revisions in the powers of the president of the 40,000-student school have yet to be discussed by the 23 trustees. ``The board should look at what other universities are doing in fund-raising. We should not be so proud as to not look at Clemson; they're spending modest amounts and raising a lot of money,'' Fair said.
