DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Wades into Crowd Near White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3 to CORRECT motorcade destination to Soviet Embassy, sted Soviet Union; picks up 4th graf, `Asked about ...' ^By LAWRENCE L. KNUTSON
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev waded into a rush-hour crowd on a downtown Washington sidewalk Thursday, shaking hands with pedestrians and declaring, ``I feel really at home.'' The bystanders cheered and applauded, and some pedestrians yelled, ``Gorby, over here.'' A few in the crowd waved small American flags. Gorbachev had just concluded his second round of talks with President Bush when he stopped his motorcade en route from the White House to the Soviet Embassy. He walked calmly up to the crowd of 500 or more people who had been waiting in hopes of catching a glimpse of him. After a few seconds on the sidewalk, he walked the street, trailed by a phalanx of security officials. Asked about the summit, Gorbachev told onlookers, ``We want to further our relationship.'' He said people ``want a better tomorrow. And the rest,'' he said, ``is not too important.'' At one point Gorbachev could hardly be seen as the crowd pushed toward him, most of the men and women holding out their hands. Gorbachev shook several during the encounter near the corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and 15th Street. Within a few moments, he was back inside his car on his way to the Soviet Embassy. Journalists crowded around as word spread of his stroll. Such unscheduled stops have become something of a Gorbachev trademark. He did much the same thing in 1987 while visiting Washington. On a Canadian stopover in Ottawa earlier this week, Gorbachev walked through the downtown shopping district for 45 minutes, shaking hands and chatting with Canadians who rushed to the scene when they heard broadcast reports he was walking about. On Wednesday morning, after laying a wreath at a Canadian war memorial, Gorbachev and his host, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, left their cars and walked several hundred yards toward Parliament Hill, making their way through crowds of delighted people.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Warned To Take Precautions in Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Americans in the Middle East or headed there should be especially careful because of the rising level of violence in the region, the State Department said on Thursday. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in a statement there have been a number of terrorist incidents in the aftermath of the murder of eight Palestinians in Israel. The latest incident was the attempt Wednesday to launch a seaborne attack on Israel. Ms. Tutwiler also noted that anti-American groups in the region have publicly threatened to attack American citizens or U.S. interests. Such statements have been issued by leaders of Hezbollah and of the Palestine Islamic Jihad and by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Embargoed for release at 8:15 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of remarks by President Bush during a toast Thursday night honoring Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev: Friends, distinguished guests _ and, especially, Mr. President and Mrs. Gorbachev: Barbara and I are delighted to welcome you to the White House _ to share ``bread and salt'' with us on this special evening. We're now nearing the end of a momentous day _ the first of four in this Washington Summit. And here in the White House, Mr. President, we will meet again _ this time to sign our names to a series of agreements that signify the progress our two nations have made in forging a new relationship. Agreements on everything from nuclear testing and chemical weapons _ to expanded contacts between the people of America and the Soviet Union. These agreements are a continuation of all that began in Malta just six months ago _ a foundation we can build on. Proof that differences can be resolved _ even while others remain. And let me assure President Gorbachev _ whatever deep differences divided us in the past, the United States and the American people approach every issue with a sincere belief that our two nations can find common ground. Indeed, because of our unique positions in the world _ we must find common ground. We meet at a time of great and historic change _ in the Soviet Union, in Europe, and around the world. Such profound change is unsettling, but also exhilarating. We do not shrink from the challenges before us but welcome them, determined to build the foundations of enduring peace and security. Mr. President, you deserve great credit for the course you've chosen _ for the political and economic reforms you've introduced _ and for creating within the Soviet Union a commitment to change. As I said this morning as I welcomed you to the White House, we want to see perestrokia succeed _ we want to see this transition now under way in the Soviet Union maintain its momentum. Mr. President, it is said that your country is ``the land of possibilities.'' You have demonstrated the truth of that statement, and we've seen this past year that ours is a world of possibilities. That our time is a time of historic change _ a time when men and nations can transform history _ can turn possibility into progress, into peace. So let us raise our glasses: To our guests, President and Mrs. Gorbachev; to the growing friendship between the American and Soviet people; and to the possibilities now open to us _ to the prospect of progress, and lasting peace.

DOC.HEAD: City Buys Rock for Tea Garden
DOC.TEXT: When Phoenix builds a Japanese tea garden, it doesn't fool around. The city has bought 900 tons of rocks, and wants to put the garden over an interstate. Phoenix plans to build the $2.9 million garden and a $400,000 replica of an Irish farmhouse in honor of Himeji, Japan, and Ennis, Ireland, two of its sister cities. The garden and the farmhouse are to be part of Deck Park, planned for a deck over Interstate 10 downtown. The park is scheduled to open late next year. Architects and landscapers from Himeji picked $14,000 worth of rocks for the 2{-acre garden. ``I don't think they realize how big these rocks are, because by the time we dug out some of these monsters, they were 8 to 10 feet across,'' said Dale Longbreak of Red Mountain Mining Co., which collected the rocks north of Mesa and delivered them Wednesday. But sometimes 1,800,000 pounds of rocks isn't enough. The architects and landscapers want 15 more kinds of rock to make the garden authentic, said parks official Mike Whiting.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Bjt Rdp
Gorbachev's High Public Profile Brings Bush To Rose Garden
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comments by U.S. and Soviet spokesmen, picks up 7th graf pvs, In his welcoming xxx etc.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was nearly upstaged by summit guest Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday as he sought to maintain a low profile while Gorbachev made frequent public appearances and pronounceents. Finally, Bush emerged at the White House in early evening to give to reporters his side of his two opening day's sessions and his impressions of the Soviet leaders. ``I feel very comfortable with him. I feel very free to bring up positions I know he doesn't agree with. That hasn't always been the case. There have been times when people banged their shoes when they didn't agree. That's not the tone of this meeting,'' Bush said. But by the time Bush made his originally unplanned remarks, Gorbachev had already spoken to a group of American thinkers, answered questions, and held two impromptu news conferences outside the White House. White House press officials, who had moved their entire operation out of the White House and to a college gymnasium about a half mile away, were clearly taken by surprise by Gorbachev's tactics. Earlier, Bush quickly got down to business in welcoming remarks by telling Gorbachev not to ``lose sight of the differences'' between the superpowers and specifying Lithuania as a prime example. Although Bush and Gorbachev exchanged cordial and upbeat greetings at a welcoming ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House, Bush's remarks were pointed in places. But after their initial session, Bush laid low for the afternoon. Gorbachev, meanwhile, was busy presenting his case. Finally, Bush, apparently smoked out by Gorbachev's constant public comments, echoed the Soviet leaders' comments on their progress in striving for reaching common ground on the issue of German unity. ``We've got a big agenda,'' Bush said. ``I am convinced that out of this meeting we will narrow our differences.'' He described Gorbachev as a man he could talk to. ``When he talks, I listen. When I talk, he listens. There is no shouting,'' Bush said. In his welcoming remarks, Bush referred to the late Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov as ``one of the world's great minds,'' quoted him and declared: ``Sakharov knew that lasting peace and progress are inseparable from freedom _ that nations will only be fully safe when all people are fully free.'' ``The agreements we've reached cannot cause us to lose sight of some of the differences that remain. Lithuania is one such issue,'' Bush said. ``We believe that good faith dialogue between the Soviet leaders and representatives of the Baltic people is the proper approach _ and we hope to see the process go forward.'' As recently as Wednesday, in Canada, Gorbachev had spoken harshly of the methods used by the Lithuanians in their independence effort. But the Soviet leader, who also had complained about Western pressure on what he considers an internal problem, did not mention the rebellious Baltic state in his welcoming remarks. Bush called his schedule with Gorbachev ``a working summit in the strictest sense of the term'' and said they would join in ``an open and honest search for common ground.'' Between their opening morning session and a 4 p.m. second session, the president had no public events scheduled. By contrast, Ronald Reagan made a number of separate appearances while Gorbachev was maintaining his own schedule during their summits. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said that Bush was using the time to meet with advisers to discuss the first summit session. ``He's also got a country to run,'' Popadiuk said.

DOC.HEAD: Apollo Capsule To Remain in Storage
DOC.TEXT: The charred Apollo capsule in which three astronauts died 23 years ago will remain in storage in Virginia rather than be buried in an abandoned missile silo or given to a museum, NASA said Thursday. The capsule was to have been shipped in May from Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., to its final resting place in a silo at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. It was to have been buried on top of debris from the 1986 Challenger explosion, America's only other space tragedy. The transfer temporarily was halted after curators at the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum said they would like to acquire the capsule as an historic artifact. The Kansas Cosmosphere and Space Center in Hutchinson, Kan., also had expressed interest. NASA spokesman Mark Hess said the decision to keep the capsule at Langley indefinitely was made after conferring with relatives of the three astronauts who died and former Apollo astronauts. ``They just asked us to reconsider and keep it, or store it in another way,'' Hess said. Displaying the capsule at the Smithsonian or anywhere else was never seriously considered, Hess said. ``I don't think you'd find a soul in NASA who thought that was an appropriate alternative,'' he said. Mike Stephenson, associate director of the Kansas Cosmosphere and Space Center, said he's pleased the capsule will not be buried in the silo. His museum had been interested in the capsule _ and still would be _ for memorial purposes rather than for display. ``It's certainly important that the artifact be preserved,'' Stephenson said. The capsule has been stored in a locked container at Langley since the 1967 fire, which claimed the lives of astronauts Virgil ``Gus'' Grissom, Roger B. Chaffee and Edward H. White II. It briefly was removed a few weeks ago so its heat shield could be cut into pieces for shipping. The astronauts died when fire engulfed the capsule during a countdown rehearsal for the first manned Apollo mission. The fire, in a cabin filled with 100 percent oxygen, was triggered by a spark when a broken or bruised wire beneath Grissom's couch contacted metal. Thirty-one cartons of hardware and investigative material were moved to Kennedy Space Center in late April for burial with the capsule. They will be returned to Langley.

Here is a transcript of President Bush's comments to reporters Thursday after his second meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush: ``Well, I'd just say at the end of a very interesting day that the talks have gone reasonably well. The mood is very positive in the sense that I had a very good, and I mean genuinely, not in a diplomatic sense, very good exchange, for a couple of hours this morning with President Gorbachev. I'm very well pleased with the ground we covered. ``This afternoon's meeting, the tone was positive. Differences remain. We talked about the German question there. I believe President Gorbachev indicated after the meeting that he didn't think the whole question of Germany would be resolved. Certainly we're not in any position to resolve that entire question. But when he said that the differences were ... had been narrowed somewhat, I'm taking some heart from that and we'll continue these discussions tomorrow. ``But I think, given the difficulties of some of the problems we face, the talks have gone certainly as well as I could have expected up to now, and we still have a lot of discussion. But we've touched on almost every contentious issue, as well as spelling out the areas in which we have common interests and where things are going very well between us. ``So, that's a report for tonight, and tomorrow I'll be able to say a little bit more. But I won't go into details that we've agreed we're not going to talk about.'' Q: ``None of us understand why you can't sign a trade agreement if it's all wrapped up.'' Bush: ``Well, we haven't said whether we can sign a trade agreement or not, yet.'' Q: ``Why?'' Bush: ``Will get ... we haven't discussed that yet.'' Q: ``(Inaudible) ... instructed the foreign ministers to discuss something that emerged today about Germany, sir. Could you tell us about that?'' Bush: ``No, because we agreed we wouldn't. We agreed we'd let them discuss it ...'' Q: ``Will you confirm that ...'' Bush: ``... and I will say I think ... I think when I heard what President Gorbachev said, that is exactly what we agreed he would talk about. So, we're just going to stay with that guidance.'' Q: ``When will they meet ...'' Bush: ``I don't know, probably tomorrow, probably tomorrow.'' Q: ``Was there some narrowing of differences that made you decide the foreign ministers should get together with some specific details you have them working on?'' Bush: ``Well, that was a proposal that President Gorbachev made, and I think the foreign ministers need to discuss in great detail the subjects we discussed to see. But I was ... I took ... I must say, Michael, I took some heart from that. I was encouraged by that. Our position has been stated and restated, and we'll see where we go. ``But I think the important point is we could talk very frankly, no rancor there, and let's hope some of the differences have been narrowed. But, when he says this whole German question will not be solved at a meeting of this nature, I would agree with that. We consult our allies, and we don't ... and he knows that. He knows that we have a lot of consultation. But, basically, my position is the same as it was when we went into the meetings. But I'm listening very carefully, listening to their views and trying to understand their positions.'' Q: ``Did you offer something specific for the foreign ministers to discuss on Germany?'' Bush: ``I think they do have some specifics to discuss, but there's ... that can be discussed after they get through talking about those things.'' Q: ``Mr. President, did you offer any concessions. Did you ...'' Bush: ``No, I want to stay with the guidance that we agreed on, but I ... our position is well known and the fundamentals have not changed. The fundamentals have not changed.'' Q: ``Has he taken offense to your stand on Lithuania or your remarks today at the welcoming ceremony?'' Bush: ``He didn't seem to take offense to anything. He knows that we had differences. I've been very up-front with him, and he's been very, very direct and up-front with me. So, that's one of the good things about the meeting. When great powers have differences, sometimes they haven't been able to talk about them in a civil way. We are talking about them in a very civil way, and I commend him for that approach. It's one I like, it's one I understand and it's one I think benefits not just the United States and the Soviet Union but a lot of other countries as well.'' Q: ``Would a trade bill be contingent on what you hear on Lithuania?'' Bush: ``Well, we're going to discuss the details of that ... probably get into some of that tomorrow.'' Q: ``Do he feel like you have a better understanding on about ... on Germany, being that he's more ready to come your way than you are to his?'' Bush: ``We're not dealing on that. Look, we agreed to some guidance, he and I, and I'm going to stick with it, and he did. And I think that's a good sign. We're in the middle of some discussions about where it stands.''
