DOC.HEAD: WASHN: it stands.
DOC.TEXT: Q: ``Why do you think that it's going so well? Both of you have talked about a really good relationship that the two of you in the talks, the hours you've spent. Why do you think this time there has been such a ... is it a good chemistry?'' Bush: ``Well, I don't know. It's a good question and I feel very comfortable with him. I feel very free to bring up positions that I know he doesn't agree with, and as I've said that hasn't always been the case. There've been times when people banged their shoes when they didn't agree. And we don't ... that's not the mood or the tone of this meeting. And we have both realized we're engaged in very, very historic and important work here. ``And I think his ... I think when these meetings are over the people in this country are going to be pleased with some of the positions he takes concerning U.S. interests. And, hopefully I can be reassuring to the people in the Soviet Union about the kind of relationship we want. So the tone of it is important so that we can try to quote, narrow differences, unquote.'' Q: ``Mr. President, does either side have a better understanding of the other's position on Lithuania now? Have you narrowed any differences?'' Bush: ``That subject has been dicussed but not in the plenary meetings and not in great detail yet. It will certainly be discussed in much more detail.'' Q: ``(Inaudible) ... your discussion on Germany. Was there any similar encourage around Lithuania?'' Bush: ``As I say, that matter has not been discussed, and I can't quantify for you my hopes one each important question and that is an important question.'' Q: ``Mr. President, have you backed off anything since his comments yesterday about dictating to the Soviets?'' Bush: ``I don't recall ... you mean something he said in Canada?'' Q: ``Yes, sir.'' Bush: ``Well, I think when I said out there that we're dealing from positions of unique responsibility, I think he understood that I have a certain respect for the standing of the Soviet Union and I'm not attempting to dictate. I'm ... but I clearly am entitled to and will put forward the views of the American side as forcefully as I can. ``But you don't get any progress if you ... if you give the impression that you're in a situation of dictation. The age of the dictator is over. Don't you remember my speech here a while back?'' Q: ``Well, Mulroney seems to think that you're ... most of the West is insensitive to what the Soviets suffered in World War II.'' Bush: ``I think Mulroney, with whom I've talked twice in the last two days, knows very well that the United States is not insensitive to the fact that the Soviets lost 27 million lives in a war, and I know Mr. Gorbachev understands that I'm quite sensitive to that. ``I think he's also sensitive to the fact that a lot of American kids lost their lives. I reminded him that I was the only one of the two of us that was old enough to remember it from being there.'' Q: ``That's why he doesn't want Germany in NATO.'' Bush: ``Well, you're putting words into his mouth.'' Q: ``Do you have enough time in three days, or is that too short a period of time?'' Bush: ``Well, I don't know. I think the Camp David meeting where we have a lot of one-on-one time is going to be fruitful. I think the ... I think we've got to do better on simultaneous as opposed to consecutive translations to speed things up and today we ... in the Oval Office, we had the ... we had the longer version. So I'd like to move that up a little bit. But I guess there's never enough time when you're dealing with an agenda that is this important. ``We've got regional questions that we haven't touched on yet. We have more refinement on ... each side to refine its views on the European questions. We have arms control that's still being talked about behind the scenes but that he and I have not gone into. So we've got a big agenda. And whether we'll have enough time to do everything that he wants and that I want, I don't know. I am convinced that out of this meeting we will narrow differences and that two ships are less apt to pass in the night based on simple misunderstanding. And I'm convinced of that, because I can talk very frankly with him. And when he talks, I listen. And when I talk, he listens. We're not shouting at each other. There's not a rancor in there. ``And once in a while both of us ... we feel strongly about something, we might get a little more passionate than the rest of the time in presenting our views. But I'm very pleased with that mood of wanting to ... his wanting to understand the United States' position, my having an opportunity to discuss it. And I hope he understand the receptivity on my part.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: my part.''
DOC.TEXT: Q: ``Mr. President, may I try once more on the question of Germany?'' Bush: ``You can try, but I'm not going to give you any more, because we agreed with the President of the Soviet Union on a guidance ... if you want me to read it to you again, I'll get my notes out, but I can't help you on it. Nice try. Another question, though, maybe.'' Q: ``Mr. President, have you noticed a change in the Soviet President since Malta? Have his domestic problems constrained him at all in your talks?'' Bush: ``He's six months older. No, I don't really ... I don't ...'' Q: ``Has he brought up his own domestic problems and offered that as a stumbling block to any solutions?'' Bush: ``No, no. He's not done that. He's not trying to hide anything, nor is he wringing his hands. To me there is a certain ... and I don't know if his friends felt this way ... but a certain strength and confidence that was there in Malta and is certainly still there now. And you could feel that. I mean, this wasn't just a casual observation. You ... I felt strongly about that. So I don't feel a weakened presence or anything of that nature. I feel a man determined to do his job.'' Q: ``Do you think there's anything you can or should do to help him in the short term?'' Bush: ``Well, I think I'm going to do what's in the national interest of the United States, our security interests, our global interests. And working closely with the Soviet Union ... a lot of questions ... is in our interest. And so with that approach in mind I think maybe we can ... he can go away feeling that he's got people here that are not just dealing from some innate animosity towards the Soviet Union. ``We're in a fantastic era of change. And we focus on the problems at meetings like this, but we ought not to neglect the fact that we're sitting here talking to the head of the Soviet Union at a time when Eastern Europe for the most part enjoys the democratic process and enjoys a freedom that none of us would have predicted possible. And a lot of that is because of the way in which Mr. Gorbachev has conducted himself. ``So, there's some problems out there, but we ought not to overlook the fact that we've come a long, long way. And there is less tension in terms of world catastrophe, but there's still some big problems. So it's that kind of an approach that I'm bringing to these meetings.'' Q: ``Sir, was there any progress today on START or CFE?'' Bush: ``Well, that's going on but not ... it didn't come up ... the arms control agenda was not discussed today.'' Q: ``Do you think you're going to Moscow?'' Bush: ``Huh?'' Q: ``Do you think he'll invite you to Moscow?'' Bush: ``Eventually.'' Q: ``Did you watch him out of the car, sir?'' Bush: ``Eventually. Huh?'' Q: ``Did you watch him when he get out of the car down there on 15th Street?'' Bush: ``No, I didn't see that.'' Q: ``A big crowd.'' Bush: ``Was it?'' Q: ``A big crowd, yes. I think he's taking your advice about parades.'' Bush: ``(Chuckling.) How was it received?'' Q: ``When he left he indicated that he was hoping there would be more in-depth discussion. Were there in-depth discussions today?'' Bush: ``I thought they were in-depth. I thought ...'' Q: ``He didn't seem to ...'' Bush: ``Well, I don't know ... I think he thinks they were in-depth.'' (Chuckles.) Q: ``Did you talk with him about the handshaking out on the street?'' (Inaudible.) Bush: ``No, we didn't. We didn't discuss that.'' Q: ``You didn't really settle anything today.'' Q: ``Did you come out here because you feared ... (inaudible) ... won the game and he was getting all the publicity by ...'' Bush: ``Michael, I knew you'd want ... (laughter) ... I knew you'd want a debriefing. (Laughter.) You know how I'm jealous about air time. It's terrible. (Laughter.) You know how I am. I'll see you guys ... you've got to stop laughing.'' (Laughter.)

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Collapses in Courtroom, Taken to Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with diagnosis of erosive gastritis, condition stable. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Asked if...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: Former Philippines first lady Imelda Marcos collapsed and coughed up blood Thursday during her federal racketeering trial and was taken by ambulance to a hospital. Mrs. Marcos, who twice in the last month had fallen ill with high blood pressure, was carried out on a stretcher, an oxygen mask on her face, and was taken to New York Hospital. Tests showed evidence of bleeding in her stomach, said Jonathan Weil, a hospital spokesman. Her condition was listed as stable. He said doctors concluded that she has erosive gastritis, a condition in which acid produced by the stomach erodes the organ's lining. Mrs. Marcos, 60, was treated with intravenous medication to suppress the production of acid, Weil said. ``It is expected that she will be in the hospital for several days until her condition, which is not life-threatening, has improved,'' he said. The spokesman said Mrs. Marcos was ``alert, conscious, awake and not excessively in pain.'' The condition wasn't thought to be related to the blood pressure problem, said Dr. David Case, an internist who has been treating Mrs. Marcos for high blood pressure. Asked if the problem could be stress-related, he said, ``It could be.'' The incident occurred just as Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerry Spence, completed cross examining a witness. Mrs. Marcos began coughing into a black handkerchief and then slumped forward in her chair. ``I heard a deep groan and she passed out on the table,'' Spence said. Jurors watched as her lawyers and supporters rushed to her aid. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan quickly excused the jurors until Tuesday and cleared the courtroom. An attorney for Mrs. Marcos, Benjamin Cassiday, said that she was ``gagging on her own blood'' and that her doctor, who was in attendance, instructed aides to hold her head up as he administered to her. ``When I saw her face and throwing up blood, I thought she was going to die,'' Cassiday said. According to James Linn, attorney for Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, Mrs. Marcos hemorrhaged from her nose and mouth as she fell forward and clutched her left hand to the side of her head. ``It was terrible. I never saw so much blood come out of someone,'' Khashoggi said. Linn, who was sitting with his client about 8 feet from Mrs. Marcos, said she appeared to have fainted. Others said she apparently was not fully conscious as she was taken from the courtroom to the nurse's office. Since her first attack on April 26, Mrs. Marcos has worn a special blood pressure monitoring device that intermittenly buzzes. She was wearing it on Thursday when she collapsed. ``If she's not well enough to participate in her own defense and if the doctors don't think she's well enough, I won't let her back for all the tea in China,'' said another Marcos lawyer, John Bartko. Mrs. Marcos has been on trial since March 20 on charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. She is accused of having helped her late husband, former Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos, steal more than $220 million from their country's treasury to buy four New York buildings and artwork. Khashoggi is charged with fraud and obstructing justice for allegedly faking documents to show that he owned the real estate and paintings. ``I think the agony of a lengthy, drawn-out trial is taking its toll on her as it has on all of us,'' Cassiday said. Family members at the hospital included Mrs. Marcos' daughter, Irene, her sister-in-law, Fortuna Barba, and her step-sister, a nun, Sister Bellarmine. Her illness came one day after Mrs. Marcos became upset when the judge angrily rebuked Spence in front of the jury. Mrs. Marcos had appeared close to tears as Spence and Keenan had a heated exchange about whether the attorney had made misleading statements to the jury.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Dept. Sues Va. Sandwich Maker Over Bacteria Complaints
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name in lede from Sandwiches Inc. to Stewart Sandwiches Inc.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Thursday it is seeking a court order to enjoin Stewart Sandwiches Inc. of Norfolk, Va. from making and distributing sandwiches until it complies with federal health laws. The complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Norfolk charges that Stewart made sandwiches containing potentially life-threatening bacteria. Stewart, which claims to be the world's largest manufacturer of sandwiches sold in vending machines and convenience stores, is accused in the lawsuit of failing to control bacteria contamination at its plant in violation of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. ``We will not tolerate any threat to the purity of this nation's food suypply,'' said Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the Civil Division. There was no answer at company headquarters in Norfolk. The department said the Food and Drug Administration received a complaint April 12 from Florida authorities that bacteria had been found in a sandwich made by Stewart and sold in that state. The same day, the FDA received a complaint from Louisiana officials that sandwiches shipped to that state were also contaminated, the department said. Two private test laboratories hired by Stewart also found bacteriological contamination during an inspection of the company's cooked food section in April, the department said. Three inspections in 1989 by the FDA found unsanitary conditions and evidence of bacteria, the department said. The complaint also asks injunctions against Stewart's president, Theodore J. Broecker, and Donald R. Beard, senior vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Family Hopes to Show Gorbachev Typical American Farm
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto MP4
DOC.TEXT: The Brand family scurried Thursday to get the farm spruced up for some special guests: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa. ``I'll clean the house if I have time,'' said Cecilia Brand, who learned Wednesday that the Russians might be coming to the farm about 20 miles south of Minneapolis. ``This was a total surprise,'' said Mrs. Brand, 54. ``... I'm excited _ and nervous.'' It wasn't certain the Gorbachevs would visit the farm during their stop in Minnesota on Sunday. But Mrs. Brand said she'd been told the Soviet president would probably arrive that evening after meeting with business and agricultural leaders in Minneapolis. ``We think of ours as a typical American farm and want to convey what American farm life is like,'' Mrs. Brand said as she stopped to relax for a few minutes during a hectic Thursday. The Brands were trying to keep up with their chores and field work as they clean the barn and other areas and mow the lawn. If the weather is nice, the Brands would like to sit around the picnic table in their large yard and talk with the Gorbachevs, telling them about their family and the farm. If it's rainy, the visit will be around the kitchen table. ``We want to welcome them here,'' Mrs. Brand said. ``This is our opportunity to promote some little bit of international understanding.'' Mrs. Brand and her 58-year-old husband, Richard, have a large dairy operation, milking about 75 cows. Their total herd, including calves and animals that will be sold for beef, numbers about 250. They also raise alfalfa, corn and soybeans on their 240-acre farm and additional acres that they rent, and sell seed corn. And about 20 to 25 cats prowl the property. The Brands have farmed their land for 32 years. They're helped by sons, Greg, 31, and John, 27, who both live nearby. The Brands aren't strangers to the job of entertaining foreign visitors, and think that may be one reason they were chosen as potential hosts to the Gorbachevs. ``We do have a lot of foreign people who come here. We've had several Chinese and Japanese and quite a few European groups,'' Mrs. Brand said. She speculated that the farm's closeness to the Twin Cities could help explain why state officials frequently steer visitors her way. However, a Gorbachev visit would be far different. ``Security will be very, very tight,'' Mrs. Brand said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachevs To Dine On Walleye, Wild Rice At Governor's Mansion
With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, will get a gourmet taste of Minnesota at Sunday's lunch at the governor's mansion, chefs say. Twin Cities writers and business people got a preview Wednesday night of the meal the Gorbachevs, Gov. Rudy Perpich, his wife, Lola, and 46 other people will be served during the Soviet leader's Minnesota visit. Before the meal, they will enjoy hors d'oeuvres including corn cakes with smoked salmon, creme fraiche and caviar and Minnesota cheese puffs. The first course will feature pecan-breaded walleye from Rainy Lake in northern Minnesota with artichokes, smoked tomatoes and local garden greens. The main course is veal medallions, with a Minnesota wild rice-corn compote and a sauce of Minnesota morels. ``The walleye is a family favorite. We do a lot of seafood and veal,'' Mrs. Perpich said. The dessert is minted sweet biscuits, with early summer berries, cream and caramel. Chardonnay wines from California will be served with the appetizers and first course, a California Cabernet Sauvignon with the veal and a white dessert wine with the berries. General Mills and Pillsbury are underwriting the cost of the meal.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
Two Sides Announce Agreements To Be Signed
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union will sign an agreement increasing by nearly four-fold the number of commercial flights between U.S. and Soviet cities, the White House announced Thursday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the airline agreement was one of a series of agreements that would be signed by U.S. and Soviet officials on Friday at the White House. Others include new pacts on ocean studies, maritime cooperation and cultural exchanges. The new airline agreement _ to be signed by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze _ would enable Soviet citizens for the first time to use rubles to buy tickets on U.S. airlines. That will open up travel to many Soviet citizens who do not have access to U.S. dollars or other easily-convertible currencies with which to purchase tickets. The Soviet ruble generally cannot be exchanged for other forms of currency. Under the agreement, Soviet airlines would serve as a middleman in selling such tickets to Soviet travelers. The pact calls for up to 8.75 percent of tickets on any given flight to be made available to purchasers with rubles. The pact would increase from the current four to 14 U.S. and Soviet cities served. Now, flights are allowed only between Moscow, Leningrad, Washington and New York. Total passenger and cargo flights per side will increase from under eight at present to 15 immediately; to 42 by next April and to 58 by April, 1992. An ocean studies agreement, also to be signed by Baker and Shevardnadze, calls for shared use of research vessels and a ``broad range of oceanographic research cooperation,'' according to a White House fact sheet. A more-modest U.S.-Soviet joint effort to explore the oceans was suspended by the United States with the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. Another agreement, to be signed by Shevardnadze and U.S. Transportation Scretary Samuel Skinner, seeks to put U.S.-Soviet maritime relations on a more normal footing _ including increased access to each other's ports. Agreements will also be signed by other administration officials and Shevardnadze on cultural centers, customs cooperation and distribution of the magazines intended for each other's country, Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: 500 Contras Disarm After Latest Accord With Government
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 500 Contra rebels surrendered their weapons on the first day of a renewed disarmament agreement, a United Nations spokesman said Thursday. The spokesman, Fernando Castanon, said the disarmament of 498 guerrillas from five security zones brings to 2,482 the number of rebels who have demobilized since the process began May 8. About 11,500 remain in the security zones policed by U.N. forces. Also Thursday, the United States turned over to Nicaragua $60 million, the first payment of $300 million in aid approved by Congress. John Leonard, charges d'affaires at the U.S. Embassy, presented the check to Foreign Minister Enrique Dreyfus. The Nicaraguan economy is in serious financial straits. The rebels agreed Wednesday to renew the demobilization process and to disarm the entire Contra army by a previously agreed-to deadline of June 10. In return the government agreed to provide more than 20 ``development zones in combat areas where Contras and their families can settle. It provides them with their own police forces and with voices in local town councils and government ministries aiding in the resettlement. The rebels will get title to land and be given priority in getting compensation for property confiscated by the former Sandinista government. The Contras agreed to demobilize at least 100 rebels from each zone daily, although they will have to double that rate to meet the June 10 deadline. The latest agreement is one of a number reached between the Contras and the government of President Violetta Barrios de Chamorro. The demobilization process was stopped by the Contras once after a series of crippling strikes by the public sector in which the Sandinista-led strikers got virtually everything they wanted. The Contras said this made them worry about the stability of the government in the face of the Sandinista opposition. The Contras, with American backing, fought the leftist Sandinista regime for nine of the 10 years it held power in a war that cost about 30,000 lives. The Sandinista newspaper Barricada said Thursday that the government gave the Contras too much. It said the deal lacks ``an obligatory clause that offers the citizenry guarantees on the disarmament of the Contras.'' Mrs. Chamorro said Wednesday that Gen. Humberto Ortega, the former Sandinista defense minister who remains in charge of the army, will develop a plan to reduce the army's size after the Contras have disarmed. Her retention of Ortega, brother of former Sandinista President Daniel Ortega, also has been a point of controversy among the Contras and one of a number of pressures on her new administration.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 21 grafs new to UPDATE with toasts, table partners of Bush and Gorbachev; picks up 13th graf, `Others who ...' ^Gorbachevs to White House for Glittering State Dinner
DOC.TEXT: Academy Award-winning actors, media moguls and political luminaries joined President Bush on Thursday in honoring Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev with a glittering evening of Maine lobster and opera arias. As the guests settled into the White House's State Dining Room for the capital's biggest social event of the year, the two president praised one another warmly for the tone of their summit talks. In his formal toast, Bush lauded the Soviet president ``for creating within the Soviet Union this commitment to change.'' ``Mr. President,'' Bush told his counterpart, ``it is said that your country is the land of possibilities. You have demonstrated the truth of that statement, and we've seen this past year that ours is a world of possibilities, that ours is a time of historic change, a time when men and nations can transform history.'' For his part, Gorbachev said the days are gone when the Soviet Union considered the United States an enemy. ``The enemy image is becoming a thing of the past. Ideological stereotypes are fading away,'' he said. Gorbachev, wearing his glasses and speaking somberly through most of the toast, held out hope that this summit meeting would yield ``the biggest results,'' of any previous Soviet-U.S. summit. ``I cannot say yet how we are going to conclude this meeting, what the results will be. That would be premature,'' he said. But based on the talks Thursday, he said it was ``possible to expect major results from this meeting.'' ``Maybe I'm too optimistic but let's wait and see, we have two days,'' he said to applause. The White House was decked out in white peonies and red roses, with President Johnson's flower-edged china set on the tables and the grand entrance foyer decorated in red and pink, 12-foot geranium trees. The Gorbachevs arrived for the black-tie gala evening dressed simply, Soviet style _ the Russian president in a dark business suit, Mrs. Gorbachev in a tea-length black, pink and green floral dress with a flowing skirt. They stepped from their limousine onto the red carpet at the White House front steps where they were greeted by the tuxedo-clad American president and his wife Barbara, who wore a sapphire blue gown, with fitted bodice and sweeping skirt. For the state dinner during Gorbachev's 1987 visit to Washington, then-President Ronald Reagan also dressed in a business suit, so as not to outshine his guest. Soviet leaders traditionally do not wear black tie, considering it an elite dress style. Bush and his wife Barbara put a personal touch on Thursday night's menu, serving lobster from their longtime summer vacation state, Maine. And, in light of the Soviet fondness for opera, they enlisted one of the world's foremost mezzo-sopranos, Frederica von Stade, to sing for the guests in the East Room following dinner. Tables were done in red tablecloth with white napkins, with crystal bowls on mirror plateaus filled with white peonies, white ixia and red roses. Complementing the lobster served en gelee, the menu for the evening featured corn sticks, roasted filet of beef mascotte with green peppercorn sauce, asparagus with sauce aveline, mixed salad, Saint Pauline cheese, and dessert of lime turban with iced raspberries and friandises candies. Guests invited to mingle with the Soviet Union's first couple and other members of their entourage included former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and industrialist Armand Hammer, who has conducted business in the Soviet Union for many years. Also holding coveted tickets to the dinner were such celebrities as Academy-Award winning actor Jessica Tandy; Tandy's husband, Hume Cronyn; Academy Award nominee Morgan Freeman; NBC news anchor Tom Brokaw and evangelist Billy Graham. Tandy and Freeman starred together in last year's Academy Award best picture ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' Tandy and Graham sat at the president's table with Mrs. Gorbachev. Among those joining Mrs. Bush at the Soviet president's table was Freeman. Others who made the list of invitees, in addition to various Cabinet members and administration officials, were: Bush's son Neil and his wife Sharon of Denver; The New York Times Chairman Arthur Ochs Sulzberger and Washington Post Publisher Donald Graham; Time Magazine columnist Hugh Sidey; Los Angeles movie mogul Jerry Weintraub; Ford Motor Co. Chairman Harold Poling; National Urban League president John Jacob and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan. Congressional leaders also were invited. As a side note to the festivities, the Gorbachevs and Bushes exchanged the customary official gifts. The president chose to give Gorbachev a five-volume biography, ``Life of George Washington,'' by Chief Justice John Marshall. The Soviet leader's present for Bush was an antique painting of Russian birch trees. Mrs. Bush chose an elegant Judith Leiber gold-and-rhinestone-trimmed handbag for Raisa Gorbachev. Mrs. Gorbachev presented Mrs. Bush with a decorative enameled tea set. For table settings, Barbara Bush decided to use the flower-edged china bought during President Lyndon B. Johnson's administration. She selected that setting over place settings that Nancy Reagan bought after deciding the Johnson dishes were not elegant enough for a state dinner. During dessert, the Air Force strolling strings orchestra were on tap to play for the dinner guests, and the Marine orchestra tuned up for music in the grand entrance hall for after-dinner dancing.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Testifies She Was Raped by Buckey But Remembers Little Else
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old girl testified Thursday that Raymond Buckey raped and molested her while she was a pupil at the McMartin Pre-School 10 years ago, and cut the ears off a rabbit to keep her silent. The last of three child witnesses in Buckey's retrial also said he squeezed birds to death to scare her into silence. But the girl said she could remember nothing else about the years she attended the family-owned Manhattan Beach preschool. Most of her answers on cross-examination were, ``I don't remember,'' and she flatly denied accusations she made against Buckey's mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, during her testimony in the case five years ago. Under questioning by Deputy District Attorney Pam Ferrero, the girl said Buckey molested her while playing ``the horsey game'' in a classroom at the preschool. Buckey, 32, is charged with raping the girl and using a finger to rape and sodomize her. Under cross-examination by Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, the girl said both she and Buckey were naked during the incident. ``... In a classroom on a regular school day?'' Davis asked incredulously. ``Yes,'' said the girl. She acknowledged that she didn't remember Buckey being her teacher nor did she remember who any of her teachers were. The defense has said Buckey didn't teach at the school from 1979 to 1981, when the girl attended. Witnesses have said he may have been a teacher's helper for part of the time. The witness, who was serious and composed, said she remembered Buckey cutting off the ears of one or more rabbits with a scissors. In earlier testimony she has said he used a knife. Pressed by Davis for more details she said she could not remember. ``He said that he would hurt my parents if I told,'' she said. ``If you told what?'' asked Davis. ``What happened to me,'' said the girl. She denied that Buckey's mother ever molested her. Davis read to the girl her own previous sworn statements that Mrs. Buckey had used her finger to rape and sodomize her. Asked if that happened, she answered, ``No.'' Mrs. Buckey was acquitted of these and other molestation charges earlier this year. The first Buckey trial, the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history, ended in January with Buckey acquitted of 40 counts of molestation and his mother acquitted of 12 charges. But the jury deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey, and the district attorney decided to retry him on eight of those charges involving three children. Prosecutors said they plan to rest their case Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Colombians, 1 New Yorker Found Guilty in Cocaine Trial
DOC.TEXT: Two Colombians and a New Yorker, captured in Canada's largest drug bust, were found guilty Thursday for conspiring to traffic cocaine worth about $200 million. The three face a maximum life sentence. Sentencing is scheduled for Monday. Moments before the jury's verdict was announced, Ricardo Delgado Marquez, 24, of New York, and Colombians Fernando William Mendoza Salazar, 27, and Flor E. Mery-Correa, 32, were seen laughing in the prisoners' box. The jury of nine men and three women deliberated for 15 days before reaching its verdict. The three were arrested April 1989 after undercover police intercepted a shipment of 1,100 pounds of cocaine flown from Colombia to Montreal and replaced most of the drug with brown sugar in an elaborate sting operation. Ms. Mery-Correa was found guilty of conspiracy to traffic in cocaine and possession for the purpose of trafficking. She was acquitted of conspiring to import and export the narcotic. Delgado-Marquez and Mendoza-Salazar were convicted of conspiring to export and traffic cocaine and possession for the purpose of trafficking, but were acquitted of conspiracy to import.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Settles Fee Case With Former Attorneys
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP agreed to drop a lawsuit against former staff attorneys who it alleged kept more than $2 million in fees illegally, the organization said Thursday. A statement issued by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People gave no details on the disposition of the fees. It said only that an agreement was reached with former NAACP general counsel Nathaniel Jones, who is now a judge on the Sixth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. NAACP President Benjamin Hooks said in the statement the dispute was ``an honest difference of opinion as to how these fees should be distributed.'' A lawsuit pending in Cleveland was being dismissed as part of the agreement, the statement said. Others besides Jones were parties to the case, but the statement did not mention them and the NAACP office did not answer a telephone call seeking clarification. The legal fees resulted from five discrimination cases dating to 1970.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Gorbachev Grapple With German Unity in Summit Talks.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, US official says ``no new ideas'' on Germany, in grafs 4-9. Picks up 17th graf a0790 ... The Soviet leader. Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev grappled over terms of German unity after an opening round of summitry Thursday that set the stage for major agreements on chemical and nuclear weapons. Overall, Bush declared, ``The mood is very positive.'' The two leaders began their talks proclaiming a new era of cooperation in spite of their differences. ``The trenches of the Cold War are disappearing,'' Gorbachev said. Bush saluted Gorbachev's leadership in a tacit boost for his plunging popularity at home, and vowed to end ``decades of division and discord.'' After nearly five hours of discussions, Bush and Gorbachev readily acknowledged they could not settle nettlesome questions this week over the shape of conventional forces in Europe or the military bearing of a unified Germany. ``It is not here that the German question will be resolved,'' the Soviet president told reporters. Separately, Bush said, ``Certainly we're not going to solve the whole issue at this summit.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze will take up the issue next week in Copenhagen during a meeting of the 35-nation European Security Conference. There was confusion over whether the superpowers were making any progress on Germany. Gorbachev said at one point that both sides had advanced ``certain ideas, certain suggestions,'' and White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said ``new ideas'' amounted ``to a way to meld the concerns of the United States and the Soviet Union.'' But several hours later, a U.S. official told reporters, ``There are no new ideas,'' and let it be known that Bush would call West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and reassure him of Bush's fidelity to the new Germany's membership in the west's NATO alliance. Gorbachev favors some formula that guarantees a renewed German militarism. The impasse didn't stay the leaders from providing an upbeat view of the summit, Bush said, ``I'd just say at the end of a very interesting day that the talks have gone reasonably well.'' Gorbachev _ who told a State Dinner audience that ``the enemy image is becoming a thing of the past''_ sprinkled the day with a series of unexpected appearances that have become his trademark. As he did during his 1987 visit to Washington, Gorbachev delighted a downtown crowd by hopping out of his limousine and shaking hands. The throng of about 500 people cheered and applauded. ``Gorby, over here!'' some shouted. Twice, he made a beeline to reporters waiting in the White House driveway for impromptu news conferences. After largely ceding the limelight to Gorbachev during the day, Bush made an unscheduled appearance in the Rose Garden to respond to questions. ``The talks have certainly gone as well as I could have expected up to now,'' he said. The White House said agreements would be signed Friday ending production of chemical weapons and sealing the major elements of a treaty to slash long-range nuclear arms. The leaders will also commit themselves to deeper cuts in the years ahead. Hopes faded for progress on reducing tanks and troops in Europe, an issue intertwined with the thornier question of German unity. Bush said he spoke frankly with Gorbachev. ``He didn't seem to take offense at anything. ... I feel very comfortable with him. I feel very free to bring up positions that I know he doesn't agree with,'' Bush said. Gorbachev said he and Bush ``understand each other's concerns better.''
MORE

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Agrees Mom Insane; No Charges in Toddler Stranglings
DOC.TEXT: A mother accused of strangling her two toddlers while they slept will not be tried for the killings because prosecutors say they have no way to disprove that she was insane at the time. Dorothy Diane Rose has been hospitalized since the January slayings and apparently still believes her 13-month-old daughter and 2-year-old son are alive. Eight defense and two state psychiatrists agree she was legally insane. ``The prosecution doesn't have any evidence to dispute or refute that finding of insanity,'' Assistant State Attorney John Skye told a judge Wednesday. When Ms. Rose's case is called up for trial Monday on two counts of first-degree murder, prosecutors say they will agree she should be found innocent by reason of insanity. That doesn't mean the 31-year-old woman will go free. With an acquittal because of insanity, Circuit Judge M. William Graybill will retain control and must decide whether to have her committed indefinitely. Ms. Rose has been under psychiatric care since Jan. 23 when deputies found her near death from a self-inflicted stab wound to the chest and slashed wrists. Her daughter, Jessica Linn Rose, and son, Michael Holt Rose, had been strangled in their beds. Detectives believe Ms. Rose, who was involved in a bitter divorce, killed her children to prevent their father from winning custody. Some psychiatrists have speculated that she thought she was saving them from an abusive situation. ``Where are my children? Where are my children?'' Ms. Rose asked on a videotape made by defense attorneys a day after the killings. In addition to the psychiatrists, friends, neighbors and law enforcement officers all agreed Ms. Rose was insane, attorneys said. ``We have no bad feelings against her although it was a terrible tragedy,'' father-in-law Donald Rose said Wednesday. ``I think we'll get over it, but we'll never forget it.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Circus Rescued by Oglethorpe University
DOC.TEXT: A university Thursday let members of a bankrupt Soviet circus move into a dormitory after a motel evicted the troupe for not paying their bills. Promoters of the Great Circus Bim Bom, meanwhile, tried to set up new shows in Kentucky to save the tour. The circus has been stranded in Georgia since May 9, when financial problems stalled the first leg of its two-year tour around the country. Earlier this week, a motel in Marietta, north of Atlanta, evicted the 125 performers after they were unable to pay a bill of more than $9,700. They stayed temporarily in another motel before Oglethorpe University agreed to take them in. Oglethorpe President Donald S. Stanton said about 40 of the stranded performers will stay on the school's Atlanta campus for about a week and will eat free meals in the dorm's cafeteria. Others will stay with families in the Atlanta area through arrangements made by a local Baptist church, Stanton said. Circus tour manager Bob Liberman said negotiations were under way Thursday for a performance in Kentucky. He said the deal is likely to be completed by Friday. Liberman said he was grateful for Oglethorpe's offer. ``They agreed to do it out of the kindness of their hearts,'' he said. Stanton said the wife of the university's registrar called him Wednesday night after seeing a televised report on the circus' woes. Stanton said he spoke with university residential officials, who worked out the details with circus members. The dorm where the performers will stay was being painted, Stanton said, but the work was halted temporarily. ``We're putting up `Wet Paint' signs in Russian, so they'll know,'' Stanton said.

DOC.HEAD: Tensions Over Germany Surface on Gorbachev's First Day in Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 4th graf to update with Bush planning to call Kohl, ``Later, a xxx''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday directed their top diplomatic aides to meet next week to seek a post-summit agreement on the military face of a united Germany. A meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was set for Tuesday in Copenhagen, after Bush and Gorbachev reached an impasse on whether a new Germany would be a member of NATO. A second June session, in Berlin, was tentatively scheduled for the two aides. Bush and Gorbachev exchanged what the Soviet leader called new approaches, and Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said optimistically: ``The ideas presented amount to a way to meld the concerns of the United States and the Soviet Union.'' Later, a Bush administration official sought to play down any perception that there had been a breakthrough. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Bush would call West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl within the next day or so ``to reassure him that we have not changed our position'' on a united Germany. Bush is determined to secure NATO membership for the new Germany once it is created, while Gorbachev is equally intent on keeping the country out of the Western alliance or at least restricting the size of the German army. ``Both the U.S. side and the Soviet side put forth certain ideas and suggestions'' on Thursday, Gorbachev said. He gave no details, but a Soviet official told The Associated Press the Soviets wanted Germany's future taken up by the 35-nation European Security Conference. ``I hope that we understand each other's concerns better,'' Gorbachev said as he left the White House. ``This exchange of views now requires that our foreign ministers have a more in-depth discussion,'' he told reporters. ``I think it is not here that the German question will be resolved.''' Bush said later that ``certainly'' was the case. But the U.S. president, who appeared outside the White House shortly after Gorbachev left, added, ``When he said that differences had been narrowed somewhat, I'm taking some heart from that and we'll continue these discussions tomorrow.'' ``Fundamental positions have not changed,'' he said. Bush offered his own public assurances to Gorbachev that ``we can work together'' to reduce East-West tensions on a broad front. The two leaders aired their differences on Germany publicly at a morning arrival ceremony and then privately in the Oval Office. In addition to the Baker-Shevardnadze session in Copenhagen, U.S. officials said Baker also will meet separately in the Danish capital with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who has been the point man for the West in trying to work out an accommodation with Moscow. Genscher, for instance, proposed keeping NATO troops out of what is now East Germany after the merger with West Germany. Baker, Shevardnadze and Genscher had all planned to be in Copenhagen to attend a 35-nation conference on human rights. A meeting also had previously been scheduled among the four World War II allies and the two Germanys in Berlin on the subject of Germany's future. Gorbachev told reporters in a White House driveway that Bush defended his viewpoint on Germany during their talks. ``I think dictation is unacceptable,'' the Soviet leader said, but he did not renew his accusation of the previous day that the United States was indeed trying to dictate to the Soviet Union. Meanwhile, Germany and unrest in the Baltics dominated the meeting Baker held with Shevardnadze at the White House while the two presidents were in the Oval office, U.S. officials said. Just a few blocks away, meanwhile, top-level U.S. and Soviet negotiators held a fifth day of talks on what will be the summit's crowning achievements _ a declaration of basic accord to cut long-range nuclear missiles and a pledge to quickly launch negotiations for even deeper reductions once the treaty is finished. But Deputy Soviet Prime Minister Viktor K. Karpov and Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew and their aides evidently were unable to make significant progress in arrangements for the withdrawal of tens of thousands of U.S. and Soviet troops and tanks from Europe. This ``is an area where we will probably not be able to reach specific agreement at this point,'' Fitzwater said. Gorbachev has slowed work on this parallel treaty partly out of concern that a strengthened Germany would be enrolled in the Western alliance while his own allies in the Warsaw Pact drift away from the Soviet orbit. U.S. and Soviet negotiators held three rounds of talks Thursday at the State Department. Baker, appearing on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America,'' made plain there would be no retreat in the U.S. position. ``All of the Western allies, all of the countries of Western Europe, and, indeed, three countries of the Warsaw Pact, think that this would promote stability in Europe, that it's important that that happen,'' Baker said. ``So the Soviet Union is, to some extent, alone among the nations involved in this who have a problem with it. So our job is to see if we can better explain it,'' Baker said. Bush, in a White House arrival ceremony for the Soviet leader, hailed the impending unification of East Germany with West Germany as a milestone toward ``enduring cooperation in a Europe whole and free.'' But mindful of Gorbachev's reservations about a more powerful neighbor, the president assured him ``we can work together at this historic moment'' to reduce remaining East-West tensions. ``The trenches of the Cold War are disappearing,'' Gorbachev said in response. In a thinly veiled reference to his concerns about German unification and U.S. demands that the new country have NATO membership, the Soviet leader recalled the Allies' victory over Nazism in World War II and, earlier, the defeat of Germany in World War I. Gorbachev then pointedly expressed a hope that ``these horrible wars will forever remain a thing of the past.'' There were indications the two sides may be in a mood to compromise. U.S. officials are hinting at negotiations in the future to scale down both the German and Soviet armies in a tradeoff deal between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Rep. Patricia Saiki Enters Hawaii Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Patricia Saiki formally announced her candidacy Thursday for the U.S. Senate seat once held by the late Spark Matsunaga. The Republican lawmaker said she could bring the overwhelmingly Democratic state more clout with the White House than could the Democrat appointed to hold Matsunaga's office until a special election in November. Matsunaga died April 15 of cancer at age 73. Saiki's main competition is expected to come from former U.S. Rep. Daniel Akaka, who was appointed to replace Matsunaga. Akaka, like Matsunaga a Democrat, has declared his candidacy. Saiki had already said she intended to run for the seat but said she wanted to make her candidacy official in her native Hilo. In a speech at Mooheau Park Pavilion, a traditional rallying spot for Democrats, Saiki pointed to her achievements as a state legislator and two-term congresswoman from Honolulu. Two other Republicans, Molokai Island rancher Maria Hustace and former state legislator Richard Sutton, also are candidates. ``I offer an independent vote for Hawaii and something more, a respected voice that can and will be heard in the Oval Office,'' Saiki said. Saiki said she wanted to debate Akaka, but Akaka has said he would decline offers to debate.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Souvenirs Abound As Visit To Minnesota Nears
DOC.TEXT: Civic leaders are hawking a collection of mementoes to help pay expenses associated with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota on Sunday, ranging from handkerchiefs and T-shirts to posters. The ``GorbaChief'' handkerchief was modeled after the ``Homer Hankies'' waved by Minnesota Twins fans during the 1987 World Series. Star Tribune publisher Roger Parkinson, who heads the committee planning the visit, said 20,000 to 30,000 handkerchiefs bearing the Gorbachev Visit Committee's official logo were printed. They're $3 each, plus tax. The poster is a replica of a $25,000 ad welcoming Gorbachev that will appear in Pravda, the official newspaper of the Communist Party. It is the first time Americans have advertised in Pravda and only the second time an ad has appeared in the newspaper, said Bill Dunlap, chief executive officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, the Minneapolis-based advertising agency that created the ad. Fifty-five hundred posters were printed and will go for $10 each, plus the inevitable tax. The T-shirts bear the official logo, which includes an outline of the state of Minnesota and a hammer and sickle. Five hundred T-shirts will go on sale Thursday for $14 each, and more are to be printed if needed. For smaller budgets, there's a postcard, bearing the logo and a postmark commemorating the visit, for $1. Gifts for the Gorbachevs were displayed in the governor's reception room Wednesday, including bottles of Boundary Waters Beer, named for the region of lakes on the U.S.-Canadian border; sweatshirts depicting the Minnesota state flower, the showy lady slipper; and a commemorative limited edition of the Russian version of the Monopoly game produced by Minnetonka-based Tonka Corp.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy off Liberia for Evacuation, President Refuses to Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with State Department ordering all non-essential U.S. personnel out of the country. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `About 10,000...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebel troops advanced to within 25 miles of the capital Thursday, and the Pentagon announced that a U.S. navy flotilla with more than 2,000 Marines was off Liberia in case American citizens need to be evacuated. President Samuel Doe on Thursday refused to resign despite the advance of the insurgents, and vowed to be the last person to leave the city. ``Tough times never last. Tough people do,'' Doe told a group of foreign ambassadors, according to one envoy at the meeting. His statements heightened fears of a bloody conflict if the two armies clash in the West African capital. So far, more than 1,000 people have been killed in the 5-month-old rebellion, most of them civilians slain by government troops. Late Thursday, the State Department warned in a travel advisory that conditions in the country were deteriorating and ordered all non-essential U.S. personnel to depart immediately. Cmdr. David Thomas, a spokesman for the Defense Department, said the U.S. flotilla includes a destroyer, an amphibious assault ship, a tank landing ship and other support vessels carrying ammunition and combat supplies. Aboard the ships were 179 Marine officers and 2,102 enlisted men, Thomas said. He said the U.S. ships are under orders to ``be prepared to evacuate American citizens in the event that they would no longer be able to leave the country by commercial means.'' About 10,000 Americans, mostly businessmen and missionaries, are in Liberia. The 11 U.N. expatriate workers in Liberia evacuated the country Thursday for security reasons. Terry Lewis, coordinator of the U.N. Disaster Relief Organization, said they were sad to leave. ``We had a lot of work to do here. People won't starve yet, but there are going to be some very hungry people.'' Lewis said they hoped to return, ``possibly in a few weeks when the security situation improves.'' Doe spoke with diplomats who protested an attack on the U.N. compound Wednesday by soldiers carrying out reprisals against unarmed civilians. According to ambassadors at the meeting, Doe promised to send troops to protect diplomatic missions. But one envoy told The Associated Press they were trying to find a diplomatic way to refuse the offer. ``The last thing we want is unruly armed Doe soldiers. We would rather have policemen,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Doe was defiant during the meeting, despite a promise he made to a rally Friday that he would make any sacrifice, including stepping down, if it helped end bloodshed. ``He said he would not resign but would be the last person to leave,'' the diplomat said. Doe's ministers appeared not to be as resolute. Hotel owners said many had moved into their establishments, fearing to sleep in their houses where they could be rebel targets. Rumors in Monrovia said Doe forced his ministers to hand in their passports to prevent them from leaving the country. Rebel leader Charles Taylor said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. on Thursday that he would not be satisfied with Doe's resignation. The rebels have accused Doe's administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor said his fighters would not stop until they had taken Monrovia and formed their own government. Taylor's fighters captured the country's main port of Buchanan, 95 miles east of the capital, five days ago. Rebels were reported to be ambushing troops within a few miles of Robertsfield International Airport, 20 miles from the capital. In Monrovia, there were reports that members of Doe's Krahn tribe and Mandingos, who are accused of supporting Krahns and exploiting other tribes, were trying to evacuate for fear that rebels would attack the capital. Many of the rebels are members of the Gio and Mano tribes, who last week were the target of attacks that killed 11 people. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said about eight soldiers wearing masks forced their way Wednesday into the U.N. compound in Monrovia, where 1,000 refugees had gathered to demand protection and safe conduct out of the country. Giuliani said the soldiers killed one guard and wounded another, then abducted about 30 people. The bodies of three abducted men and a youth were found later dumped outside the capital. Doe denied responsibility and said he would punish those responsible. Doe seized power as a master sergeant in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of slaves who discriminated against native Liberians. Liberia, a country of 2 million, was founded by freed American slaves in 1847. Doe and his officers are members of the Krahn tribe, which makes up only 2 percent of the population in this nation of 14 small tribes. The rebels are chiefly Gio and Mano tribesmen, although Taylor had an American-Liberian father and a Bassa mother. The rebellion began Dec. 24 with an invasion of 200 rebels from Ivory Coast. What started as a minor rebellion escalated into a war because government atrocities have won the rebels thousands of recruits.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Evacuated as Floods Hit Vicksburg
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `We were...,' to UPDATE with rainfall measurement, quotes, water subsiding. Pick up 7th graf pvs,`Gov. Ray...
DOC.TEXT: Flash floods fed by up to seven inches of rain forced closure of low-lying roads and chased hundreds of people from their homes Thursday, some of whom fled in boats. Creeks that empty into the rain-swollen Mississippi River overflowed their banks in heavy thunderstorms. ``We've had flash flooding all day. It hit pretty suddenly,'' said Warren County Sheriff Paul Barrett. ``A lot of them have lost everything they had.'' Barrett said more than 130 houses in the city were flooded and between 30 and 40 county homes have been flooded. No injuries were reported, the sheriff said. ``We were lucky,'' said Barrett. ``We packed some people out on our backs and some out in boats, but we didn't lose anybody.'' ``I'm not going to sit here and watch it,'' said Billy Harvey as he watching debris float across his back yard and the water creep up to his steps. ``I've got my `get-away' bag and my poodle and I'm heading to a motel.'' Up to seven inches of rain fell during the day in some areas. By 8:35 p.m., the Vicksburg Police Department reported that most of the flooding in the city had subsided. Gov. Ray Mabus declared a state of emergency in Warren County and called out the Mississippi National Guard to help officials and residents deal with the flooding. Barrett said some residents could probably return to their houses Friday, while others may have to wait through the weekend. Parts of U.S. 61 were closed because of high water for several hours Thursday but had been reopened by late Thursday. Other county and city roads also were closed, city officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's New Press Secretary Makes International Debut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes category code; SUBS lede to make it ``American debut'' sted ``debut.''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: He almost missed his American debut. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater waited more than an hour for his new counterpart, Arkady Afrikanovich Maslennikov, to appear at the summit press center, then decided to go ahead without him. ``We have received differing reports on my counterpart's progress,'' Fitzwater told the hundreds of assembled journalists, who had been waiting with growing impatience for the first joint U.S.-Soviet briefing on the start of the summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Maslennikov eventually did appear, explaining his tardiness with a quip that instantly pitted him against Fitzwater as a spokesman-cum-humorist. ``I was trying to get more information so I could be more specific than my counterpart, Mr. Fitzwater,'' the new Soviet presidential spokesman said. Maslennikov, 58, replaced the familiar face of Gennady I. Gerasimov, who remains chief spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry but no longer speaks for Gorbachev, who appointed his own press secretary in April after assuming his new, stronger presidency. There has been speculation that Gerasimov was passed over for the job because he did not get along with the Western press corps, which has become increasingly important to Gorbachev. A longtime Pravda reporter who speaks heavily accented but quite fluent English acquired during tours in India, Pakistan and Britain, Maslennikov paried reporters' questions like an old pro, joking occasionally but never varying from his boss's familiar positions on prospects for a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement, the disagreement over the military future of a united Germany and the agreements the leaders are scheduled to sign on Friday. He said he would speak in Russian and use a translator for the largely English-speaking press corps because ``I just don't want to use my very ugly English.'' But he quickly found his English was up to the task and more convenient than wrestling with the earphones and wireless receiver used for listening to the interpretation. He confessed he had spoken to Fitzwater in advance for some pointers on handling the horde of reporters that far outnumbers the Moscow press corps. But as he was surrounded after the formal briefing and peppered with an unceasing string of more questions, he pleaded, ``Don't squeeze me dry. Leave something for next time.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Gets Year in Attack on Man
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager pleaded guilty Thursday to assaulting a male jogger the night a female jogger was raped, beaten and left for dead in the Central Park ``wilding'' case. He was sentenced to a year in jail. Michael Briscoe, 18, who wasn't charged in the attack on the woman, pleaded guilty before state Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan to one count of second-degree assault, the top charge in his indictment. Briscoe could have been sentenced to seven years in prison on the assault charge. He had already pleaded guilty on May 7 to selling a small amount of PCP, or ``angel dust,'' to an undercover police officer on May 4. Galligan gave him a year on the drug charge, to run concurrently with the assault sentence. ``It was a deal he could not turn down,'' said Briscoe's lawyer, Joseph Klempner. He added that nothing in the deal requires Briscoe to testify against codefendants but he will continue to talk to prosecutors. Briscoe was one of eight youths indicted in the attack on David Lewis, 31, a banker who was jumped and beaten viciously as he jogged in the north end of Central Park the night of April 19, 1989. A second teen-ager, Jermain Robinson, was sentenced to one year in jail after he pleaded guilty earlier to one count of first-degree robbery in the attack on Lewis and another jogger that night, John Loughlin, a teacher. Lewis, reached at his office, refused to comment on Briscoe's sentence but said, ``I've been told by the DA's office to be prepared to testify. It's their call.'' The other six youths are awaiting trial in the attacks on Lewis and Loughlin and the near-fatal rape and beating of the woman jogger. The woman, now 29, was left battered and bleeding in a mud puddle. She recovered remarkably, doctors say, and has returned to work at an investment bank. The viciousness of the attack shocked the city and garnered headlines around the nation. Jury selection is scheduled to begin June 13 for the three of the defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Performers Granted Visas To Stage Memorial to Tiananmen Memorial in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Seven members of a Hong Kong theater troupe who'd been denied visas to come to New York for a performance commemorating the Tiananmen Square massacre were granted permission to enter the country Thursday. The seven had been stranded in England, where they recently completed five performances, and were to arrive in New York on Thursday night, said Eleanor Yung, director of the Asian American Arts Centre. The center is sponsoring the New York performance of ``Deep Structure of Chinese Culture,'' scheduled for Saturday at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. A pro-democracy movement in the People's Republic of China was crushed last June 4 when government troops killed hundreds of demonstrators in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. The visas were denied by the U.S. Embassy in London last week due to concern that the performers with the Zuni Icosohedron theater troupe would not return to Hong Kong once they were in the United States, Ms. Yung said. She said the visas were issued after the Hong Kong Consulate General assured U.S. officials the performers would not try to immigrate illegally. She said numerous U.S. politicians and other concerned citizens had lobbied on the performers' behalf. The visas were granted Thursday morning in London, she said, and the performers boarded a flight to New York later in the day. ``I'm very happy,'' Ms. Yung said. The theater company's name refers to an American Indian tribe and a 25-sided geometric shape. Four members of the troupe were issued visas earlier, and will take part in the performance with the seven performers flying in Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: North Korean, Japanese Salmon Poaching Protested by Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has protested illegal Japanese fishing in its waters and is seeking millions of dollars in compensation for losses, an official said Thursday. The Foreign Ministry delivered a protest note to the Japanese Embassy in Moscow complaining of systematic violations of fishing treaties to the point that ``the agreements themselves are threatened,'' spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev said. Perfiliev told reporters that illegal fishing exhausts stock reserves, costing the Soviet Union millions of dollars. He said the illegal fishing must be stopped and the damages paid. In Tokyo, Soviet diplomatic sources said a protest was addressed to North Korea as well concerning the illegal salmon fishing in Soviet-claimed waters of the north Pacific. It referred to the seizure of six Japanese fishing boats May 9-13 off Soviet-held Sakhalin island, said the diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The boats and their crews were released soon after the seizures. Perfiliev said the ``actions of the Japanese side'' were to blame for the incidents. ``It's obvious that if not for such crude violations, the Soviet side would not have seen the necessity of acting to correct the situation.'' The protest lodged with Japan did not, however, mention the highly publicized seizures May 19-22 of 10 North Korean vessels, manned mostly by Japanese fishermen, that were also found operating illegally in Soviet waters. Moscow has filed a separate complaint with the North Korean Embassy over those seizures, the diplomatic sources said. ``I believe this is the most large-scale case to date,'' one source said. ``They were caught with 170,000 salmon on board. That's quite a lot.'' Although 70 percent to 80 percent of the crew members and much of the equipment aboard the vessels were Japanese, the sources said, the Soviet Union believes legal responsibility remains with North Korea because the ships flew the North Korean flag and had North Korean captains. The Japanese Foreign Ministry on Thursday announced that 169 Japanese fishermen were being held by the Soviets on Shikotan, a small island in the Kurile chain just off the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. The Soviet sources could not confirm the number of Japanese fishermen being detained. The Japanese fishermen are believed to have thought they would be given more lenient treatment if caught while flying the North Korean flag. North Korea is a Soviet ally. The North Korean-flagged ships were seized outside the 200-mile Soviet zone, the Foreign Ministry said. But under international rules, migratory fish such as salmon belong to the country where they were spawned. One of the Soviet sources denied speculation that the seizures indicate a worsening of relations between Moscow and North Korea. Japan and North Korea have no diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney to Hold Ministerial Meeting Sunday on Meech Lake Pact
DOC.TEXT: Canada's 10 premiers will meet this weekend to make a final attempt to rescue the controversial Meech Lake accord, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Thursday. Mulroney in an announcement said the meeting will be held Sunday during a working dinner in the capital. He said the meeting could continue Monday if there are signs of progress over the constitutional accord, which by law must be ratified by June 23 by all 10 provinces. ``What is in dispute is modest _ extremely modest _ when compared to what is at stake,'' said Mulroney, who is in favor of the accord. ``What is at stake is Canada.'' The accord, opposed by New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Manitoba, would recognize Quebec as a ``distinct society'' within Canada. About one-fourth of Canada's 25 million residents live in Quebec, a French-speaking province.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
First Ladies Share Tea, Warm Words
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 16th graf, bgng, The two women xxx etc., to CORRECT Bush daughter-in-law's name to Sharon; ADDS xx grafs, bgng, In the afternoon xxx etc. to UPDATE with Library of Congress visit.
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush welcomed Raisa Gorbachev to the White House Thursday with tea and warm words _ and an instant fan in Millie, the Bush family dog. They all went for a tour of the mansion while the two women's husbands talked business in the Oval Office. ``We had a great meeting renewing an old friendship,'' Mrs. Bush said afterward through spokeswoman Anna Perez. ``She said that Mrs. Gorbachev and Millie bonded,'' Ms. Perez added with a laugh. The English springer spaniel is a favorite of many White House visitors, and is quick to warm to strangers. ``Millie sat on Mrs. Gorbachev's foot and she followed her ... all over the house.'' By the end of the day, when the Gorbachevs attended a White House state dinner in their honor, the two wives were what President Bush wanted to talk about. Bush began his formal toast by telling his Soviet counterpart: ``Tomorrow Mr. President, comes the day that so many have been waiting for, the day when expectations will be at fever pitch. That's right, tomorrow _ Barbara and Raisa go to Wellesley.'' The line got an appreciative laugh from guests well familiar with the controversy over Mrs. Bush's appearance at Wellesley as a commencement speaker. Her selection prompted objection from some students that she was not an appropriate role model because her success is due to her husband's achievements. Mrs. Gorbachev has accepted the first lady's invitation to accompany her to the comencement and make remarks as well. There was an air of cordiality between the U.S. and Soviet presidents' wives from the moment the Gorbachevs arrived for the start of the four-day summit. The last time Mrs. Gorbachev visited Washington, in December 1987, she ruffled Nancy Reagan's feathers by observing that the White House was more a museum than ``a regular house.'' Thursday, after a ceremonial welcome on the South Lawn and a diplomatic receiving line inside, Mrs. Bush took Mrs. Gorbachev upstairs to the second-floor family quarters for tea and to show her the Lincoln Bedroom and other parts of the mansion. Mrs. Bush described her guest as ``very knowledgeable and very warm,'' as well as ``very beautiful,'' according to Ms. Perez. Outside, Mrs. Bush put a gentle hand on Mrs. Gorbachev's back and guided her down a line of dignitaries to their places as their husbands took center stage. Mrs. Bush wore a Bill Blass suit, with a lime-green jacket trimmed in white over a white skirt, and her trademark triple strand of fake pearls. Mrs. Gorbachev wore a scarlet double-breasted jacket over a black skirt. Even in her black high heels, Mrs. Gorbachev was a couple of inches shorter than Mrs. Bush, who had on white pumps. Mrs. Bush led the applause when her husband said Mrs. Gorbachev's return to the White House ``brings joy to all of our hearts.'' The two women had tea with two of Mrs. Bush's daughters-in-law, Margaret Bush of Alexandria, Va., and Sharon Bush of Denver, as well as the wives of Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Assistant Secretary of State Ray Seitz, Jack Matlock, the U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union, and Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet ambassador to Washington. Later, Mrs. Gorbachev and her husband lunched at the Soviet Embassy with American film stars, intellectuals and other luminaries. In the afternoon, Mrs. Gorbachev cut a golden ribbon at the Library of Congress to open an exhibit of Russian religious books and manuscripts that she said convey ``the national spirit of Russia.'' Several hundred guests packed a newly renovated gallery at the library's ornate Jefferson Building to hear Mrs. Gorbachev, Marilyn Quayle and other dignitaries at the opening of the exhibit of illuminated manuscripts and other works on loan from the Soviet Union. It is called ``Living Traditions of Russian Faith: Books and Manuscripts of the Old Believers'' and several prominent Russian Orthodox churchmen were on hand to greet the wife of the Soviet president. Mrs. Gorbachev expressed hope that Americans would find ``the national spirit of Russia'' in viewing the works of the Old Believers, a branch of the Russian Orthodox Church that until recent years faced difficult times in its communist homeland.

DOC.HEAD: Nurse Accused in IV Slashing Incidents at Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A nurse accused of slashing seven patients' intravenous feeding tubes because he was angry at the hospital where he worked was arrested Thursday on a felony charge. No one was seriously injured, although the last incident discovered Monday, involving an 83-year-old woman whose tube had also been slashed Saturday, was potentially life-threatening, authorities said. Kevin Koss, 38, of Broward County was charged with tampering with products with intent to do great bodily harm or death, and was being held late Thursday in the Broward County Jail awaiting a bond hearing. If convicted, he faces up to 30 years in prison. Kloss, a licensed practical nurse, was working on the fourth floor of University Community Hospital in this Fort Lauderdale suburb, where eight slashing incidents occurred over the Memorial Day weekend, the county sheriff's office said. Kloss, who police say confessed under questioning, had worked the overnight shift, when nearly all the incidents occurred, said sheriff's spokesman Jim Leljedal. ``His motive was that he was angry at the hospital for some disciplinary action ... and he wanted to get back at the hospital,'' said Sheriff Nick Navarro. Detectives were still investigating, and it wasn't clear what prompted the disciplinary action, Leljedal said. ``We know that he had some disciplinary problems with the hospital and as a result of that, the hospital had taken away his key to the narcotics cabinet and he took that as a personal affront,'' Leljedal said. Kloss had worked at the hospital for more than two years, the sheriff's office said.

Boris N. Yeltsin, the newly elected president of the Russian republic, has called for making the Soviet Union a federation of strong states that can overrule Mikhail S. Gorbachev's central government on most matters. Outlining his plans at a news conference Wednesday, the radical populist reformer said he would seek sovereignty for Russia, the largest Soviet republic, within his first 100 days in office. He also demanded that Soviet Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov resign for what he called a failure to deal decisively with the country's economic turmoil, and said he would open treaty talks immediately with the secessionist Baltic republics. ``We must turn this pyramid on its head,'' Yeltsin said.

Frightened residents of this jungle town spent their second night in the streets after earthquake-prone Peru's deadliest temblor in two decades killed at least 115 people and injured hundreds more. Hundreds of people crowded into Rioja's central plaza, afraid to enter their damaged homes. Many lay inside tents or beneath umbrellas while others crowded around smoky cooking fires in the jungle twilight. More than 800 people were injured and at least 40 missing after the earthquake, which registered 6.2 on the Richter scale, rocked northern Peru late Tuesday night, civil defense authorities said. The damage was centered around Moyobamba, a farming center of 50,000 and the capital of San Martin department, 400 miles north of Lima, officials said. Rioja is 15 miles west of Moyobamba.

Senators padded their incomes by $2.7 million last year by speaking to special-interest groups, but the practice seems to be losing some of its appeal. The total honoraria income for senators in 1989, reported Wednesday in annual financial disclosures, was slightly below the levels for the two previous years. And the lobbying group Common Cause said that for this year, more than one-third of the Senate _ 34 members, up from 19 in 1988 _ have sworn off keeping speaking fees for their personal use. One member on the Common Cause list, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, has relapsed. After declining in the past to keep honoraria, he retained $11,284 last year, saying he was strapped for funds because of the cost of maintaining three houses. Boschwitz, president of a lumber company, has holdings that could be worth more than $3.4 million. Common Cause said he has promised to resume his old policy this year. As usual, the top talker was Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., who raked in $108,900. Senators are not allowed to keep more than 40 percent of their salaries in honoraria, so Dole gave all but $35,750 to charity.

Vincent ``The Chin'' Gigante is no dapper don: he prefers a bathrobe and pajamas to a silk shirt and designer suits and wears slippers instead of Guccis as he rambles through the streets of Greenwich Village. But authorities say that Gigante's befuddled ways are a dodge and that the reputed boss of the Genovese crime family is every bit as ruthless as the better-known, better-dressed John Gotti. Gigante even put a contract out on Gotti in 1987, authorities in New Jersey allege. Gigante, who until now had been untouched by a government crackdown on the Mafia, was among 15 people from four mob families charged Wednesday with monopolizing the installation of windows in the city's housing projects since 1978. The business brought mob companies more than $191 million, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said.

You've seen ``Dick Tracy: The Hype.'' Now it's time for ``Dick Tracy: The Movie.'' The Disney Co. screened the Warren Beatty-Madonna film for reviewers Wednesday, climaxing months of buildup aimed at acquainting potential patrons with the half-forgotten comic strip and Beatty's efforts to convert it into a megahit. Scheduled for wide release on June 15, ``Dick Tracy'' bears Disney's hopes for another smash like ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' The production cost was high _ estimates range from $23 million to $30 million _ for a film with little apparent built-in appeal for the younger crowd that is the backbone of today's film audience. The competition for summer tickets is fierce: ``Total Recall,'' ``Days of Thunder'' and rehashes of ``Die Hard,'' ``Robocop,'' ``48 Hrs'' and ``Back To The Future.'' Against such predictable fare ``Dick Tracy'' is distinguished by its originality.
