DOC.HEAD: Land Institute, Founder and Prairie Agriculture Gaining Acceptance
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The eroded soil swirling in the Smoky Hill River after a hard rain is the legacy of sod-busting pioneers and more than a century of poor farming practices. The Smoky Hill and other rivers look like a spilled cup of heavily creamed coffee because they carry a muddy mix of water, rich top soil and farm chemical residues. Ecologist Wes Jackson blames ``exploitative agriculture'' _ farming that relies on working the ground with heavy equipment and tons of chemicals to fertilize crops and protect them from weeds and pests. ``Mining the soil,'' he said, describing modern agriculture as a carryover from the days when people farmed a patch of ground until it was unproductive and then moved on. And agricultural chemicals, he said, are ``substances with which our tissues have had no experience.'' At 53, Jackson, founder of the Land Institute, has held to his ideas long enough that admiration has replaced ridicule. He has gone from the target of mocking barbs to a respected leader in the sustainable agriculture movement, which seeks to reduce or eliminate the use of chemicals and and change other consumptive farming practices. The message from Jackson has been much the same as it has been for 20 years. But the world around him has evolved, and he now sits on a U.S. Department of Agriculture panel evaluating proposals for low input sustainable agriculture, or LISA, research projects. He addressed an Earth Day crowd of 100,000 people at Lincoln Park in Chicago. George Ham, a Kansas State University associate dean of agriculture and former head of KSU's agronomy department, has a cordial relationship with Jackson. They disagree on the definition of sustainable agriculture and other points. ``I certainly recognize his professional background and expertise and certainly recognize where he's coming from,'' Ham said. ``In terms of our approaches to sustainability, ours is short term while his is more long term.'' For instance, Kansas State is helping farmers gradually decrease the amount they plow and the quantities of chemicals they use. Jackson, however, looks to the day when the plowing and chemical use would be, for the most part, eliminated. Ham agreed that agriculture has evolved and environmental concerns now are more important. Kansas State is placing new emphasis on looking at water quality and how chemicals move through the soil, he said. ``An increasing number of people are finally recognizing that agriculture itself is an ecological problem outranking industrial pollution,'' Jackson said. ``A lot of the resistance to my ideas came from my well-known stands on the Vietnam War, civil rights and the environment,'' Jackson said. ``People thought I was some kind of nut.'' Even his wife, Dana, concedes he is outlandish. She says that's why he is a sought-after speaker. And how receptive could farmers and agricultural academicians be when a speaker refers to farming as ``the barbaric plunder of nature'' and compares chemical treatment of soils and crops as ``fossil-fuel chemotherapy.'' Jackson has chided farmers for wearing caps with seed and chemical company logos ``advertising the corporate agribusiness lords for whom they work.'' And he said helping farmers cope day-to-day is like caring for a cancer patient. ``This is noble work, but it is more for the purpose of helping someone cope than it is to change the patient's fate,'' he said. Jackson _ who has a bachelor's degree in biology, a master's degree in botany and a doctorate in genetics _ has been a teacher and lecturer for nearly three decades. He doesn't pretend to have answers for all the questions he asks. He doesn't suggest farmers immediately abandon all chemicals and tilling. He believes a radical political agenda and an as yet undiscovered economy are needed to reform agriculture. The Land Institute, which Jackson and his wife founded in 1976, uses the prairie as its standard for a new agriculture. Supported by foundations and a corps of individual donors, the non-profit institute employs 13 people and has 10 interns each year for a 43-week term of study. The interns receive $125 a month. Preference is given to people who plan to earn graduate degrees and work in the field of sustainable agriculture. Most of the work is targeted at developing a domestic prairie. In technical terms, Jackson calls it ``a herbaceous perennial seed-producing polyculture'' that wouldn't require fertilizer, pesticides or herbicides. The legumes and seed-bearing grasses grown for human and animal food wouldn't need annual plowing. Several plants show promise. They are Eastern gamma grass, a high-protein warm season grass related to corn; leymus, a cool season wild rye, and Illinois bundle flower, a native prairie legume. Researchers also are working with a grain sorghum-Johnson grass crossbreed. They hope to wed the domestic milo plant's grain production with the noxious weed's perennial and winter hardiness traits. Of the institute's 278 acres, 90 are native prairie and 50 are replanted prairie. There are also a herbery, where more than 300 wild plants were transplanted for study, a 140-foot greenhouse, and various test plots. A brick 1960s-era split-level rural home serves as administrative and research offices. The Jacksons live in the small home they built nearby in 1971. As the institute has grown, its budget has climbed from $16,000 a year to nearly $500,000. The time frame for results from work at The Land, as its backers call it, is 25, 50 or 100 years. Even then the effort might not reach its goals. But he is resolute about his calling. ``Let's find out from the ecology what it is about nature's community that sees to it all the ecological bills get paid,'' he said. ``What other choice do we have?''
DOC.NOTE: End advance for June 4
$adv 04
For release Monday, June 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Farmer-Doctor Battles Nature on Different Levels
With BC-EXP--Wes Jackson
DOC.TEXT: On windy days, when black clouds of soil bury farm fences and blot out the sun baking North Dakota's prairie, Don Nelson wonders if the loss of precious earth will ever end. ``We're so hopelessly behind,'' Nelson said. ``With these winds we've had, it sucked almost all the moisture out.'' North Dakota, entering its third straight year of drought, leads the nation in acres of land lost to wind erosion. Figures from the federal Soil Conservation Service show a record 1.6 million acres in North Dakota were damaged by wind erosion from Nov. 1, 1989, through February. That compares with 474,200 acres for the same four months of 1988-89. Farmers like Nelson are the underdogs in the fight to save the soil. Nelson, 53, leads a double life. He does research and consults with doctors as a pathologist at a Bismarck clinic, then dons a plaid shirt, blue jeans and hat, lights up a cigar and heads for his wheat and barley fields east of Bismarck. Farming is a life he has known since childhood in Beresford, S.D., near Sioux Falls. But two years of drought have sapped the moisture from his 3,000 acres, and Nelson has been fighting to keep the soil from blowing away. ``This year, I'm going to do less tilling and use more chemicals,'' Nelson vowed last week as he maneuvered a huge planting drill into a shed. ``I don't know what the answer is. I'm beginning to think more about continuous cropping. But we may not ever solve the problem.'' The main problem comes on land left to rest before its next crop is planted, Nelson said. The drought has reduced cover crops like grasses and small grains that would keep the soil in place. Tilling leaves the soil more vulnerable to erosion, and herbicides could seep into water supplies. Nelson, however, said chemicals may be the lesser evil because they are not used as intensely in North Dakota as in other states. Myron Senechal, a conservationist with the North Dakota Soil Conservation Service, said farmers gradually are changing their style of farming to cut down on erosion, mainly by tilling less. ``Producers are aware of the erosion out there,'' he said. ``It's a learning process we have to promote on a day-to-day basis.'' ``Part of the problem is the winter,'' adds Doug Gasseling, state SCS agronomist. ``We've had 60-degree temperatures in February, and it just broke the soil structure down. A lot of our farmers didn't have moisture to start with.'' The persistent drought also has taken an emotional toll. Rain and snow that fell last week were the talk of the state, bringing smiles to farmers' faces and a touch of green to the grass. But much more is needed. ``I don't see signs yet that the pattern has changed,'' Nelson said. ``As you get close to planting time, you think the drought can end with a rainstorm. I was waiting the last two years for that rainstorm, and it never came.'' Nelson, who is unmarried, said his double life keeps him on the go, but he likes it that way. He relaxes by going to medical meetings. ``It's like dealing with nature in different levels. I probably diagnosed 15 different cancers this morning and I don't know whether I can control them. I know I can't control the drought. ``It gives you a pretty good vision of the magnitude of the struggle,'' Nelson added. ``But I know eventually this drought is going to end, and we're going to have good crops again. I think that's what keeps anybody going in this business.''

For release Monday, June 4, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Most People Choose Doctors Old-Fashioned Way, Poll Finds
DOC.TEXT: Most people still choose their doctors by relying mainly on advice from friends or family rather than fee considerations, despite growing worry over medical costs, a poll has found. But one watcher of the health-care market suggested the figures mask the large number of patients who automatically put fee considerations first by belonging to managed health-care plans that limit physician choices. And the head of a health-consumer group said more people might make decisions based on fees if fee information were easier to get. A Gallup poll of 1,500 randomly selected U.S. adults found that the factor they most often cited as their main reason for choosing a doctor was the recommendation of friends or family. That reason was offered by 19 percent. Referrals by professionals were close behind at 17 percent, followed by specific medical reasons at 13 percent and convenience at 9 percent, according to the survey, commissioned by the American Medical Association. Only 1 percent of those surveyed cited fees as the main factor in their most recent selection of a physician, said an article in the May 25 issue of the AMA's weekly American Medical News. But 20 percent of respondents said cost was at least part of the picture when they chose a doctor. That compares with 60 percent who said they believe cost is the main problem facing U.S. health care and medicine today. ``The results show that although the public is concerned with the big-picture concept of medical costs, patients care far more about how a physician treated their neighbor or their cousin than which physician has the cheapest fees,'' said Dr. James S. Todd, acting AMA executive vice president. But other specialists offered different interpretations, including Roger Holstein, president of Consumer Health Services Inc., which operates a physician-referral service called Prologue in eight cities. He said 32 percent of people choosing physicians already belong to cost-saving managed-care plans, such as health maintenance organizations or preferred provider organizations, that restrict their choice of physicians, so ``the process of choosing a doctor has much more to do with convenience.'' An additional 27 percent of people looking for doctors are limited to physicians who can offer payment plans or will accept their insurance, Holstein said from Boulder, Colo. ``There is evidence that 59 percent are choosing a doctor largely on the basis of payment plans,'' said Holstein, quoting figures from a study his company did this year. Arthur Levin, director of the Center for Medical Consumers, a non-profit medical information service with 15,000 subscribers, said he believes few doctors will release fee schedules over the telephone. ``There's no way to compare unless you go around to 10 doctors and make appointments'' and ask for prices of varying services during the course of an examination, he said from New York. ``That's kind of an inefficient and expensive way to find out what the price is,'' he said. The Gallup poll, conducted in January and February, found that concern about doctors fees is growing. The proportion of respondents who agreed to the statement ``doctors fees are usually reasonable'' fell from 33 percent in 1988 to 25 percent in 1990, said the poll, which had an error margin of 2.5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Began With Nuclear Power Reserarch, but Now Helps Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Early research at the Argonne National Laboratory helped create nuclear power, but now scientists there are turning crop waste into plastic, unlocking the secrets of photosynthesis and preparing to study soil with a powerful new X-ray. The laboratory's basic mission of energy research has produced spinoffs that could help farmers produce food and find new markets. ``Advances in agriculture are most likely to occur as a result of the application of modern science, and that's precisely what we're attempting to do,'' lab Director Alan Schriesheim said. Argonne, which opened in 1946 with a mission of finding peaceful uses for atomic energy, has 1,700 acres 25 miles southwest of Chicago. Rare white deer roam the grounds. Part of the U.S. Department of Energy, it is operated under contract by the University of Chicago. The staff of 3,000 includes more than 1,000 scientists, engineers and technicians. Argonne spokesman David Baurac said much of the research focuses on energy sources. For example, polymer chemist Patrick Bonsignore has been converting potato scraps and cheese whey into degradable plastics. ``We want useful products from waste, and we are optimistic about their use in agriculture,'' said Bonsignore. ``But the current technology needs to be upgraded significantly so we can lower the costs.'' He said the degradable plastic material could be used to mulch farm fields and coat pesticides to give them a timed-release effect. Argonne also is preparing to build a $700 million Advanced Photon Source _ billed as the world's brightest X-ray _ to begin working in 1995 or 1996. Agronomist Darrell Schulze of Purdue University said it will give researchers a powerful tool to examine soils _ how they shrink and swell, how minerals are arranged within them, and how plant roots behave. ``We should be able to see things in their natural state without cutting them or digging them out,'' said Schulze. ``One thing this might be useful for is understanding drought tolerance in plants.'' Biochemist Deborah Hanson is using photosynthetic bacteria to study photosynthesis, and believes her work could make crops more efficient and increase their yields, and lead to the design of herbicide-resistant plants.

DOC.HEAD: Cookie Man Changes His Way of Eating
DOC.TEXT: The man who made a living on chewy cookies that were almost as much chocolate chip as dough now is preaching weight loss. For him, the conversion was essential. His life depended on it. In a witty and honest book, David Liederman offers practical advice to people who share his addiction: compulsive eating. ``David's Delicious Weight-Loss Program'' (St. Martin's Press, $18.95) is not a medical book, nor is it a magic bullet. But it is inspiring. The ``cookie man,'' at 5-foot-11, weighed more than 300 pounds and had dangerously high cholesterol and blood sugar levels when his doctor let him know: ``I wouldn't live to see my children grow up.'' That did it. Liederman changed his life. He calls himself a compulsive eater in remission. And happily so. ``My sense of humor had disappeared when my eating was out of control _ I was angry at myself and it spilled over onto the people around me. I was sneaky, too, as all compulsive eaters are when they try to keep their binges a secret. Now I'm neither.'' Liederman opened David's Cookies, shops that sell fresh warm cookies, and owns two New York City restaurants. This is his third book. Written with Joan Schwartz, it includes exactly how to keep a food journal, sample menus, a guide to eating in restaurants, and recipes for such dishes as wild mushroom soup, roasted chicken salad, white clam pizza, potato pie, and oat bran cookies. Liederman, who says he was overweight since childhood, had more going against him than most dieters _ surrounded every day by the ``the world's finest chocolate, butter, pastries, ice cream and cookies.'' But while he once tasted everything, he now depends on the aroma, or on tastings by his wife, Susan, and two daughters. ``Sure, I would prefer the old way, but a compulsive person can't afford preferences. If you are a compulsive eater you are eating yourself to death _ death by overweight or death by cholesterol or a combination of both.'' His effort included avoiding foods that would increase his cholesterol; eating good, well-prepared food; learning what foods triggered his binges and avoiding them; keeping a food journal; and exercising. Like many specialists, Liederman says a ``diet'' is not the answer, and his own litany of diet failures is plenty of evidence they didn't work for him. ``You have to take responsibility for your own eating habits and change your own behavior,'' he writes. ``You need a program that makes sense for you as an addictive personality.'' Trained as a French chef, Liederman said his diet recipes meet standards he demanded at the three-star Restaurant Troisgros in Roanne, France. Liederman's stories, or versions of them, will sound familiar to compulsive eaters. One night at the dinner table Liederman, his brother and his stepfather _ forks first _ surged toward the one remaining pork chop. The stepfather speared the brother, and in the chaos, Liederman got the meat. ``We ate fast and we talked fast; at the dinner table we went for speed and volume. We were so eager to get to the next portion that we barely tasted what we were eating and whatever hit the table was devoured as if hit by a buzz saw.'' He also tells of eating frozen pastries, standing at the open freezer door. Later, vacations revolved around getting to the most three-star restaurants in France in the shortest amount of time. ``The name of the game was overkill. I would start lunch at 12 and finished somewhere between 4 and 5 p.m., having polished off seven courses of food, two bottles of wine, 10 desserts and Cognac or Armagnac.'' Despite the humor in his stories, Liederman takes overeating seriously, recognizing the excuses, denial and self-pity and fighting over and over against his addiction. Not all compulsive eaters are overweight, he notes. And many hide their bouts of overeating, if not from everyone, from some people. ``A compulsive eater doesn't eat fast and overeat because he or she enjoys food,'' he said. ``The idea is to control the food, to make it all belong to him or her.''

DOC.HEAD: Not All Victims of Alzheimer's Are Elderly
DOC.TEXT: The tragedy of Alzheimer's disease comes early to some victims, who find their reason and memories slipping away in middle age. Of the 4.5 million Alzheimer's patients in the United States, 5 percent to 10 percent are younger than 65, said the national Alzheimer's Association. ``We're not talking about a public health problem, as these cases are extremely uncommon. But it is always very distressing to see a dementing disorder occur in the prime of life,'' said Ranjan Duara, medical director of the Wien Center for Alzheimer's Disease at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. In Broward County, a 38-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's. One of the youngest cases in the country, she had to quit her job as a school teacher last year and lives with her mother. Disability checks have been slow in arriving, and the family recently applied for food stamps. These young Alzheimer's patients often find themselves shut out of day care programs and experimental drug trials that will admit only those 60 and older. ``We're recognizing that these people have special needs because they don't fit into the age categories typically associated with Alzheimer's patients,'' said Mollie Charters, president of the Broward County chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. About one-third of people age 85 or older will develop Alzheimer's, said Creighton Phelps of the Chicago-based Alzheimer's Association. By comparison, less than 1 percent of the population younger than 55 is at risk. Nearly all early-onset patients have a family history of the disease. They also can exhibit defects in the chromosone that causes Down's syndrome, specialists say. Many Down's patients also develop Alzheimer's disease in their 40s. Steven Sevush, a neurologist and psychiatrist at the University of Miami Medical School, said that because a definite diagnosis of Alzheimer's only can be made by cutting into the brain, ``aggressive attempts should be made to find other causes rather than making a clinical guess.'' Some other diseases that occur in middle age have symptoms similar to Alzheimer's and some of them are treatable.
DOC.HEAD: Tester Strips Show if It's Time To Ditch Batteries
DOC.TEXT: A battery maker is enclosing tester strips with its batteries that give a thermometer-like reading on how much juice they have left. Duracell U.S.A. says it has patented the Copper Top Tester strip, which is squeezed to the top and bottom of the battery. A liquid crystal bar creeps up to either ``replace'' or ``good.'' The tester can be used for alkaline batteries and can be used over and over on standard AA-size, AAA-size, C and D batteries, said a spokesman for Duracell. It also can be used on other brands of batteries.
DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Patients Skip Medications
DOC.TEXT: Patients with high blood pressure who skip their medication are pushing up health care costs each year in the United States, a university researcher says. The research quantified the relationship between hospital admissions for high blood pressure and failure to take medications. The study was published recently in the journal ``Medical Care.'' Researchers studied Medicaid patients in Los Angeles County, comparing those who were hospitalized for high blood pressure during the year of the study and those who were not. On average, those who were rehospitalized did not take their medicine 46 days over the year. Those not rehospitalized skipped their medication 25 days. Studies of other chronic diseases, such as epilepsy and glaucoma, show similar trends, said Lee Strandberg of Oregon State University, one author of the study. Nationally, the cost to the health care system of patients who fail to follow directions for taking medicine is $7 billion to $10 billion, Strandberg said. ``Studies such as ours will help target the cause of the problem. Then we can develop strategies to manage the situation,'' he said. The issue is of particular importance in Oregon, where a panel is developing a priority list for rationing health care for the poor, Strandberg said. The study was done with researchers at the University of Southern California School of Medicine, University of California-Berkeley School of Public Health, Los Angeles County and a private consulting firm.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for June 4

DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge fell in April for the second time in three months, a sign analysts said portends continued sluggish growth with pockets of weakness in construction and manufacturing. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, fell 0.2 percent in April _ due in large measure to the third straight monthly drop in building permits.

New home sales plummeted in April to their lowest level since the nation's economy emerged from the 1981-82 recession, the government said. Analysts attributed the fifth consecutive monthly decline to continued double-digit mortgage rates. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday that new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 546,000 units in April, the smallest number since 521,000 units were sold in December 1982.

With the return of bull-market enthusiasm that has carried stock prices to new highs in the past few weeks, Wall Street is setting its sights on a lofty target _ the 3,000 level in the Dow Jones industrial average. In less than five weeks from April 27 through the close Wednesday, the ``Dow'' _ the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices _ surged up 233.51 points, or 8.8 percent. From Wednesday's record reading of 2,878.56, it needed only a 4.2 percent advance to reach 3,000.

The Japanese government has approved the sale of audio tape decks that can make direct digital recordings of compact discs, a move expected to aid marketing and sales of the expensive devices. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry's approval Wednesday was timed to allow Japanese manufacturers to introduce the machines at the Consumer Electronics Show, which opens Saturday in Chicago, industry officials said. The new decks' ability to make virtually perfect copies of CDs is expected to boost sales for the much-debated recording medium, the officials said.

``Draconian'' clean-air proposals under debate in Congress threaten the the U.S. steel industry's recovery from its severe slump of the early 1980s, industry leaders said as they gathered for their annual meeting. Also threatening the industry's health are the high cost of capital in the United States and foreign competition, leaders of major U.S. steel companies said Wednesday at the American Iron and Steel Institute meeting.

Ivan Boesky's chief trader testified that John Mulheren Jr. temporarily held large blocks of securities for Boesky in 1985 in an alleged scheme to help his former friend avoid taxes and securities rules. Michael Davidoff, testifying Wednesday at Mulheren's trial in U.S. District Court, offered a trade-by-trade breakdown of an alleged pact with Boesky's Seemala Corp. that forms the heart of government's case against Mulheren. The government has said Mulheren entered into the trades with Boesky in exchange for information about pending corporate takeovers. Mulheren is charged with 41 counts of conspiracy, mail and securities fraud, and record-keeping violations.

After a more than 40-year lull, stocks and bonds could be traded again in Warsaw this year if necessary legislation is approved, two visiting Polish officials said. The pair, winding up a two-day meeting with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission officials, said Wednesday they are drafting Poland's first securities regulations since the Communists took power after World War II.

U.S. and European officials failed to break a deadlock over government payments to farmers, throwing further doubt over ambitious plans to overhaul the world trading system. European officials resisted American attempts to use a meeting of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to give a political push to the stalled Uruguay Round trade talks. ``We have hit a snag in our negotiations,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Wednesday at the end of lengthy discussions with officials of the European Community.

Big Macs wowed Moscow, so perhaps it should come as no surprise that the Walt Disney Co. says Muscovites gobbled up all 200,000 Russian-language Mickey Mouse comics magazines the first day of release. The 32-page magazine, designed as the first in a quarterly series, was released May 16 and sold for 1.5 rubles a copy _ about $2.40. It contains five comics of various lengths already published in other countries, with dialogue in the ``word balloons'' translated into Russian.

Prices moved moderately higher on Wall Street Wednesday, nudging the Dow Jones industrial average up 8.07 to finish at 2,878.56, another high. Bond prices advanced slightly in light trading. The dollar gained against most major currencies except the British pound. Gold prices posted moderate losses. Sugar futures prices fell for the second straight day in reaction to a report of increased sugar production and a supply surplus. Grains and soybeans futures were mostly lower, energy futures gained, precious metals fell, and livestock and pork futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Sells $6 Billion in Bills
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department on Wednesday sold $6 billion each in 20-day and 111-day cash management bills. The average discount rate on the 20-day bills was 7.93 percent while the average rate on the 111-day bills was 7.78 percent. The discount rate understates the actual return to investors of 8.08 percent with a $10,000 20-day bill selling for $9,955.90 and 8.08 percent also for a $10,000 111-day bill selling for $9,760.10.

DOC.HEAD: ``Draconian'' Clean Air Proposals May Hurt Steel, Industry Leaders Say
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. steel industry's recovery from a severe downturn in the early 1980s could be harmed by clean-air controls under consideration by Congress, executives of major steel companies said at their annual convention. Reining in proposed pollution regulation has become a major policy issue for the industry, said Thomas C. Graham, president of USS, the steelmaking division of USX Corp. Other issues of concern include the high cost of capital in the United States and foreign competition, executives said Wednesday at the American Iron and Steel Institute gathering. ``Clearly, the environment is again the major public policy issue facing steel producers after a decade in which trade was at center stage,'' said Graham, who called some clean-air proposals being considered by Congress ``draconian.'' He said the steel industry is willing to spend more to install pollution-control equipment, but only if the results justify the costs. ``We oppose requirements which would drain our available capital _ and which would cause plant closings and substantial job losses _ without verifiable scientific indication of real benefit to the environment or improvement to public health,'' he told industry executives and reporters. Graham, who heads the nation's largest steelmaker, said steel producers spent $7 billion over the last three decades to eliminate 90 percent to 95 percent of the pollutants they put into the air and water. The industry's main concern in the current debate is provisions of the Senate clean-air bill that would force automatic shutdowns of plants that produce coke _ a key ingredient in steelmaking _ unless they meet certain pollution standards, Graham said. He called a provision that would give steel companies up to 30 years to comply with the coke oven standards misleading. ``The fact is that the mere passage of the shutdown provisions would have an immediate, chilling impact,'' he said. ``How could we justify making the major investments needed in the next five to 10 years to rebuild aging (coke) batteries ... if they face mandatory shutdown in the future? ``Foreign steelmakers _ who are not facing the kind of environmental cost burdens we are _ would love to see passage of the Senate shutdown provisions,'' Graham said. The executives said research continues into direct steelmaking _ in which iron ore would be melted directly, eliminating the need for coke _ but that the technology was at least 10 years away. The chairman of the trade association, Frank W. Luerssen, called the cost of capital the domestic steel industry's top concern. Without access to lower-cost borrowing, U.S. steel companies cannot compete with foreign makers in modernizing plants, said Luerssen, who is chairman and chief executive officer of Inland Steel Industries Inc. He said companies in Western Europe and Japan can borrow money at lower interest rates, a major factor in the decision by many U.S. steel companies to enter joint ventures with foreign companies and in foreign purchases of U.S. steel plants. ``The profitability of steel companies is occasionally too low to attract low-cost capital,'' said Joseph F. Toot Jr., president of steel products maker Timken Co. ``On the other hand, profitability can be substantially improved through investment in world-leading technology.'' Commenting on Japanese investment in U.S. steelmaking in recent years, he said, ``It is intriguing to observe that the Japanese investor can apparently see through this Catch-22 and see that in the long haul, the American steel industry will become more profitable.'' On another topic, industry leaders said they support the Bush administration's efforts to eliminate dumping of foreign steel in the United States and subsidies from foreign governments to their steelmakers. The current limits on steel imports are scheduled to expire in March 1992. By then, the administration hopes to have eliminated subsidies and dumping, or selling foreign steel in the United States at below the cost of production. Graham said the industry would seek no further protection or extension of the import limits if dumping and subsidies were eliminated. He also said the industry believes the main reason it wasn't competitive globally several years ago was a ``grossly overvalued'' dollar, rather than just unfair foreign competition. A stronger dollar makes U.S. exports more costly in terms of foreign currencies. He said the Federal Reserve's move to ease inflation in the early 1980s by raising interest rates, thus increasing the value of the dollar, ``helped almost destroy American manufacturing competitiveness.''

With PM-Dow 3,000, Bjt

Jan. 12, 1906 _ Closes above 100 for the first time, at 100.25. Sept. 3, 1929 _ Reaches its closing peak for the bull market of the 1920s, at 381.17, less than two months before the Great Crash. Oct. 28, 1929 _ Plummets 38.33 points, the worst drop on record until 1986, cutting nearly 13 percent of the average's value, closing at 260.64. July 8, 1932 _ Closes at its Depression low of 41.22, having fallen 89 percent in less than three years. March 12, 1956 _ Closes above 500 for the first time, at 500.24. Jan. 18, 1966 _ Reaches 1,000 for the first time in mid-session, but drops back to close at 994.20. Nov. 14, 1972 _ Closes above 1,000 for the first time, at 1,003.16. Jan. 11, 1973 _ Peaks at 1,051.70. Dec. 6, 1974 _ Closes at a 12-year low of 577.60, ending the worst bear market since the '30s. April 27, 1981 _ Closes at an eight-year high of 1,024.05. Aug. 12, 1982 _ Closes at a two-year low of 776.92, just prior to the start of a historic rally. Aug. 17, 1982 _ Rises 38.81 points, to 831.24, in its then-largest one-day gain as the long rally begins on Wall Street. Dec. 11, 1985 _ Increases 12.50 points to close at 1,511.70, its first finish above 1,500. Jan. 8, 1987 _ Breaks the 2,000 level for the first time, rising 8.30 to 2,002.25. July 17, 1987 _ Climbs 13.07 to 2,510.04, closing above 2,500 for the first time. Oct. 16, 1987 _ Plunges 108.36 points to 2,246.73, falling more than 100 points for the first time. Oct. 19, 1987 _ Dives a record 508.00 points to 1,738.74, a drop of 22.6 percent that dwarfs the drop on Oct. 28, 1929, in the market's Great Crash. Feb. 4, 1988 _ Falls 5.63 to 2,057.86, the same day New York Stock Exchange announces it will experiment with a 50-point ``collar'' on program trading. The exchange bars the use of its computers for index arbitrage on days the Dow rises or falls 50 points or more from its previous close. Feb. 8, 1988 _ Falls 14.76 to 1,895.72, its low for the year. March 25, 1988 _ Closes down 44.92 to 1,978.95; the 50-point ``collar'' is triggered on the down side for the first time during the session. April 6, 1988 _ Jumps 64.16 to 2,061.67, triggering the collar on the up side for the first time. Jan. 24, 1989 _ Gains 38.04 to 2,256.43, regaining its Oct. 16, 1987 level for the first time since the Black Monday crash on Oct. 19, 1987.
