Oct. 16, 1989 _ Gains 88.12 to 2,657.38 in rally led by Dow industrials. Jan. 2, 1990 _ Gains 56.95 to 2,810.15, reaching a record high for the first time since the Oct. 13 plunge. Jan. 12, 1990 _ Falls 71.46 to 2,689.21 on worries about higher inflation and earlier declines in the Tokyo and London stock markets. Jan. 22, 1990 _ Falls 77.45 to 2,600.45, putting the Dow industrials 7.47 percent below its record high of Jan. 2. May 11, 1990 _ Rises 63.07 to 2,801.58 in rally sparked by economic reports suggesting mild inflation. May 14, 1990 _ Gains 19.95 to 2,821.53, topping the Jan. 2 record close for the first time. May 29, 1990 _ Jumps 49.57 to record 2,870.49. May 30, 1990 _ Rises 8.07 to 2,878.56.

DOC.HEAD: New Delaware Law Allows Banks To Sell And Underwrite Insurance
DOC.TEXT: A new Delaware law that allows banks with operations in the state to sell and underwrite insurance nationwide was only hours old when the insurance industry challenged it. Gov. Michael N. Castle signed the legislation into law Wednesday and it took effect immediately. Two hours later, a petition was filed with the Federal Reserve Board to block Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, from taking advantage of the law. Citicorp plans to locate an insurance headquarters in Dover and sell insurance nationwide through a subsidiary of its Delaware bank. The petition, filed by five national insurance agent associations and three local groups, alleges Citicorp is attempting to evade the federal Bank Holding Company Act, which prohibits bank holding companies and their subsidiaries from selling insurance, said William R. Anderson, associate general counsel of the National Association of Life Underwriters in Washington. Citicorp officials, who had not seen the petition, were expected to respond today, said David Swayze, a Wilmington attorney and Citicorp lobbyist. The law is a continuation of Delaware's effort to stay in the forefront of an ever-changing financial services industry. In 1981, the state enacted the Financial Center Development Act, which offered tax incentives and eliminated interest rate ceilings to lure out-of-state banks to move their credit card operations to Delaware. Delaware was the first to relax its banking laws and other states soon followed suit. Since 1981, the state enacted about eight laws aimed at making it more attractive for financial service companies to locate in Delaware, and Castle said the trend would continue. ``We cannot rest on our laurels. It's not just banking, but all financial services that interest us here in Delaware, and we're always looking at ways to improve our business environment to be ahead of the curve, to be ahead of our competitors, to be ahead of everybody else in the country ...,'' Castle said. Secretary of State Michael Harkins said there is a possibility that with the new law, a major European bank could open a subsidiary in Delaware. He would not identify the bank. He said, however, that Delaware wants to bring in foreign banks. In addition to banking reforms, Delaware is known worldwide for its favorable incorporation laws. More than half of the nation's Fortune 500 companies are incorporated in the state. As he signed the bill Wednesday, Castle said it was possible the new law would be challenged by insurance companies or other states. But he predicted such challenges would fail. The law allows banks chartered in Delaware after 1934 to sell and underwrite insurance nationwide. Most banks chartered before 1934 already have such powers. Those chartered earlier that do not have such powers must obtain permission from the state Legislature. A companion bill also signed into law restricts the types of insurance banks can sell within the state, but allows them to sell a full range of products outside Delaware. The banks must locate their insurance headquarters in Delaware to take advantage of the laws. Chase Manhattan Corp., the nation's No. 2 bank, also has said it plans to sell insurance through its office in the state. More than half of the states allow banks to engage in some form of insurance sales, but they limit the sales to within state boundaries, said Mary-Liz Meany, spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association in Washington. The banking industry considers the new law a boon for consumers because it expands the market. ``There's been a sense that if the insurance industry allowed more players in the market, the price will come down,'' Meany said. She said the law gives insurance powers to about 40 financial institutions nationwide that have affiliates in Delaware.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Stocks Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today while stock prices moved higher. The dollar closed at 151.75 yen, a gain of 1.00 yen from Wednesday. The dollar, which had risen on overseas markets overnight, continued to advance in Tokyo as institutional investors bought the U.S. currency against the yen for technical adjustments, said Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Halting the dollar's advance were profit taking and concerns over the release of the U.S. jobless rate for May, scheduled for Friday in Washington, Tabata said. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed 204.54 points, or 0.62 percent, closing at 33,130.80. The index rose 108.59 points on Wednesday. ``Trading was active and strong for a day when the yen weakened against the dollar,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 800 million shares, unchanged from Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Court: Caller ID Invades Privacy, Violates Wiretap Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A state court has denied Bell of Pennsylvania the right to install telephone devices that flash the numbers of incoming callers, saying the feature invades privacy and violates wiretap laws. The 4-1 ruling Wednesday by Commonwealth Court reversed a November order by the Public Utility Commission allowing Bell to offer the service. Caller ID lets people know who is calling before they pick up the receiver. The caller's number flashes on a small device attached to the telephone. The American Civil Liberties Union, the Pennsylvania Coalition Against Domestic Violence and others sued to block the service. Some argued it would threaten battered spouses and children by revealing their location. Bell offered blocking devices to domestic-violence shelters and law enforcement agencies to prevent their numbers from being revealed to users of Caller ID, and Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr. contended in court papers that the service did not violate Pennsylvania's wiretap law. But the court disagreed, and said Caller ID is unacceptable even if offered with a blocking device. ``In the framework of a democratic society, the privacy rights concept is much too fundamental to be compromised or abridged by permitting Caller ID,'' the court said. Bill Harral, Bell vice president of external affairs, said the company mahy appeal. ``Because of this decision, Pennsylvanians are being denied a service they eagerly want and badly need _ a weapon against unwanted, harassing, threatening or obscene calls,'' he said. The service could be vital to emergency dispatchers, allowing them to locate people who call for help even if the caller hangs up, Rabe said. Bell spokesman Eric Rabe said about 1,000 people had registered for the service. The company had proposed charging $6.50 per month. Caller identification is offered in parts of New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia, according to Bell Atlantic, the corporate parent of Bell of Pennsylvania. They are under review in Delaware and the District of Columbia.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Audio Tape Decks Approved for Sale by Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A tape deck that has aroused the ire of record companies because it can make near-perfect recordings of compact discs has been approved for sale by the government and will soon be introduced to the U.S. market. Despite its expense _ about $1,200 _ the digital audio tape recorder's ability to make direct digital copies of CDs is expected to boost sales for the much-debated recording medium, industry officials said. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry's approval Wednesday was timed to allow Japanese manufacturers to introduce DAT recorders at the Consumer Electronics Show, which opens Saturday in Chicago, the officials said. Opposition to DAT technology has persisted in the United States in the music industry over concern about copyright protection, and Congress has not yet passed legislation setting a new standard for the machines. Japanese electronics companies, which make virtually all DAT equipment, have refrained from actively selling DAT decks in the United States because of opposition from record companies and songwriters. But Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. spokesman Akira Nagano said his company, which makes Panasonic equipment, might begin marketing in the United States before legislation is approved if congressional action is delayed. Current laws do not prohibit DATs. One version of the DAT recorder has been sold in Japan and some parts of Europe since 1987, and are available through the ``gray market'' in the United States. But in a concession to record companies, the equipment currently on the market cannot make direct digital recordings of CDs. Instead, they convert the high-quality digital signals on CDs to analog signals and reconvert them to digital form before recording them, resulting in a slight loss in sound quality. That, combined with the high price of blank DAT tapes that cost almost as much as CDs, has held DAT sales far below initial expectations. Last summer, however, U.S., European and Japanese record and electronics industry groups agreed on an international standard that would allow sales of DAT equipment that can make direct digital copies of CDs. But they also agreed the machines would include a ``sequential copy management system'' that adds a ``flag'' signal to the tape when CDs are recorded, to prevent the DAT copy from being copied further. That version of the DAT recorder was approved by the Japanese government on Wednesday. ``After studying the situation carefully, the Japanese government has decided that the standard agreed upon represents the best balance between the interests of equipment makers and record producers,'' Hisato Nagao, a ministry official, told The Associated Press. Unlike analog recordings, digital tape recordings deteriorate very little from generation to generation. Record manufacturers had feared that DAT machines would result in a flood of high-quality copies of CDs that would cut into their sales. Company officials said they were unsure until Wednesday's decision whether they would be able to announce prices and marketing plans for their DAT recorders at the Chicago show, the main trade exhibition for the lucrative U.S. consumer electronics industry. ``If the ministry hadn't decided now, it would have meant a many-month delay in marketing the new DAT equipment,'' said an official at a major electronics company, who spoke on condition of anonymity. U.S. electronics companies, which have virtually abandoned production of consumer electronic goods, are unlikely to oppose DAT marketing, officials say.

DOC.HEAD: Advocacy Group Accuses Car Rental Companies of Ripping Off Consumers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Car rental companies are coercing consumers into buying damage coverage they don't need, a consumer group claims. ``It's just a way for (rental companies) to make a lot of profit. The product itself is inherently a fraud on consumers,'' Lucinda Sikes, a staff attorney for the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, said at a news conference Wednesday. But Jan Armstrong, executive director of the National Car Rental Association, said only about one in five auto renters opts for the so-called collision damage waiver, which pays for a vandalized, wrecked or stolen car. Sikes said the collision damage waivers can run as high as $13 a day in addition to the actual rental price. ``A lot of people don't need it at all but are buying it out of fear,'' Sikes said, adding that the cost of the coverage is too high, sometime boosting the rental price by as much as 48 percent. ``It really should be only a few dollars a day,'' she added. The U.S. PIRG report said collision damage waivers often are ``sold under coercive circumstances, at excessive prices and with deceptive statements about coverage.'' The report did not describe the type of coercion it said was used. The report was compiled from a survey of 10 companies operating in the Washington area. Consumers often are left in the dark about exceptions to the waivers, which may be voided for reasons ranging from travel on a gravel road to driving after only one drink, Sikes said. ``It's written in the fine print,'' she said. About 60 percent of personal auto policies cover rental cars, Sikes said, and some credit card companies provide collision damage waivers when rentals are charged to the card. Armstrong contended Sikes was unfair in suggesting that the industry was cheating consumers ``when we're in business to provide a service.'' Armstrong said customers are not being coerced into accepting the coverage. Most of those who do pay for the waiver, she added, either don't own cars, are from other countries or do not have credit cards or personal auto insurance that provide the coverage. ``It's a safety net,'' she said. Armstrong said industry leader Hertz favors doing away with the waiver, but the alternative generally has been higher prices for all rental cars. ``The price is built in and everybody pays,'' she said. Both Sikes and Armstrong said people planning to rent cars should find out first if their personal auto policies or credit cards would pay for a damaged rental car.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Forecasts Increased Farm Exports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: American agricultural exports for the fiscal year ending in September will total $40 billion, an increase of $1.5 billion from the February estimate, the Agriculture Department forecasts. USDA on Wednesday issued a statement revising the estimated volume of agricultural exports to 150 million metric tons, a increase of 1.5 million from the February forecast. The department said, however, that much of the increase would result from a change in the system under which shipments between the United States and Canada are reported, the department said in its situation and outlook summary. The change was designed to eliminate under-reporting of exports by both countries, USDA said. In addition, though, USDA said that since February the prospects for exports of U.S. corn, soybeans and cotton have improved in terms of both volume and price. USDA also raised the forecast for U.S. agricultural imports from $21.5 billion to $22 billion. It said the main reason was an upswing in fruit and vegetable imports from Latin America in the wake of December's freeze in Florida and Texas. The department forecast the U.S. agricultural surplus for the year at $18 billion, only a shade below that for fiscal 1989. The surplus had been rising steadily since fiscal 1986 when it skidded to an anemic $5.4 billion. In terms of volume, the estimate of $150 million tons is up from last year's total of $146.4 million. The forecast puts exports of grains and feeds at $16.3 billion, wheat and flour at $5.1 billion, rice at $800 million, coarse grains overall at $7.9 billion and corn at $6.9 billion. It estimates total exports of oilseeds and their products at $5.9 billion, with soybeans at $3.7 billion, soybean cake and meal $900 million and soybean oil at $400 million. The forecast was for livestock products of $5.5 billion, poultry and products $800 million, dairy products $400 million, horticultural products $5 billion, tobacco $1.3 billion, cotton and linters $2.9 billion, seeds $600 million and sugar and tropical products $1.4 billion.

USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service is proposing to lower from 25 percent to 22 percent the limit on fat in ground beef under its institutional meat purchase specifications used by schools, hospitals and the armed services. The change would be part of a broader revision of the institutional meat specifications, the department announced. It said the move was designed to reflect increased consumer interest in lower-fat beef. ``Its a step in the right direction,'' said Bonnie Liebman, director of nutrition for the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``They could do more.'' Currently, USDA defines lean beef as having no more than 10 percent fat by weight but makes an exception for ground beef and puts its level at 22.5 percent. ``That's why I like to speak of so-called lean ground beef,'' Liebman said. Regular ground beef can range up to 30 percent fat by weight. Under the institutional purchase specifications, the limit applies only if the buyer does not negotiate to obtain the beef at a different level of fat.

USDA is cosponsoring a National Sustainable Agriculture and Natural Resources Conference on Aug. 15-18 in Lincoln, Neb. Sustainable agriculture refers to growing techniques that reduce reliance on pesticides and other chemicals that have been shown to pose health risks. ``The conference is designed to achieve a profitable agriculture that is environmentally sound, resource efficient, socially acceptable and thus sustainable in the future,'' said Charles E. Hess, assistant secretary of agriculture for science and education. The conference will bring together educators, government officials, farmers, agribusiness executives and environmentalists, USDA said. It said they would ``develop guidelines to form state teams to implement programs for sustainable agriculture throughout the nation.'' Other sponsors include the Rodale Institute, Dupont Co., the American Forestry Association and the Wildlife Management Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Officials Wind Up Trade Talks, Fail to Budge on Farm Subsidies
With PM-Summit-Trade
DOC.TEXT: A four-year effort to revamp the world trading system remained in doubt after U.S. and European negotiators failed to budge from their positions on government payments to farmers. No headway in resolving the stubborn dispute was reported Wednesday after lengthy discussions by key trade officials of the United States and the European Community. ``We have hit a snag,'' said U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Mrs. Hills and other American officials tried to use a meeting of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to advance the Uruguay Round of trade talks. But their efforts were blunted by the community, made up of a dozen West European nations. ``This is not a negotiating forum,'' said Frans Andriessen, the community's trading chief. The Americans want the Europeans to agree to do more to slash their costly subsidies to farmers, but the Europeans so far have refused. The dispute has stalled the Uruguay Round negotiations, an ambitious effort to overhaul the world trading system by reducing trade barriers in 15 areas, including agriculture and textiles. The bargaining among nearly 100 nations began in Uruguay in 1986 and is scheduled to end with a final round of talks in December. But the latest failure to find common ground on farm subsidies does not bode well. The talks are held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and an agreement for promoting freer trade. Canada's international trade minister, John Crosbie, was glum when he came out of Wednesday's discussions. ``It was discouraging,'' he said. Both sides, he said, ``seemed to be so adamant of their own positions.'' Andriessen acknowledged that the inability of the community to change its position might be viewed negatively. But he predicted the trading partners would be able to ``come to a satisfactory agreement.'' Mrs. Hills said the negotiators would be in ``grave difficulty'' if they were unable to settle the farm subsidy dispute by December. The United States has linked agreement on the agriculture issue to success in other areas as well. But Andriessen noted that ``agriculture is not the only issue,'' since the talks cover 14 other areas. American officials wanted Thursday's final statement at the OECD meeting to show that both sides were willing to lower trade barriers so that farm exports would have better access to other countries' local markets. They also wanted the community to promise to reduce farm payments that encourage overproduction of crops and to slash subsidies that help farmers sell their goods on foreign markets. The United States complains that export subsidies have helped the community increase its share of the world market. The community refused to pledge to widen its markets to foreign food products or to curb export subsidies, according to U.S. officials. The community has argued that it has adopted a plan limiting the maximum annual amount of expenditure on price guarantees. But it says it cannot wipe out its subsidy programs entirely. OECD members are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Broadly Lower at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were broadly lower at midday Thursday in what some dealers described as a natural reaction to the sharp gains of recent days. ``We've gained about 80 points in the past couple of days, so a fall of up to 20 points is probably healthy,'' one trader said. Other dealers pointed to surprisingly weak trading in stock futures. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 9.9 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,336.3 at midday. Volume came to 308.1 million shares at midday, compared with 330.4 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell, Northwest Reach Accord To Navigate Via Soviet Satellites
DOC.TEXT: A tentative deal reached by Northwest Airlines, Honeywell Inc., and the Soviet Union could relieve overseas air routes and make ground-based navigation equipment obsolete, officials from the two companies say. ``It will allow us to put more airplanes in the sky more safely,'' Bob Buley, manager of flight standards and product development for Northwest, said Wednesday. ``We think it could be the sole source of navigation by 1995,'' said Jim Koch, vice president of Minneapolis operations for Honeywell. The joint venture allows for the simultaneous testing of Soviet and U.S. satellites as a navigation guide for commercial jets. It was announced at a news conference by Honeywell Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James Renier and Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi. The executives said the agreement signed by Honeywell, Northwest and the Soviet Union is subject to government approval in both countries. Under the agreement, the Soviets would deliver equipment to Honeywell and Northwest late this year. The exchange would enable Honeywell to build units capable of reading commercial aviation signals from the Soviet Glosnass satellite system. Military aviation signals would not be accessible, Koch said. The equipment would be mounted on a Northwest 747 cargo plane for test flying through September 1991. The same plane in April began testing Honeywell equipment that reads commercial navigation signals from the U.S. Global Positioning System of satellites. The 21 active satellites planned for each system could enable pilots to double-check the positions of their planes to guard against inaccurate readings, Buley said. The system also could enable planes to land at airports that lack sophisticated ground-based navigation equipment, he said. ``It will literally open up the globe to commercial aviation,'' Buley said. Koch said Northwest and Honeywell will strive to have the dual satellite navigation system certified for use in all commercial jetliners by 1993. They will seek certification for the system as a plane's sole source of navigation by 1995. Trans-oceanic air travel would benefit the most by the advance, Buley said. The absence of ground-based navigation during overseas flights requires pilots to approximate their whereabouts and keep about a 60-mile buffer between planes, he said. Satellite navigation would allow pilots to nearly pinpoint their whereabouts and fly within five or even three miles of other planes, he said. Today's reference systems for flying overseas can result in position errors of about 10 nautical miles for every five hours of flying, Honeywell said in a news release. ``We're running into gridlock over there now,'' Buley said of routes from the United States to the Pacific Rim, where Northwest is dominant. ``We're having to take delays getting off the ground because we have to wait for the planes ahead of us to get well into the system.'' The agreement would not give Honeywell exclusive rights to develop equipment capable of reading Soviet satellite signals, but it would give the controls maker a head start on a potentially huge market, Koch said. Koch said the Soviets alone have up to 4,000 commercial airplanes. Excluding the Soviet Union, the worldwide fleet of commercial aircraft is estimated at about 9,100, said Tom Cole, a spokesman for the aircraft maker Boeing Co. of Seattle. Buley said it could cost between $25,000 and $50,000 to equip each plane with equipment needed to receive satellite signals. The sales would be made by Honeywell's space and aviation division, which accounted for about $2 billion of the company's $6.1 billion in sales last year. Checchi said Northwest would eventually like to extend its routes to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. But he said such an expansion ``is not our highest priority.''

DOC.HEAD: Kemper Corp. Laying Off 600
DOC.TEXT: Kemper Corp. says it will lay off 600 employees and restructure its unprofitable stock brockerage operations in an effort to save about $30 million a year. As a result of the restructuring, the suburban Long Grove, Ill.-based company said Wednesday it would take a $126.5 million charge against second-quarter earnings. The changes are due to be completed by year's end and will affect about 12 percent of the brokerage's U.S. work force of 5,100, the company said. The plan calls for the company's five regional brokerage firms, which had functioned largely independently, to operate as divisions of a management unit, Kemper Securities Group Holdings Inc. The five firms are Blunt, Ellis & Loewi in Milwaukee; Boettcher & Co. in Denver; Lovett Underwood Neuhaus & Webb in Houston; Prescott, Ball & Turben in Cleveland and Kemper Clearing Corp. in New York. The five firms will keep their own names but administrative and support activities will be based in Illinois. ``By operating as completely autonomously as we were, we found ourselves int he position of duplicating many activities,'' said James Boris, chairman of the Kemper Securities Group.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Officials Predict Stock Trading Soon in Warsaw
DOC.TEXT: It may not happen right away, but two Polish officials say their country is ready for that hallmark of capitalism, a stock market _ even after more than 40 years of Communist rule. ``If all will be well, we will be able to do it, I think, in the late fall, say October, November 1990,'' Grzegorz Jedrzejczak told reporters Wednesdasy. He and Leslaw A. Paga, both advisers to Poland's Finance Ministry, are drafting that country's first securities regulations since the 1930s. They met with reporters in the offices of SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden. ``We expect that in early fall we'll be ready with drafts of securities law which we will present to our Parliament, and of course, nobody knows how long it will take in Parliament because that's an advantage of democracy,'' Jedrzejczak chuckled. The visitors said securities trading could resume in Poland quickly if legislation creating a Polish securities and exchange commission is passed. But the pair conceded it won't be easy to win foreign investment. ``We cannot declare that we just now are a trustworthy country,'' said Paga. But they said there would be no problem finding capitalists in Poland. Noting the thriving black market in foreign currency in Communist-dominated Poland, Jedrzejczak said ``people are quite smart. It won't be a problem. There are hundreds of people trading commodities on the streets now.'' Meanwhile, Breeden announced the appointment of top officials from the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and other industry professionals to an advisory panel on emerging markets in Eastern Europe. In addition to outgoing Chicago Merc Chairman Leo Melamed and NYSE Chairman John Phelan, who will be stepping down at the end of the year, the panel includes: Joseph Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, a self-regulating organization that oversees the over-the-counter stock market; and Matthew P. Fink, senior vice president and general counsel of the Investment Company Institute, a mutal fund and investment company trade oranization. Also: Shaun F. O'Malley, chairman of the accounting firm, Price Waterhouse and Merrill Lynch & Co. Chairman William A. Schreyer. The panel, which expects to hold its first meeting in mid-June, will recommend what action the SEC and the financial industry can take to help create and organize securities markets in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. It was the third visit to the SEC for Paga and Jedrzejczak, who said they hoped to create a securities regulating agency ``in the Polish tradition'' and not just a carbon copy of the SEC. They have been studying not only U.S. markets but those in Canada, Spain, Italy, France and other countries because ``we need to follow ... the international standard,'' said Paga. He said the pre-war Warsaw stock exchange was comparable to other stock markets in the 1930s, but necessary regulatory legislation was all but demolished ``during the Stalinist period.'' Jedrzejczak said new growth in Polish securities trading would rely on the speed of privatization which, in turn, would ``depend on political decisions, at least partly. But we expect within two years from now there will be about 100 companies which will be traded on the stock exchange.''

DOC.HEAD: France's LVMH Moves to Increase Guinness Stake
DOC.TEXT: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, a French liquor and luxury products group, on Thursday moved to increase its stake in Guinness PLC to 24 percent, in line with the British liquor company's stake in LVMH. LVMH said it didn't intend to increase its holding beyond that level, and that the move was part of an agreement reached with Guinness in 1988 to hold equal stakes in each other. Guinness said it welcomed the move. LVMH makes Moet champagne, Hennessy cognac, Louis Vuitton luggage and perfumes. Guinness, a brewer, also makes Johnnie Walker Scotch whisky and Gordon's gin. The companies have said the cross-holdings underscore their commercial cooperation. LVMH said it was lifting its Guinness stake to 24 percent by offering to buy 6.8 percent of Guinness through a tender offer. LVMH was offering to pay as much as $13.86 a share for up to 59.4 million Guinness shares. LVMH's current holdings include 42.8 million shares which the company acquired Thursday. These purchases plus the tender offer will cost a total of about $1.4 billion, LVMH said. Guinness shares stood at $12.80 on London's Stock Exchange Thursday morning, up from $12.47 at Wednesday's close. Guinness gradually acquired its 24 percent stake in the French group over the past two years. LVMH's statement that it doesn't intend to raise it fairly compatible companies,'' Davidson said. Last year Guinness had after-tax profit of $793 million on sales of $5.2 billion. LVMH said its profit and sales figures were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer's Lien Unzips Jeans War Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Guess? Inc. is cq; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Feuding family owners of two designer blue jeans companies settled a multimillion-dollar dispute, but hours later a row developed among the lawyers. A lawyer for Guess? Inc., which settled a legal battle with Jordache as jurors were deliberating Wednesday, jeopardized the deal by seeking a $17.7 million lien on the settlement, another Guess lawyer contended. Marshall Grossman, who represented Guess during the trial, filed the notice for a lien to make sure he would get his salary bonus, said Pierce O'Donnell, who represented Guess in the settlement negotiations. ``It's a very treacherous act to have a lawyer turn on his client,'' said O'Donnell, who described the Guess clients as ``outraged.'' A lien is a claim on another person's property as security for the payment of a debt. Grossman would not comment on whether a lien notice had been filed, citing attorney-client confidentiality. But he asserted: ``The settlement is in no jeopardy whatsoever.'' The family feud involved four French-born Marciano brothers, Maurice, Armand, Paul and Georges, who founded Guess in 1981, and three Israeli-born Nakash brothers, Joe, Ralph and Avi, who own Jordache and purchased a half-interest in Guess in 1983. The partnership disintegrated in allegations of fraud and double-dealing, which led to two separate trials to resolve the claims. The Marcianos contended the Nakashes intended to steal for Jordache the Guess designs that were making a splash in the fashion world. In ensuing years, Guess soared to the top of the lucrative designer jean market. Over the past four years, Guess profits have averaged $45 million a year. The settlement filed in Los Angeles Superior Court rescinds the sale of Guess stock by the Marcianos to the Nakashes. The Nakashes agreed to return the half-interest in Guess, which they bought for just under $5 million. The Marcianos won an earlier court fight in which a jury determined the Nakashes had defrauded the Marcianos when they purchased the interest in the then-fledgling company. The terms for division of some $106 million held in an escrow account were not revealed. The agreement also included restraining orders forbidding either Guess or Jordache to spy on the other company through electronic surveillance, telephone wiretaps or other means. O'Donnell said the Nakashes' attorney, Howard Weitzman, was ``shocked and very concerned'' about the lien notice. A call to Weitzman's office after business hours Wednesday was not answered. Before the lien was filed, Weitzman said he had been trying to settle the case for nearly a year along with about a dozen other related cases pending in civil and federal courts in Los Angeles, New York and Hong Kong.

The stock market was narrowly mixed today, bogging down after another advance Wednesday to a record high. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 2.14 to 2,876.42 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers held a slim edge on losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 475 up, 459 down and 539 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.22 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market's steady rise to new highs in recent days had stirred up considerable enthusiasm for stocks. But traders apparently adopted a cautious approach today while they awaited Friday's report from the Labor Department on employmentin May. The data are expected to be skewed by the temporary effects of government hiring of census workers. Even after that is factored out, many observers are uncertain whether the figures will lend any fresh conviction to recent hopes for lower interest rates. Elsewhere, evidence of a weak showing by the economy in April continued to accumulate. The Commerce Department this morning reported a 2.3 percent drop in new factory orders. Tyco Toys climbed 3{ to 28[ in the over-the-counter market. The company said it had received takeover inquiries from a party it didn't identify. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .05 to 196.70. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was unchanged at 362.91. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.07 to a record 2,878.56. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by 8 to 7 on the NYSE with 802 up, 701 down and 508 unchanged. Big Board volume reached 199.54 million shares, up from 137.41 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: `Mad Cow Disease' Provokes Cross-Channel Dispute
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: France today rejected a European Community demand to lift a ban on imports of British beef and cattle, saying it would await a report from veterinarians sent to assess the so-called ``mad cow'' disease. British officials were infuriated when France imposed the temporary ban Wednesday on the ground that the beef may be tainted by bovine spongiform encephalitis, a nervous disorder. Britain accused France of using the disease as an excuse to protect its domestic market. France is Britain's biggest market for beef and cattle. ``They ought to lift that ban straightaway,'' said Francis Maud, British minister of state in the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. ``British beef is perfectly safe. All the scientific evidence points in that direction. This French ban is unjustified and clearly in breach of Community Law, and as good Europeans we find that intolerable.'' The disease, which so far has killed 13,648 cows in Britain, eats holes in the brains of infected cattle, leaving tissue spongy. The British government says there is no indication the disease can be transmitted to humans. Nevertheless, beef sales have declined sharply in Britain. The European Community Commission, in a statement today, said it ``regrets ... the action of the French authorities, taken without prior consultation.'' ``In the absence of convincing arguments for this action, the commission calls upon France to revoke the ban immediately,'' the statement said. It said the EC has taken all necessary health precautions regarding the disease. EC Agricultural Commissioner Ray McSharry, in Paris for the annual ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, said there was ``absolutely no justification'' for France's action. Aides to French Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said the ban would remain in effect pending the return by this weekend of French veterinarians sent to Britain to investigate the disease. The concern of the ministry, Nallet's office said, is ``to guarantee the health of French consumers and cattle.'' The cause of the disease is not known. Because the symptoms are similar to scrapie, a sheep disease, it is assumed that the disease was transmitted through cattle feeds which use sheep offal as a protein supplement. The British government has allocated $19 million this year for research into the disease, which was identified in Britain in 1986. The outbreak has largely been confined there, although a few cases have been confirmed in the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Belzbergs Sell Stake In Armstrong
DOC.TEXT: The Belzberg family of Canada has abandoned its bid to acquire Armstrong World Industries, ending a feud that prompted the enactment of the nation's toughest anti-takeover law. First City Capital Corp., a Belzberg entity, said Wednesday it had sold its 4.8 million shares in Armstrong, a flooring-products and furnishings manufacturer with $2.5 billion in annual gross revenues. Armstrong purchased 3.7 million of the shares and its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 4 million shares, said company spokesman John Scheldrup. He said the shares were bought at $35.75 per share. The move comes about a month after the Belzbergs failed to seat three of four nominees on the Armstrong board and the state enacted legislation that requires corporate raiders to surrender short-term profits from thwarted takeover bids. First City spokeswoman Dezanne Philips acknowledged the stringent takeover law and the largely unsuccessful proxy fight played a role in the decision. The anti-takeover legislation was drafted last year after the Belzbergs first disclosed an interest in acquiring the company. Its introduction triggered a nationwide debate between investor groups and state labor and business interests. The Belzbergs mounted an aggressive lobbying effort to defeat the bill in the Pennsylvania Legislature, claiming it would protect ineffective management and strip stockholders of traditional rights. But the bill was approved by wide margins. In addition to garnishing profits in failed takeover bids, the law also restricts the voting rights of raiders and preserves labor contracts when corporations change hands.

DOC.HEAD: Dow 3,000 Looms Closer on Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with early trading; picks up 5th graf, As always.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: With the return of bull-market enthusiasm that has carried stock prices to new highs in the past few weeks, Wall Street is setting its sights on a lofty target _ the 3,000 level in the Dow Jones industrial average. Should the market keep rising the way it has all through May, analysts point out, that once-distant objective could be reached in very short order. In less than five weeks from April 27 through the close on Wednesday, the ``Dow'' _ the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices _ surged up 233.51 points, or 8.8 percent. From Wednesday's record reading of 2,878.56, it needed only a 4.2 percent advance to reach 3,000. And in today's early trading, the Dow edged even closer, rising 4.98 to 2,883.54 by 11 a.m. As always when the Dow approaches a round-number milestone, many professional traders and money managers in the financial world are inclined to downplay its significance. For all its renown, the average comprises only a small sampling of 30 big-name stocks that do not necessarily mirror what is happening to the shares of hundreds of other substantial companies. Still, analysts generally acknowledge that a Dow reading of 3,000 could be widely read as a signal that the bull market of the 1980s had survived a series of scandals, the crash of 1987 and a recession in the securities business itself to persist into the 1990s. ``I think it is a big psychological target,'' said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall-Twenty-First Advisers Inc. A move to 3,000 in the Dow any time soon would come less than 3{ years after the average first broke 2,000, in January 1987. That kind of advancing pace has few parallels in the history of the century-old average. It first touched 1,000 in 1966, during some of the headiest days of a ``go-go'' era of enthusiasm for stocks that faltered badly in the bear markets of 1969-70 and 1973-74. It took more than 16 years, until early 1983, for the Dow to break decisively above 1,000 and start moving steadily higher. But as impressive as its recent exploits may look, they have left a good many veteran analysts unawed. For one thing, these observers note, a tripling of the Dow since the '60s still leaves it struggling to keep up with inflation over the same span. There is plenty of skepticism as well about the prospective significance of a 3,000 Dow for the economy as a whole. The doubts arise partly from the stock market's penchant during much of the 1980s, and again more recently, for staging its strongest advances during periods of sluggish economic growth. Whenever business activity has picked up momentum in recent years, stock prices generally have bogged down amid fears of increasing inflationary pressures and higher interest rates. True to form, the latest market gains have come on evidence of slackening growth, which has been accompanied by a dropoff in inflationary expectations and a decline in interest rates. As long as stock traders think this way, some analysts contend, they are in danger of being caught napping should a recession hit. S. Jay Levy and David A. Levy, economists in Chappaqua, N.Y., argue that the markets reflect ``wishful thinking about a continuing expansion of the economy. ``The weaknesses of the economy that were reported this month may be the prelude to, or even the beginning of, a recession,'' the Levys contend. ``The chances of avoiding a downturn this year are only two in five.'' But Edward Yardeni, economist at the brokerage firm of Prudential-Bache Securities, maintains that overall growth can continue while ``rolling recessions'' run their course in individual sectors of the economy. Stocks also stand to benefit, Yardeni says, from a long-term downtrend in interest rates and the profit gains American companies can reap in the changing political worlds of Europe and Asia. His forecast for the Dow Jones industrial average: 5,000 by the end of 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasts of More Rain Push Grains, Soybean Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures opened mostly higher this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market continues to be weather driven, as the latest National Weather Service six-to-10-day forecast calls for continued wet conditions in the Midwest, said Victor Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Corn futures opened lower but were staging a comeback largely due to the same factors that were helping soybeans. Wheat was getting a boost from concerns the harvest of red winter wheat could be delayed by wet conditions. DOC.HEAD: Third Chrysler Resignation Will Stir Investors, Analyst Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Greenwald, the... to include amount of buyout proposal; INSERTS 3 new grafs after 10th graf pvs, Greenwald, vice...to UPDATE with UAL stock higher, further background on buyout attempts. Picks up 11th graf, After the...
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald's resignation, announced at a time when the automaker is scaling back and struggling to regain lost market share, is troubling to the company and investors alike, analysts say. Greenwald, the apparent successor to Chairman Lee Iacocca, said Wednesday he was resigning to head United Air Lines employees' $4.38 billion proposal to buy the carrier. He became the third top Chrysler executive to quit this month. Iacocca, 65, whose contract expires at the end of 1991, said when Greenwald was named vice chairman in November 1988 that the chairmanship was his to lose. But Greenwald, 54, flew earlier this week to Iacocca's villa in central Italy to discuss his plans with his longtime boss, a company spokesman said. ``Lee made a major effort to try and change his mind,'' an unidentified company source told The Detroit News. But Iacocca and Greenwald returned Wednesday to Detroit to make the announcement. ``It has to disturb investors that ... the person who has been designated as the next chairman of Chrysler would leave Chrysler just a few days after the Chrysler treasurer announced his resignation,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco. ``Not only will investors be disturbed by the management succession, they will wonder what these managers know about Chrysler that we don't know,'' Glantz said. Greenwald's resignation, effective immediately, follows those of Michael Hammes, who was vice president of international operations, and Chrysler Treasurer and Vice President Fred Zuckerman. Chrysler also has seen its market share slide and its earnings dive. The automaker reported a 80 percent drop in earnings during the first quarter of this year. It made $71 million during the period, or 32 cents a share, compared with $351 million, or $1.50 a share in the first quarter of 1989. Its U.S. market share for cars and light trucks fell from 14.1 percent at the end of April 1989 to 12.4 percent at the end of April 1990, and an austerity program launched last October will slice $1.5 billion from Chrysler's $426 billion annual budget by 1991. Greenwald, vice chairman since November 1988, will become chief executive officer of the Chicago-based United Employees Acquisition Corp., an entity formed by the airline's three major unions to handle the buyout efforts. UAL stock was up $4.75 a share to $155.62{ in mid-day trading on news of Greenwald's move. United's pilots union led an ill-fated $6.75 billion plan to acquire the airline last year. The proposal collapsed after the union and its partners, which included senior management and British Airways PLC, were unable to get bank financing for the deal, sparking a stock market panic. After the acquisition, Greenwald, 54, will become chairman and chief executive officer of UAL Corp. and United Airlines, its chief subsidiary, the employee group said in a statement. Glantz added that Greenwald is putting himself in position to cash in on the buyout. ``He's paid about $1 million a year (at Chrysler) ... but his Chrysler stock options are worthless,'' Glantz said. ``In a leveraged buyout that works, you can make tens of millions of dollars, maybe even hundreds of millions of dollars.'' Chrysler spokesman Steve Harris said there has been no decison on who will replace Greenwald, but Glantz said the logical successor is Robert S. Miller Jr., 49, now Chrysler's chief financial officer. United Auto Workers union vice president Stan Marshall, who leads the union's Chrysler department, speculated that Robert A. Lutz, president of the automaker's Chrysler Motors Corp. subsidiary, also will have a shot at filling Greenwald's shoes. ``He's been the one out there pushing the cars while Greenwald held back on putting cars on the market,'' Marshall said. Harris said the recent resignations were unrelated to each other or to the company's belt tightening. ``This really shows the depth of Chrysler's management,'' Harris said from the company's Highland Park headquarters. ``There are some very talented people here. They are sought after.'' Hammes left May 17 to become an executive vice president for Black & Decker Corp. and vice president of Black & Decker's power tool group, Harris said. Zuckerman said he resigned, effective this summer, to look elsewhere for a position in ``corporate restructuring or other senior financial officer activities.'' Greenwald worked with Iacocca at Ford Motor Co. and followed him to Chrysler in 1979. He played major roles in securing federal government loans that saved Chrysler from bankruptcy in 1979, and in negotiating the purchase of American Motors Corp. in 1987. ``I can understand Jerry's interest in an opportunity like the one United Air Lines presents today,'' Iacocca said. ``He is a major management talent, and he'll have a chance to show it.'' Greenwald said the difficult part about resigning from Chrysler will be leaving Iacocca and other Chrysler executives. ``Looking back, the most gratifying period for me were those uncertain years,'' he said. ``I've been offered an opportunity to lead another great company during a period of major transition, and it's an opportunity I can't turn down.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Backs Residents of Ashland Oil Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Ashland Oil Inc. was ordered to pay $10.3 million to four neighbors of its Catlettsburg, Ky., refinery who said emissions from the plant hurt their health and damaged their property. Residents of Ceredo and Kenova, W.Va., and Catlettsburg, Ky., sued in state court after finding a caustic white substance on their cars and homes. The substance was not easily removed and damaged their property, they alleged. ``The verdict recognizes the magnitude of the problem that people have been living with for a number of years,'' attorney D.L. Hamilton said Wednesday. ``I hope Ashland Oil got the message.'' The exact nature of the caustic substance was not established at the trial. More than 270 Kenova-area residents have suits pending against Ashland for a total of more than $840 million. Wednesday's verdict should force Ashland Oil to re-evaluate whether to settle out of court, Hamilton said. ``My answer to that is that we're going to appeal this case,'' said Dan Lacy, an Ashland Oil spokesman. The company's appeal to the state Supreme Court will target Judge Tod Kaufman's decision to block former Environmental Protection Agency administrator Lee Thomas from testifying, Lacy said. Thomas was to testify about air quality standards, Lacy said. Kaufman said Thomas' testimony would have been confusing to the jury and that Thomas was not qualified as a technical expert on air quality standards. The court also refused to allow testimony on the company's air monitors. ``Had we been able to bring that information to the jury, we honestly believe the jury's verdict would be different,'' Lacy said. Ashland Oil attorneys argued residents had no evidence of illness or property damage, such as medical expenses or repair bills. Ashland Oil, Kentucky's largest corporation, had 1989 revenues of $8.46 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Paris Or London: MCA Ponders Site For A Rival To Eurodisneyland
DOC.TEXT: Senior executives from MCA Inc., the U.S. entertainment giant, conferred Thursday with Premier Michel Rocard about the proposed construction of a movie-oriented theme park and studio complex near Paris to compete with Walt Disney Co.'s Euro Disneyland. The MCA delegation, headed by President Sidney J. Sheinberg, is considering both Paris and London as possible sites for the $1.2 billion project, trying to determine which location offers better financial opportunities. Rocard, according to his office, told the visitors he was amenable to the proposal provided that MCA addressed environmental concerns and cooperated fully with the French TV and film industry. MCA's final decision is expected within the next few months, and the complex is tentatively scheduled to be opened in 1993. The proposed site in France is Melun-Senart, a new suburb being developed about 20 miles southeast of Paris. The complex would include a golf course, hotels with 5,000 rooms, a high-tech industrial park oriented toward the audiovisual industry, production studios and an amusement park. MCA, which is based in Universal City, Calif., has projected 5 million visitors to the park in its first year, and estimates the complex would create 12,000 jobs. About 20 miles north of the site, foundations are being laid for Euro Disneyland, an even bigger project, scheduled for opening in 1992. Disney executives anticipate 11 million visitors in the first year, and have estimated the total cost of the undertaking at $7.6 billion. British officials have been trying to woo MCA with a 1,600-acre site on the outskirts of London. Their hopes are based in part on the premise that the company might shy away from direct competition with Euro Disneyland. There is evidence, however, that MCA won't back away. It has decided to compete head to head with Disney World in Orlando, Fla., by opening Universal Studios Florida nearby. The Times of London reported recently that several British officials travelled to Hollywood to lobby on behalf of the London site.

DOC.HEAD: American Home Names Canavan President
DOC.TEXT: American Home Products Corp. said Thursday its top health care products executive, Bernard Canavan, has been elected as its president. Canavan, 54, succeeds John R. Stafford as president. Stafford, 52, had been president since 1982 and remains chairman and chief executive. Among American Home's most recognizable brand names are Woolite detergent and Easy-Off oven cleaner. Canavan is a physician who has been with American Home Products since 1969. He was elected to the board in January and put in charge of nearly all the company's health care operations, American Home said. Late last year, American Home bought A.H. Robins Co., which makes Robitussin cough syrup and Chap Stick lip balm, for $3.2 billion. In April, American Home agreed to sell its household products business to Reckitt & Coleman PLC, for $1.25 billion. ``It is most appropriate that as the company has become more concentrated in the areas of Ben Canavan's expertise, that he take on a greater role in the management of all our operations,'' Stafford said. He added that health care represents more than 85 percent of the company's sales. In his new job, Canavan will oversee drug and medical supply and devices as well as food and household products. Stafford will continue to oversee financial and administrative functions, industrial relations and the general counsel.

DOC.HEAD: EC Says U.S. Farm Subsidy Demands Are Politically Impossible
DOC.TEXT: American demands that the European Community slash its export subsidies to farmers would be ``politically impossible'' to meet, a trade bloc official said Thursday. But other officials warned that the community's refusal to budge was threatening the outcome of ambitious plans to overhaul the world trading system. U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said the fight over subsidies that broke out at the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development was ``a disagreement that was waiting to happen.'' But, Brady told a breakfast meeting of reporters, it ``is best that we face the differences in the free world openly and with some energy now rather than wait until the last minute.'' At issue is an American demand that the 12-nation European Community do much more to slash its costly subsidies to farmers, which the United States claims hinder trade. The Europeans so far have refused. Ray MacSharry, the community's agriculture chief, said the trading bloc could not eliminate its export subsidy program. ``That is politically impossible and will not happen,'' he said. ``We're best to get involved in serious negotiations about making progress ... for greater liberalization of trade.'' He said eliminating the subsidies would mean higher farm prices in Europe and unemployment for millions of farmers. The community gives exporters help so more expensive European farm products can compete with lower prices on the world market. The deadlock has stalled the Uruguay Round negotiations, a four-year effort to overhaul the world trading system. Australian Foreign Affairs Minister Gareth Evans said the European position was ``simply not a tenable long-term position.'' ``They will be putting at risk not just agriculture but the whole round (of trade negotiations) if they stick to a position as tight as that,'' he said. The talks, involving some 100 nations, are designed to reduce barriers to trade in 15 areas, including agriculture and textiles. The bargaining opened in 1986 and is due to end in December. It is being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and agreement for promoting freer trade. Trade and finance officials of 24 industrialized nations ended the OECD meeting by agreeing ``to take urgent steps to reform agricultural policy, as regards support and protection, so as to permit greater liberalization of trade.'' But their final statement reflected the differences between the United States and the community over how to do that. The statement said some nations wanted the others to pledge to make changes in the areas of internal support, barriers to market access and export subsidies. U.S. officials had pressed for that wording. In addition to resisting elimination of export subsidies, the Common Market has refused the U.S. demands that it open its markets wider to foreign farm products and cut farm payments that encourage crop surpluses. The EC has urged a more general approach, such as finding a way to measure a country's trade performance in agriculture and then work to reduce that level. The United States and other countries have insisted the farm issue is crucial to a successful outcome of the overall trade talks. In their final statement, the ministers promised ``to make every effort to overcome the differences'' by a July 23 negotiating session in Geneva. By then, the United States wants preliminary agreements or negotiating texts in all 15 areas under discussion. OECD members are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on 52-Week Treasury Bills Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills fell in Thursday's action to the lowest level in more than three months. The Treasury Department sold $10 billion of the bills at an average discount rate of 7.65 percent, down from 8.05 percent at the last auction on May 3. The rates were the lowest since Feb. 13, when the one-year bills sold for 7.42 percent. The new discount rate understates the actual return to investors _ 8.24 percent with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,226.50.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Bringing Back Movie Theater Newsreels
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network is reviving the movie theater newsreel, but some film experts doubt the cinema CNN will be a hit among audiences who already have expressed disdain for advertising on the silver screen. CNN is hoping that reviving the newsreel, a relic from cinema's pre-television golden age, will help promote the round-the-clock cable TV network that is available to 54.4 million subscribers. The two-minute film segments, called ``CNN Reel News,'' make their debut Friday in a New York theater chain. If successful during a 90-day trial period, CNN officials say they will expand the program nationwide. ``This is a way to inform and to, most importantly, entertain. And it's another way of getting CNN's image out,'' said Rick Salcedo, vice president of news promotion at Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which owns CNN. Ironically, television hastened the demise of movie theater newsreels. The most famous of them, Fox-Movietone News, ended production in 1963, when TV's comprehensive news coverage made the novelty of seeing faraway events on the big screen obsolete. ``Television was probably the major factor'' in the demise of newsreels, said Glenn Smith, who maintains the Fox-Movietone archives at the University of South Carolina. Smith said he is skeptical about whether today's audiences want or need to see news stories at the movies. ``My personal opinion is, you better have a very novel approach to it,'' he said. CNN's newsreels, which will be shown before feature films and rotated biweekly, will tend to the lighter side of the news. Salcedo said he figures audiences have plenty of opportunity to see the big stories before they get to the theater. ``It's got to be something that doesn't have such a short shelf life,'' Salcedo said. ``It's more of the lighter stuff, more of the entertaining, informative type of information as opposed to the hard news.'' The newsreels include items plucked from CNN's regular programming as well as stories that never made it to TV. A sample newsreel shown to a reporter included 30-second segments on elephant seals, frozen smoke experiments, an electronic movie ticket seller and oatmeal wrestling. The opening and closing credits include vintage black and white images, which turn into a color picture of a space shuttle. Those segments, which were still in production Thursday, will prominently feature the CNN logo, according to Salcedo. It borders on advertising, and that could mean trouble. Saying moviegoers don't like commercials, Walt Disney Studios and Warner Bros. have banned on-screen ads at theaters showing their films. Salcedo said the newsreels would not be shown before Disney films, but he was unsure about Warner Bros. Jack Boozer, an assistant professor of communications at Georgia State University who specializes in movies, said it's difficult to predict how audiences will react to the CNN newsreels. ``I don't think it will be resented as much as the advertising, which is just blatant,'' Boozer said. ``I don't think it's a viable idea unless it is `large picture' type of stories. Straight news, talking heads won't work.'' TBS has sunk about $100,000 into producing ``Reel News'' but is not paying the 11-theater City Cinemas chain in New York to show it during the trial period, Salcedo said. He said TBS will seek a corporate sponsor before going national with the project. Although Turner owns a six-screen movie theater in Atlanta, Salcedo said it was thought that a more objective appraisal of the newsreels could be obtained in New York. ``You get a much more critical audience up there,'' he said. ``If they start throwing things at the screen, it might tell us something.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Won't Expand Medfly Quarantine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS style on Medfly, sted medfly, throughout. ADDS reference to Mediterranean fruit fly in 2nd graf. CORRECTS spelling of Bernardino sted Bernadino in last graf. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department has no immediate plans to expand a Southern California quarantine ordered to combat a Medfly outbreak, a USDA spokesman said Thursday. The Mediterranean fruit fly attacks more than 200 varieties of fruits and vegetables and citrus is especially vulnerable, with losses of 25 percent to 50 percent of production likely in cases of severe infestation. ``We feel our quarantine procedure and the area that is quarantined are adequate at this point to prevent the spread of Medflies,'' said spokesman Larry Mark. He said the decision was made Wednesday after the National Plant Board Advisory Council, meeting here, recommended no change for at least 30 days. Florida Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner last week urged the department to order the entire state of California under quarantine to fight the Medfly, one of the world's most destructive pests. The worst outbreak was a decade ago in the area south of San Francisco. USDA enlarged the quarantine area May 8 to include parts of Los Angeles, Orange, San Bernardino and Riverside counties. A Medfly quarantine also is in effect for part of the Miami Springs-Hialeah area of south Florida.

DOC.HEAD: House-Hunting Season: A Hard Sell In Soft Markets
Graphics in AP Access under MORTGAGE AND REALESTATE
DOC.TEXT: To entice buyers for their one-bedroom Boston condo, Kenneth and Cheryl Bell are prepared to offer just about anything from low-cost financing to the (newly renovated) kitchen sink. In Culver City, Calif., Bruce Preston is a bit more relaxed. He expects to sell his three-bedroom stucco colonial about $20,000 below the asking price within a month. But he laments, ``If this was a year and a half ago, it would have taken a week.'' The Bells and Preston live on opposite coasts but are coping with a housing malaise that's sweeping much of the country, a reflection of higher interest rates, tougher mortgage lenders and troubled regional economies. Experts say it's difficult to generalize about something as varied and vast as the American real estate market, where one home sits unsold for months while another might get snapped up quickly. Nonetheless, a random sampling of sellers nationwide suggests more sob stories and fewer successes. ``There are a great many markets doing well and a significant number that are pretty flat. Unfortunately, the flat markets are where most people live,'' said John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, a professional trade group of property brokers that tracks housing trends. Real estate hot spots this year include the Pacific Northwest and portions of the Midwest and the South, experts say. The cooler spots, which represent some good buying opportunites, are largely in the Northeast and Southwest. ``I call it democratization,'' said Robert Van Order, chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Co., a federally chartered company that buys mortgages. ``The Northeast had it good for several years. Now it's slowing down. The Midwest and Southwest are coming back. I think the West will always be good.'' Even so, the ``good'' markets like California aren't immune to sluggishness. Preston, a 30-year-old social worker selling his three-bedroom Culver City house, said he recently lowered the asking price about 2 percent to $299,000. That would have been unheard of a year and a half ago. He expects it to sell for around $290,000. The biggest losers, though, have been those who bought when prices were at their peak and are now trying to sell into softened demand. Some sellers, particularly in the Northeast, have resorted to desperate gimmicks ranging from higher broker commissions to free trips to Disney World. Others have turned to the auction block, once a forum for bankrupt farmers and professional business liquidators. Jim Gall, president of Auction Co. of America in Miami, said he expects auctions in single-family homes to quadruple this year to around $100 million. The Bells of Boston are good examples of eager sellers. Their first step was to make the price attractive: $78,000 for the condo they bought three years ago for $80,000, even though they renovated the kitchen and bathroom. While ads for the condo highlight those improvements, they also promise ``owner will help,'' a rarity just three years ago when prices were higher. Bell, a 27-year-old laborer, said he and his wife were willing to aid potential buyers in obtaining financing or even loan the closing costs. The Bells need more space for a growing family. Feeling more pressured is Andres Deleon, a 26-year-old businessman relocating to Venezuela. Deleon is hoping buyers will be attracted to the cut-rate price on his two-bedroom condo a few neighborhoods away from the Bells. He's asking $79,000, about 20 percent below what he paid four years ago. Underlying the real estate problem has been high mortgage rates. They crept toward 11 percent in March after falling into the single digits earlier this year. Rates on conventional 30-year mortgages now average between 10.25 percent and 10.5 percent, but some economists say they could edge up again soon. ``The rates are what's killing me,'' said George Mojica, a 64-year-old retired maintenance supervisor, who wants to sell his Baldwin, N.Y., house and move to Florida. ``Once interest rates go down, there will probably be more activity.'' The runup in rates has caused single-family home sales and housing starts to fall to the lowest levels since the 1982 recession. In April, the last month for which data is available, new home sales fell 1.6 percent, the fifth straight monthly drop, to a nearly 7{-year low, government data show. The National Association of Realtors said April sales of existing homes fell 2.1 percent. Starts for houses and apartments fell 5.8 percent that month, the third consecutive monthly decline, to the lowest rate since October 1982. For single-family homes alone the decline was 7{ percent. Mortgage volume, a barometer of housing industry health, totaled $390 billion in 1989, 16 percent lower than four years earlier. The Mortgage Bankers Association of America estimates it will fall to $380 billion this year. A more informative picture of lending emerges in regional looks at mortgage activity, which reflect the health of the local economies. For instance, Stephen Ashley, president of Silbey Corp. of Rochester, N.Y., a mortgage lender in the troubled Northeast, said applications were off between 10 percent and 15 percent in the first four months of this year. By contrast, Ronnie J. Wynn, president of Colonial Mortgage Co. in Montgomery, Ala., said business is booming, with volume during the same period up to $85 million from $25 million. Wynn said the gain reflects the company's decision to move into healthier regions, such as Atlanta and Houston, and out of depressed areas. Many lenders stress that even in areas where the housing market is sluggish, slightly higher interest rates don't mean they aren't willing to loan mortgage money. ``The residential homebuyer still has plenty of credit availble,'' Ashley said. ``It's still within the realm of what we could determine to be affordable.'' Nonetheless, homebuyers still face more restrictions than they did a few years ago. For example, most banks are asking for higher downpayments, generally at least 10 percent of the price of a home. They're also abandoning some gimmicks once used to lure borrowers, such as ``no-doc'' or ``low-doc'' loans, in which they approved some loans without verifying an applicant's income or employment. ``I think we're basically back to basics a little bit more,'' said Ashley. In addition, lenders have been monitoring business conditions more closely, wary of plunging into areas where job layoffs or cyclical industries such as automaking or defense work could affect a homeowner's financial health. ``Now I think lenders are trying to be more predicting in terms of where the local economies are going and how the housing markets are doing,'' said Fred Koons, chairman of Chase Home Mortgage Corp. in Tampa, Fla. ``They adjust credit to reflect those forecasts.'' Chase, for instance, is looking at home appraisals more carefully, Koons said. ``You're reliance on appraisal is high particularly if markets are not inflationary,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Housing Market
DOC.TEXT: An increasing number of homeowners, frustrated by softness in the housing market and escalating moving expenses, have been turning to alternate methods of selling their property. Some opt for a discount broker or real estate counselor. Some choose to handle everything themselves to save commission costs. Others offer inducements to buyers that range from owner financing to paid vacations. For those do-it-yourself homesellers here are some tips offered by J.R. Paine, author of the ``The 30 Day Way to Sell Your Home.'' _Make a checklist of all critical areas of your home, eyeing areas that need repair. _Dress up your home. Avoid giving prospective buyers the impression you don't like where you live or think the home is less valuable than your asking price. _Have a reliable appraiser assess your home's true value. _Select the best time to go on the market. In northern climates, the most popular season is in the warmer months; in southern areas, colder weather is best. _Get a ``For Sale'' sign. _Select a real estate attorney. _Select a title company to do your title work. _Obtain current interest rates from a local bank. _Emphasizes money appeal in advertisements with words like ``economical,'' ``bargain'' or ``value''; or ego appeal, with words like ``elegant,'' ``graceful'' or ``fashionable.'' Use ``low traffic street'' instead of ``dirt road,'' and describe a rundown house as a ``handyman's dream.''
