DOC.HEAD: Rose $128.3 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 502 money market mutual funds rose $128.3 million to $381.54 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $94.7 million increase in fund assets the previous week, the Washington-based mutual fund trade group said. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 239 general purpose funds fell $231.2 million to $129.25 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds increased $481.4 million to $159.62 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds declined $121.9 million to $92.68 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds was 7.68 percent in the week ended Tuesday, unchanged from the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield held at 7.68 percent, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, down from 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.20 percent as of Wednesday from 6.21 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.06 percent from 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.96 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 8.16 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.17 percent; 8.18 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.19 percent; and 8.24 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced Thursday against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart amid buying ahead of a key U.S. economic report due Friday. Nervousness about various world matters also encouraged currency dealers to buy dollars. Gold prices gained slightly in the United States after weakening abroad. The start of the summit between U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Washington set the market on edge, particularly because a dispute appeared possible over the future role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization after the planned German unification. Tension elsewhere, including in the Middle East, also helped the dollar, traders said. Dollar investments are typically favored in times of uncertainty. A strong undercurrent influencing trade in dollars was speculation in foreign exchange markets that U.S. employment figures for May could indicate economic health. The monthly report, scheduled for release Friday, will furnish the first information of how the economy performed during the month. The British pound tumbled Thursday after remarks by West German Bundesbank President Carl Otto Poehl, who on Wednesday said the time wasn't right for British entry into the European Monetary System. Sterling had been bought aggressively in recent days on the assumption that Britain soon would relent in its opposition to joining the exchange rate mechanism in which many European countries participate. The pound traded in London at $1.6760 compared to $1.6930 late Wednesday. Sterling continued to stumble in U.S. trading. A pound fetched $1.6780 late in New York, down from $1.6950 Wednesday. The dollar's trading day began on a strong note in Tokyo. It closed in the Japanese capital at 151.75 yen, a gain of 1.00 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 152.65 yen. It was quoted at 152.10 yen at the end of New York trading, up from 151.45 yen late Wednesday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6825; 1.4290 Swiss francs, up from 1.42265; 5.724 French francs, up from 5.6735; 1,248.25 Italian lire, up from 1,237.75; and 1.17285 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17675. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with Wednesday's late levels were: 1.6990 West German marks, up from 1.6810; 1.4325 Swiss francs, up from 1.4210; 5.7300 French francs, up from 5.6715; 1.9060 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880; 1,247.00 Italian lire, up from 1,237.25; and 1.1740 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1778. Precious metals prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for June delivery added 20 cents to close at $364.30. But Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $363.70 for a troy ounce of gold bullion, 85 cents lower than Wednesday. Gold prices had declined in earlier European dealing. A troy ounce of the precious metal was quoted at a bid price of $363.75 late Wednesday in London, down from $366.65 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the gold bid was $364.00, down from $366.25 late Wednesday. Silver also had a mixed day. Silver for June delivery rose to $5.074 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $5.047 on Wednesday. In London, silver was quoted at a bid of $5.08 a troy ounce, down from Wednesday's $5.15.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished mixed Thursday, flattening out as traders cashed in some of the gains from the market's recent upsurge to record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 57.64 points Tuesday and Wednesday, slipped back 1.90 to 2,876.66. That still left the average with a 219.90-point gain for May. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 801 up, 682 down and 534 unchanged. Analysts said the market's strong showing of late had stirred up considerable enthusiasm for stocks. But traders apparently adopted a cautious approach Thursday while they awaited Friday's report from the Labor Department on employment in May. The data are expected to be skewed by the temporary effects of government hiring of census workers. Even after that is factored out, many observers are uncertain whether the figures will lend any fresh conviction to recent hopes for lower interest rates. Elsewhere, evidence of weakness in the economy in April continued to accumulate. The Commerce Department this morning reported a 2.3 percent drop in new factory orders. Bond prices rose slightly in the credit markets, lowering yields on long-term Treasuries to the 8.57 percent-8.61 percent range. UAL gained 4| to 155{ on word that Gerald Greenwald was leaving his job as vice chairman of Chrysler Corp. to lead a proposed buyout of UAL's United Airlines. Tonka fell 3 to 7[ in active trading. Late Wednesday the toy manufacturer said it expects to post a sizeable second-quarter loss because of disappointing sales of some of its products. Westinghouse Electric rose 1] to 36]. The company said it plans to buy back as many as 20 million shares of its stock. Losers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, down ] at 42[; International Business Machines, down ~ at 120; General Motors, down | at 48|, and Eastman Kodak, down ~ at 40\. Tyco Toys climbed 3] to 28 in the over-the-counter market. The company said it had received takeover inquiries from a party it didn't identify. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 165.69 million shares, against 199.54 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 199.77 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $3.32 billion, or 0.10 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .19 to 196.94. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose .41 to 422.03, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up .37 at 361.23. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market edged up .20 to 458.97. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 363.06, up .15.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Prices Plunge on API Inventory Figures
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices plunged Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange following the release of figures showing a buildup in crude oil and gasoline stocks. On other markets, grains and soybeans were mostly higher; precious metals futures were mixed, and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower. The release of the American Petroleum Institute's inventory figures Wednesday showed an increase rather than the expected decrease in gasoline and crude oil stocks. The API reported that gasoline inventories as of last Friday increased 1.1 million barrels from the preceeding week to 214.2 million barrels. The nation's inventory of crude oil increased by 2.1 million barrels and distillates, which includes heating oil, by 737,000 barrels. ``The build in crude is particularly ominous,'' said Nauman Barakat, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. ``Crude stocks are at eight-year record highs ... so you've got to give the benefit of a doubt on prices to the down side.'' Adding pressure to energy prices were API figures showing an increase of 492,000 barrels a day in refinery runs. And as refineries return to operation after seasonal maintenance work, output is expected to continue climbing. Barakat said the consensus in the industry is that demand will be flat in coming weeks, which will mean prices will continue to fall. He also noted that there are rumblings that the Saudi Arabian government is growing irate with continued overproduction by members of OPEC. Barakat said the Saudis may eventually overproduce themselves in retaliation. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 2 cents to 68 cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $17.40 a barrel; heating oil was .45 cent to 1.08 cents lower with June at 50.07 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent to 2.98 cents lower with June at 63.89 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade as weather concerns continued to dominate trading activity. Corn futures were pushed lower as a result of selling by professional traders and funds, and a National Weather Service six-to-10-day forecast of more favorable planting weather. Heavy rains in recent weeks have delayed the planting of corn, and a dry spell could allow farmers to catch up, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. Soybean futures were higher on conjecture that the amount of corn acreage given over to soybeans may not be as large as expected, Biedermann said. Because soybeans mature more quickly than corn, farmers usually plant soybeans when corn planting is delayed into June. Soybeans also received a boost on speculation that a planned Brazilian port strike would cause enough shipping delays to shift export business to the United States. Wheat futures opened weak, then surged late in the trading session on news the Peoples Republic of China had bid for 600,000 metric tons of wheat under the export bonus program. Wheat was 4 cents lower to 1{ cents higher with July at $3.33} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with July at $2.78 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with July at $1.44{ a bushel; and soybeans were 1} cents to 3 cents higher with July at $6.07\ a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hog futures were pressured by lower cash prices, while pork bellies were the limit down due to technical trading. The weakness in pork futures spilled over into cattle, which gained some support from active boxed beef sales. Live cattle were .30 cent lower to .18 cent higher with June at 74 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 83.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent lower to 1.30 cents higher with June at 65.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent to 2 cents lower with July at 64.05 cents a pound. Precious metals futures were mixed in sluggish trading on the New York Commodity Exchange. Gold was 20 cents to 70 cents lower with June at $364.30 a troy ounce; silver was 1.8 cents to 2.7 cents higher with July at $5.110 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Greenwald's Departure Further Strains Chrysler
LaserPhoto DT2
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. scrambled to realign its top management Thursday and fill gaps created at a critical time by the resignation of Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald and other executives. Responding to Wednesday's surprise resignation of Greenwald, heir apparent to Chairman Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler named Robert S. Miller, its executive vice president and chief financial officer, as vice chairman. Greenwald, 54, quit the nation's No. 3 automaker to lead a $4.54 billion employee buyout of UAL Corp., parent of United Airlines. Miller, 48, and Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz had been considered likely successors to Greenwald. Lutz, 58, was given slightly expanded responsibilities. Greenwald's resignation was the latest in a series of top-level depatures at Chrysler, which is struggling to halt the erosion of its market share and earnings in the face of a weak U.S. auto market and stiff competition from foreign automakers. Michael Hammes, the company's international operations vice president, quit to head Black & Decker's tool division. Chrysler Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman said he would leave the automaker this summer to pursue other interests. Also, 62-year-old Bennett Bidwell, chairman of Chrysler Motors, has cut his work load. Iacocca had said he would leave more of the day-to-day operation to other executives. But his recent remarks that he may remain as chairman beyond 1991, combined with the rash of top-level departures, have increased speculation that he might increase his role in the company's operations. The talent drain on Chrysler's upper level management began after a similar depletion started late last year when Chrysler adopted a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program to trim white-collar work force by about 2,500 people. ``The (stock) market probably views this as a further indication that the operating problems at Chrysler are really severe and probably increases the potential for Chrysler losing its independence in the future,'' auto analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. said Thursday. Chrysler finished up 25 cents at $15.62{ on Thursday. Chrysler's U.S. market share for cars and light trucks fell to 12.4 percent at the end of April from 14.1 percent a year earlier. The automaker's profit dropped by nearly 80 percent in the first quarter of this year, although analysts said the results would have been worse if not for a company austerity program. ``Chrysler is not in (financial) trouble,'' said Joe Phillippi, an auto industry analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. ``They've got plenty of cash. Clearly they're struggling with (sales) volume. Even with modest profitability, we're looking at cash flows that are still excellent.'' Greenwald, meeting with reporters Thursday, dismissed suggestions that Chrysler was a likely takeover target. ``I don't put much stock in a major partnership or a major merger,'' Greenwald said. Chrysler has close working relationships with the Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors Corp. and the French automaker Renault. Italy's Fiat SpA and Chrysler reportedly have been talking about a sizeable deal. Greenwald said Thursday he began thinking seriously about leaving Chrysler 10 days ago and finally decided to do so Wednesday morning after spending a day and a half with Iacocca. Greenwald, who has been roundly supported by the United Auto Workers union, repeatedly declined Thursday to say whether he felt Iacocca would step down then or seek a new contract with the automaker. Speculation that Iacocca would be active after 1991, whether he officially retires or not, apparently didn't sit well with Greenwald, although he denied being frustrated. ``I think he (Greenwald) recognizes that Lee is probably going to be around for an extended period of time,'' Phillippi said. ``Even if Lee were to become chairman only and Jerry were to become CEO, he's still going to have the old boss looking over his shoulder,'' Phillippi said. ``And that may have bothered him.'' Greenwald said the challenges of financing the UAL buyout _ which would be the largest employee buyout of a U.S. company if it succeeds _ were too good to ignore. ``Here I am having a second chance to go through a major industrial event in American history,'' Greenwald said. Greenwald was a major player in Chrysler's winning of loans and federal loan guarantees to pull the company from the brink of bankruptcy in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

DOC.BYLINE: Court Decision Could Boost Efforts To Block Phone Devices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Janlori'' in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A Pennsylvania state court ruling barring a phone company from installing devices that alert customers to the numbers of incoming calls could provide ammunition to those trying to block the service elsewhere. The Caller ID service has been criticized as an invasion of privacy by foes but praised by supporters as a way to detect unwanted calls and speed the jobs of emergency workers. Pennsylvania's Commonwealth Court ruled Wednesday that Bell of Pennsylvania may not offer the service, on the grounds that it is an invasion of privacy and violates state laws on wiretapping and phone-number tracing. Bell of Pennsylvania said it might appeal to the state Supreme Court. Janlori Goldman, an attorney with the American Civil Liberties Union, said the decision ``changes the nature of the debate'' over Caller ID. Most groups with concerns about the service, such as the ACLU, have said they will not oppose it if the phone companies provide a way for customers to block their numbers from appearing on Caller ID screens when they place calls. But the Pennsylvania court went beyond such concerns in finding that Caller ID as a concept violates state laws, with or without the number-blocking devices. Ms. Goldman said the ruling, by implication, could mean Caller ID services are illegal in other states that have similar wiretap and number-tracing laws. She said the ACLU is pressing for Congress to enact federal legislation regulating Caller ID services. Bills to do so are pending in the House and Senate. Bell of Pennsylvania does not plan to provide blocking devices for most customers, including those with unlisted numbers. Such devices only would be provided to domestic violence shelters and law enforcement agencies. The phone company argues that blocking devices would negate the usefulness of the service by allowing those who abuse the phone system, such as obscene callers, to elude detection. Rochelle Dreyfuss, a law professor at New York University and an expert on privacy law, said the Pennsylvania decision could be used to bolster lawsuits in other states seeking to block or modify Caller ID services. ``It's common for lawyers to argue that `this is what other states have done with this issue,' '' she said. Edward Martone, executive director of the ACLU's New Jersey chapter, said the Pennsylvania decision ``helps us with our arguments here.'' The New Jersey ACLU opposed the Caller ID service that has been offered by New Jersey Bell since late 1988. Both the New Jersey and Pennsylvania phone companies are part of Philadelphia-based Bell Atlantic Corp. The ACLU has no active case against the state or the phone company seeking to block the service, but Martone said it was considering several options to return the issue to public discussion. The office of the New Jersey Public Advocate, which represents consumer interests before state bodies, also opposed Caller ID in hearings before state regulatory agencies. The office said it believed the service was a privacy invasion and that it could harm hotlines and similar services that offer anonymous advice, said Robin Portnoi, the assistant deputy public advocate. New Jersey Bell _ which offers no blocking devices to any customer _ has addressed the concerns of law enforcement agencies and social service groups such as shelters by offering them outgoing phone lines only, Ms. Portnoi said. Shelters fear battered women would be afraid to call their spouses if it would lead to alerting the husbands to their location. When a person called by a shelter or law enforcement agency tries to return the call by using the number that flashed on his Caller ID screen, he either gets a recording saying the number does not accept incoming calls or is transferred to an answering service, under several options provided by New Jersey Bell, said spokesman Peter Ventimiglia. However, Ms. Portnoi said, the state public advocate ``has asked us in light of the Pennsylvania decision to take another look at caller ID in New Jersey.'' Concern over privacy issues sparked California lawmakers to ban the service unless the phone company offers a blocking device. New York regulators took a similar stance when they approved Caller ID on a trial basis in the Rochester area. Caller ID is already available or is about to be introduced in other states, including Maryland, Virginia, Tennessee and West Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Two Money Measures Fall in Latest Reporting Period
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended May 21, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,266.1 billion from a revised $3,266.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,062.9 billion from a revised $4,063.9 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $807.1 billion from a revised $803.1 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.1 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.7 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,267.9 billion, a 4.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,066.0 billion, up 2.0 percent, while M1 rose 5.2 percent to an average of $805.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $1.157 billion, compared with an increase of $943 million a week earlier. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $924 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $327 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $389 million in the two weeks ended May 23, down from a revised $628 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $305.3 billion in the two-week period ended May 30, down from $306.0 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Foundation Investment Chief Taking Harvard Management Helm
DOC.TEXT: Jack R. Meyer, investment chief at the Rockefeller Foundation, was named the new head of the Harvard Management Co., which manages Harvard University's assets and related accounts, the school said Thursday. Meyer, 45, has been treasurer and chief investment officer of the Rockefeller Foundation since 1983, managing its $2.1 billion in assets. He will assume the new post Sept. 1. The Harvard Management Co. was formed in 1974. Its assets include a $5 billion endowment. Meyer succeeds Walter Cabot, founding president of HMC.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Concerns Send Energy Prices Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to include contract month.
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices slumped Thursday as traders, anticipating an oversupply of gasoline and crude oil, sold down their holdings. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline plunged 2.98 cents to 63.89 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The July contract tumbled 2.00 cents, and subsequent months also declined. Gasoline prices were slammed by an American Petroleum Institute report late Wednesday that refineries had sharply increased their output of the fuel, analysts said. Meanwhile, the July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, was down 68 cents to $17.40 a 42-gallon barrel. Later months also settled lower. Peter Beutel, an analyst with at Elders Futures Inc., said traders were concerned that Saudi Arabia would raise its crude output. The publication Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday that Saudi officials were studying oil production by other countries and would decide whether to increase their own output. The Saudis are believed to be angry because their fellow members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are not abiding by new production limits. If the Saudis raise their output, it would worsen the oversupply of crude and knock prices lower. Home heating oil declined in sympathy with other futures prices Thursday. The June contract for heating oil fell 1.08 cents to 50.07 cents a gallon, and later contract months also dropped. Meanwhile, natural gas moved higher. The July contract advanced to $1.590 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.585 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Cat Food Sales Too Late To Save Alpo Head
DOC.TEXT: Five days after taking Alpo Petfoods Inc. off the market, an official of the parent company visited Alpo headquarters and ordered top management to move out. Ian A. Martin, who heads American operations for Grand Metropolitan PLC of Great Britain, Alpo's parent, broke the news Tuesday to Frank Krum, Alpo president and chief executive officer, and Willard H. Cressman, senior vice president of finance. Alpo's 1,500 employees were informed later that day that Krum, 56, was being replaced by Rob Hawthorne, 45, previously president and chief executive officer of Pillsbury Canada, also part of Grand Metropolitan. Industry analysts Wednesday attributed the move to the expensive promotional campaign to introduce Alpo's new cat food. Krum will serve as a special adviser to Martin on trade and industry relations. Cressman has elected not to stay with the company, a Grand Met spokeswoman said. Krum, Cressman and Hawthorne were unavailable for comment. The 54-year-old pet food company was put up for sale Feb. 8, when Grand Met Chairman Allen Sheppard decided it didn't fit into the conglomerate's plans to focus on its human foods business. Alpo spent $70 million in promotions and advertising for the introduction of its cat food this year, including the use of the cartoon character Garfield. Alpo, the sixth-largest pet-food maker in the United States, now holds 9 percent of the $1.3 billion canned cat food market and 5 percent of the $1.1 billion dry cat food market, analysts said. Alpo, which earned $45 million in 1989 on sales of about $400 million, expects cat food sales to top $100 million in 1990. Because of the rapid growth of its cat food sales, Alpo was pulled off the market May 24. Martin said Grand Met and potential buyers were ``not able to reach agreement as to the value of Alpo's recently launched cat food business.''

DOC.HEAD: Move By Greenwald to UAL Buyout Group Gets Cautious Thumbs Up On Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, Wall Street ... to show closing stock price. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, But the ... SUBS 7th graf, After a ... to show takeover would have to be successful for appointment to take effect.
DOC.TEXT: Employees seeking to buy UAL Corp. for $4.54 billion did well in landing Chrysler Corp.'s Gerald Greenwald to head the effort, but still need a top executive with airline industry experience, analysts said Thursday. Wall Street quickly signaled its approval of Greenwald, who was instrumental in arranging the federal government's bailout of Chrysler a decade ago. UAL stock surged $4.75 to $155.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. But the stock remained well below the $201 a share in cash and securities offered by the employee-led buyout group, reflecting skepticism that the latest in the long line of attempts to acquire UAL, parent of United Airlines, would succeed. The employees _ led by the Air Line Pilots Assocation, the Machinists union and the Association of Flight Attendants _ still must arrange financing for the deal. That hurdle caused the collapse of a $300 a share, $6.75 billion offer made last year by a group led by the pilots union. Nevertheless, ``Greenwald is a known entity in bank circles,'' said a New York-based airline analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It will make them (the buyout group) much more credible.'' Greenwald, vice chairman of Chrysler since November 1988 and heir apparent to Chairman Lee Iacocca, said late Wednesday he would become chief executive officer of United Employees Acquisition Corp., an entity formed by the airline's pilots, flight attendants and machinists unions to handle the buyout efforts. After a successful acquisition, Greenwald, 54, would become chairman and chief executive officer of Chicago-based UAL and United Airlines, replacing Stephen Wolf. At a Thursday news conference in Highland Park, Mich., Greenwald said he began seriously considering joining the buyout effort 10 days ago, about five weeks after the employee group first contacted him. ``The offer kept getting more tempting,'' he said. ``At one point, I wasn't at all clear who was going to be running the company. My mind changed from it being a problem to being an opportunity about 10 days ago.'' Greenwald said he first needed to arrange the takeover financing. The UAL board has given the buyout group until Aug. 9 to come up with the financing for the takeover, with completion of the deal due about a month later. At a press conference in New York later Thursday, Greenwald tried to reassure potential lenders that the new UAL would be run for profit and cash flow needed to pay off debt and grow. ``The employees are going to be in the position of investor, not management. This company is going to be run like any other company,'' he said. Plans for the company provide money to pay off loans as well as buy more planes to help the airline grow, he said. After examining the company, Greenwald said he became convinced financing will be provided based on UAL's financial health. The unions, he said, have just begun visiting potential lenders after waiting to hire a chief executive. Greenwald conceded his lack of airline experience is a weakness, but added that his work putting together the Chrysler financing is a strength. He said he hoped much of UAL's management would stay if the buyout is successful and said any replacements would come from the airline industry. If financing is arranged, Greenwald will seek as his second in command someone from the airline industry. ``While he (Greenwald) has a good record on financial matters, the airline industry is unique,'' said Robert Joedicke, an airline specialist for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Bankers also need the assurances that would come from a chief operating officer with a strong knowledge of the airline business, Joedicke said. ``They (the banks) don't have the luxury to have someone to come in (and undergo) on the job training,'' he said. ``The key requirement is that there is someone there that understands how to run an airline.'' Greenwald played major roles in securing federal government loans that saved Chrysler from bankruptcy in 1979, and in negotiating the automaker's purchase of American Motors Corp. in 1987. A big obstacle to success at UAL is continuing skepticism about the chances that the buyout will be completed. In 1987, UAL stock rose to more than $100 a share on a decision by the board of directors to sell assets and distribute the proceeds to shareholders. The October 1987 stock market crash quickly followed and UAL's stock fell to about $60 a share. Last year, a buyout offer from United's pilots and management sparked wild speculation in the stock, which soared to $294 a share in September. The deal collapsed a month later, helping to trigger a one-day free-fall on the New York Stock Exchange and sending UAL's stock plunging. ``There is so much pain in people's minds over the losses suffered in the past,'' the analyst said. ``Many investors are staying away.''

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Announced In General Mills-Cholesterol Cereal Case
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. has agreed to pay $21,000 to settle complaints by three states over its anti-cholesterol claims for the now-defunct Benefit cereal, the company said. Minnesota Attorney General Hubert Humphrey III and the attorneys general in Iowa and Wisconsin alleged that an advertisement claiming that ``Benefit removes cholesterol from your body'' was false and misleading. Golden Valley-based General Mills said Thursday it agreed to pay each of the three states $7,000. The settlement is not an admission of wrongdoing, the company said. ``The settlement was the fastest and least costly way to resolve differences over a single newspaper ad for a product that hasn't been sold for over five months,'' the company said in a statement. Humphrey has urged the federal Food and Drug Administration to ban food health claims unless there is scientific consensus that the claims are true. He also urged the federal agency to spell out the exact wording that food manufacturers must use in making any health claims about their products.

DOC.HEAD: SEC To Explore Easing Rules in Foreign Tender Offers
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators voted Thursday to explore rules changes that could allow U.S. investors to participate in tender offers by foreign companies. The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously to seek public comment on the appropriateness of permitting selected foreign tender offers to proceed in this country under foreign rules and regulations. Such an exception to SEC rules is still a long way off but the commission took the first step toward even considering it. Currently, those buying and selling publicly-offered securities in this country must comply with SEC regulations _ which some foreign concerns find too expensive or too onerous. Consequently, rather than cut in U.S. holders of foreign stocks on tender offers for their securities, overseas concerns have chosen to exclude them. The SEC will issue what they call a ``concept release,'' seeking public opinion on the idea of allowing foreign rules to apply where the U.S. securities holdings involved constitute a relatively small portion of the securities in the transaction. Among the things that have yet to be decided: the definition of a ``relatively small portion.''
